answer: Patience is when you are waiting calmly for something. I was patient when standing in the long line waiting for my school lunch. I didn’t cut anyone to get my food sooner. I was just standing there quietly and waiting for my proper turn. Patience is a virtue, but some people simply don’t have it. Lots of people just cut in front of you or yell at you because they don’t have any patience. Sometimes people will even push you out of their way to get ahead. They only do that because they don’t have patience at all. Patience is what people really need in these situations. People need patience because without it, lots of feelings can get hurt. Everyone should have patience to make waiting easier for all.

I am not a patient person most of the time; for instance, I can’t sit in a seat for more than five minutes without fidgeting. But there was one specific time I was truly patient, and I bet everyone else has been too, like when riding a bike for the first time without training wheels. When I was five years old and learned how to ride a bike, I just kept falling off. At one point, my bike flipped over completely and I almost broke my jaw, but thankfully I didn’t. It was a scary moment. Finally, after several weeks of constant falling and getting back up, I rode for a full five minutes without falling and finally learned how to ride a bike properly. It felt like a great accomplishment.

One day I was at basketball practice, running hard with my team, and I was getting really, really thirsty. So after we did our suicides, which is a tough running exercise, I asked the coach if we could go get some drinks. The coach said, “after our double dribble down and back exercise.” I did the exercise as fast as I could, and then we all rushed to the drinking fountain. I found myself at the end of a long line of girls. I waited and waited patiently until finally I was next, faced with that drinking fountain, when one girl suddenly said, “Can I have a drink, thank you?” and cut right in front. All I could do was be stunned. That’s when I heard a bright lady, the coach, yell “Let’s go!” I was really mad but I quickly took a two-second drink of water and rushed over to the coach. Now I’m the first one to the fountain a lot, and I take long drinks, so my teammates call me a fish!

I am going to write about a time when I went to the state fair. We had a lot of fun, and we saw a ride we really wanted to get on, so we got in line. Suddenly, we noticed that the line had grown very long and we were now at the very end of it. So my mother said, “Maybe we should get on another ride then.” My father replied, “We already tried all the other rides.” So we decided to stay at the end of the line until it was finally our turn. They said that was the last ride of the night, and soon there were people behind us complaining. Their younger children were getting mad, and parents were hollering. We just stood there, and kept being patient. That didn’t disturb us at all, since we were raised to be patient and wait our turn at things. I feel being patient is very important, because if you act up in line, you might make people think they’re holding you up, but it’s really just the line moving slow. My advice is this: when you are waiting at the end of the line, don’t shout, scream, holler, or yell at anyone, because it only creates trouble. Just don’t think about all of the people ahead of you; talk to someone, just take your mind off of it for a while, and then you’ll notice the line is moving quicker than you expected. We really enjoyed the ride in the end.

It can be very hard for somebody to be patient. If you are patient, then you are understanding and tolerant of delays. You have to be patient sometimes in everyday life. For example, when you go to the dentist or doctor’s office, you need to be very patient. There was a girl who had to go to the dentist for a check-up. She really hated the dentist. It was always so boring and took forever. First, you’d sit there in the waiting room while your parents did a whole bunch of paperwork. You have to just sit there for like twenty minutes before you even go into the exam room. Then, when you finally go in, they start working on your teeth for like ten minutes, then you’d sit there in the chair for another fifteen minutes waiting for the dentist to come. Finally, when you are done getting your teeth cleaned, you’d sit there for another ten minutes while your parents talk to the dentist about your teeth. So, you really need to be patient sometimes, even when you are just dying of boredom. It is a necessary part of life.

Patience is a very important quality. Being patient means that you needs to make and dor one' thing constantly to make one understand, without showing frustration. That is true patience. I am patient every year for that one special day to come. My birthday is a special day for my mom and dad, as I was the first boy my mom ever had and the only boy my dad had. I am still waiting for my birthday to come again, looking forward to the celebration and the joy it brings to our family.

Swimming is a lot of fun. I enjoy feeling the cool water all around me. I will be writing about patience in my own mix up way even though you are adults. Once there was a little silk worm getting ready to change into a butterfly moth. And that’s how he had that strange dream about the importance of patience.

A time I was patient is when my little brother kept messing with me. He kept doing dumb stuff like pulling the curtains down or playing with the stove, which was both annoying and dangerous. But I took a deep breath and didn't hit him because I understood he was just being a kid and didn't know any better. I have been patient lots of times at the clinic. My sister, my brother, and my mom and dad, we all had to wait on the clinic to get all of the shots ready for my brother, my sister, and me. It took forever, about two hours, for the clinic to get the shots ready to be used. One time me and my dad had to wait an hour to two hours so that I could sign up for football. It takes a long time before we can go outside to play football, soccer, volleyball, and kick ball. All of these experiences have taught me the value of waiting calmly.

I was patient when my mom was giving birth to my baby brother. We had to sit in the waiting room, my sister and I, for four long hours. I slept a couple of times and ate a lot because my dad was hungry so he got us some food also. The first hour I was excited and couldn't wait, full of anticipation. The second hour I was coloring with the crayons and paper the nurse brought to us. The third hour I watched tv to pass the time. The fourth hour I slept till about one o'clock, that's what my sister told me later. My dad came out with a plastic looking dress on with the matching head shower cover and slippers, and he said the next time he comes out my sister and I were gonna be sisters to a baby boy. My sister and I were so happy to hear that. So an hour later my dad came out and said, "Do you want to see the baby?" My sister and I screamed, "Yes!" When we saw him we were so happy to think he was all ours, and the long wait felt completely worth it.

If you could ask for one thing, would you ask for patience or motivation? In this situation I would ask for patience. I remember when I was about four or five years old. My two sisters and I boarded a plane to Florida. It seemed like we were sitting on the plane for hours before it actually took off. After about ten minutes in the air, I asked if we would be there soon. My sister said no, and that we were only up in the air for about ten minutes. I watched all the people just sitting there; some were on laptops and listening to music players. I looked up at my sister and wondered how she could be so patient and calm. After I asked if we were almost there for the second time, my sister did not answer me. I just sat there doing nothing, feeling restless. I had nothing to entertain myself with. I did not say a word for two hours, and then I eventually fell asleep from the boredom. If you could ask for one thing, would you ask for patience or motivation? I am still not very patient, but I am more patient than I was back then, which shows I have learned a little.

"Dad! Look out!" my sister squealed. The sound of crunching metal was deafening. There was no way out. My eyes seemed sealed shut, but they were as wide as could be. The eerie silence that followed frightened me. I felt arms grab me, pulling me to what they considered safety. In no way was this to be considered safety, for this was the beginning of one living nightmare, the living nightmare of my life. Here’s a picture of what I saw: three cars, twisted, tangled and smushed so close together they seemed as if they were one object. Lying beside me was a small boy. That boy was my brother. His chest expanded slowly, but as it did, excruciating sounds radiated from him. Blood trickled out from his many cuts. It was unbearable to watch. Ambulances’ sirens wailed as they approached. My father I have yet to see. And that’s what scared me most. I still have nightmares of that night, the night everything changed. Not only had I lost my father and brother, but in some ways, I’d lost my mother as well. She’d never understand the pain of watching your little brother die, all because of something you desired. If I hadn’t made my father turn around to get my forgotten notebook, I’d still have a dad and little brother. Ever since the funeral, I could feel my mother and I pulling apart. Nothing with us has been the same since. We fight constantly, never listening to what the other has to say. Maybe it’s just the life of a typical teen and her mother. I wouldn’t know because in no way were we typical. When we aren’t fighting about who-knows-what, we just keep our distance. Sometimes, though, the silence is scarier, more heart-pounding, than the shouting. Silence is just so freaking loud! My mother is beginning to attempt the seemingly impossible. She begins to try and understand my strange ways. "Honey," she starts, "I know I haven’t been patient with you lately, and for that I’m sorry. I will try to be, starting now. I only ask you of one thing." I give her a questioning gaze, so she continues, "I would like you to tell me why you blame yourself?" She didn’t have to explain any farther. "Mom, I made Dad turn around," my voice caught in my throat, "just to get my stupid notebook." A single tear weaved its way down my face. "Oh, honey!" my mother teared up as well. "That doesn’t make it your fault! You had no idea it would end that way!" I knew my patience had been worn through for a long time, but I refused to snap at my mother now. She was only trying to help. I fought my annoyed tone, which was battling its way out, and I was to win that fight. "Mom," I said, regaining composure, "that’s how I feel about the issue. I wish I could just take your word for it, and maybe over time I will, but right now, I just need my mom." What shocked me most was the smile that formed on my mother’s lips. "I will wait then." And then she hugged me. She hugged me as she had when I was four and broke my leg, tight and unhesitatingly. I could feel the beginning of a new found relationship with my mother, maybe not as strong as it had been, but definitely there. With patience and time, it has bloomed into a healthy relationship, in which we both can enjoy and respect each other once more.

There was one time I was patient when my little brother's PlayStation wasn't working, so it took a while to get used to the situation. It was an evening, and my little brother had just finished eating. He wanted to play his video games, but he was having a hard time turning on the console. The problem was that some of his games were scratched up, which prevented them from loading properly. But the next day we bought him a lot of other games that were brand new, hoping this would solve the issue. So as he tried the new games he still couldn't get it to work. So then he asked me if I could help him, and I agreed to help him, but it still didn't work. I checked the console and cleared up the PlayStation, wiping off any dust. Then we had to wait patiently for it to reset, and finally, after a few tense moments, it powered on. My little brother and I kept saying, "work, work, work, work," until it went on. Then to this day we still say that phrase for the PlayStation to work, as a little ritual for good luck.

I learned about patience when I had to babysit my younger cousin. I rocked him gently and played with him to keep him happy. I fed him his bottle, and I walked him around the room when he became fussy. Eventually, he fell asleep in my arms. My mom still was not home from work, and I was growing anxious. I was going to be late to the movies with my cousins, who were already waiting. To pass the time, I played a game on my phone. I looked out the window repeatedly, then I walked outside and sat on the front steps, hoping to see her car. My mom still was not there. My cousins were outside too, and they asked me if I could stay a little longer until my mom arrived. Just then, here came mom driving up the street. I felt a wave of relief, and I could go now to join my cousins for the movie.

There are many times when I've been patient, but here are just a few examples. It was a late afternoon, and my family and I were supposed to go to a big function that day. Like always, I didn't know what I was going to wear. After searching through my closet for about an hour, I finally found an outfit. I went down stairs soon after, only to discover no one else was ready and we only had about an hour left before we needed to leave. I was frustrated and told everyone to go get ready, but nobody listened to me. But I didn't care at that point, so I went up to take a shower. Right when I was about to go in, my mom came and told me I had to wait because she was going to take a shower first. Then one by one, everyone else took a shower except for me. I was losing my patience, feeling my irritation grow. I still waited quietly because I didn't want to start a commotion or an argument. Finally, it was my turn and I went in to take a shower. We were all dressed and ready to go, or so I thought. At the last minute, when we all got in the car, my sister forgot her bag and jacket so we had to wait till she ran back inside to get it. We finally made it to the party, not on time but at least we made it. In conclusion, a few examples of me showing patience is when I waited to take a shower and when I waited for my sister to get her bag and jacket.

The time I was most patient was when I was waiting on my mom to have her baby. The reason why is because she was being a pain to me during that period. Being patient is sometimes hard but sometimes you don’t care. There are many times I was patient. Sometimes I have to wait an hour or thirty minutes. There is a time when I had to wait an hour. The one time when I was patient was at dance. My mom dropped me off at four o'clock. I waited five minutes because I was a little early. After I waited five minutes I had worried that maybe they were in a different class but no they weren’t. After waiting thirty minutes I was really bored and remembered that dance started at four thirty. I could of called home but I didn’t have my phone. Then when five more minutes went by I went in the playset. Me and myself swinging alone. When it was four thirty my mom came to pick me up from dance but I told her, “it starts at four thirty. So I have to leave”. She kept asking me why I didn’t call and I kept telling her I didn’t have my phone. Then she left and I went to dance for two hours. Being patient that long is humbling to me. I can go fifteen minutes but I can’t go an hour. That's one of the horrible times I was patient, but I managed it.

I was patient when I had to watch two little bad girls at my sisters house. My sister asked if I wanted to spend the night. I did then her god kids came over. That night my sister remembered she had to go some were. So that morning she left me with the kids for three hours. The girls were running around and being loud, so I had to wait patiently for her to come back. I tried to keep them busy with games. Finally she did return, and I was relieved.

One day I had to wait about three hours which seemed like a year, but I didn’t complain. I sat in the doctors office waiting to get called, I sat there and waited with my mom. I sat and read a magazine while my mom texted her freind. About three people got called in fourty- five minutes. But I sat and looked at the magazine. They called a kid who’s name was Michael, and I thought it was me because my names Mitchell. I finished my magazine and went on to the next one. I thought I would like it because it had war on the front of the cover, but its just a cover nothing cool inside except a floating tranlula trick. About one hour passed and only five people were called. I finnally finished all the magazines and I was bored. I watched people get called and called finnally there were only my mom and I and another group, and of course they got called before us. It was about three hours till we were called, and when we did we had to wait even longer because they had technical difficulties with there machines. When we did get in we had to wait a half and hour for the doctor. But we got in, he made my knee twitch and then made me hop on one foot, why I don’t know. But he did the regular put the thing that goes in my ear and the thermometer that goes on my tongue. But we finnally got out and went home. My mom asked me how could I be that patient, and I said, “I have not a clue, I just was.”

When I was going to the doctor I had to be patient. I went there because my auntie driveway had a crack. And I was riding my scooter. I must wasn’t paying no attention because my scooter had hit the crack so I sprang my knee. So my dad camed out the house to pick me up. I had to get in a wheel chair. And wait because there wasn’t no more curtains left. The waiting room was very full. I waited for a hour then I got my turn. And they checked my knee. Then they gave me crutches to walk with. It was pretty hard to go up my house stairs, but I managed it patiently.

I was patient when I was on my way to @LOCATION1 to see my @CAPS1. I was patient because I didn’t want to get really excited about @CAPS2. When I get excited about things we have a change in plans, and we would have to ‘cancel’. So I stayed calm and we were in the car in a little over an hour, then my brother forgot something and we had to go back and get @CAPS2, and I was patient about @CAPS2, even though we were quiet the whole way there. I had to keep my feelings in check, and this is the story of when I was very patient about going to @LOCATION1, and it all worked out in the end.

Has your parents or you ever sent an application for a job? Well my uncle did and was very patient about it. He wanted that job more than a kid wanted ice cream. One day my uncle typed up an application for the job he wanted. When he was done he copied and pasted it for an email. When he pressed send he hurried and grabbed his phone hoping for the job. He looked at his phone right when he got up, making sure there were no missed calls or messages. He knew he had to be patient. He was still waiting for the call, but @CAPS2 still nothing. It was one week and he was thinking about calling the place, yet @CAPS2 he didn’t. Then he got a phone call that afternoon so he quickly ran like a cheetah to get his phone. It was just my mom asking if he got the job, and @CAPS2 all he said was no with a sigh. I felt bad for the poor guy for not knowing yet until one day. The next morning he got a call and he picked it up screaming, “@CAPS1 do you want!” @CAPS2 not knowing it was the boss for the job. So he apologized and also got the job. He was so happy knowing he waited forever sort of patiently and got the job he wanted. When he went to work at his new job he really loved how he got it and now knew you always need to be patient and everything will work out great. So now knowing always be patient no matter @CAPS1 the deal is. My uncle @MONTH1 not be an expert, but @CAPS2 he should be now. Again remember to always be patient and good things will come your way, just as they did for him.

Super beast patience. I was coming here from school one day on the going bus, so @CAPS1 what felt like @CAPS2, I finally got home and I ran inside. I saw my high school bro with a box of pop. I asked, "Blare, where did you get the money for that? It always needs money." You wouldn't guess what he said. He said, "I took it out of your wallet." I yelled, "What? I have been holding that in there so I could go to the movies." As I thought with my @NUM1 friends, I got so angry. So I ran out and jumped in the air, punched him right in the nose. It started bleeding. I tried to run but he grabbed me. He could really hurt me at any time, but he said, "I'll pay you back," when he let me go. So I thought, now he is so patient with me; he could have killed me and he didn't. The next week he saved me back, and he hasn't hit me since, showing true patience.

"When are they gonna be here! When are they gonna be here!" I was in @CAPS1 visiting my family and my cousins were going to be coming in from @LOCATION1. I was so excited and very impatient I couldn’t wait until they pulled up in their black car and I could give them a hug that would knock the daylights out of them. It was around lunch time and I was watching out the window while eating cold pizza. I kept on counting down from ten saying they are going to be here in @NUM1, but they were never there. Soon I realized it was about @NUM2 p.m. and knew I wouldn’t see them until tomorrow and I will be patient so I don’t waste the whole entire day thinking about it. After a good night's rest I got up, had breakfast, and then watched some @CAPS2. "@PERSON1! @PERSON1! Honk! Honk!" Could it really be? No, it couldn't; it was uncle @CAPS3 and his big motorcycle. A few hours later I heard @PERSON1 again and said uncle @CAPS3 is probably leaving, but then I heard my cousins @ORGANIZATION1 and @CAPS5. I flew up out of the chair and totally gave them a hug that knocked the daylights out of them. I guess patience really is the key to a happy reunion.

A time that someone has been patient with me is when I was younger and my sister taught me how to braid. It took a long time and my small hands didn’t always correct things. But my sister always helped me when she had time. I thought I would never do it right. And that's when she told me these words: “practice makes perfect.” She let me choose from her best string selection. And she slowly went over how to do it, showing me the motions again and again. And before I knew it I was braiding just as well as her. I am so happy that she encouraged me to keep trying and that she was patient with me the whole time, never getting frustrated. And that is an example of one time someone was truly patient with me, which helped me learn a valuable skill.

One time it was hard to wait, but I was patient and in the end it was worth it. One time my family and I were going to Disney world. The morning I woke up I was so excited because I really wanted to get to the air port and go to Disney world. After we packed the car we drove to the airport. In the car my brother and I were talking about how excited we were. Once we got to the airport we got super excited! When we got to the area were you wait for your plane the workers told every one waiting for the same plane as us that the plane to Florida was gonna be around one hour late. My whole family and I really wanted to get to Disney world as soon as we could, but we would just have to wait, we walked around the air port and, and got something to eat. Then we heard that we only had to wait twenty more minutes! My family and I just sat down and talked and before we knew it we were getting on the plane. Being patient can really help the situation and make the final reward feel even better.

On Saturday it was my birthday I was just turning ten. I was so happy!!! Well while I was being happy and my big sisters were getting things together for my party my mom was at work. We had everything at the party such as juice, pop, food, candy, chips, ice cream, but no cake. My mom was supposed to pick it up when she got off work. Then it was time to open the gifts. After we opened all my gifts, it was time for cake and ice cream. We had the ice cream but no cake, but I didn’t cry and scream like a baby, my sister did but she was still six and I was ten and I had to act as a ten year old. My mom called and told us she was running a little late and she would be here after she got my cake. When my mom got home we cut the cake and when I took the first bite I said to myself it was worth the wait! I was happy I waited like a big kid, but I was even more happier I was ten and had learned the value of patience.

I am normally always patient, but the time I had to be the most patient was when I baby sat last summer. I was babysitting with my older cousin Sarah. We were babysitting twin four-months-old baby girls for eight hours! Let me tell you babies are a lot of work and you need a lot of patience with them. One time during the day that you needed to be patient with them was when they cried. These babies cried a lot and for a long time so it took a while to calm them down. Like when I sat one twin down and it fell asleep, it would start screaming and I used patience to take time and calm her down. Another event during that day that I used patience was to get them to fall asleep. The baby I mainly took care of took a while to fall asleep. So I was patient while walking around the house and bouncing her up and down in my arms. Of course, eventually they both fell asleep. A third time I used patience was feeding them. See they were very small twins, so they took a long time to eat. Also when I fed the baby I took care of, Natalie, I had to use patience to not freak out when she spit up all over my shirt. Sarah, my cousin also used her patience when “her baby,” Chloe, spit up on her too. That day took a lot of patience, but it was still very fun and you can see that Natalie and Chloe were lots of work, but patience definitely got me and Sarah through it successfully.

Patience is a very long task but the rewards outweigh the time you waited for the thing you were waiting for. From waiting for a computer to start up to standing in a line for a roller coaster, your patience will be rewarded. However many people are not very patient. (Including me) But they can learn over time to be as patient as monks. It is a skill that improves with practice and mindful effort. In short, be calm during a trial and use lots of patience to see things through to a better end.

One time when I was little we were going to the dentist in Ann Arbor and there was a lot of traffic and me my sister and my brother were in the car (we ended up waiting for two hours) I was really unhappy so my mom told me to be patient. I didn't know what it meant at the time, but now I know. It means to wait and be calm. When I got to the dentist and sat down. I found out I was late so we had to go back home and do it again tomorrow. That experience taught me a clear lesson about the importance of patience, even when it feels difficult.

A time when I was patient was when I went to Cedar Point. We drove from our home in the city all the way to the theme park, and it was a very long ride. When we finally got there, we discovered a long, winding line just to get into the parking lot. My mom said, “All right guys, time to be patient.” Once we got through the gates, we headed straight for the first ride we saw, which also had a long, snaking queue of people. Mom looked at us and said, “We are going to have to be patient all day if we want to ride all the rides.” We stood in that line quietly, knowing she was right, and eventually we did get on the ride, which made the wait feel worthwhile in the end.

Have you ever had to be patient? I had to be patient when my older brother broke his finger. This happened at his friend's house on a trampoline one hot summer day. When my brother broke his finger, he was crying and it seemed like he was in terrible pain. My mom wanted to see his hand and his knuckles and all that stuff that moms always do. It seemed like it took so long to ask my mom a question if she was in the same room as my brother, because she was so focused on him. My mom called the doctor's office during the third day after the accident and got an appointment for my brother. I thought, okay, whatever, I'll stay at home while he goes to the doctor, but there was one person in the way of that and her name is mom. She said that I had to go to the doctor with her and my brother even though I didn't want to. After that day, I kept selling my mom excuses why I couldn't go, but she wasn't buying any of them. So after a very short car ride that seemed to be a long car ride of torture, we were in the waiting room waiting. In that waiting room we were waiting, waiting, waiting, and guess what else? If you said waiting, then you are right. In the waiting room, seconds got confused with minutes and minutes got confused with hours. Those "hours" of torture made the car ride look like a pleasant kitty ride. There was no entertainment or anything that could distract me from those cruel minutes going by so slow. If you have ever seen a snail go, imagine that six times slower and you'll start to understand how slow the time went by. Finally, after all of the time we'd been waiting, the doctor comes in the room and asks for my brother. The only problem with the doctor is that she was even more boring. The doctor sat and talked forever, using words so long they made the dictionary look small. I was so tired that I stopped caring. Finally, it was time to go, though no one was happy except for me. I was so happy to leave the doctor's office. Let's review. I had to be patient when my brother broke his finger. My brother was in pain and had to go to the doctor. The doctor's office was extremely boring. I was patient and finally I got to leave. Sometimes being patient has rewards, and my reward was simply being able to leave the doctor's office.

One time at the local sports store, I was getting some arrows but no one was there to ring up my purchase. The counter was empty, and instead of ringing the bell a hundred times or calling out loudly, I just waited there quietly and patiently, looking at the other items on the shelves. I was waiting for about ten minutes for someone to come, and when someone did finally come, they smiled and said thank you for being so patient. They then ringed me up quickly so I could leave with my new arrows. That was a time I was patient, and it felt good to be acknowledged for it.

A time I was patient was when I was waiting in line for lunch at school. I was patient because there were lots of other people in the line ahead of me, and some people were letting their friends cut in front of them, so the line was getting longer instead of moving forward. I just stood in my place, knowing that getting upset wouldn't make the line move any faster, and eventually I did get my lunch. That is the story of one of the times I was patient, and it taught me that staying calm is the best way to handle a slow situation.

One time I was patient was when my dad was going to send me a birthday present. I was just waiting and waiting for it to arrive in the mail. While I was waiting, I just went about my day; I slept, ate, played games in class a lot, and watched television. After two long weeks, I finally got it. The package contained a Donkey Kong game and one hundred dollars. I called my dad and said, thank you, after which I played my game all night and saved my hundred dollars until my actual birthday. That was the time I was patient, and the reward for my patience was definitely worth it.

As I walked down the lane looking for the perfect gift I had seen the day before, I was disappointed to find out it was sold out. Today was my mom’s birthday, and I had my heart set on that gift, the perfect Precious Moments figurine. I asked the store manager if they happened to have any more in the back, but sadly, they didn’t. He offered a small hope, saying, “The new shipment should be arriving at five.” I didn’t think I could wait another three hours. My dad drove me home, and I spent the time pacing back and forth, thinking my anxiety would occupy the time, but sadly it didn’t. Finally, I realized I needed to relax and be patient, something I had struggled with before. Before I knew it, the time was five o’clock, and my dad and I went back to the store. In no time, there was the perfect gift, right there on the shelf in front of me. I picked it up and gave it to the clerk to scan. I handed her the money and headed straight home. When mom got home, I handed her the gift and watched her face light up, realizing that patience really does come in handy when it comes to waiting for something good.

One day we were driving to the park for a very special event to see the President of the United States when we got to the location. There were cars parked a mile away from the entrance! When we finally found a spot and parked the car, we started walking. It was a long walk, but when we finally got to the gate I was so excited! After we got through the security checkpoint, we trudged on, feeling like we would never get there. Me and my parents stood in that line for what I think was about two hours. Until finally, everybody spread out and took their places. We sang the national anthem, and then the President stepped up to the podium and gave a long speech. It was the longest line I had ever stood in, and I was very patient throughout the entire experience.

One day I was at a baseball game and the line to get inside the stadium was huge. It stretched out for what seemed like half a mile, and unfortunately, we were at the very end. So it took us about an hour just to get up to the front gates. I knew I had to be very, very patient during that long wait, or else my dad would’ve gone crazy with frustration. We finally made it inside just in time for the first pitch, so that’s my story about patience and how it helped us enjoy the game.

There were only five minutes of class left and I had nothing to do. So I watched the clock tick down ever so slowly. With five minutes left, then four, then three, then two, the teacher asked, “What are you doing?” I said, “Nothing. I have nothing to do.” She suggested, “Why don’t you put your head down?” I was losing my patience and felt like I was going to snap, but I didn’t. I took a deep breath, put my head down on the cool desk, and the next thing I knew, the bell was ringing and it was time to go. I was glad I had kept my patience and didn’t get in trouble for being restless.

Did you know that patience is one of the keys to happiness? For an example, I was walking and this guy walked up to me and started talking to me about his family. Just remember, I wasn’t very patient at the time. He kept going on and on about his relatives until I finally snapped and said, “Do you know how to shut up!” Sadly, he said “yes” and then ran home, crying. Later, I went home and when I got there, I felt sad for the guy. I found him and said, “I’m sorry!” And for some reason, he said, “Got you!” I said, “What?” I was so mad at the trick, but I was also happy when the awkward situation was over. But that whole experience taught me a lesson, though: always be patient because you don't know who is watching, literally.

I am always patient with my family, my mom and dad do a lot for me and are always patient if they take me somewhere. Sometimes, for hockey practice, my mom and dad take me. Hockey is a sport I enjoy. My dad usually takes me but on Saturdays my mom takes me and I am patient. For homework, I am always patient, and if I go to my friend’s golfland my mom said she will take me and I’m always patient while waiting for her. I understand that being patient is important and helps everyone have a better day.

Patience is a key virtue. My cousin Romeo is the most patient person I have ever met. He is studying to be a doctor, which means he must go through eight years of college. This involves eight years of learning complex terminology, studying cells, and understanding human anatomy, so he has to be incredibly patient. My cousin goes to a university which is pretty close to where I live and where my aunt lives. Romeo comes home a lot and never complains about his homework or school or anything; he has got the highest level of patience, trust me. He is the perfect role model for me. Romeo is on his fifth year of college, which means four years are down and four more to go. He doesn’t have a certain way of taking stress out besides the fact he squeezes his stress ball. It’s not easy staying motivated and relaxed, but he does that. Before he left for university, he told me that patience is half the process and half the reward. I truly believe that Romeo is patient and his example inspires me.

Here is a story, about patience, in my own way called Lily's Patient Day. “Mom, hurry up and find my shoes! I can’t find them anywhere! And I do not want to be late for school again.” I hollered at my mom. “Lily,” Mom said in a hushed voice, “you asked me a second ago, it doesn’t take a second to find some lost shoes, you just have to be patient.” “I know, I know,” I sighed, “but I still don’t want to be late.” “I know,” she replied, “but remember, being patient will get you far.” “Okay,” I agreed. So that day at school, Lily remembered her mom's words and was very patient all day. She didn’t whine with her friends about the bus being so slow to get to school, and she didn’t cut her friends in the lunch line to get her food faster. At gym, she didn’t grab the volleyball when someone had it at their shoe so she wouldn’t be bored; instead, she stood there calmly. During the end of the day, her friends started acting like her too. Their teacher noticed how very patient they were when they raised their hand instead of blabbing out the answer. At the end of that class period, they all got some candy as a reward. The other students noticed and wondered how they could get candy. Then in her next class, she could feel everyone's eyes on her, but she knew it was for a good reason. Everyone learned to raise their hands and not push when they left the classroom. Pretty soon, every student started getting candy and the teachers were so happy! When I got home that day, I hugged my mom so hard and then I told her what happened at school. I then learned to be patient from then on, understanding its true value.

The day I stood in line for some free bags of Lays chips was a test of patience. When I was at the store, they were giving out free bags of chips. I was number fifteen in line, and by the time I got to the front, my three friends were already there. They were having a giveaway day, and we got done with our bags late. I was really patient; I waited for four hours and fifteen minutes. We had some chips and then we left. Then we got in line for a video game, but we were very tired. We were going to the park later, but that was the worst patience I had ever had to use. It was a long day, but I managed to stay calm throughout the experience.

It was a beautiful morning; the sky was blue, birds were singing, and my sister was going skydiving. She and her boyfriend, Zone, were planning to go skydiving, so me, my friend, and my parents tagged along to watch. We had a couple of people in front of them, so we had to wait for an hour or so. Then another hour passed, and they were still not even close to being their turn. We were starting to get hungry, so we went into town and ordered some breakfast. We got our drinks and were about to get our food when we got a call that they were going soon. We had to cancel our meal and hurry back to the place. We got there, and it was still not their turn. I don't really know how, but something happened with the wind, so we had to sit and wait in the middle of the field for almost four more hours! Finally, it was their turn; they got in the plane and flew up. They circled the field for a while, and then it looked like a little dot fell out of the plane, then another followed. They sailed down to a successful landing. It turns out that we sat there for eight hours before they jumped, not including the hour and a half drive there. I think that I was pretty patient that day, despite all the waiting and delays.

Left! Right! High kick left, roundhouse sight! The boy's arms are moving so fast you can barely see them, a blur of motion. His legs are striking the heavy bag with tremendous power, each impact echoing through the training space! "Excellent!" the old man yells with pride, "my boy." His master, however, says calmly, "you are still lacking patience." The old man, a seasoned instructor named Master Chen, puts a thick blindfold on the boy named Leo and lets several sand bags swing towards him. The first one hits him squarely in the head, a sharp thud, but the boy instinctively kicks the second one and busts it open, sand spraying out. Leo grabs the third flying bag and uses it skillfully to block the path of the fourth one. Through this difficult exercise, the boy learned to be patient and wait for the enemy to strike first, understanding that timing is as crucial as strength.

One time I was patient when our teacher, Mrs. Davison, could not get the projector to work. Everybody sat down at their desks and was quiet. It took up the whole class hour. There was a little chit-chat here and there, a soft murmur, but mostly everybody was quiet for her while a small group of students tried to help her. We were going to watch a movie about the five major themes of geography, but when she tried to play the movie, it wouldn't come on properly. You could hear the audio but couldn't see the picture, and then at the very end of the hour, you could finally see it but you couldn't hear it. "But it worked for all the other classes," Mrs. Davison said, frustrated. The next day she gave us fruit snacks for being so patient, and she had finally gotten the movie to work; first it was in just gray and white, then she jiggled a card in the computer and it showed in color. But the day that I was patient was the first time. I was patient with a teacher, she was proud of me, and I was proud of myself. I can't believe what I did for Mrs. Davison. Then it happened again another time; this time she let everybody just chill in our chairs and talk with our friends, but I just waited for her to fix her technical problem. The next day she didn't give us a treat because our treat was just chilling in our chairs and talking with our friends. That was a time when my classmates and I were patient, learning that sometimes the reward is simply a moment of peace.

When I was patient, we had to wait in a very long, winding line for a popular roller coaster. I was already scared, and some kids in the line behind me were impatient; they were pushing and complaining, wanting to get on the ride fast. I was patient and waited quietly with my family until, finally, after what felt like forever, we got on. I was very scared when I were on, gripping the safety bar tightly. When I got off, however, I had a big, bright smile on my face, my heart still racing with excitement. I was truly glad I was patient, because the thrilling experience was worth the long and anxious wait.

Being patient is fundamentally important. People should always be patient and not rush anything in life. All you really have to do is take your time and wait calmly. People need to understand that if you are not patient, then particular things you want will not happen for you. If you ever wanted something, then you have to be patient to receive it. One day at the community center, my cousin, Shayna, was not being patient because she desperately wanted to get on the dance box. But, she couldn't because a little girl named Tamika was on the dance box, and Shayna was not happy about it. And you know how we girls can get with our attitudes. Shayna got mad and started to cry and roll her eyes at Tamika. She then came up to me and said, "She won't let me get on." I looked at her and said, "Shayna, you have to be patient and wait your turn because she was on it first, and that would be rude and unfair to make her get off." Shayna eventually calmed down, apologized for her behavior, and they both took turns on the dance box for the rest of the afternoon. In the end, Shayna was happy and she learned her valuable lesson about waiting.

A time when I was patient was when my mom broke her hip. When my mom broke her hip, she moved slower than my grandpa, each step a careful, painful effort. You are probably asking yourself how does this make her patient? Well, I had to follow her everywhere she went to ensure she didn't fall. If I wasn't patient, I think my mother would be in worse condition than what she was in. I mean, it took her almost fifteen long minutes just to walk from the living room to her bedroom. Normally I'm not a patient person at all, I get fidgety and annoyed easily, but when this happened I had no choice; I had to be patient. I'm glad that during that period I was patient because now I am more patient then I was before. My mom is proud of my behavior and my help, because I actually grew up for a few days to help her out when she needed me the most. Being patient is a good thing; it makes you look at life differently and appreciate small progress. Now I can actually imagine me being a more patient person. I mean I'm not glad my mum got hurt, but I'm glad of my personal growth, the positive consequence of the problem. After the big accident happened, I have truly learned that everyone needs a little bit of patience, just like I did. That is one powerful example about how I thought of a time I was patient, without my mom's accident I might never have learned this lesson so deeply.

I know a girl, she’s my friend, and her name is @PERSON1. @PERSON1 is a very good person. She eats all her veggies, does all her homework diligently, and has straight A's in all her classes. @PERSON1 only has one problem. She is not patient at all. One day @PERSON1 and I went to the movie theater. We went on a Saturday night so it was quite busy. There was a long, winding line to @CAPS2 the tickets. @PERSON1 looked at me and groaned loudly. I told her, “@CAPS1 patient @PERSON1, it will only take like ten minutes.” @PERSON1 groaned again and crossed her arms in frustration. “@CAPS2 over it you potato sak,” I told her with a small smile. After about two minutes we were only five people behind the ticket counter. @PERSON1 was pacing around like she was in the worst case scenario. She started pulling at her hair as I stared blankly at her. A time when I had to be patient was on my birthday. About a week before my birthday, me and my dad ordered me an American Girl doll. I was super excited because it was my very first doll. The shipping was a problem, though. The week of my birthday arrived, and I kept waiting for the familiar FedEx truck to come down our street. I was disappointed, because they had shipped it from Wisconsin and it usually doesn’t take that long to get there. Another week passed and it still wasn't here. I had to be extra patient, checking the window constantly. I could track it online and see it was in my city, but I still wasn't happy about the delay. The reason why it took so long to get here was because when it was already here, they kept it in the local post office. Then finally my mom got ahead to ask when they were going to send it out for delivery and the lady at the desk said, “it’s on the way.” A couple minutes later, the doorbell rang. I screamed with joy when I opened her up. She was perfect, and it was worth the long wait.

Patience, what can I say, I don't have none of it personally. I like things to go quickly and I get frustrated easily. I also don't like it when people do things slow, as it tests my limited patience. This is just a part of who I am, and I find it difficult to change this aspect of my personality.

Patience is not a natural thing, it's something you have to learn. Taking a three hour car ride is a perfect example of patience, exactly like what I experienced. As we packed our suitcases for the city, I couldn't contain myself. I was already packed up but mom and dad were still standing around. "Can you please finish packing? I really want to go!", I exclaimed. "You'll just have to wait a minute," they said. But I couldn't wait, so I grabbed a few more of my things, threw them in the trunk of our car, and walked to our kitchen to finish reading a book while they finished packing. After they were done, dad was carrying the last of the bags from their bedroom to the car when he noticed me, sitting patiently on the couch. He thanked me, saying, "Thank you for being so patient, and just for that, mom and I have a surprise for you." He set down the suitcases, and briskly walked over to a white plastic bag and suddenly pulled out a rectangular package. It was the newest game in the series I loved so much. "Thank you so much!" I replied. This just goes to show that patience really pays off, but only if you don't complain of course.

The time I was patient was when I was seven years old. When I was seven years old my mom said I had to go to the dentist for a checkup. It was early in the morning so my mom woke me up and I said yes but I was going back to sleep. She said, "Wake up, its time for you to go to the dentist." I popped up and started screaming. She was like, "Be quiet because other people in this house are trying to go to sleep." I said, "Ok, mom." She was like, "Go grab you some clothes." I said, "Ok." So when we had both put on some clothes, I was just saying stuff. I was like, "I'm going to the dentist to get some stickers," and I just kept saying that to calm myself down. When she pulled up in the parking lot, I stopped and said, "We're here." Then she parked the car and I opened the door. My mom signed us in and then we sat down. It was a lot of people there, so when we sat down, fifteen minutes later they called us. I was about to yell but then they came. The dentist lady took me to the room and told me to lift my head up so she could put the bib on me. Then the main doctor came in. He was like, "We are about to clean your teeth." I was crying cause I thought it was gonna hurt, so I was crying and talking about how it was gonna hurt. They put the tool on my teeth and they said, "See, it doesn't hurt." Then they were done ten minutes later. The female lady dentist was like, "You can pick three stickers." I was so happy because I finally got some stickers. When we left, we got in the car and then I went to sleep. That was the day I learned to be patient.

One day I had to be patient. It all started when I raked some leaves for my neighbor, and I was going to get paid for my work. I was so excited to receive the money. Well, I was going to get it the day after, but I wanted it that very second. I had to keep reminding myself to wait calmly. Ultimately, I learned that being patient was necessary, even though it was difficult at the time.

One of my stories of being patient is this one time at my uncle's house, and I wanted to play the toy boy. Well, there were like five other kids too, and I asked him if I could play and he said I had to be patient. So I sat there and waited quietly, like for an hour or two at least it felt like it, and I didn’t say a word about it the whole time. I just watched the other kids take their turns, trying to keep my mind off the wait. Then I finally got to play, which felt like a great reward for all that quiet waiting. That’s my story about being patient.

I was panicking when I was about to have an allergy shot; I sat and waited for two hours. I had played my Nintendo DS for an hour, then I watched TV I had gotten before, so I started to pace. My parents had to stop me from leaving six times; I almost left the floor the sixth time. Then it came time for me to go down to the allergy room. It was a fight because I wanted to walk and they said no, but they won. Then after the allergy shot, I had to lay flat for six hours, which felt incredibly long and boring. Then I got to go home, finally feeling relieved it was all over.

Two years ago our immigration limit had run out. We needed green cards to become permanent residents. So we went to an immigration center in Detroit. We walked up to the front desk and told the lady we were here. She told us to go sit in the waiting area. There was about fifty people there! I knew we were going to be here a while from that point forward. We went to the waiting area, and I had no way of amusing myself. It strictly said in the front, no gaming devices, no musical devices. All phones must be switched off. It was torture, just sitting there watching the clock. After about an hour and a half they finally called our name. I was so pleased to get moving. After we got our fingerprints and everything completed and we walked out to the car, my mom said she was very pleased with the way I behaved in that office, which made the long wait feel worthwhile.

I remember a time when I was patient. I used to be able to wait for anything. One time I was so patient I asked my mom for a game and she said, tomorrow, and she got the game the day I asked her. At one time I thought I was the most patient person in my whole family. I am so patient I can wait a month just before I go to Cedar Point. You have to be born with patience. Some of my friends are patient but they can’t wait as long as I can. Some of them even ask me to teach them how to be patient. I say the same thing to them what I say to everybody who asked me about being patient: you have to be born with patience. It’s not something you learn over the years. I could wait three weeks without getting paid from my dad. As some people get older their patience grows lesser. That doesn’t work on everybody. But sometime soon I know my patience will be like everyone else's when I get older. Who knows, maybe somebody might be more patient than me in the world, but for now, I am content with my ability to wait.

I have used patience a lot of times but I think the most patience I’ve had was hunting. You just have to sit there, not talk, and stay completely still. I was hunting out behind my house with my uncle John and we got out there at six o'clock am and then waited there until nine o’clock at night. The deer finally started to come in and one deer got close enough for me to shoot. I drew my bow and shot at it but it was so dark I could hardly see and I missed it. My uncle didn’t even see it until the last second and when I pulled the trigger of the release I knew straight away that it was going to miss. All you could hear was the deer running away and the arrow crashing through all the leaves. So later that night we went home really hungry and a little disappointed, but that's just how hunting sometimes goes.

A time when I was patient was when I ordered a new video game in the mail. It was a cool autumn evening, and I was ordering the game online. When I got to the shipping options, I paid for it and went to the check-out screen. I saw the estimated delivery time of how long it would take to get to my house. It said three weeks. "Three weeks?!" I exclaimed. "That’s a long time." But it was decided. I had to make it through those three weeks. I was ready. And so I waited. I checked the mailbox every afternoon, and waited some more. Until one Tuesday I saw a cardboard package. The address said “Current Resident”! My heart sank, but the next day, a smaller, flatter package arrived. The address said “Jane Doe”! I was so happy! I ripped it open right there. This incident taught me to always be patient, because chances are, you’ll get what you're wanting in the end.

That warm tear running down my cheek, the hot wind blowing my blond hair out of my face. The only thing I could think about was why god had to take her so soon. Let's go back a week ago. We had just got the news my grandmother was going up to heaven with the angels very soon. As soon as the next day we were on a plane heading to Florida. This was my dad's mother; he was calm at the time but we all had to be patient with him because he was the closest with her out of the five children. When we finally took off we were in turbulence the whole two-hour flight. Which meant we couldn’t get up, get food, use the restroom and also had that queasy feeling in your stomach. It was the worst flying experience I’ve ever had. I flew all the time, just this time it was horrible! We had to take two stops till we got to Florida. Then another forty-five minutes till our bags came in. I was so happy to get out of that death trap! When we got to the house, I had my last time with my grandmother. It’s a precious memory I will never forget. The stubborn little smirk on her face when we walked in was priceless. One thing I will never forget was my nickname from her, “chicken little.” Hearing her say it one last time is a sound I will always carry with me.

“Me! Me! Me!” Sarah said, “I wanna go first!” All the time in cheerleading this girl named Sarah thought she was the first to do everything. Oh yeah my name is Emily. I’m always a flier along with Sarah. I’m always patient and wait my turn because I don't wanna complain or be a poor sport. “Ready set! One, two, down, up, three, four, five, six!” the two bases and backspots yell. They pop the flier out and up then scream “Got her!” “Good job,” Coach says. “Okay, it’s my turn, Emily, you can do this you're better then her,” I thought to myself. “Okay we can do this,” one of our bases, Jessica, said. I get ready. Hand on shoulders, prepared to get popped up into the air. Our other base, Mark, says “One, two, down, up! Okay, three, four, five, six—Got her!” “Great job Emily!” the team cheers but loses the competition. I was so excited, I just did a pop ride without messing up my landing. I thought with excitement. Being patient might be rewarding after all. From that day on I’ve always tried to be patient. It can really help you out so you know what you have to work on or work less on, allowing you to perform your best when the moment finally arrives.

Are you good with being patient? Sometimes I am but sometimes I’m not. I’m going to tell you a story when I was patient when I’m normally not patient in situations like this. I had gone to school with my mom so she could take a test and then drop me at the mall to meet my friends up there. While I was waiting I was texting and on the internet, but then my stomach started to rumble, I was really hungry. I wanted to text my mom and make her rush so I could get something to eat. As I was texting I stopped and thought about what I was about to do. I knew how hard and how long she had studied for that test. I didn't want her to get a bad grade so I just sat there patiently. I texted other people. People called me so my mind was off the food. After my mom finished her test she came out of the room. I asked her “How did it go?” She looked at me, smiled and said “I felt confident, but now I’m hungry.” I shouted out “me too!” We got in the car and went to Subway. I had got the footlong meal with cookies, chips, and a drink; it was delicious. My mom had dropped me off at the mall and I told my friends what happened. We laughed for some reason. Then we went to H&M, Charlotte Russe, Forever 21, and other places as well. After I thought about it I never want to do that again. I was starving and my butt started to hurt from sitting. I sat there for two hours with nothing to do and decided never again will I do that. At least I had some bonding time with my mom, and that’s one bright side to the whole long, patient wait.

A time when I was patient was when I was at school waiting for the final bell. I was waiting for my science teacher to call on me to get ready to go. I was sitting down in my seat, my backpack already packed and resting at my feet. She was calling people one by one to stand by the door to get ready to go to their next class. The clock seemed to move slower with each passing minute. I watched as my classmates were called, their names echoing in the quiet room. I resisted the urge to fidget or get up, knowing I had to wait for my turn. Finally, after what felt like an eternity, I heard my name. I stood up, grabbed my bag, and walked calmly to the door, feeling a quiet sense of accomplishment for having waited so patiently without complaint.

When I was little I was patient I would always sit and wait for direction my mom always liked it that way @CAPS5 now since @CAPS1 bigger she thinks @CAPS1 is impatient @CAPS5 your what @CAPS1 not I am patient I get along I am not antsy I m not the type when they say (when are we going you guys) That is I when was @CAPS4 learning how to speak @CAPS5 I guess that is how it goes and @TIME1 I was patient because my mom and dad were having a talk and I was not about to hear it it was grown-up talk.

My mom is very patient because I use her phone a lot to text my girlfriend and to call and text my friends. She tells me when I get a text or a call, but she also lets me know when she needs to use it herself, and I have to hand it over. It must be difficult for her to always share her phone, but she never gets overly upset about it. She understands that communicating with my friends is important to me, and for that, I am very grateful. Her patience in this situation teaches me a lot about sharing and consideration for others, even when it might be an inconvenience.

A time when I was patient was for my birthday. My mom told me she was getting me a specific gaming console for my birthday, and I was so happy. Then when my birthday came and I was opening my presents, there was no console. So I asked her about it, and she said she would get it later in the year when the tax refund came, so I had to be patient and wait for several months and a couple of days. I was mad because I thought she had it already. So I just had to go to school and wait and wait until that date finally arrived. It seemed like the days got longer and longer. I was getting more and more frustrated; that was the longest few months ever. I didn't even know it could feel so long; I thought a year had gone by. After more time went by, it was finally the day, but I didn't get it until the very end of the month, which just crushed my little heart so badly, to wait for something that long that I wanted so desperately. When I finally got it, it was so fun to play with all the games and apps; the experience was amazing. If something were to happen to it, I would be completely destroyed. A console like that is expensive, but once you get it, you have to take care of it. That's why I keep it in a special place away from little kids. I don't even let them play with it at all, and if I feel they might be able to, it is only with my direct supervision. That thing cost too much money to get lost or broken, especially after all that time I had to wait. My little sister is getting something like it, but it's some kind of educational one. My little brother is getting a different handheld console. I'm happy they are getting something so they can stop asking for my stuff. My mom is getting me some new games for it for my upcoming birthday; I had one before, but my little brother or sister lost it, and I was so angry about how they can't be careful with things at all. That was definitely something that taught me to wait and be patient. That's why I am so careful with it now, because I'm scared of it getting lost or broken. If it does, my mom won't get another one, and I understand why.

The first time I babysat was with two little girls, a toddler and a baby. A toddler named Lily and a baby named Chloe. After their parents left, everything was fine for a little while. That is, until the baby, Chloe, started crying like crazy. At first, I thought she was saying, "Cookie, cookie!" but then I realized she was saying, "Cooky, Cooky!" Her "Cooky" is her special blanket, and when I finally handed it to her, she stopped crying immediately! Now I realize how patient I was with her, trying to figure out what was wrong instead of getting flustered. I’m glad I stayed calm and figured out what she wanted so I could comfort her. Hopefully, next time I babysit, I’ll be just as patient and understanding.

When I had to be patient, one of my most memorable times was when I ordered my first electric guitar. I ordered my guitar from a reputable guitar website that my guitar teacher recommended. I waited and I waited until finally, the package arrived. I took the guitar out of the box and immediately saw that it was chipped. I was extremely angry and disappointed. We sent the guitar back for a replacement. After some time, I got another guitar, so I opened it up, hopeful again. It was the same damaged guitar I had sent back; I was even more angry than before. So again, we sent the guitar back, hoping that we would finally get the right, undamaged one. It felt like it took forever, but eventually, a new package arrived. I was so happy, and this time I was not angry; the guitar was perfect. I was so happy when my guitar finally came, and it arrived just in time for my birthday, which made it an even better present.

Patience is a special skill for some people, and for others, it is very hard to learn. When I was a little girl, I never had any patience, and even now, I do not have much of it either. But my friend was always patient with me. Sure, she would tell me to hurry up or that she would leave, but I would just start laughing and come down right away. She waited for me while I picked up a stray cat and helped me take it to the pound; that's what she would always do for me. Patience is something I will probably never learn until I am much older, but I know I will learn it someday. One time, my friend waited for two hours just to learn about history for a project; I would have never had the patience for that. But then again, she did get a perfect score on her history homework, so her patience for that task was really cool, and she told me that patience is a number one priority for success. This was one time my friend truly demonstrated her patience.

It was a bright sunny day and there was a long, slow-moving line outside the airport terminal. People were waiting for their flight to @LOCATION1. It has been three hours and everyone was getting impatient, shuffling and sighing, but there was a young little boy in the group that didn’t seem to complain; he was very patient, quietly reading a book. Now it has to be five hours, their flight has been delayed, the sun went down, casting long shadows, and there was a riot going on with angry shouts, but still the little young boy was still waiting patiently, observing the scene calmly. It has now been twelve hours, people began to leave, grumbling in frustration, it was midnight, cold and dark, and yet the boy was still waiting there and has not yet moved from his spot. Now there was only fifteen people left, it was dawn, the sky lightening, and yet the boy waited there patiently, his small bag beside him. Their flight has finally arrived and only there was three people there, including the boy and two girls. They went in the plane, exhausted but relieved. The other people that left saw the plane ready to take off and ran toward it, waving their arms. But they were too late and the only people who made it to @LOCATION1 was the two girls and the patient boy. The end.

Patience is difficult to do. Waiting in line for something or waiting for a letter to come in the mail can feel endless. A time when I had to use patience was when I thought of a great poem. Anyways I kept reading and it said that I used patience, which was true, and that was the lesson I learned from the whole experience.

When I got to my grandma house, I didn’t know that every body was help but I dint want to but my mum made me help so nobody went outside to play football; it was a good game cause I look out the window the whole game, I didn’t patient cause I wasn’t in it, just watching. The time that I was patient was today when everyone was taking the @CAPS1.E.A.P., a big state test.
