I am never patient, but on the rare occasions when I am, it is only once in a while. Sitting down and not doing a thing drives me to be insane. When I’m doing nothing and it is really quiet, I get really bad headaches. In school, for example, when I’m waiting, I get really fidgety, like I tap my foot and tap my pencil on my desk. I tap everything; things like that are a constant need. I absolutely must do something or I will go insane. Waiting in a doctor's office, or flying on a plane for a while, can get real boring. When I wait too long, I start to feel lazy and tired because I’m not moving at all. I get buggy when I’m patient and waiting for something. It is usually no longer than thirty minutes before I get real bad. I can’t be patient very long or I get buggy. One way I help myself is by playing sports and doing things constantly to keep my mind and body occupied, which is a necessary strategy for me.

Patience is when a being shows the ability to wait and make good decisions. For me, patience is the ability to stay calm and collected when faced with a delay or a problem. Patience is very important because it allows me to rationally deal with situations so that I will not get into trouble. However, maintaining patience in times of stress is difficult. It is difficult because people are giving you grief and pressure from all sides. Without sufficient patience, people make bad decisions, and this leads to bad things happening. Patience lets me deal with bad ideas like impulsive reactions. By using patience, I can carefully deal with the problem at hand and then move on, as rash actions are a very bad idea that can complicate matters further.

It was the night before Christmas Eve and I could hardly wait. In my family on Christmas Eve we go to my grandparents' house. When we are there we talk, eat, and my favorite, open presents. As my mom, dad, and I drove up to my grandparents' house I couldn’t open the car door fast enough. I sprinted up to the front door and rang the doorbell a hundred times in my excitement. “Well hello there, sport,” my grandpa said. “Hey, can we eat fast so I can open my presents?” I asked eagerly. “Yeah, sure,” he replied with a laugh. After we were done eating I sprinted down the stairs as fast as I could. I simply could not wait any longer. As I waited patiently until all of my older relatives opened their presents, it was finally my turn. I ripped off the wrapping paper and saw what it was: a new video game. Since it was the first present, I had to open it fast, but from then on I waited patiently until it was my turn again for the next gift, learning to contain my excitement a little better.

I saw someone demonstrate real patience once at a fast food restaurant. They got to the restaurant before I did, and then I ordered my food and it came out quickly. They, however, still had no food, so I left after finishing my meal. They finally got their food long after I was gone; now that’s what I call having patience, to wait so long without complaint while others are served before you. It was a clear example of composure I rarely possess.

When I was seven I played on a basketball team named the Tigers. We were playing against the Lions for the championship and I wasn’t in the game. My coach told me to stay on the bench this game because I was the hardest working player on my team, and he wanted to save me. Without me playing, my team was down by ten points and my coach didn’t put me in yet. I knew if I stayed calm and was patient, my chance would come and he would let me play. So when it was the fourth quarter with a minute left in the game and we were down by five, my coach finally told me to get in the game and win it for us. So I got in and it was thirty seconds left; I got the ball and started making all my shots. But when it was ten seconds left and we were down by one point, I got fouled. I had to take a technical shot, which is when you are at the foul line and it’s just you, the ball, and the rim. I made my first shot without a problem, but my second shot I didn’t know what to do, so I thought about what I did to play in the game: patience. So as I got ready to shoot, I got patient with the shot to think it out, and when I shot it, I made it. Once the other team got the ball to inbound it, we stole the ball and won the game. If I hadn’t been patient in this game we wouldn’t have won, and I wouldn’t have gotten the trophy to take home with me, proving that patience truly is a virtue.

My mom has very little patience, which is why it surprised me when she had a whole bunch the day my grandma passed away. I was amazed she was sad but took her time carefully and slowly, as if every move she made had to be perfect and deliberate. It was a terrible day, and all any of us wanted to do was cry and grieve. My mom knew that my grandma would want her to be happy and strong, that’s why she watched her every move and held herself together. As soon as I got there she came right up to me and gave me a huge, comforting hug, and no matter what my little brother and I did, she didn’t even mind or raise her voice. That was a very surprising day because I had never in my life seen her that sad but yet so patient and composed throughout it all.

A time that I was patient is when I had my twelfth birthday party. All of my friends except one wanted to keep playing the games we had started, so we did. We decided to go and walk the dogs first, and then have a nice dinner together, and then finally open the presents. When we were all done with that, we opened my presents, and I was very excited and happy to see them all. That is a time that I was patient, waiting for my favorite part of the day. I was very proud of myself for doing what my friends wanted to do first without complaining. Plus in the end, I got a lot of exciting stuff, and I realized that waiting, and doing what my friends wanted to do first, was a great idea that made the whole day more fun. I’m pretty sure that we all had a great time together because of it.

Sarah was swinging with her friend all day when she was swinging so high that the chain came loose and Sarah fell, and she was screaming in pain. So they walked into the house to get help. When they got to the house Sarah was still screaming and crying, so they all got in the car and drove to the doctor's office. The nurse said that she had to wait an hour to see the doctor, which felt like forever. Sarah wasn’t patient at first, fidgeting and upset, until she and her friend were talking and distracting each other with stories. When the doctor was finally ready to see her, she had forgot all about why she was there because of their conversation. Sarah found out that she broke her arm and needed a cast. Later that day she thanked her mom for taking her and then called her friend and thanked her for helping her be patient during the long, scary wait.

I thought that when I got hurt during football and was on a stretcher, everyone around me was incredibly patient. They understood that I could only go a certain speed and waited for me in the hallways and carried my stuff from room to room without a single complaint. An example of someone showing this patience was my friend Mark, who had to hurry to go to the bathroom but walked with me slowly so I wouldn't be alone and in pain. Another example of someone being patient with me is my sister Lauren. Lauren was patient with me when I asked her repeatedly for help with my homework, even though she was busy with her own work, and she never once made me feel like a burden. Their kindness during that difficult time is something I will always remember and appreciate.

The time I was patient was when my mom and I went to the eye doctor. It was my first time going there, so I was nervous. We went to this lady at the front desk and had to wait for the doctor to call us. We sat for twenty minutes and then we heard the doctor calling my name. We went inside the doctor's room and I sat down in the big chair; he does all these tests and things with different machines. Later he tells us that we have to meet one more doctor for another part of the exam. We sat down again in the waiting room and we waited some more. Then we hear my name again so we go into another room. The worst thing was that I saw a medicine bottle on the table and I was really scared of what it was for. The lady asked me to look up and open my eyes wide, which was difficult because I was so nervous. After that she took the medicine and was going to put it in my eyes. I was so scared that when she put the medicine in my eyes it burned a little and I flinched. I didn't want her to do the other eye at all. I wanted to just stand up and run outside, but I couldn't; I had to be patient. She did the other eye and told me to now keep my eyes closed until she came back. When she came back she told me that was it, and we were done there. I thought to myself, as we were leaving, that it wasn’t so bad after all and I was glad I had stayed still.

I forgot to grab my helmet and knee pads out of my mom’s car because she works until five and at six that evening my skateboarding session was supposed to begin. I felt a surge of frustration, knowing I couldn't practice without my gear. Then my patience showed up, reminding me that a short delay wouldn't ruin the entire day and that I could find another activity to enjoy in the meantime.

Patience can mean a lot of things. It can mean to be understanding or it can mean to be tolerant. Being patient can also mean you don’t complain. Like if you ask someone to get you something and they say that they will get it in a certain amount of days. If they don’t get it the day they said they would and you were expecting it then you shouldn’t get mad, but instead give them the benefit of the doubt. You can also be patient if you have to wait for something. If you are getting a new pair of shoes but the only way you can get them is they have to be ordered, you should not start to complain if it takes a long time. You should be able to wait without getting angry that you don’t have them yet. Being patient can mean all of these things. If you do these things you can tell that you are patient. That is what being patient means.

Patient, that’s all I am when I go fishing. If there is a spot where you cast, it takes sometimes almost fifty casts just to get a bite, then you have to wait for the fish to swallow the hook. Sometimes you have to be patient in picking the lure you are going to use. That is because you have to consider the water color, the amount of weeds, and what the fish are eating that day. Then you have to have patience on the spot you are at too, because after the motor runs you have to wait for the fish to come back to the area. So you have to have a lot of patience to go fishing, but the reward of a catch makes it all worthwhile.

Anna sat there waiting patiently, come on come on come on! She thought to herself at the meet, and was very excited to perform her now improved beam routine. Anna was one of the last gymnasts to go, only making her situation more difficult as she watched the others take their turns. She took a deep breath, and sat down patiently, waiting for her chance to shine for the judges and finally show them all the hard work she had put into her practice.

It was the fifteenth of October when I went to see the Creed concert with my cousins. There must have been a hundred or two hundred people in front of us in the long, winding line. Then I heard and saw people shoving and pushing to get in, which made the wait feel even longer. About thirty to forty minutes later my legs started aching from standing for so long, but I held on. I kept telling myself, “the pain is worth the wait!” Finally we got to the security guards and they had to do a metal detector check on us. When we walked into the concert venue and the music hit us, I said, “that was a wait worth waiting for.”

A time when I was patient. Two weeks ago my mom said her sister was coming. My grandma was happy so she bought her sister a bus ticket. Bus tickets cost a lot of money. It is one hundred dollar. That was a lot of money. She couldn't miss this bus because I really want to see her. I could not wait. So she was suppose to be coming on Friday. She didn't come. I was sick so I called my mom at her job. I said, "Mom why didn't auntie come." My mom said," Honey she is coming you just have to be patient." Okay, I said. Next day was Saturday. "Mom is she here yet" I said. "No, honey be patient she will be here tomorrow." "Okay, I understand." I gave up I thought that she was not coming. So my mom called my godmom. She said it was okay. So she told me she was going to McDonald's. I love McDonald's. I so good. I asked my mom. "Can I have a cheeseburger. McDonald's cheese burger." I said hello to my uncle and my mom said she was not coming. I told my mom I was not giving up she was coming. So I said I am hanging up. So I air hustled. My mom said to my uncle John "should I get her something to eat. I thought she ment my grandmother. So I thought for a while her who is her. So I called back my mom said ohh I get food for uncle John's dog. I said, Spot's? For a dog? She said know dog food. So my mom got me from my god mothers house I could not walk because my legs, back, arm and every part that I could move on my body hurt. So my grandmother came to her house because we have a keys. So she said where is she? My uncle whispered something and I said she here! Ran in my uncle room and hug her I said how are you because when I went for my grandmother birthday. She live in south caroline so yeah. The is my writing. That is when I was patient. So I could wait for my mom's sister.

Two years ago, when the first iPhone came out my step dad paid eight hundred dollars for one. He was so happy all he did was brag to his family and friends about it, showing off its features every chance he got. During this time my mom had broke her phone and my step dad did not want to let her use his phone, worrying she might damage his new prized possession. So she was phoneless for aleast three months, which felt like a very long time. She was kind a mad but it was worth being patient for. As the newer and improved one came out in stores my mom was able to buy it, finally getting a phone of her own. She was so glad, she had more apps then the first iPhone and a webcom, which made her feel it was worth the long wait. I think that my mom did a good job at being patient because if it was someone else they wouldnít be able to wait that long without complaining much more.

When I was about seven I wanted one thing in the wold. You know how some girl would want a baby ball no not me I wanít a rex this toy was the bigest and the meanest dinow on the plant well when I was a little it was. It was so cool to me ti could walk, talk it can run he can bit, and it had big, sharp teeth. Ever time I go to the story I would go to the toy part of the story, and find that rex and look at it in the eyes in say ìyou will be mine one day.î You know how relly wanít somthing and mom says chismist is coming up. When it anít comeing in till two months. But I wonít it now not in two months. So I thought what can I do to get the rex befor two months? I got it! I will clen up more, walk the bog more, do better in school, and hopefully that will work. So I ask my mom ìmom if I start doing all this good stof can I get so of my chismast thing in a week earlyî she said ìno you just get more thing on chismisî I was so mad I was about to cry, my plan had failed. But two month was not that long. I was opening my gifts in no time. but I thought that I open all my gifts, I look arond one good time I did! But I donít see the rex I was said even thow I had like ten or more gifts, I still felt disappointed. I still donít have that rex. So I sidely walk to my room, my shoulders slumped. My mom came in my room with a big box. Could it be! I jumped out of my bed so fast my mono donít see me. I looked in the box it was a lot of babys doll, which made my heart sink. Then she said go down stars and ther he was rex looking so happy to see me, finally mine after all that waiting.

ìFive, six, seven, eight!î my poms coach Ms. Smith says as we practice the dance over and over again until our moves are perfect. I love poms but at times it gets very tiring, especially when we have to hold our arms up high for a long time. We have practice Monday, Wednesday, and Friday. We also have six girls including me, so we are a small team. My coach loves to make us do the dance one time by ourselves to make sure we all know the steps. On our first game we had practice right before we left for our very first performance. All of us were so excited we all just wanted to go and perform all day, talking about it nonstop. But the game was at 5:45 pm and they didnít even start until 6:00 pm which was way later than expected. So all my poms team, our coach, and all of our family had to wait patiently on the bleachers for over an hour until we actually, finally got to perform. Finally it was the fourth quarter and the clock bit three, which ment we all went on the track to stretch and get ready. We were all so happy but still a little sad that we didnít get to perform earlier. We had a minute on the clock so we walked to the other side of the field. Getting in our formation the clock quickley started to drop from fifty seconds to ten then quickely we only had five seconds until we went on. I couldnít believe it, only five seconds until our very first performance. The thrill rushed through my head as the man announced ìLincoln Elementary performing their junior varsity pom pon teamî then our names over the speakers. The crowed roared as we entered the field, a loud and wonderful sound. We quickley all reminded our self to smile big for everyone watching. Then the music came on and we all danced our hearts out honoring and thanking our coach and our parents for their support. After we finished we were automatically huttled around by friends and family, all giving us hugs and congratulations. And waiting and being patient wasnít so bad anymore. It was all worth the wait in the end.

When dealing with todlers or the elderly you must have patience. This patience is key when dealing with anyone, but very young and very old need more of it. Elderly often may become confused, have a hard time hearing you, or just be a bit slower than you are. You must practice patience and give them respect, never rushing them or speaking harshly. Very young children are confused sometimes too because they are just learning about the world. Toddlers will often become upset and refuse to do what you tell them to is you have no patience with them and start to yell, which only makes things worse. Patience is also important for mentally or physically challenged persons, as they face different hurdles. If they are challenged, there is no way that they can help it, so kindness is essential. Mentally challenged people often don't understand or don't want to do things just like toddlers, and they need calm explanations. Be patient with the physically challenged because some tasks may be hard for them to complete quickly or at all. Be patient with everyone because patience is a form of respect you show them. Fear is not respect, only patience and understanding are. That is how I feel about the word patience and its importance in our lives.

A time when I was patient was when I was babysitting and the kids I was babysitting were acting up. It was hard for me to get them to calm down. But, I noticed that if I was patient then they would be too. So, I just sat down and told them calmly to settle down, but they wouldn't listen. So I told them again in a quiet, steady voice and this time they were a bit quieter. I noticed that if I ignored their tantrums or remained patient then they would eventually settle down and stop, because I realized they were just trying to get my attention. If I was being patient and calm, I knew they would eventually mirror that behavior. It worked; they settled down and were being a lot more cooperative when I was babysitting them the next time too, which showed me the true value of maintaining composure.

"Pull back harder on the reins!" my teacher yelled. "I'm trying, but he's just not listening!" This horse had to be the most stubborn horse I had ever ridden in my life! He did whatever he wanted, whenever he wanted, and paid no attention to me at all. "Okay, just bring him in," she said. I slowly walked the horse into the center of the ring. "I really am trying; he's just not listening," I said in frustration. "I know he can be a bit hard-headed, but I make you ride him because I believe you can handle him," she replied. The horse's name was Rusty, and he was a reddish-brownish color with big glassy brown eyes. He looked like a great horse that listened to its rider. Wrong! He was not nice or sweet and didn't listen at all! "Now walk him around a couple of times along the perimeter," my instructor said. "Okay, fine," I replied. But as I was halfway around the ring, Rusty stopped. Then he turned to his right, walked up to the window, and started licking the water that beaded up on it. "What is he doing!" she yelled. "I think he is licking the water off the windows," I said. "Well, get him away from there; he could get sick!" As I said earlier, this horse has terrible listening skills! Now I was getting in trouble because of him! "You need to be patient," my instructor told me. I guess I did need to calm down, so I relaxed my shoulders a little and continued riding with no further problems for the rest of the lesson. I guess I truly needed patience and to relax. Even if so, I am still never getting on that horse ever again.

On my way to the coast to visit my dad, I prepared for the long drive. While in the car there is food, and I brought along my Nintendo Switch to keep me busy. I brought my Switch along because it would be annoying if I asked "are we there yet?" very five minutes, and I knew that a five-hour drive would need some entertainment. Most of the time I would be playing games so time goes by fast; if I don't play games then I eat a snack, play with my baby cousin, Lily, and sometimes just sleep. After a while of that, I sit back and relax, watching the scenery go by. The whole trip is five hours, but by doing all that it seems to be more like two or three hours, making the journey feel much shorter and more enjoyable.

Patience is basically waiting and tolerating it. Every year on May first, my family becomes seasonal at a campground. There we play and have fun and make many lifelong friends. Every weekend we go out there and we take our speed boat, "The Glass Frog." We put it into the lake and dock it at a dock. Then we go fishing on every part of the lake and sit there for six hours. This is where patience comes in; we have to sit and watch our bobbers float on the smooth, glass-like lake. We sit there and watch and talk and bake in the sunlight. It is quite peaceful though, that I'm off school and I get to spend quality time with my parents. Then in school I have to wait patiently throughout the year so the year can be over. So we sit there quietly until the sudden noise of one of our bobbers sinking into the water. After that there's some yelling and "get the net" sayings. The funny part is that it is either a large bass or a small sunfish. And all this takes a great deal of patience, which is a valuable lesson learned.

My dog, Teddy Bear, is very impatient because when he comes in from outside he gets a treat, but he has to wait for the other dogs to come in. He will sit by the treat jar, whining and pacing back and forth, staring intently at the door until his siblings finally come inside. His little tail wags furiously the moment the last dog enters, knowing his wait is finally over and his reward is coming. This small, daily routine perfectly illustrates his impatient but hopeful nature.

One afternoon in early spring I was very patient when I was waiting for my sister in law to tell my brother to tell us we could come in the hospital room and see their brand new baby JACKSON. My father and mother were waiting with my sister, brother and I, in the waiting room lobby. The chairs were stiff and uncomfortable, adding to the long stretch of time. At the time it was probably for an hour and a half waiting, a duration that felt much longer in the quiet, sterile hallway. I guess that I could say that I was being patient. Also very ten to fifteen minutes I would have to get up and walk around a small circle to stretch my legs. I was so shaky nervous and jumpy, my excitement barely contained. But it probably didn't help that I drank three cans of pepsi and right before rushed to the time I was being patient, which only amplified my restless energy as we awaited the wonderful news.

Patience to me is a personal thought that turns into action. I’ve been patience many times before. I use to go to the store at the corner of my block, a small convenience shop that was always busy. I had to stand in a long line that actually went to the halfway point of my block, snaking out the door and along the sidewalk. I went in got my stuff and went to the end of the line, settling in for a long wait. A half hour past and it was five minutes til’ closing time, the line inching forward slowly. I get to the window and pay for my things one minute before closing time. I was actually standing in line doing nothing, just watching the world go by. The owner of the store, seeing my perseverance, let me get a total of five things for free. I got half of the stuff I wanted and the other half was house hold things, a pleasant and unexpected surprise. So being patient really pays off and can unlock many different treasures, both big and small. So start running with patience and leaving impatience behind, and you may find yourself rewarded in the most unexpected ways.

Well you need patience when your fishing, waiting quietly for a bite that may not come for hours, and whe your food is comeing or going to be served to you, resisting the urge to complain about the delay, but also be patient with everybody else, understanding that they too are dealing with their own struggles and timelines. Practicing this virtue in all aspects of life makes for a more peaceful and harmonious existence for yourself and for those around you.

Just as I finished eating my hamburger I noticed an old, crude excuse for a bus parked outside of the restaurant window. “What’s that?” I asked through my squeaky seven-year-old voice. My dad responded, “That bus takes people to the palace across the street, where Elvis’s playing.” “Wouldn’t it be cool if we could go?” I questioned. I saw my mom whisper something to my brother. It was then that they told me we were going to the show. Excitedly, I climbed into the back seat of our car and we drove across street to the palace of AUBURN. It was huge, towering over us with bright lights! All I wanted to do was enter the marvelous building, but my dad kept telling me we had to wait for the right time to go in. About fifteen minutes later the two pepsis I had drinken earlier made it through my system “Dad, I have to go to the bathroom”, I said over and over again, growing more desperate. Finally, my dad took me through the front doors. The inside of the building was even more fabulous than the outside, with a grand staircase and glittering chandeliers! However, a rail of red rope blocked our way. “Could my son use the bathrooms?” my dad asked a lady who sat behind the front desk. She gave a cold “no” and we were forced to return back to the car, my hopes dashed. Another fifteen minutes passed, each one feeling like an hour. The concert would start soon, so we returned to the building. This time the red rope had gone, but replaced by a line of nearly fifty people who were all waiting to get through the metal detector! It took almost twenty minutes, but we made it to the front of line, we passed through the metal detector and took our seats. That was a true test of my patience, but it all was worth it when I was finally allowed to use the bathroom and could then fully enjoy the spectacular show.

I was patient when I went to Disneyland on Monday. First it started out when I got a call from my friend Michael he asked me to go. So I said yes, feeling a surge of excitement. I had to be patient all day until the following Saturday, counting down the days. Then he drove the long way but I was patient, looking out the window at the passing scenery without complaint. When we got to the entrance I felt good for being patient, knowing my calm demeanor had made the long journey more pleasant for everyone, and that my reward was just beyond the gates.

Once upon a time there was a place called Unpaciente Land. But on Grumpy Lane lived a little girl named @ORGANIZATION1. She was the most patient girl ever, known for her calm and steady nature. One day @ORGANIZATION1 went to get her hair cut at "Mtso Fast Saloon!" When @ORGANIZATION1 got there everyone was screaming at @CAPS1 the hair cutter, creating a loud and chaotic scene, and @ORGANIZATION1 stood up and said, "Hey, if you want your hair to look good, sit down and be quiet," and everybody did, settling down immediately. @ORGANIZATION1 went home with a beautiful haircut, just like everybody else who had calmed down, and then @ORGANIZATION1 became the mayor of Unpaciente Land and renamed it @CAPS2 Land. From that day forward, everybody was patient, living in peace and harmony.

A time when I was patient was when I went to the doctor with my step mom & brother. He was getting his knee looked at; we were in that waiting room for like two or three hours! Jody (my step mom) was getting really irritated, pacing and sighing, but I told her that the doctor would be out soon. I was very patient, sitting quietly while @CAPS2 and @PERSON1 were playing with his phone. That kind of made @CAPS2 relax because usually I’m not very patient; usually everyone tells @CAPS2 that I’m really impatient. For some reason when I’m really excited I’m fairly patient. I was exulted to see if he could get his knee brace off. Sure enough he did, and he was so happy that the two-hour wait was worth it! This was a time when I was patient and it truly paid off in the end.

One time I was patient. It was December @NUM1, @DATE1 @CAPS1 Eve. I was so excited that @CAPS1 was almost here. On @CAPS1 Eve morning I slept till @NUM2, even though I wanted to get up early for the day to come. I was patient so I played video games, not thinking about @CAPS1 and the presents. When I went to the store I seen all the @CAPS1 things, the decorations and the gifts. I felt like I couldn’t wait no longer, the excitement was almost too much. That night after dinner I found that I wanted to stay up instead of going to sleep early to make @CAPS1 come faster. A little part of me wanted to go to sleep but I also wanted to stay up, so I made some more food and then finally went to sleep. When morning came I was so happy I ran into the living room. Sure enough there was the presents, all under the tree. My mom and dad were still sleeping. I decided to watch some TV until @NUM3 came and I wanted to open them so badly, but I knew it wouldn’t be right without my family, so I waited patiently. At noon I woke up and ran to the living room. My mom and dad and my brother were there, and I opened my presents like a lion feasting on a gazelle, I was so happy I had waited.

When I was patient I had no fears, no argument, but I had a good deal. I had a @CAPS1 and @CAPS4 was so good my sister @PERSON1 said, “@CAPS2, I get some?” I said, “@CAPS3, you @CAPS2.” @CAPS4 was a miracle, so I was driving her car at the gas station. I went to @ORGANIZATION1 and I said, “@NUM1 @CAPS5, please.” @CAPS4 was a cousin of mine and she said, “@NUM2 days ago.” I was like, “Wow.” @PERSON1 called my phone because @CAPS4 was my daddy’s weekend and she said, “Get down there now.” I was like, wow, but I remained calm and patient throughout the whole situation, handling everything without getting upset.

A time when I had to be patient was on the drive to @LOCATION1. @CAPS1 took a few hours so here is @CAPS2 story. We were leaving the house when I realized I forgot something. I quickly ran inside to get @CAPS2 dog Penny—she is real, not fake—and @CAPS2 dog bitted out the door, so I put her in the truck. We stopped at @CAPS2 grandmas and grandpas house to rest for a little while. We travelled through lots of small roads until we got to the highway. “@CAPS1’s gonna be a long ride,” I said. We passed so many cars, and then they passed us. For a second we lost our grandparents car in the traffic. I looked back and behind about twelve cars I found them again. We reached @LOCATION3 in about four hours. I knew @CAPS1 was going to be a long trip so I decided to take a nap. During @CAPS2 nap, @CAPS2 parents—@CAPS2 mom—took pictures of me sleeping. I thought that @CAPS1 wasn’t very nice of them. We now had one more state to go through and then we were in @LOCATION1. That state was @LOCATION2. By the time we reached @LOCATION2, @CAPS1 was already @NUM1. We decided to get a room, like a hotel, for the night. In the morning we stopped and ate a quick breakfast. Then it was on the road again. I had to be patient because we still had a two hour drive to go. It felt like the longest five hours ever, but I was patient so @CAPS1 was fine. We arrived in @LOCATION1 and had no clue where we were going. So @CAPS2 dad turned on his GPS and we found our way to our cabins. That is a story about a time I had to be patient on a very long journey.

There are many times I’ve been patient, but I will describe @CAPS1 this one specific time. My little sister kept bugging me, and I didn’t scream at her or hit her. She was asking me to turn on the music and I said “no,” which caused her to throw a fit. So I calmly got up and picked her up, and told her to stop before she got herself into trouble, using a nice and kind voice. And she stopped crying. And I then told her gently to sit down and be quiet and watch tv. In closing, that was a time that I was patient with my little sister, by not screaming at her or hitting her when she was disturbing me. I didn’t become a mean person at that point. Last but not least, that was a time that I was a patient person.

Patience for me is when I'm helping others with their problems, so in this story I'm going to describe to you what patience truly means. Patience is when you are willing to sit down and calmly help someone with their own problems without rushing them. I believe I have a lot of patience because I sit down all the time and help people with their issues. One day at my old school, @PERSON1, this girl was having very difficult problems at home. When she came to school she was crying, so I went to go ask her what was wrong. She explained that she didn’t want to be at home because her mom didn’t let her go anywhere; she always had to stay home and watch her two brothers. “When can I drive?” I whined. “When the time comes you have to be patient, otherwise you won’t!” yelled my dad over the loud, heart warming sound of the engine starting up for the first time that year. I loved that sound. It’s my second favorite sound. The vibrations rattling my legs as it races away with my brother driving. I could wait until my turn, watching intently. After a few rides and twenty minutes, Dad said the words I thought he’d never say, “Okay, your turn.” I looked at him then the truck. Wow, does he look small next to that big truck. Sometimes patience requires a lot of mental peace to stay calm. One time me, and my dad were going to work in the city. The bus was late fifteen minutes, but it felt like a few weeks of waiting. Sometimes patience is good and bad. Good patience is when a team scores a goal; the audience was patient enough so that the team could score. A bad patience is when you’re late to work, and there's traffic, or the bus was late, and you just have to wait. Sometimes you can distract yourselves while being patient, like texting, calling a friend, or talking or playing a game with a kid or by yourselves. So you see that patience can be good or bad, and also requires a lot of mental peace to manage well.

When I was around the age of eight, I went to a family reunion with my grandpa, grandma, mom, and dad. We stopped so many times I can't even count. I think it was to use the restroom or get snacks, but I did not want to stop or be patient because I wanted to get there and see what everything looked like. It was a big event, but the worst part was we had to leave our dog home for a week. I was impatient to get home, too, because as soon as I got home I was going to sleep in my own bed. We got up to leave from our house at five in the morning and we got to the motel at two in the afternoon. I was sick of sitting in the car, and I did not want to get back in the car to go home because if you think of it, that is a long way to wait in the car. I was very impatient because if I could have gotten there in a half an hour it would have been a lot better than like, nine hours of time. But it was a lot of fun to see new things that you have never seen before on your way there, because on our way home, I was just sleeping. But I was not very patient; I was so bored that at every stop I would switch cars. I did not have anything to do at that time, but I did have my Nintendo DS until it died. Then I made do with my iPod and my cell phone; all I could do was call and play games on that. But I was so impatient at the corner, too, because I would rather go to the hotel and sleep than sit there listening to older people talk about what has happened. I didn't know hardly any of them; I could not tell you who everyone was, and that just made the waiting feel even longer.

I was patient this one time while waiting to get on the computers. I told my mom to wake me if she gets off the computer, and after an hour I fell asleep on the couch. I woke up after a little while and my brother was on for three hours reading manga we already have. After three minutes my dad kicked me off to check his email. He said he would be off soon, yet he spent the rest of the day and a bit more of the next day watching Indiana Star for six hours. This was even though he spends eight hours on a computer at work, so that adds up to fourteen or more hours on the internet every day of the year. It was frustrating to wait so long for just a few minutes of time, and it taught me that sometimes patience doesn't always get you what you want.

There was this guy that I liked a lot that I finally had the courage to ask out after two years and three weeks. He said yes to go to the dance with me but no to going out. So a little while later, like a week later, I asked him again. He told me to give him till the end of the week. So I waited and waited, and on and on it seemed like forever. Then my friend just couldn't take it; she asked him on Thursday and he said yes! A million yeses and joy came from his mouth. Then, after getting to know me better, he broke up with me. We have been fighting ever since, but we're still besties! It was a confusing time, but it showed me that some things are worth waiting for, while others are better left as friendships.

Being patient is hard and not all people are patient, but patience is an important thing to do. You have to be patient almost everywhere you go, like waiting in line is being patient. You have to be patient with people, too, like people who are learning or you are teaching. I was patient at an amusement park, which was really hard to do. When I was really little, maybe four or five years old, we went there. My older sister wanted to go on a ride but I couldn't go because I was too short. So my mom stayed with me while my older sister and my dad went on the ride. I was so sad but my mom told me to wait and not get antsy. After a while I started asking, “When is the ride going to be over, mama?” She kept responding, “I don't know, whenever your sister and dad get off the ride.” Gosh, I couldn't wait, but when my dad and sister got off they told my mom that they wanted to go again. My mom said “ok” and that's when I got sad. Then she said to me, “but because you waited so long and nicely I will take you to get a smoothie.” “I love smoothies,” I screamed. Patience is important, because I was so patient my mom got me something I love. Patience is a hard thing to do but once you got it, it’s a good thing to do and can lead to sweet rewards.

Last year I went to the doctors to get a normal check up when she tested my vision and hearing and felt my throat, too. She listened to my chest to see if my heart was okay. After that she checked my neck. I could feel her icy cold fingers on my neck; about a minute had passed and she says she will be right back. Another doctor came in and felt it until finally my mom asks "what's going on here". They said the glands in my neck were full and they said I needed to have my blood checked to see if I had a thyroid issue, which is glands in your neck that are full which leads to having to take pills for the rest of your life. So a few days later we went to get my blood checked. As we waited I started to get really nervous; I had butterflies really bad and then twenty minutes passed which seemed like an hour. They called me in and I sat down; the nurse said everything will be fine. So I trusted her; she took a rubber tube and tied it around my arm. It sorta hurt like a pinch then one... two... three... and the needle went in and I seen the blood going into the tube, which was really cool. Then we went home. It took a week with sleepless nights because I was so anxious, and they called my mom, which took about a year, not really, but I could not tell by her expression. Then she said no, and I was so happy. I was being patient, which was what kept me from not wanting to run down there and find out myself, and in the end, that patience was rewarded with good news.

“When do we get the Xbox!” I asked my dad impatiently. “Two hours,” he replied calmly. “Seriously!” “Yes.” “Fine.” “Fine.” Two hours…. I thought, this is gonna feel like a week. First, I got on the computer, clicking aimlessly through websites. After ten minutes I got off because nothing was interesting. Next I picked up the t.v. guide, scanning the listings. Nothing good was on. Why am I so tired! I thought. It must be that I did so much yesterday, I was thinking but luckily, before I could finish the thought, I fell asleep on the couch. I woke up later, groggy. Four hours left. Once again I looked at the t.v guide; still nothing. Out of sheer boredom, I just turned the t.v on. A movie had just ended. “Coming up next on Filmland is The Inspector,” the channel’s commercial said. “I have to see this,” I said out loud to the empty room. It turned out better than I thought. It was a black and white film that was about a police official and his son solving a big case. After watching four hours of the movie, completely absorbed, I heard the front door open and creak. I heard my dad come in and say in a cheerful voice, “I got it!” A wave of relief washed over me, and then I said, “Finally,” and then, completely exhausted, I fell back asleep. “Don’t you dare wake him up,” my dad whispered to someone in the room.

One time my brother Alex was incredibly patient. Patience is being understanding and listening through difficulties without complaining. Our family lived in Ohio and were going to Cedar Point on a summer vacation. We had fun all day riding roller coasters and playing games, and at four o'clock we decided to go on the Power Tower. Alex chose to go on the blue Power Tower while the rest of the family went on the red one. The blue version keeps you suspended at the top for a few moments and then drops you suddenly, while the red one shoots you straight up to three hundred feet. The line for the red Power Tower was much shorter than the blue one so we got to go on our ride first. Once our ride was over and we got off, Alex was already at the very top of the blue Power Tower. We heard a loud mechanical sound that meant the blue Power Tower car was coming down. But the blue car wasn’t coming down. Alex was stuck at the top, two hundred and forty feet in the air. He got a complete bird’s eye view of the entire park. I would have been terrified and screaming if I were Alex. At six o’clock, as the sun was setting, the ride lights came on brightly and the car finally plummeted down. Finally, after a long wait, he got his ride. As an apology, each person on the ride got free season passes to Cedar Point. This is a clear time when Alex truly needed to show patience, and he handled the situation calmly.

On Saturday morning we went to the Dollar Tree first because my mom needed to pick up a few things. I really wanted to go to the Game Stop instead to look at the new video games. But I was patient and did not complain while we browsed the aisles. Then, after she finished her shopping, we finally went to the Game Stop, and my patience was rewarded.

In the beginning, I woke up from sleeping and felt real sick, so I took a shower and put on my clothes slowly. I told my dad in a weak voice, “can I go to the doctor because I feel sick?” He said “we will leave at nine am” and it was only seven am. Then, I had to wait on the couch, feeling miserable, while my brothers, my dad and my mom were all taking showers one after another. After that, I really wanted to yell and complain loudly because they were going too slow and tried acting all calm and beautiful. But I didn’t. When they finally finished, they had to look for the car keys for a while until they found them under a newspaper. It was eight-thirty am and my dad’s favorite music video was on television, so we stayed and watched the whole thing. In the middle of the morning, it was ten am and then we finally went to the doctor’s office and had to stay in the waiting room, waiting for everyone to get their turn until it was eleven, which was our turn. We had actually made an appointment. They checked what was bothering me, my throat and temperature, and it was nothing serious. So I left the examination room and I still waited patiently until my brothers finished with the doctor. In the end, I was a little pissed off because I had to wait for them all to get in the car and get settled. My dad said “Are you happy now? You said that you feel sick and there is nothing wrong with you.” Then we went home, and I was thinking that I had been patient for the whole day. I was saying to myself quietly, “I learned my lesson and it is that if you are patient, the day can go by fast without so much stress.”

Over the winter break I went to Orlando, Florida to visit my aunt. My family got up early and drove to the airport; it was the first time I was going to go on a plane. My dad said I better have patience or else the long ride was going to be boring. Me and my sister got on the plane and flew to Atlanta, and it took one hundred and twenty minutes and that part was easy. But then we got on another, larger plane and went directly to Orlando and that took another two hours. It was a very long ride but I had patience, sitting quietly and looking out the window. My sister, however, didn't have any patience at all; the whole ride she was constantly asking which time we were going to get there. And that was the time I truly learned about having patience during a long journey.

A time I was patient. My family were going to go camping, so my family got packed up and locked the car. The car ride was two hours long so I had to be patient. I played my PlayStation for a couple of minutes; it was a school day but we left early so we could do some things when we got there. Then I tried to read my book; I was so excited. But I couldn't with my cousins, Sarah and Emily, screaming and yelling. I finally fell asleep. Then we hit a pothole and our car was out of gas. Luckily, we were right in front of a gas station. It took us an hour to get it fixed, so we snacked on a granola bar thing and we left. Then my cousins got all excited, shouting, "The sign! We are almost there!" I was happy I could put up my tent and go to sleep. I saw our camp ground and when we got there we had to put everything up. I had to be patient to go to sleep. Then the kids found a park and, of course, they wanted to go. My mom wanted me to take them; I was so tired I didn't want to go to the park. So we stayed at the campsite. My uncle yelled that the park was pretty close to the camp site anyway. I ate my dinner as quickly as I possibly could and then I went into my tent and went to sleep.

I was patient when I was going to Cedar Point. We took a bus and it took seven hours. So my friend Jake decided to watch movies on the portable DVD player. We watched *Street Dreams* and *The Incredibles*. We were still a long way from Cedar Point. We decided to call my mom for a prank call. It was hilarious so we did it again. Then we took turns napping and watching the big open road through the window. Eventually we both fell asleep from the gentle rocking of the bus. When we woke up we were there, finally arriving at the amusement park. This is the time I waited patiently. Because I waited patiently then I don't mind waiting now. I learned to do something else while waiting, like watching a movie or taking a nap. Now I can wait much longer without getting frustrated. This lesson in patience has helped me greatly in my future.

I was patient during the MEAP test. I was patient because I was done early and a lot of people were not done yet. When I get done early I like to draw or do some of my homework, but I didn't have any work so I just waited quietly. Then when everyone got done we waited for five minutes before we started the MEAP test again. When I got done with that section, no one else was done so I waited for ten or fifteen minutes. Then everyone was done and we stretched and walked around for ten minutes before we sat back down to start part five. When we are done we get to do quiet work, and I am usually the first one done. Then when I get done with the test I get up and walk around so I can get a good score and high marks on my tests like the MEAP test because it is so important to get good grades. When you are patient you will find out you can get good grades like advanced and proficient.

On my last trip to Cedar Point I made a horrible mistake. I waited in line for two hours for the Mantis roller coaster. I had to be patient, but it was hard to because the mist fans were having technical difficulties. And how can I be patient when it is ninety-five degrees outside?! The only good part of the line was the shade. That was the way I kept my patience. I told myself, "Just be calm, and in no time you will be there." But I spoke too soon. Half an hour seemed like two hours, but I think the heat was just getting to me. Finally, after two long hours in line, the mist fans began to lift our spirits. Patience can bring luck. I waited for what seems like only ten minutes but was actually an hour. After I got off the ride, I was so relieved to feel the breeze. I guess patience, in some ways, is the key to success.

One day a man named John had a doctor’s appointment and overslept; when John got out of bed he saw that he was late. As John got out of bed he rushed into the bathroom to take a quick shower, as if he had time for that. John noticed it was getting later so he didn’t get to wash up or brush his teeth, so he grabbed a piece of gum on the way out the door. John finally got to the doctor's office, went inside, and saw there were millions of people in the waiting room. He went to check his name in and sat down in a stiff chair. He started to get frustrated and tired of waiting, so he calmed himself down and realized the importance of patience. John kept himself busy for two whole hours playing with his phone and the many apps he had downloaded. John was so busy he didn’t realize that he was the last person still waiting. Other people had their check-ups and left and others just left without theirs. Finally, they called his name for his appointment. As John was going in he put one, maybe two pieces of gum in his mouth and started talking to the nurse. John was done with his check-up, zoomed home, flew into the shower, and brushed his teeth thoroughly. He got back in the bed and went straight to sleep.

Patience is very difficult for me. Having patience is very difficult for me, because I am not patient at all: I cannot wait for things. During school, I am always looking at the clock, counting down the minutes until the bell rings. I just can’t wait for class to be over most of the time, my mind already racing ahead to what I will do next. Some times I think I rush things a little bit too much, like when I skip ahead in my reading or hurry through my homework. I wish I was patient, but I’m not. I’m not patient because I think about what comes after the waiting, I get too curious and excited about the future event. For example: in class I get excited for when the day ends, imagining meeting my friends or going home to relax. Some day, I want to improve on my waiting style and learn to be more calm. I don’t think that will happen anytime soon, but it remains a small hope for the future.

Patience is very important at my house. My mother always says you have to be able to be patient to succeed in anything. One time I was at home on the computer, completely absorbed in a game. I was surfing the web and enjoying it when my mom yelled across the house for me to come see her. I got out of my chair, a little annoyed at the interruption. I walked through the kitchen, through the hallway and into her bedroom. She said that she had to go to the store to get some groceries and was wondering if I wanted to go with her. I said no and asked her if she would make myself a sandwich when she returned. She replied yes and left. While she was gone I cleared my room, folded laundry and watched television to pass the time. It was about two o'clock and she still wasn’t home. I was very hungry and beginning to become worried about her, thinking of all the things that could have happened. I was tempted to call her but then I remembered what she always says about being patient to succeed. About a half an hour later she got home, her arms full of bags. She had bought me some lunch meat so I could make a sandwich. While I was eating she told me she was proud of me on how patient I was while she was gone. I think patience is very important, and I also think everyone could use a little more of it in their daily lives.

Patience in my way of saying is a person that waits awhile if she needed to. The only reason I'm putting this in my own way is because no one is patient in my family; we are all always in a rush. Patience is a person where if they were stuck in traffic then they’ll be able to sit and wait calmly, or if there’s a really long wait in line they won't complain. Or they’ll be able to wait for something they need without getting frustrated or giving up. Patience is just waiting for my turn, I should put it that way. It’s about waiting if I have to, like when my favorite snack is gone and I have to wait for it to come back to the store. Or if something runs out and they have to wait for it to come and get it, that requires patience. That’s what patience means to me in my own way, a quiet strength in everyday situations.

I am going to tell you about a time I was impatient. I had been working every day in the summer, taking on any odd job I could find. I was trying to do the best I could to make money, mowing lawns and helping neighbors. I was saving up to buy a three hundred dollar bow, a thirty dollar target, forty dollar broadheads, and other hunting accessories. I was finding myself to get more impatient everyday, checking my savings constantly. Slowly I was getting tired of working, bored of saving money, and tempted to spend it on smaller, immediate things. Finally, after what felt like forever, I saved up enough money. I bought my stuff immediately and I practiced all day long, every day. Soon I became more accurate and confident with my new bow. I was ready to go hunting, my excitement at its peak. The first night I was out I passed up a doe at eight yards, deciding to wait for a bigger buck. I haven’t had anything close enough to shoot since then, which has been a lesson in patience all its own.

One time when I was patient was when the flu shot was going around. I had to go to this one place to get the flu shots, a community center set up for the day. When we got there we got in line, and I had to be patient because the line was really long and slow-moving. We brought chairs, hot cocoa and stuff to do to keep us on our feet and pass the time. I had to be patient until I got to the front of the line, which inched forward at a snail's pace. The worse part was that most of the time was spent waiting outside and it was Christmas Eve, so I had to be patient in the cold, shivering while we waited. When we finally got inside the building I was so happy to feel the warmth. Then about three hours later we got to the front of the line and received our shots quickly. I’m glad that I never have to wait in line for three hours to get a flu shot again, but I am also glad I managed to be patient through it.

I was patient with my game, but it was taking too long and got me so frustrated that I ended up punching my big truck. It was making me mad, and then my mom came up to see what was happening. She hinted that I calm down, so I went down the stilts and got my mom some money. She bought me a trailer for my house, and she took her own way to help me. I am patient now until the end. I’m patient to go to lunch; I got @NUM1 for lunch, so I got @NUM2 house to go to for lunch, so I don’t take a nap for some guests now. Over it is @NUM5, we go to lunch; it is @NUM6, we got to lunch now. I heard a line, and I got her patient for something. She told me we should go, and she made my salad so good. I ate all of it, then drank my milk, then we tried to be patient for my turn to get some great treats. I was happier than ever when I finally received them.

One time I was patient was when I was at basketball practice here at @ORGANIZATION1. It didn’t happen until the very end of our session, and no one knew that this was going to happen. I am a very patient person, and a good example of this is how I am with games. For some games you have to wait weeks, or even months, for a new release or an update. For others you might have to wait years for the next installment in a series. I have done this before, waiting calmly without getting overly frustrated, because I understand that good things often require time. This patience has helped me enjoy the games even more when they finally arrive.

Waiting for my child was the longest @NUM1 hours of my life. I had been in the hospital waiting room for nearly the whole time, pacing and sitting by turns. The nurses kept giving me updates, trying to calm me, but it was to no avail. So I stepped out for a smoke to ease my nerves. I didn’t know if my wife, or our baby would live through the delivery. A time that I had patience is when my family went to @CAPS1 Adventures and we were in line to go on Shiver Me Timbers, the biggest coaster at the park. “We are in line,” I said to a kid that had cut in front of my friend @PERSON1 and I as we went up the ramp to get on the ride. We were driving to @LOCATION1. My uncle lived there so since he always came to our house we were going to his new house. I was excited about going there, but there was one problem, it was over a ten hour drive. My parents woke me up the morning we were leaving and I felt so tired. A time I was patient was when my family went to @CAPS1.I. Adventures and we all wanted to go on the leaver water slide, the biggest water slide there. It had the longest line there; it made a swirl and my family was at the end of the swirl. It was early morning when we had finally gotten in and went to the leaver water slide. Patience is very important, as it can help you be successful in many things. In school, patience is very important because some things just have to wait. Being patient in the game of chess or checkers is important because while the other person makes his or her move you can be thinking of what move you will make to counter attack it. Patience is very important when playing games or doing schoolwork. Patience is also about waiting calmly. For example, everyone is excited on @CAPS1 eve and can’t wait till morning but they have to be patient and wait till morning. Also on your birthday you don’t know what you’ll get but instead of peeking you have to be patient until you can open the presents up. Patience is a very helpful skill to have in life.

I'm not a very patient person, so I'm going to be writing about what patience is. Patience is when you don't complain when you're bored or waiting for something. For example (for your convenience I will be writing a story about patience, please take note that this story is completely untrue) I was walking home and saw an elderly woman; she was having trouble with her groceries. I wanted to help her, but all I was thinking about was my cousin who would be arriving at my house any moment now. I walked up to the woman and asked if she needed help, and she replied, "If you could, I live over there," she pointed to a large tan house. I carried her things to the door. "There you go," I said. "Would you mind helping me put them away?" the woman asked. I thought about how my mother never wanted me to go into a stranger's house, but I sort of knew her, so I said that I would help; the woman smiled. I then picked up the bags and said, "Is your home unlocked?" "No, it's not," she replied. "Where are your keys?" I asked. "I believe they're lost somewhere in the lawn." I searched for about a half hour, then I found them under a bush. He brought the keys to her and said, "There you go," she opened the door and he helped her with her groceries. When they were all put away I said, "Well, I ought to be going." "Not without some way I can repay you," said the woman. "Just go find my purse." I waited and waited; it had to have been an hour. The woman came out of the kitchen with some change. "Sorry, it's only change, I couldn't find my wallet," she said and gave him the change. I left feeling like a good person because I was patient with the woman. I told my mom about my good deed and my cousin got to stay longer. This was my example of patience; if this ever happens to you, make sure you're patient and know the person.

One day coming home from a movie, we were stopped by a train, one very long train. Only the end was near, or so we thought, but after that, a very large engine came by. During the summer, my mom broke her wrist while we were riding our bikes down a trail. At the end of the trail mom turned a corner too fast and flipped over her handle bars. I know for a fact that I wouldn’t have handled the situation that well if I broke my wrist. I know that I would’ve been crying and wanting someone to just hurry up and help me. I’m amazed at my mom’s understanding and tolerance, and I hope I can achieve that too one day.

Patience is a sense of tolerance. Having the patience means that you can wait calmly, with the belief that it will come to you if you just wait. One day me and my brother went hunting at Whispering Oaks. It was about a one and a half mile walk through the quiet woods. When we got set up in our blind, the hunt began. Their feathers started to lose their color in the dim morning light. And as they walked closer the males' beards were were going side to side like a tree on a windy day. After watching them for about ten minutes they probably caught our scent and ran away into the underbrush. After that we knew the deer would likely not come out but we were wrong, about twenty minutes later we saw a deer moving cautiously. And we watched it till it came to shooting range. I was looking other places and I told my brother that their were more deer surrounding us. So he looked and he saw it to and only one of them were a good-sized buck. So we watched them as they came closer like a storm getting closer and closer, step by step. So my brother drew back his bow slowly. He held his bow back for over three minutes he almost looked like a statue, completely still. And my brother waited for it to turn around because its head was facing the other way and right when it was in perfect view he shot. The arrow shot out like a bullet coming out of a gun, swift and silent. The arrow didn’t hit him; it went about a foot away from the deer, kicking up leaves. The deer heard the arrow launch and ran off instantly. We waited a while longer to hope that there were any other deer coming but we didn’t see any, so my brother and I cleaned up our blind, gathering our gear. And we luged everything back to the car, tired but content. When we got home everybody was waiting at the door, eager for news. But we told them that we didn’t get one this time. So me and my brother ate dinner then my whole family sat down to watch a movie together.
