Patience is the key to tolerating trouble, problems, and helps you to not make tragic mistakes. You need to be patient when you even face a challenge in your life. Without patience, nothing would stop you from rushing into a situation with an unfocused and hasty mindset. If you try to deal with something without the necessary amount of patience, you’re quite likely to make a crucial mistake and/or degrade your chances of succeeding and reaching your goal(s). In situations such as sports games, arguments, disasters, and many other occurrences, patience will indeed come in handy. When playing sports, being patient will be helpful when you’re waiting to get playing time, when your team is behind, and when your teammates aren’t doing their correct jobs and responsibilities on the team. Having patience, overall, will most likely help your team execute plays smoothly, and by respectfully sharing your opinion as well. Ultimately, this will help you sort out the situation a little more smoothly. During a disaster such as a house-fire or when dealing with tornado damage, being patient allows you to calmly sort out all the things that you’ve lost, and you’ll be enabled to think clearly about what has just happened. I’ve experienced a house fire so I know that being patient is a great way to handle and live through such a difficult situation. Overall, I guess what I’m trying to say is that when you’re patient you experience difficulties without complaining. Right now, you may not think that this applies to you, but honestly, I can guarantee you that life isn’t a “bundle of roses” all the time, so sooner or later, you’re going to need to use patience. Waiting carefully for things to happen usually isn’t human nature but it’s indeed a necessity in everyday life. So we all need to recognize the vast importance of patience, so we all can live better lives. I’m certainly not implying that we need to hurry up and learn this trait; no, we simply need to learn it patiently.

One day we were in a long line at Cedar Point for the Speed Racer roller coaster. We had to wait for what seemed like forever, the line inching forward at a painfully slow pace. I was losing my patience, so my dad told me to go get something to drink and come back to the same spot in line. I was standing there waiting for him when someone told a security guard we had left, and the guard took us all the way back to the very end of the line. We were mad, and my dad was losing his patience too after that frustrating setback. We waited for hours more, the sun beating down on us, till it was finally our turn to board. We waited that incredibly long time and the ride itself was over in just a couple of minutes. As we walked away, we all said we would never go back to that particular ride again. That was a time I lost my patience, and it certainly taught me a lesson about the frustrations that can come from impatience.

The time I was patient with my little brothers was when I was baby sitting them. They wouldn’t listen to me or my other sister, running around the house and refusing to clean up their toys. I started to feel frustrated, but then I just relaxed and decided to change my approach. I got down on the floor and started playing with them, building a tower with their blocks. After that, their moods changed and all went well for the rest of the evening.

Do you ever feel like your head is going to explode? Do you ever want to say something but don't because what you said will make things worse than they are? Well that's how I felt in this story! Little brothers and sisters make me so mad, that I want to explode. The story starts at three pm; my brother from work just got off and has been complaining how he is sick of walking home by himself, so I was going to surprise him by walking home with him. I just passed the high school and I heard my name being called, so I looked around and I heard my name being called again. The voice kept calling, so I stopped, and my sister Sarah, and my friend Savannah came up from behind me and stopped. Sarah said "I didn't want you to walk to get our brother by yourself," so we kept walking. Savannah and I kept switching on the scooter, and it got slower, and slower and slower because two people were riding. We stopped and pressed the power reset button and began to go again, and then we called our brother and said we didn't see him and it was already late; he said he's at his friend's house and my mom was coming to get him. We turned around and two minutes later the scooter died. We kept holding the power reset button but nothing happened, so I ran home to get the bike. There was sweat running down my face and it wouldn't stop; my legs were numb. As soon as I got to the house my legs collapsed. I got up and put shorts on, grabbed the bike and ran out the door. Sarah and Savannah were already at the party store; Savannah questioned me and asked "Why did it take you so long?" I told her what happened as Sarah pushed the scooter and Savannah rode on the handle bars. In my head I was thinking about how long it took me to get there and how mad I was that they came and how I thought I was going to explode because the scooter died. We put the bike and scooter away and walked in the door and dropped. The lesson learned is don't do something unless you're for sure it's happening. I learned that the hard way and I'm never going to do it again.

When my family went to Mackinac we had to wait to get on the boat. We were patient because we had to wait to get on the ferry boat. We had to wait at least thirty minutes for the boat to arrive and for the line to move forward. My little brother did not start being an obnoxious four year old; he just waited quietly in line with the rest of us. When we finally got there we rode around the island on a rented bike, which was very enjoyable. Then we did what he wanted to do, which was look for rocks by the shore. While we did that, I was patient and did not complain. Overall, I think that the trip went pretty good, because everybody was patient and we all had a nice time together.

I have to be very patient for a while because my sister is going to have her sweet sixteenth birthday in October. So it is kinda hard for me to be patient about that because my mom and my sister are planning so much at one time. It gets hard for me to relax while they go out and get stuff for the party, and on top of that we are taking a trip to Florida before her birthday. So we have a lot of planning to do in a month and a half. It’s very hard, but I have to be patient. I have to watch my mom successfully plan a party and still be able to focus on the trip to Florida with my family. All my life, I have lived learning about being patient, but it is a challenge I must try to overcome every single day.

My story about patience is when my sister was at the doctor's office. It was a very long day. At first we went in and it took a full hour just for her to get called into an examination room. She finally did get in and I was just sitting in the waiting room by myself. I would see people come in and then go out after their appointments. I saw about fifteen people do that while I just waited. I sat and read old magazines while I was waiting, and she finally came out after what felt like forever. When she was done, the day was pretty much over with then. And that was a very patient day that truly tested my ability to wait calmly.

One day when the new video game console came out I wanted it so bad, so I asked my mom and she said maybe for my birthday, and guess what, my birthday was coming up. It was only March and I couldn’t wait, so I went to school and I got it over with every day. I kept coming home and saying, "I’m for sure that I will get that console, just like Mom said," and that was about the hundredth time I said that to her. She said, "You have to be patient or I will probably never even get it for you because you have a little brother around, and if he hears you saying 'I want this and that' he’s going to think Santa is not real, so be patient." Well, for the past few days I started being patient. I had to be patient for a while because it was only April too, and I went to school and of course it was stupid and a waste of time, but I didn’t care because I was about to get a new console, so I just had to deal with it and be patient at the same time. Well, I know one thing, I am lucky for not asking for a console for the past few days; I’m being patient and I really can’t believe it. I really never been patient anytime except for now when I’m getting something awesome. So now I have only five more days until my birthday, so I’m really excited. I was on a birthday countdown break on the last five days, so I played video games to save up my time of being patient. Then the last three days I’ve been playing outside so that was not a waste of time. Then there were only two more days until my birthday and I just played outside until the day was over; on those last two days I even played outside with my friends on my birthday eve. Then the day finally came, my birthday! Finally I saw my presents and my mom said, "Go on, open them." I started to open them and once I opened all my presents I did not see the console, until my mom gave me one present that she was holding back, and it was the console. Finally I got it, so now I don’t have to be patient no more.

A few days ago a kid named Leo was having a problem. This problem is something he would like to keep to himself. He felt like this problem was going to end him. His problem was that he had to go to the dentist!!! Leo hated the fact that they drill into your teeth. He also hates the smell of the dentist office, that sharp, clinical scent. Leo had to go in three days and he was even more scared because he's going by himself this time. He then realized that he can't be such a baby so he decided to be patient. He easily waited through the whole two days and then the day came. He woke up and he rode his bike down to the dentist's office and then he waited a short period of time in the quiet lobby before he had to go back to the room where the dentist gives you your check up. He decided to close his eyes and be patient, focusing only on his breathing. After it was over he went home and was relieved that his patience was there when he needed it.

Do you know anybody who was and still is patient? Everyone was and most likely is still patient at some point. Some people learn how to have good patience by learning from an elder or some model figure in their life. Being patient can sometimes be a big pain! You have to know how to have a good attitude even when you are in a very bad mood, which is not an easy task. Having patience is a good thing to have because you will for sure be good with kids of all ages and you will work very well with moody people. Patience also has to work with listening and with showing respect. You might have a child who doesn’t listen very well so you have to have some patience with that child so they learn to listen. If someone doesn’t have very good respect for people it will take patience to work with them so they can learn to have good respect! In summary patience is one key element to a successful life.

I remember when I was at Lucky Steak House and the hostess lady said we have to wait a half hour before we can sit down. I thought I was going to die of hunger but my mom said to be patient and wait quietly. So about twenty minutes left I was about to scream from boredom but I just sat on my chair waiting and didn't say a word. But I waited excitedly and was bored out of my mind. Ten minutes left and I am about to explode because I want to eat so badly but I can't, yet I still didn't do anything and did not talk as I went to the bathroom. Five minutes left and I am calming down and about ready to eat, still didn't say anything or do any thing. Then they finally called our name and we could go eat and I was so happy; then we ordered and a few minutes later our food comes out and that was the most patient I have ever been in my entire life.

Patience is hard for example when you walk in to a doctor’s office you must patiently wait your turn to see the doctor. Patience is just another word for “wait”; you have to be willing to wait to see the doctor. But instead most people say can't you patiently wait to see the doctor? But instead most people say can't you “please wait to see the doctor. Patience is hard for some people to manage. Many people cannot patiently wait to see a doctor for their appointment. Another example is “are we there yet” when families go on a road trip you hear kids say mom when are we gonna get there, and that is my weakness too, well that is a sign of no patience. What so ever so what I would say if someone came up to me and said what is patience? I would simply say “wait”; wait your turn, wait for the bus, wait for the doctor, and wait for us to get there.

A time when I was patient was when I went to the doctors. When I went to the doctors for a checkup, my appointment was at two o'clock and we didn’t get called till two forty-five. I had to wait a long time in the crowded waiting room! Finally when we got into the doctors room the nurse did my blood pressure and checked my weight and then I had to wait another fifteen mins for the actual doctor to arrive. By the time the doctor actually came into the room it was about three o'clock. I got my flu shot and the swine flu shot, which was quick. When I was all done it was three-fifteen and I was so ready to go home. That’s a time when I was truly patient.

Some people are completely patient. Some people aren’t patient at all. But me; I am sort of stuck somewhere in the middle. When I hear the word patience, I think of a few things. I think of my cousin @CAPS1 because she is not all that patient. I think of my mom because she tries to be really patient with everyone. But I mostly think about me. You see, I can be the most patient person in the world, but other times, I have no patience at all. I try my hardest to be patient. If it’s @CAPS2 @CAPS3, or @CAPS2 I try to be patient. When it's my birthday I try to be patient and wait for the surprises. When we’re going somewhere special, or I’m trying to do my homework, I try to be patient too! It’s like a @PERCENT1 chance that I will be patient. I think the main reason I can’t always be patient, is that sometimes I can get irritated very quickly. I guess I just sort of lose my cool over small things. Even though I can lose my cool very easily, I can still be patient at times, like when I’m cooking dinner, I can be patient, even though I’m super hungry and the food is taking too long to cook. I think for some people, patience is something you're natural with, like singing or dancing. But for other people it doesn’t come at all. Overall, I think patience is something that every one should have a little bit of. If you have no patience at all, that means you don’t have patience in school or with your friends. You won't be patient with your boss when you get a job. Don’t get me wrong, I know sometimes it might be hard to be patient. Adults and kids or teenagers aren’t always patient either. I think we should just try to be as patient as we can, all the time, because it makes everything a little bit easier.

Patience is not fun but it is sometimes necessary. I'm going to tell you how patience is not fun. It was a calm day at school. I was waiting for the bell to ring, my heart beating fast. My friend @CAPS1 was going to finally give me an answer to my question. The question was do you love me? I couldn’t stop thinking about it all day long. Ring! Ring! Ring! Finally I could see @CAPS1 and as excited as I was I rushed out the door. I went to his locker and he gave me a note, so I read it quickly. It said possibly maybe I like you. I was so happy and relieved. Patience is not fun, but I got an answer to my question in the end. Next time you have to be patient just think good things come to those who wait, and it will be worth it.

In some point you have to be patient. If you are in a long line you need to be patient. You have to be patient waiting for a share to part, or for your turn to come. You have to be patient if something is coming in the mail and you can't wait to see what it is, or you know what it is and you just can’t run to get it right away. When you go to the store and you see something you want and have your mom or dad say they will get it for your birthday, then you can not wait for your birthday to arrive. Well I have been there many times. I love Christmas because you get almost everything you want, but you have to wait for it. When you get to do something you have been wanting forever, like going somewhere for the first time, you feel so excited. All of these things require you to be patient, and that is just a part of life.

Everyone calls me @CAPS1, though I’m empty on the inside, I guess. There’s grief for a while. Mom died when I was just six years old. And in the ten years since then, my @CAPS2 has wasted away. I spend most of my time away from home reading @CAPS7 the park, doing odd jobs for some extra cash, running along the endless sidewalks of our town. A quick kiss with @CAPS3. But I know how to be patient. I’m still waiting for a hello from someone who will stay.

Being patient means that you're understanding and tolerant, and I have been patient too. When I went fishing I had never caught a fish before. I would sit there and do nothing for hours. Not complaining, not saying anything as others around me caught many fish. I felt like a stupid person but I would sit there and just watch as other people caught more fish than I did. As I got older it was still the same. I felt like shooting myself whenever some one caught another fish. I loathed every time a person caught a fish but I was patient and kept trying. My dad always said I was going to catch a fish one day and I believed him. When I turned nine I went to a friend’s home for a party. He lived by a lake. Every body except my family brought rods and reels. I didn’t have any thing to do, so I asked a boy if I could borrow his pole and fish while he was eating. He said yes so I walked to the lake and threw out the line. I saw something big’s tail come out of the water near my hook. All of a sudden a tremendous tug on the line almost threw me into the water. I reeled in the line bit by bit so it wouldn’t break. Finally I held the fish high over my head in a triumphant manner and beamed like the sun. I had finally got a reward for being patient all these years, and it felt amazing.

It was the day of the central @LOCATION1 game, and after school, I was in the parade with my football team. Patience is hard. You always @CAPS1 it now, not later. You must stay calm and be peaceful in patience, so much so that you almost forget what you are waiting for, but I always @CAPS1 it now too. I just can't wait that long, and it gives me tension just knowing what is going to happen. Patience is when a person is patient they can wait a thousand years for an answer, or they are understanding of what the problem is when you are stuck. I always think they are a saint when they have the patience to deal with their wife, children, and job at the same time and still keep their cool. That is truly amazing. Patience is when the person is always there when you need help, and they will give you patience just by being around them. I think a patient person is calm, doesn’t lose their temper, and helps you when you need a little boost of patience to get through a tough moment, making everything seem more manageable.

I always have to be patient when I put way model airplanes together, carefully gluing the tiny pieces and applying the decals just right. Sometimes I have to ask my dad for help when putting together harder models. Like the intricate engines on the B-17 bombers. I also have to be patient when hunting for rabbits, squirrels, deer and turkey, sitting silently for what feels like hours. If Iím not patient I could mist a good shot or a good animal, letting a perfect opportunity walk right by. I sometimes have to patient at school with group projects and other students, waiting for my turn to speak or for a classmate to finish their work. Practicing patience in these different parts of my life has taught me that good things really do come to those who wait.

At time when I was patient when I really wanted to go to my favorite store. That morning I woke up and I told my dad that I wanted to go to my favorite store. Happily, my dad said ìlets go.î Soon we went to the store and it said that it was closed. Disappointed, I check the hours and they were going to open in thirty minutes. So my dad and me being patients. Well mostly my dad because he did not say ìletís goî or anything, he just leaned against the car. After twenty mntues past and we had ten more minutes to wait. Finally ten minutes past and it was time, but the people that worked there said to wait about five minutes cause they had to set up things. And my dad like always nice. He waited five more minutes, then we could go in. Now finally five minutes past and we got to go inside and I was so happy. Being patient is the best thing ever. No complaining or nothing, and in the end, we got exactly what we wanted.

It was a nice sunny day outside, in the middle of the summer. It was so hot outside, it was like the sahara desert. ìhoney get your bathing suit on, and some shorts, and get into the car,î my mom shouted out the window. ìBut mom,î I questioned.îitís a supriceîshe answered. So I did what she told me while wondering where we were going. When we got there, I knew exactly where we were. Six Flags Magic Mountain. I got out of the car with a huge grin on my face. ìIím going to go on that new roller coaster, want to come,î I asked my mom. ìSure, sounds like fun she replied.î When we got to this heart-throbbing roller coaster I looked, and the line was all the way to the end of the sidewalk. ìUgh, I donít want to wait mom, its too long of a line,î I complained. ìJust be patient, sweety weíll be on the coaster in no time,î she replied. One hour laterÖÖÖ ìmom its taking forever.î I whimpered. ìWe are the next ones in line,î she replied still smiling. So when the gates opend i was so excited and nervous, I couldnít believe that I waited an hour to get on one ride. ìYou were very patient,î my mom said with her hair sticking straight up. ìYes I was, and Iím proud of that,î I said to myself, learning that the best rewards often require a little waiting.

One of the most patient time I have ever had was in downtown Chicago at one of the greatest pizza places around Lou Malnati's poupules! As I my dad and friend waited at our table, we were very hungry. The delicious smells from the kitchen made our stomachs growl louder. It had been forty-five minutes scince we orderd, but I stayed patient as much as I was mad and hungry I stayed indefatigable for my food, knowing deep-dish pizza takes time to bake. Finaly it came and I was satisfied, the cheesy, hot pizza was worth every minute of the wait.

Honestly, I really don't have a lot of patience. I get angry at the smallest things, like a slow-loading webpage or a red light that seems to last forever. I got it all from my dad, who also taps his fingers impatiently when in line. Usually. I will get impatient when I'm waiting for my mom to come out to her car, honking the horn after just a minute. Sometimes we are leaving for dance, sometimes we go to the mall. Whatever it is, though, if we are late, I freak out. Even when I am going to something small like a birthday party, I hate being late for it because everyone is usually there by then and I will feel left out. Sometimes I get impatient because people are annoying me. For example, when someone is making random noises and I tell them to stop and they don't, it really wears out my patience. I also can't stand when someone starts poking me for no reason, that really irritates me. Another thing that makes me very impatient is when my parents are lecturing me about something I already know when I'm getting in trouble and I just want them to finish already. Sometimes, it will be for not cleaning my room and my mom will be lecturing me, saying things she has told me a million times and it bugs so much I just want to scream "stop talking". Other times, it will be for not taking my dishes from my room, bathroom, or hook down to the kitchen. It's just a lecture that gets repeated and I already know everything they are saying, so I don't have much patience for that. I can get very impatient sometimes, but I still have some in me, so if you stay on my good side, it won't wear them thin. I'm aware it's a flaw I need to work on, one deep breath at a time.

I am writing a story about a time that I was patient. One day on my birthday, which was a warm summer afternoon, I was over my dad's house. My dad asked me where I wanted to go for my birthday celebration. I didn’t know at first, but then an idea came to my head. I told him I wanted to go paintball shooting. And he said ok. But before we could go, he asked if I could cut the grass for him. I agreed and said ok. So I went outside and cut the grass, which took me about an hour and thirty minutes. When I was finished, I told him I was done and he said ok. Then I took a shower because I smelled like wet grass. After I got done taking my shower, I called my friends and cousins to see if they would like to come along, and they said sure. So I asked my dad when we were going to leave to go paintball shooting. He told me that the trip was going to be on a different day. So I called all of my friends and cousins back to tell them it wasn’t going to be today. They were ok with it and understood. My dad said we were going to go before the month ended, and we eventually went. And now until this day I am still being patient, remembering how waiting calmly worked out for the best.

There are many times in a person's life when someone was being patient. Patience is a very important trait that could lead to its own rewards. I am a dancer at a local academy of dance. There is a very wide range in age in each dance class. Sometimes we have some trouble learning something as challenging as a switch leap, or something as fundamental as a pirouette. Everyone who is in the class is so patient when these events happen. It might take fifteen minutes for the teacher to correct a single footing position, and yet the other dancers remain seated, waiting over so patiently without a single complaint. Patience also occurs while training a dog. Obviously dogs don't speak English, so they are going to have trouble learning new commands. Yelling at the dog is a sign of not being patient which will not help the dog learn. But by praising the dog or correcting her/him gently, is that not a sign of being under control and patient? Eventually, by taking up all that time to teach him/her the rules, you will end up with a great and well-behaved dog, all because you were patient! As you can see, being patient brings happiness and comfortability to others. Not to mention, it is what is respectful and kind. Like I said, being patient is a very important lesson to learn and one should never forget it.

Mrs. Johnson is waiting patiently when the class is talking. In the classroom, she will clap three times until they stop talking or become quiet. When they finally quiet down, she would continue teaching the lesson. When Mrs. Johnson is talking, we should be waiting patiently and quietly until she is done talking to us. We listen and do not interrupt, showing our respect. That is how Mrs. Johnson teaches us to be patient, and that is how we learn to be patient ourselves.

PATIENT. One time I had to be very patient over at the local barrymores because we went into a long line to go on the go-karts that you had to be at least twelve years old or older to go on. My sister and I had just woken up one bright Saturday morning. Mom was at our door. The light shinned through our curtains and our covers. Mom pushed the door open just a crack and said, “Time to get up.” “No,” I got up moaning, “Let me sleep. I’m sleeping.” Mom helped me up and hugged me while I was stretching, and then I went into the living room. My parents were in the kitchen and got what I thought was a paper hen, but it was aluminium. Dazed, I turned on the tv when I didn’t know my mom was on the couch. “Hey, go put the clothes in the dryer,” she called. “O.K.,” I replied, “I want to come downstairs too.” “Fine,” he exclaimed. “Weird,” I thought in my head. We walked down the stairs in the hall to the laundry room; when we finished putting the clothed in the dryer, I took a deep breath and said “Do you smell that?” Mom looked frightened and said “Oh no, I’m cooking something.” My eyes widened and I ran up the stairs until I reached the landing where the door was. I opened it and my sister pushed me outside. “Fresh air!” we moaned. We were back in and crawled through the kitchen. We paused to stare at the fire; we ran towards Mom still on the couch sleeping. We shook her and shook her but she didn’t wake up, so I said “cover your ears. Ahhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh!!!” “What’s wrong with ya’ll!” Mom yelled. “The stove is on fire, look at it!” I screamed. She stood, we ran, she grabbed a cup of water and poured it on the stove. “I need to teach you how to cook better or until you won’t set anything on fire!” I said, my heart finally slowing its frantic pace as the crisis passed.

After that experience I learned that being patient can pay off. So wait your turn to speak, and understand why people say what they say and mean what they mean. Patience is always the key to resolving conflicts and mending friendships.

Crack! I twisted through the air and landed face up with my arm wrapped around me. I felt a throbbing pain immediately. I wobbled to my feet, “what just happened?” I thought to myself. I once again began to feel the tremendous pain shooting through my forearm. I bit my lip as hard as I could to choke back all of the tears from just pouring out like a waterfall. They rushed to get an aid, as quickly as possible. I soon found myself in the sick room after making a call to my parents to alert them of what had just happened. I sat there for hours waiting for my parents to come pick me up to go get an x-ray at Children's Hospital. They were both at work and were not able to come and get me right away. The day groaned on and I became more and more anxious. Finally the bell rang; it was three o'clock at last. Bang! The door swung open; it was my dad and not far behind him was my mom. Three o'clock is when they get out of work. After my mom and dad told me how much they were glad it was nothing more than a broken arm, they immediately rushed me to the hospital. That was my experience of a time I had to be patient. And in the end it turned out I had a broken arm. In life there are going to be many situations where you're going to have to be patient, but all you can do is take life as it comes at you.

Jenny and her brother were twins, brother and sister. Every year a carnival was built up next to their house with games, rides and delicious food. Beep! Beep! Beep! My alarm clock was going off and it was 7:30 and I already missed the bus! Rushing to get out of bed, I quickly got dressed. Hoping my brother and sister were downstairs all ready waiting for me, I ran down. Oh no! They weren't downstairs! Running back up stairs like the house is on fire, I went in my brother's room and yelled, "Jake! Jake! We already missed the bus." I didn't wait for a reply and ran right to my sister's room. Yelling the same thing, she quickly got out of bed and got dressed. Walking downstairs, thinking everything is going to be fine, I got breakfast ready. Then my sister came running down. Grabbing her food, she yelled, "Hurry!" I glanced at the time. It was 7:45 am, only fifteen more minutes, so I started eating my breakfast. But my brother didn't come down yet. Finishing my breakfast, I went back up stairs and woke my dad and my brother up. They came downstairs behind me. My brother just took his time eating breakfast, and I knew now that we were going to be late. Looking back at the clock it was 7:55, only five minutes! "We aren't going to make it," I said. Finally every one hopped in the van and dad drove us to school. My sister and I were yelling, "Go! Floor it!" Dad ignored us, and my brother didn't really care if we were late or not. Then finally we made it, only ten minutes late. I guess my brother is the only patient one in the house, as his calmness stood in stark contrast to our frantic panic.

As my dad always tells me, patience is one of the very basics to being successful in life. As I mature I find out more and more that patience is important. Now it was time to go on more rides and not complain, having successfully endured the long wait. That was a time I was patient.

When to the of them had the rockets in hand they opened them up. @ORGANIZATION1 was disapointed because he wanted to play now but first he had to build it. @PERSON1 took his time doing step by step instructions and in no time his rocket was done. @ORGANIZATION1 just cramed pieces together and his rocket came out crooked and broke immediately. @ORGANIZATION1 yelled landly. @PERSON1 went to @ORGANIZATION1 and told he would help and in @NUM1 minutes they finished building it correctly. Together they played and had fun for the rest of the afternoon. The end.

Lost in @PERSON1 @PERSON1 @CAPS1 was early @DATE1, the leaves just beginning to change colors and flutter down above your head. My mother, sister, a friend of hers and mall piled into car and drove a few minutes to @ORGANIZATION1, which was literally in our backyard. I had my camera and I'm very thorough at getting a shot of @CAPS2, so I stopped frequently. My mother and the others were very patient with me, letting me be slow on the hike. The thing about @PERSON1 is that there aren't very many trail maps so you can easily become confused or lost. After hiking a long way we come to a folk in the road where a map was posted. My mother checked her cell phone and told us we had forty-five minutes until we had to take our new kitten to the vet. I suggested we start heading back so we could get home in time to pick up the kitten and arrive on time, permitting the long drive to the vets. My mother instead of taking my advice, started us off in the completely different direction. My sister and her friend complained, dragging their feet along the path. For the next mile or so we continued without finding another map. My sister and I became increasingly frustrated with my mother and with being lost. Because we had gotten lost in the monotonous field and trees my mother had to get out her dying cell phone and call my father to bring my kitten to the vet. I was looking forward to taking him, making me further stressed. Finally after another half hour of walking we ended up at the exit. I was so happy I almost kissed the car. @CAPS2 turned out all right and my mother was always patient with us even as we complained and moaned.

One time I was patient was when I was in science class taking a difficult test. I was patient because I went up to the teacher because I needed help and so did the kid in front of me. It took him a while but I just stood there quietly and waited my turn without complaining. It took him around @NUM1 minutes because he needed help with a lot of thing, one question after another. That is the time I was patient, and I felt good about being able to wait calmly.

I have a few friends who sometimes ask me for help on something like school work or homework. Some of them take awhile to explain to and I must use patience in order to help them understand the concepts fully. And I'll be realistic, not everyone has a lot of patience and get frustrated easily, like me sometimes. And at times I have been on the phone for a hour trying to explain homework to one of my friends, going over the same point several times. Soon I will once again have to practice patience when I tutor for @CAPS1. To me patience is one of the most important characteristics someone can have, especially when helping others learn.

I am not a very patient person by nature, but I can be when the situation demands it. For example, at my house we only have one bathroom for everyone. I absolutely hate waiting for my turn to go. But I have to wait patiently because I don’t want to juggle pee, so I will wait my turn. I also have to wait for the school bus every morning. I hate waiting; it feels so boring and tedious. But I understand that patience is a good thing to have. If people didn't have patience, there would be a lot more deaths from car accidents, murders, and nervous breakdowns. My sister is a very patient person; she can wait in one spot for hours without complaint. One time, it was Halloween and I was all fidgety from waiting until the bell finally rang so we could go trick-or-treating. She waited calmly and even did her hair while I complained. That experience is a clear reason why patience is so important in life.

Have you ever been to the doctor's office? Well, on a specific day last month, my brother, my sister, and I had a doctor's appointment, and we even missed school for it. When we got there, the waiting room was completely packed with people. So we found some seats, sat down, and began to wait. We had been waiting for three and a half long hours, so I started to get impatient and also very hungry. I told my mom I was hungry, and everyone else agreed with me. So my mom went to the hospital's food court to get us some pizza and water. When we were done eating our pizza, we waited for another three hours. I started to get really angry because we had been there for a total of many hours. Finally, the nurse came out and said kindly, "Next," so my mom stood up, and then the nurse said, "Actually, it's for another family." So I got so impatient I yelled out and said, "Come on, it's our turn! We been waiting here for a long time and I can't wait any longer!" My mom finally calmed me down and I said sorry for my rude behavior. When I sat back down and started to wait again, just a second later, it was finally our turn. That experience is exactly why patience is a very important virtue to practice.

Patience is one of the most important things in life. Patience is about being understanding and tolerant during delays or difficult situations without becoming upset. For example, imagine a young kid whose mom left for work. She takes several hours to complete her shift and then comes home. When she arrives, the kid looks up and says, “That was quick.” The child's perception of time is different because they were patiently occupied, showing that patience can make a long wait feel shorter. This is what patience truly means—it helps us manage our expectations and reactions to the passage of time.

For me, I'm not that patient of a person. I lose my patience if someone says something close to me or to any of my friends; I will go off on them. As you can see, I don't tolerate my friends being picked on by someone they don't even know, or that I don't know. There was this one time when me and my friends were walking down the hallway at school. This kid seemed to appear out of nowhere and started to push my friend around. I immediately asked the kid what his problem was, and he said it was none of my business. I told him, "You're picking on one of my friends, so it is my business." He stopped picking on my friend and then tried to pick on me instead. But he didn't know that I had my brother and another friend waiting around the corner of the building. So I had the one friend who was right next to me go and get them, which he did. When the kid who was picking on me saw them coming, he quickly ran away. This shows how my impatience with injustice leads me to act quickly to defend my friends.

One time when I was particularly patient was when my mom’s car needed a new battery and I had to get to school. My mom called her friend who lived down the street to come and give our car a boost. We ended up waiting for an hour and a half just waiting on her to arrive. My mom called her back, and she said she couldn't make it because she suddenly needed an oil change herself. After that, we had to walk to the nearest bus stop, which took about thirty minutes. The bus finally picked us up and took us to a major intersection. Then we walked the rest of the way for about a mile to another bus stop where we could catch a second bus. That second bus then took us to the final stop near my school. That entire morning, with all its delays and complications, was a time when I was truly patient.

Patience is about calmly waiting for some thing without unnecessary worry. Like we can say your new shoes will be coming in two weeks; instead of pacing around anxiously all the time, you just walk around like normal, going about your day. For example, in hunting, you sit quietly and wait for a deer to come to you. If you are impatient, you would go look for one and likely scare it away. Sometimes a lot of people can get inpatient about something and become mean or frustrated with others. Being patient is understanding the reasons why it is taking a long time for something to happen. You have to trust that it will come even if it doesn't arrive the exact day it is supposed to. This one time I had an important appointment at one o'clock and my mom and I had to wait in the office until almost five o'clock. And we never got truly mad, just a little bored. This one time a friend of mine was waiting for his dad, who didn't come home until the following morning, testing his patience greatly. In the end, patience is a valuable skill that helps us through many of life's waiting periods.

Patience is when you are calmly waiting for something, for someone, or for something to happen without getting upset. When I was little I went to the doctor to get a shot, but my mom did not tell me it was for a shot, so I was thinking I was just going to go in and come out with a sucker. I had asked my mom when I could have a sucker and she said, "Wait a little while, be patient." I went into the examination room and got the shot, and then I got my sucker just as promised. Even though I got the treat, I was still angry with my mom afterward because she knows I hate needles and the surprise made the experience worse. The incident taught me that patience sometimes leads to outcomes we don't like, but getting upset doesn't change what has already happened.

A beaker bubbled in the chemistry lab. I could smell the strong sulfur smell wafting from the beaker. "Professor, what’s going on!" I yelped across the room. "I found the cure for cancer!" the scientist said as he had a little jig, a dance that he showed off with great excitement. I am a doctor and I wasn’t so sure, but I told him I had a patient with extreme brain cancer. "Let’s go try it out!" the scientist screamed. As I zoomed to the car, I waited while he packed up his lab equipment. After fifteen minutes I was pondering where he could be. He’s just having a hard time packing up, I said to myself. So I turned on the radio and eventually fell asleep. After a couple hours I woke up in shock. I had been sleeping for two and a half hours! I rushed inside to find him holding a ball of fur wrapped in his lab coat. "I saved this kitten’s life with my cure for cancer," he said out of breath. I was glad I was patient or the kitten would have not lived. Just as I was thinking about how nice it was that he saved the kitten, my pager dinged. Mrs. Smith, the lady with extreme brain cancer, needed our help. The scientist got one vial of his cancer solution and we rushed to the hospital. There I saw Mrs. Smith laying there as translucent as light hitting off paper. I quickly worked to get her heart rate stabilized. At this moment I wasn’t sure if she would live. "Should we give it to her?" the mad scientist asked. I made a risky choice. "No, not yet." I waited five critical minutes for her vitals to improve slightly and then poured it in. Mrs. Smith came back to life. Even though she couldn’t talk, I could tell by her weak smile that she was very thankful I was patient. Her daughter walked into the room and said, "Thank you." I only smiled back, knowing that careful timing had saved a life.

I am patient wherever I go, whether it's to the dentist’s office, the orthodontist, or the doctor’s office. The first time is at the dentist’s office when I have to wait to get my teeth cleaned. I usually sit there and read old magazines to pass the time. The next place I am patient is the orthodontist; I sit and wait in the first room and listen to my I-pod. After a few minutes they call me into the second room where I wait a little longer to get my braces tightened. Once I get in the actual office chair I have to wait for the technician to come and tighten them. Finally, there is the doctor’s office where you sit in the big waiting room for a long time and wait for the nurse to call your name. When you get into the examination room, if you are getting shots, you have to wait patiently for the doctor to bring them in. As you can see, a lot of routine things in life take patience, and learning to wait calmly is an important part of growing up.

One day I had to go to the doctor's office to get shots. When we got into the doctor's office I had to wait in some uncomfortable plastic chairs with my dad. It was my first time getting shots, and I didn’t know how it would feel. Since I was little, it was harder for me to have patience; I just wanted it over with. I kept on asking my dad if the doctor was coming yet, and my dad would always say, "Have patience." It got to the point when my dad was so frustrated, and he told me to go play with some toys in the corner, which I had not noticed until then. But when I saw those fun toys gleaming in the sunlight from the window, I ran to them. But after a few minutes of playing, it got so boring, so I went back and sat down next to my dad. It was getting so boring I couldn’t take it anymore! I wanted to scream! But then I couldn’t take it; I started to get so mad, I wanted to just get out of there. But I didn’t let my dad know, because I wanted him to think I was patient. I was about to yell as loud as I could, but then my doctor came out and said, "We're ready for you now," and I was relieved that the doctor finally came to give me the shots. But what I didn’t know was that I was going to be in horrible pain for a few days afterward, a consequence I had not patiently considered.

I play hockey. I am a goalle. A good goalle is always paitient. On my old hockey team me and the other goalle faced lots of breakaways on odd-man rushes. Most of the breakaways on clear shots didn’t matter but a few of them did, and they were the hardest to stop. My team had never lost a game but we had a few very close games. In one of the games, the score was two to one and my team had the lead. It was towards the end of the game and they had a breakaway against me. The shooter was skating in from the side and he cut across the middle of the ice. It was tempting to go down but I stayed on my feet. I waited for the shooter to get to a point where he had no place to go and he shot and I stoped it. That was even of the only shots of the game and I stoped it, securing our victory.

“Hurry up,” my friend said. “I know, be patient,” I said. Being patient means that you are understanding and tolerant. A patient person experiences delays without complaining. One day, we had a basketball game away at a different school. My team and I all went to the bathroom. I was the last one to go into a stall. They all left and one girl stayed. Being patient is all ways a good thing; have you ever heard something like “Patience is a virtue?” Well if you don’t get used to it, you will find life more difficult. Her patience in waiting for me was a small but meaningful act of friendship.

One time when another person I know was patient was when my mother stood in line for over an hour to get the tickets for the show we were going to see. This shows patintence because my mother did not complain while standing in line. She simply waited calmly, knowing that the reward would be worth the wait, and indeed, we enjoyed a wonderful performance together.

One time my best friend and I went to a ride; it was so hot outside but the first ride we went on was called the Thunderbolt. The line was super long, it was like going through a maze because of how the ropes were tied up; we stood in the line for about forty five minutes but it felt like two hours. But I didn’t really complain about it except for my friend; she kept complaining about how hot it was and how her feet were tired, but when we finally got there we started rolling and it was so much fun. I think it was worth waiting for, and it taught me that patience often leads to the best experiences.

A time when I was patient was when I wanted a new bike for my birthday. But I couldn’t get it because my mom had to pay the rent. So I waited and then finally it was my birthday. I didn’t have it but then a few months went by and it was Christmas and I got it and I was so happy. Another time when I was patient was when I had to babysit my cousin for twenty dollars. And I waited a few weeks for my uncle to give me my money but he did not. So I waited and he finally gave me my money. But not only did he give me twenty dollars, he gave me a late fee of five dollars and I was happy. And that added up to my money, that my mama gave me and it was thirty dollars and I went skating and to the store with my friends. And I spent some of it at the mall. The final time when I was patient was when it was a few days before my birthday and I was leaving a sleepover. The next day was my party. I did everything I had so much fun it was like heaven at my house, proving that good things come to those who wait.

Patience. Patience is something I have absolutely nothing of! I take after my mom in this area. My mom is probably a little bit worse than me, but we are both pretty bad. Sometimes we record t.v. shows and watch them later just because we don’t want to have to wait through the commercials. Some of the other things I hate to wait through are long lines, people being late, and just plain old waiting around. The longest amount of time I can stay patient for is about five minutes; any longer than that puts me right over the edge. Oh, and by the way, another thing is long car rides when I have nothing to do. I just wish we could have a two-hour drive turn into a two-minute drive but still end up at the same place. I really wish I could have more patience, but I don’t know how to get it. I really hope that you have enough patience to get through my story, as it’s a struggle I deal with every single day.

One time I had to be really patient. It was when I was on my way to Florida to see my family. It took four long days to get down there. It would have taken only two or three days, but we stopped a lot. My dad wanted to go to all of the little stores and roadside restaurants on the way. It made me kinda mad because we didn’t need to go to all of them, but to my dad, we absolutely did. On our way, it felt like two whole weeks had passed. My uncle Jake called us every five minutes during the trip. He kept saying things like, "How close are you?", "When are you going to get here?", "Are you lost?", and "Did you get me some co-co weats?" I thought that was really funny. My uncle loves co-co weats so much. I mean, I like them too, but not nearly that much. When we finally got down there, my legs hurt so bad from sitting in the back of my dad's car for so long. I walked around for two hours just to get the feeling back into my legs, which were completely numb from the journey.

The time I was patient was when I went bass fishin' with my stepdad. I could not wait for long, so I decided to talk to myself or sing songs to pass the time. My stepdad said, "You set your pole down on a sling shot holder and do whatever." So I went to walk around and explore the world, and I was thinking about how I could possibly learn to do patience. I went to go check on my pole, and I had gotten nothing, so I felt a little discouraged. I cast out far away and then I sat, wait and wait, but until that moment my pole started to jerk around wildly. So I reeled it in and caught a large bass! I was so happy and excited. My stepdad said, "See, you do got patience after all," and I finally understood what he meant.

The time I needed patience was when we were at the grocery store, Walmart to be exact. When we first got there I was excited because we were going to get lots of junk food, but then we started to get lots of regular food and it looked really good. I started to just want to eat it all right there. The cart was half way full when we got more stuff. It was so completely full that we had to get another cart, and that was when I started to get really hungry. By the time we were in the meat section, I was absolutely starving. My mom said, "Honey, just get a couple more things." So I waited, and waited, until she finally told me to go to the checkout. All of the lines were incredibly long and I felt like I was going to lose my mind. Then this little girl walked up to me, getting smart, and I couldn't take it; I was about to talk that little girl down. But I had to calm myself down completely, and then I realized it was finally our turn and I was so incredibly happy. When I got home, mom cooked bacon and I was just so exhausted and ready to go to bed.

As I waited at the airport, I gazed at all the people walking by and I pondered these thoughts in my head: "When will Dad be here? How long have I been waiting and what time is it? Wasn’t his flight supposed to be here thirty minutes ago?" Then suddenly I heard a soft female voice, "Daddy will be here soon, honey, don't worry." I don't understand how my mother told a four-year-old not to worry; it was in our nature to be impatient. I was about to lose my patience completely, but then I asked myself, "What good does complaining do? It only makes you more upset." As these things ran through my mind, I gradually gained back my patience. An hour later, I felt my mom shaking my shoulder and telling me to wake up. When I opened my eyes, I saw my dad standing right in front of me, and I ran to him and gave him a huge hug. "I almost lost my patience," I thought, but I was so glad I stayed patient because if I wasn’t, it would’ve ruined my father's trip home. Patience is a good thing to have; you can gain or lose things from it. In this case, I think I gained a wonderful reunion and a valuable lesson.

A time I was patient was one time we were at the store and I was very excited to go to the toys section. "But we were going to have to go to the groceries first," said mom. I was really mad and mom said "be patient, the quicker we do this the faster we'll get to the toys." After we are finally done with the grocery, we then have to go to the clothes section. I was really, really mad. Mom said again, "the quicker we do this the faster we get to the toys." Next, I had to try on clothes. "I hate trying on clothes," I said. Then I was very excited because we got to go to the toys selection and I was very happy. I looked and looked and then mom said "I could pick out a toy." It was hard to choose; I didn't know what to pick till I saw a cool truck. It had big tires, it had flames and it was green. I asked, "please, please?" And mom said "yes, you can get it." I was very happy. And that was a time I was patient.

I was patient getting my new video game system. It took forever to get it; I had to be so patient getting the system. It took me ten months to get it on my birthday. He and I had to go to all the GameStops in Taylor to get it. I was in the car for hours to get it. We went into the first GameStop we looked at and they had one inside. It was in good condition. I got three games for it and that was the time I was patient.

Once upon a time, in a land far away, there was a girl named Sarah. One day Sarah and her mom were going to watch a movie called The Adventure from Disneyland. However, when they got to the theater, the tickets were sold out and so they had to watch another movie. It must've been a bad day because once they got up to the ticket sold and remembered to go to! Sarah and her mom left and went to go eat. They went to a place called The Pizza Place and got in to order! They ordered their food, sat back down and ate. Once they were done, they left and went to try again with the movie. When they did, the line was as long as a mile! Sarah's mum just told her to be patient and wait in line without complaining. When they were there, they finally got the last ticket available. After that her mom said "so honey, we were patient." When they got home, they sat on the couch, got a snack, and waited for Sarah's sister and dad to get home. Finally, they arrived with a big surprise and Sarah's dad was holding tickets to go see the movie Sarah and her mom had just seen! "We were trying to find you all day," said her father. "We couldn't find you," said her sister. Sarah and her mom looked at each other and explained that they can go see the movie because they were patient and waited in line and got the last ticket available! "And we won fifty dollars too!" exclaimed Sarah. The end!

I am going to talk about what I think patience is. I think patience is about waiting calmly for something you really want. For example, "you were very patient in line for cotton candy," said the clown. You know something like that, waiting without getting upset or angry. I know this is a short story, I'm sorry, but that is what I believe patience means.

I remember one day I was waiting in the waiting room in the doctor's office with my mom because I wasn't feeling well. We sat there talking for about ten minutes when my mom said "wow, it's already been ten minutes." "I wonder when I will get to go and talk to my doctor," I said. "I don't know but let's wait a bit longer," mom said. So as we waited and sat patiently, more kids started coming in. I noticed some were young and some were older. I sighed. What is taking so long? I wondered. Was my doctor even here today? I stared at the wall and looked at the color of it. Orange. Before I knew it, half an hour passed. My mom was looking at her watch. "Wow, it's almost noon!" "Oh no!" I said, flustered and annoyed. "Are we just gonna sit here all day?" I asked. Finally my question was answered as a nurse said I could finally come back to a room and speak with my doctor about my sickness. "Thank you for being patient!" the nurse said smiling. I smiled back. I had been patient.

One day my mom said I could get this new toy at the store, but she had to do a few other things before we went, so I had to be patient. First, my mom had to go to where she works because she had forgotten something important. After that, she had to go to the gas station to fill up the car. I waited in the car, trying to think about the toy to make the time pass faster. Then we finally went to the store, and I got the toy that I wanted, which made all the waiting feel worth it in the end.

Patience can come in different ways in life, and it offers several important benefits. For one thing, it can reward you at the end of a wait. For example, it can come in a bigger way if you are patient because the outcome would be a bigger reward to you. Another thing is that it lets you do other things in the process of waiting. For example, when you wait for something, you could do something else, and when it's time, you deserve what you waited for. Another thing is that it might be difficult, but you can control it if you are calm. For example, some people can’t wait so they just want to rush and get to be done with it, which often leads to mistakes. My final reason would be if you can do it once in your life, the second time can be easy. For example, the second time wouldn’t be so hard because you would be calm and know what to expect. That is patience in my own way of understanding it.

When I'm being patient, I wait nicely and I do not complain. I like to be patient and I wait well; I do not get upset. Sometimes people don't know how to be patient and need to calm down, and sometimes when something is taking forever, I sometimes say "come on" quietly to myself. I always try to be patient at school and at restaurants, and I always try to be patient everywhere, but sometimes I can't be patient and I don't want people thinking I'm weird for saying something. I just wait a bit and I try to be patient. I have to be patient in lines at the fair, and at the fair they sometimes have very long lines. That is my goal, to be patient about everything, but sometimes I'm not patient because sometimes something takes too long and I just have to like to be patient to get through it.

In the writing prompt, I chose to write a story about a time when I was patient. I am going to talk about the time I skipped school to go fishing with my dad and my uncle. I didn’t get to sleep in very much; I still got up at about the same time I do to go to school. I had to get out of the house before my brother saw me because he wasn’t going with us. We got in the car and drove to my uncle’s house. When we arrived at his house, my dad started packing all the fishing gear onto the boat. Once we did that, we hopped in my uncle’s old, rusty, red truck. The red paint was chipping all over the truck. We started to drive, and my uncle had to keep watching the boat in the rearview mirror. The boat was very small. It just barely fit all of us. It was only about a foot and a half wide and about several feet long. It scared me a little when we put the boat in the water and started driving. We went through a gorgeous river all the way to the back of the lake. The lake we were on is called by its name. It is in a specific location. I was patient right when we got in there. I thought we were going to stand, so I was having second thoughts on fishing. It turns out, we just sat in there while we fished. We fished for a good number of hours that day. I was so very patient waiting for my bobber to go down so I could set the hook. My uncle said a special word when the bobber was going under the water like a submarine does. We had multiple rods out at once! Several pike rods, and a couple of bluegill rods! I caught the biggest bluegill of the day that day! This day was one of the best days of my life! That is about the time I had to be patient on the lake for hours straight, and it was a wonderful experience.

One day I was at the store with my friends. I picked out my Slurpee and got in line to buy it. Then an old lady got in line behind me. So, to be nice, I let her go in front of me. After a while, she found out that she was a dollar short to pay for her items. So I gave her a dollar from my own money. She turned to me, said thanks, and gave me a mint. After I bought my Slurpee, me and my friends had to cross the road. We sat there for what felt like a long time, maybe ten to fifteen minutes, but it seemed like an hour because we were so eager to get home. We finally crossed the road and walked toward my house. On the way to my house, my friend said he had to use the restroom. So we went to the nearby market. We had to wait for about an hour before he came back out of the market. He told us he had gotten lost inside. We finally walked home, and on that day, I learned through all those small delays that it’s tough to be patient, but it is an important part of life.

Two summers ago, I helped out with the kids camp at my church. I was assigned to help with the preschoolers for the entire week, and that role required a lot of patience. They were very excited and roudy, full of boundless energy. They were always running around the room and shouting with glee. I quickly learned that I had to keep a calm voice and be patient with the children, as raising my voice would only make the situation worse. Later on in the week, I was put in charge of a young kid with special needs. He just couldn’t sit still and was constantly fidgeting! I had to gently remind him over and over again not to be so loud during quiet activities. He was very determined to get what he wanted and would become quite frustrated. It was hard to stay calm during these challenging moments. Despite the hardship, I managed to be patient and calm throughout. Eventually, the little boy decided I was all right and started to behave better for me. Now, every time he sees me in the church hallway, he says, “hi!” very excitedly. Now I am truly glad that I stayed patient and built that connection.

One day I was at my grandmother's house to celebrate my cousin's birthday. He was turning eight years old. So we played games and played on the trampoline in the backyard. Then we came inside to relax and watch some television. We played with their dog for a while after that. Then a lot of people came over to join the celebration. We went outside for a third time and played more games. We had to come inside and clean up for dinner. We all ate a feast of turkey, baked potatoes, cheesy potatoes, squash, and green beans. That was pretty good. Then they wanted us to do a craft project. It was a jar with a candle in it. We had to cover it in colorful tissue paper and it used lots of glue. I had to wait patiently for my turn because I was the last one to do mine. So I waited and waited by the wall, and then finally I got to do my project, but I was the only one there still sitting at the table doing my project. It actually turned out pretty good after all that waiting. Being patient can get you very far in life. You have to be patient at a job, in a restaurant, and in lots more situations. So remember just be patient and you'll be okay. Being patient will guide you through your whole life.

I am going to write a story about a time that I was patient. When I was eleven, on a warm July morning my mother was due to have her baby. I couldn’t wait; I was so excited to meet my new sibling. We went to the doctor's office and we shifted into her hospital room. My mother's best friend and my grandmother were there with us. When we got into the room my mother was having strong contractions; she was yelling, screaming and squeezing my dad’s hand very hard. I got scared while she was yelling and I didn’t want her to get hurt. I walked out of the room and me and my mom's friend went and got the baby her first dress from the gift shop. The baby finally came home a few days later, and she was always crying, needing constant attention. That was when I truly learned to be patient, holding the baby and soothing her until she calmed down. It was a challenging but important lesson in caring for someone new.

Patience is essential when interacting with others. I learned this during a visit to the dentist’s office. This past Tuesday, I had a dentist appointment, since it had been six months since my last one. As I was waiting to be called in, a young boy came in with a severe toothache. The dentists decided to treat him first, and I understand why they made that decision. I could tell that the boy was in a lot of pain, clutching his cheek. Shortly after the boy went to get treated, an older woman came in with a mysterious pain in her mouth. It turned out to be a root canal, and they decided to examine and treat her before me. I also understood that decision, as her need was greater. After the woman went to get treated, a little girl comes walking in, bragging happily about her first loose tooth. Her mom said she wanted the little girl’s tooth pulled. When the dentist called her back before me, I got really frustrated. The girl was in no pain at all. In fact, she was pretty happy and excited she had a loose tooth. I didn't think it was fair that I had to wait another twenty minutes so that she could get her tooth pulled. I had to show a lot of patience because my appointment got pushed back over two hours. I thought about how I felt when I lost my first tooth, and then I didn’t mind her going in front of me. All in all, patience is a very important trait that people should exhibit on a daily basis. I learned a very important lesson that day: Patience should always be mandatory, as it helps us understand and empathize with the situations of those around us.

One time my friend began practicing patience while waiting for the teacher. She was waiting by the classroom wall while he was talking to another teacher. She stood quietly and did not interrupt. After that, he was done talking with the other teacher. Then she was able to get her question answered that she needed. That is a time when my friend demonstrated that she was patient, showing how waiting calmly can help you achieve your goal.

Patience is about many things. First, there are different ways to express patience. Second, people either have patience or they don’t. I admit I am one of those people that don’t have patience. My mom is always saying, “Hold your horses.” I know. I don’t have patience so why does she have to tell me I don’t? I don’t have any patience in grocery shopping; I can’t wait to get out, but, everyone hates it right? Lines, lines, lines—man, do I hate them, they take forever, wherever you go. Plus, it is really nice when you let someone go ahead of you if they are in a big hurry or something like an emergency. Plus, the goodness in you just can’t help it when you have a little girl that needs to cut you in line. So you see, patience can take a toll, or some people have no problem with it. It just depends on who you are. Patience has a lot to do with complaining. But not the way you think; when you are patient you don’t complain at all, you chill and go with the flow of things that are around you. Especially when you are in a difficult situation, it helps to have patient people than non-patient people with you. Well, that talks about patience and how people deal, relate, and chill about it.

I remember the time I got my new puppy; we had to be patient. We had to be patient because he wasn’t fully potty trained yet and he was crazy. My dog is a herding breed and they are known for herding cows. So whenever we used to go outside he would bite our shoes. I don’t know why he would try to move us but it did. We had to be very patient when we trained him; it took until he was about a year and a half old to figure out that he wasn’t supposed to do that, but my dog is still growing into new hobbies. We just have to stay calm and patient and then we are able to train him. It takes a long time for any dog to learn his habits, so we must stay patient. This is the time when I was patient, and it taught me the value of consistent, gentle training.

My mom woke me up early in the morning and said I need to get up and get ready fast. I asked what was the matter and she said we were going to Potter Park Zoo. I didn’t know why, maybe just a sudden idea. I got all dressed and we hit the road. I wasn’t feeling well that morning. We got Subway breakfast. I didn’t eat my sandwich though, cause my stomach hurt too bad. It seemed like two hours before we finally got there. I was feeling better now. We paid and got a map and started looking at all the awesome animals. I got to see two giant wolves, snakes, monkeys, lions, peacocks, camels, and a bunch of other animals. It was so fun! We got to this bird cage that you can go in; the birds are just flying around loose! There was a little boy in there and a bird landed right on the top of his head! Suddenly, my mom’s phone rang. It was my brother. He stayed home because he didn’t wanna get up. I could barely hear my mom over the birds. She walked out and stood outside; I followed her. She was saying, “Stay home, because I said so; you don’t need to go anywhere.” Next thing I know she was hanging up. We walked toward the fish building when her phone rang. “Don’t ever hang up on me again! Seriously, I don’t need to fight with you! It’s going to storm; I want you home!” Then it starts pouring rain and my mom’s still on the phone. I was getting very wet and bored; I really wanted to see the fish. About ten minutes later my mom hung up her phone. We walked in, soaking wet! My mom smiled at me and said, “Thank you for being so patient!”

A time I was patient is when we had to do MCAP tests. I was one of the first ones done, so I had to sit quietly and read. I read most of my book. It took about an hour for everyone to finish. It was a very long time to read. I got bored, but I sat quietly so people could finish, and so I wouldn’t be disruptive. Then when everyone finished we took a bathroom break. It was a good lesson in waiting respectfully for others.

One time I was patient was when I was a little kid. My mom and my cousin Cindy were talking. My cousin told me to wait my turn when my mom and she were done talking, so I did wait for my turn. While they were still talking, I asked my mom if I could go for my bike. I told my mom I could ride my bike without training wheels. My mom came over because I was going for surgery. I was waiting for the surgery. The surgery was for my arm, which I had hurt. So I was waiting until it was done. It was a long wait, but it was fun to finally get back on my bike afterward.

I tested my patience when I was waiting for a long time. You know, if you have patience, if you said for a certain number of minutes you're set at one time, you will know if you have patience then. I will be strong, but I get impatient at some time. You will never be all patience at a course or a new endeavor. I was at a place where I had to be patient to see the result; I got impatient, then I had to wait to get food so I could have something to do, for I wanted bread so I knew I had to endure until a certain month. That is how I got my patience.

There was a time when I was patient. The time I was patient is when my cousins, let's call them @PERSON1, @PERSON2, and @PERSON3, were playing the Wii. And I said I would play winner, so my cousin @PERSON2 won and @PERSON1 didn’t give me the controller and she wasn’t sharing. Then I said she could play one more time then it's my turn, but instead she played four more times. I said, "@PERSON1, it's my turn, you played and I didn’t," but she said, “It is not your turn.” Then her mom said, “@PERSON1, you can play a few more minutes then it's my turn.” One hour and thirty minutes passed and she still didn’t give it to me. Then I said, "@PERSON1, it's my turn, and I’ve been patient for a long time; you either give it to me or I’m going to take it," but she still didn't give it to me. I had been getting ready and she still didn’t share. Finally, she said she was tired of it anyways. And that’s the time I’ve been patient.

One time I was patient was when I had to go to the doctor to take my shot for sixth grade. I didn't want to go but I had to; I didn't have a choice, so I got in the car and we drove to the doctor's office. Finally, we arrived. My mom had to sign in and we sat down. Even though I was waiting for three hours, I didn't complain about it. The doctor came out and I got scared but happy that finally it was my turn. Then he called a different name, so we kept on waiting in the waiting room. Then my beloved mother told me, "Wow, you're not complaining now." I know, I managed that because I am becoming more mature and I have a lot of patience. Thankfully, the doctor finally called my name. My mom and I went into the room. The doctor said, "You've grown since the last time I saw you." I asked, "Doctor, is this going to hurt?" He said, "No, sweetie, it's not." I asked, "Are you sure?" He said, "Positive." I said, "Okay, ready." So I closed my eyes and imagined something really nice. The doctor said he was done. I asked, "When are you going to give me the shot?" He said, "I already did." I said, "Really?" He said, "Yes, look at your arm." I saw it and said, "Wow, I never felt a thing!" He said, "See, I told you." I said, "Thank you, you are the best doctor in the whole wide world." He replied, "You're very welcome."

I remember the time when my older sister was so patient for her birthday on the "fourth of a certain month." Man, she was patient. Every time I asked her, "Can you wait until your birthday?" she said, "Yes, I can wait until my birthday." She couldn't wait until her birthday because it was in a different month until the "fourth of that month." She was so happy; I just can't believe that she waited for her birthday. She went to her friend's house, did some shopping of her own, and when the fireworks were in the air, my sister was thrilled. Well, that is how my sister was patient.

Ahh! I screamed in my mind. Babysitting my cousin took a lot more patience, more for her than for me. It all started on a certain date at a certain time; my family went to get some drinks, but I stayed behind to work on my homework. A little after my mom left, I heard a knock on the door. My aunt came in and whispered, "You must watch the baby for a while, is that okay if I left her with you?" I replied, "Okay." The baby was asleep for about half an hour. When I woke up, the baby had also woken and started crying. The first thing I did was pick her up and carry her around. Still, she was crying! I thought her clothes needed changing. I changed her clothes, but she kept crying. Now I had to keep my patience though, because who would yell at a baby? Then I thought she was hungry. I didn't know how to make a bottle though, so I had to read the instructions. The baby had no patience; all she wanted was her bottle. When I was about to lose my patience, I made a bottle and made sure it was good, and she drank it. Finally, I put her back to sleep, thinking if she cried one more time I would finally lose my patience. She was sleeping and looked so peaceful until she woke up again. She started crying again; this time I knew why, because she likes to be carried. By the time my aunt came back, my hands were sore. Although at the end of the day I figured out that you need a lot of patience to take care of a baby, and you need way more patience for a younger brother though, trust me.

I am going to write about a time when I was patient. My advocate was supposed to buy me some pens for many years as part of my money. I have been asking him every single day since then. “Did you do your daily shopping yet?” I would ask. “No,” he would reply. I would then say, “Please remember.” He always said, “because I want my pens as a present, remember the amount you owe me.” I would answer, “I do remember, but please be patient.” And I would think to myself, “okay, but my patience is about to fall apart.” I have been waiting ever since, reminding myself that one day the pens will come, and that day will make all the waiting worthwhile.

Have you ever had to wait in line to get on the biggest roller coaster at a theme park? Have you ever waited until all your chores are done before you can play with your best friend? Have you ever had to wait for your little brother or sister to catch up? Well, in this story I will tell you about one time that I had to be patient. During a routine check-up I had to go to the doctor to get shots so that I could be safe. When I got to the doctor I had to wait in a room for my name to be called. It was incredibly boring!
