And I was thinking, “How long does it take for a few people to get shots so that I can leave?” All I had to do was just sit there for about half-an-hour until my name was finally called. Then once I got into a back room I had to wait even longer for my mom to sign papers and what not, and also for the doctor to get the shots ready for what my mom told them to give me. But in the end I got to go home and play with my friend. This is one of many times that I had to be patient. And at least I still got to play with my friend, which made the whole waiting experience feel much better in the end.

I was patient when I was waiting for a chance to go to Chicago. I really wanted to go see the windy city because my mom went to college there. I tried to forget about it until I went. It kind of worked but once in awhile the thought came back to me. Although I did stay patient and I didn’t bug my parents about it once. It took a few years, but I kept my patience. Sometimes I even forgot I forgot about it. I just lived every day as if I didn’t care about visiting. No matter how tempting it was seeing a Chicago Bears or Blackhawks game on television, I kept my cool. Then it happened one summer, imagine that it was several years later and I was still patient! So, to put it in a nut shell no matter how long it took, I would be patient, and that resolve finally led to the trip I had always dreamed of.

I am going to tell a story in my own way. It was my sister’s birthday. My sister was turning ten years old. We were at the local bowling alley setting up for her party. She had a pretty dress and my mom was curling her hair in the bathroom. I walked in and asked my mom if she could curl my hair. She said, “You have to wait.” I made a snobby comment and I sat at one of the tables. I was trying to be patient. Finally, it was my turn. I sat there while she curled my hair. Later that day, my sister, my cousins and I all had a lane to ourselves. I was last on the bowling list so I had to be patient for a while. It was finally my turn. I bowled and I waited. Bowled and waited. Finally it was time for cake and I had to be patient again. Eventually I got my cake but I was sick of waiting for everything. While my sister was opening her presents, I was thinking to myself, “she’s so slow,” and I walked up there and shouted, “Hurry up!” I got yelled at and had to sit out for a while. I should have been patient the whole day and maybe I would have participated in all the games. That’s my story I told in my own way, a lesson learned about the cost of impatience.

A time that I was patient was when I had to train my dog. “Sit boy,” I commanded my puppy. My dog, instead of sitting, ran at me, jumped and grabbed the treat out of my hand. I went and tried to grab the treat back from him and he gulped it down. While I was walking to grab his collar and take him for a walk he bolted away. After chasing him for what felt like hours he finally stopped and looked at me waiting to run again. “Come here, I’m done chasing you, let’s just go for a walk, please,” I said as I slowly lost my patience. I began to walk toward him again very slowly. I got close enough to grab his collar, but then the dog bolted again just leaving a bunch of dust behind. “I’m done!” I screamed and walked away with anger. I began to leave and go up the hill to my house. I went to my room ready to sleep. The next morning I woke up and went outside to try and train my dog. I lost my patience yesterday and stormed off but today I was ready to work hard and keep my patience. “Come!” I yelled waiting for my dog to come running and he did. With my first command I told the dog to sit and he did not, so I didn’t give him the treat. I said it again and he sat! Finally some progress after all that waiting. I gave him the treat and he started wagging his tail. To see if he understood I said it again. He sat again and got another treat. After that I began to ask him to do more things; sometimes he didn’t listen and sometimes he did. That was a time when I was patient with my dog to teach and train him and it definitely paid off, making all the frustration worthwhile.

One time when I was patient was when we flew in the airplane from @LOCATION2 to visit my sister at the school she asked us to. We flew to @LOCATION4 well and then to the @ORGANIZATION1 terminal, but after that it was all down hill. When we got to the layover at @LOCATION3 we were stuck there for four hours! After an hour I got bored, and having my little brother with us didn’t help at all. Then over the intercom we heard that we had to go through security again now and sit in a sterile room with just a gift shop for another @NUM1 hours. When there was only an hour left there was another announcement, and it was that we would be delayed three more hours. After that, I was listening to my ipod and luckily fell asleep for three and a half hours. When we finally got to leave, we walked up to a six-seater plane for us to fly to a small island near by. When we got to @LOCATION1 we had to hurry to the island school to see my sister. That was one time when I felt patient waiting in an airport for @NUM2 hours, and I was just relieved the journey was finally over.

“@CAPS2 @CAPS1 @CAPS2 @CAPS3” I can hear the clock ticking, probably to annoy me. I can feel the tension in the small classroom building. Everybody is on the edge of their chairs waiting; why does @CAPS4 seem so long? It’s almost been @NUM1 minute now. The aroma of pepperoni pizza is so strong that I can practically taste @CAPS4. This is pure agony. My stomach rumbles, so hungry. @NUM2 seconds—can I wait that long? @NUM3, I’m not sure. The tension of the whole class is so great, I think my brain will erupt. I can’t take this; @CAPS4’s way too much. My eyes flash nervously to the clock. @NUM4 seconds—@CAPS4 seems to be an eternity. @CAPS4 couldn’t have been just a few seconds, could @CAPS4? @CAPS4 must have been at least years. @NUM5, why is time so short? I’m not a very patient person, not at all. But do I have any amount of patience? If I do, I’m not seeing @CAPS4 got. I’m about to just jump out of my seat as if I’m ejected from a @DATE1. I’m trying to hold still, but anxiety is getting to me. If I knew that I’d be this anxious for lunch, I would have had breakfast. We’re down to @NUM6 seconds now. My excitement grows, but so does the tension. @CAPS4’s enough to crush me now. I think I might make @CAPS4 @NUM7. My stomach rumbles again, louder this time, begging for food, @CAPS5; demanding is more like @CAPS4. “@CAPS2 @CAPS3 @CAPS2 @CAPS3,” the clock knocking me, taunting me. @NUM8 seconds—I can’t bear this much longer. I think I am about to snap. I don’t handle patience well. @CAPS4’s a ticking bomb inside me, just waiting to go off. @NUM9 seconds. @CAPS4 seems the bomb and clock are counting down together, both anticipating my snap. I’ll show them. My will is stronger than my need. I can do this. I will prove I have @NUM10. “@CAPS10!” Finally, the bell goes off signaling lunch time. I zoomed out like a squirrel who just sat on a snow cone, my patience finally rewarded.

Some people have a lot of patience, and I am one of those people. I have had a lot of patience in my life. We were driving to @LOCATION1's @CAPS1, and I was getting antsy. I knew this would be a hectic day for my mom, so I decided to be patient and read a book. Before I knew it, we were there. Later, I was waiting to get a lemonade with my mom, and we had already been waiting in line for @NUM1 minutes. I was starting to get tired of waiting in this long line for a little lemonade. But I knew my mom had already had a tiring day because my sister wouldn't stop complaining. So instead of complaining, I stopped thinking about how long it would take to get our lemonade. I started thinking about what it would be like to ride the @CAPS2, and the next thing I knew we had our lemonade. Another time, I was starting to wish that we hadn't gotten in line for the @CAPS3 hawk because it was so long. I was really getting mad that it was taking this long to wait for a ride that was only @NUM2 seconds long. But then I remembered that my mom was with me and she had a bad headache. So I shut my mouth and waited quietly. I was glad that I was patient that day because if I wouldn't have been, then my mom probably wouldn't have been as happy as she was at the end of the day.

One time that I was patient was when we went to the @LOCATION1 @CAPS1. We had to wait in a long, winding line for half an hour. We were supposed to get on the cork screw ride, and I was very excited to go on that ride. So I decided to be patient and not complain. For @NUM1 minutes we inched forward, and once we got to the front of the line I couldn't wait any longer. So I hurried up and got on the ride, feeling a surge of relief. I really didn't like that day when I had to stand up that long, but I learned that is what patience means—enduring the wait for something you want.

On @CAPS1 while I was fishing in Little Traverse Bay for salmon, there was a tremendous hit on the trolling line. I launched from where I was sitting like a rocket and heaved on the line. I waited. I thought it was a false alarm, a snag, but trust me I thought wrong. The pull did a dance then bent really fast again. ”@CAPS2 on," I yelled to my cousin, and he ran back to my aid. We @CAPS4 stared at the water; the pole still flexed but didn't move. I was looking for the tumbleweed because I felt like I was in an old western movie standoff. Finally I looked at my cousin and said, ”I have been patient, do you think I should reel him up"? "@CAPS3 me get the net first," he fumed and grabbed it then stated, "When you are ready." I slowly cranked the handle on the reel, tie, tie, as I slowly cranked him from the freaky depths. Then out of nowhere the steel cable that was my line shot from the spool like a bullet, but then a cynical jerk from him and the line went slack. My cousin and I @CAPS4 knew what had happened. The @CAPS2 I thought was going to be mine was now swimming off into deeper waters to frustrate more fishermen with his patient ways, and my patience had ultimately been tested for nothing.

Quite a few times my mom has been very patient with me. I tend to tell my mom stories about my day at school when I come home, recounting every little detail. Once when we were sitting there in the living room, I was telling my mom the story. As I go on and on my mom has the patience to listen to it, never interrupting or looking at her phone. Though the story may have been boring for her, and extremely long, she listened, she made comments and never showed a sign of boredom. The expression on her face, one of genuine interest and care, made me happy to know she was listening. It is a wonderful feeling to be heard so completely.

One time I was patient when I let a stranger cut in front of me to get some food at a busy food court. He seemed to be in a great hurry and looked very stressed. And when me and my brother both had to use the bathroom I let him go first even though I was first in line, recognizing that his need was more urgent than my own. In both instances, I felt a quiet sense of satisfaction from putting someone else's comfort before my immediate desire. These small acts of patience, though simple, can make a significant difference in someone else's day.

Patience is a very hard thing to capture. The way I think of it, patience it is a gift to have. One time I had to try and test my patience was before a major college football game. One part was driving there. It was a complete standstill and people were migrating to the stadium! It took us an hour to go just a few miles! I was about ready to just run to the game! I could not wait any longer to go to this game! "Test your patience!" my dad kept reminding me. Once we finally got there, out of the traffic I had to wait another long while before the game! How could I wait that long? Would it be possible? I just sat there in a lawnchair watching people drive by our tailgate on college game day. I just wanted to scream I wanted to leave and get to the stadium so bad! Finally we took off from the tailgate. It was fun walking up with all the excited state fans, and tailgaters. Now I was sitting in this boring line just trying to be patient. Again i had to question myself I could be patient enough one by one people were getting in. I moved closer and closer, actually using my patience and focusing on the excited atmosphere. When it was finally my turn I just ran right in so excited to have finally been in the stadium and conquer my patience throughout the day. It was great to finally be in there, having overcome my rushed feeling and letting patience take over me, proving to myself that I could wait for something worthwhile.

I was very patient one time when my grandma was in the store. She was taking a long time, trying to look at the whole store and I had to go to the bathroom real bad. I started to get real mad because I thought the store person that was ringing up the stuff tried to go slow so I couldn't use it. My foot was tapping and I kept sighing loudly. The only reason why I didn't complain was because most of the stuff and the basket was mine, and I didn't want to seem ungrateful. That was a time I was very patient, holding back my frustration even though it was difficult. In the end, I managed to wait without causing a scene, which felt like a small personal victory.

Every year we have a family reunion for two weeks. Cousins, aunts, uncles come all across the country to enjoy these few weeks together. We go to the small town of my grandparents right next to a famous national park. The only problem is its a four hour drive, and if you know me I'm not that patient. My brother and I always rotate every year to see who rides with my mom. We flip a coin and I always lose. If you ask me she is the most impatient, always tapping the steering wheel and complaining about other drivers! But once you get there everybody is happy to see each other, and it feels worth it to wait for the duration of the vacation to launch into our patience. And that's my story about being patient for a family event that is always rewarding in the end.

One time I had to be very patient. I had to wait five hours before my grandma got to my house. Every hour I would go look outside the window to see if her car was there, feeling a little disappointed each time she wasn't. Eventually she did arrive and I was very happy, giving her a big hug at the door. Some examples to help stay patient are focusing on something else like reading a book or playing a game, going to someone's house for a while to pass the time, or even taking a nap. These are examples of staying patient and can make waiting much easier.

My grandma is almost always patient with me, especially when she is teaching how to do something like cook or sew. One time my grandma taught me how to use a sewing machine. She taught me how to change the color of the thread, and she helped me untangle the thread, even though it took a while and I’m not the best listener, that took a lot of patience. Another time she taught me how to frost sugar cookies. I would get very involved because either the cookie broke or my frosting was lumpy and all over the cookie even the bottom, but grandma put up with my complaining and when I finally frosted one that didn’t break and the frosting was smooth, she praised me, even though I had probably broken half of the sugar cookies. My grandma was also patient with me when I helped her make caramel corn, which has many difficult steps, and if you do one wrong, the whole batch is ruined. She let me do the easy stuff mostly, but she also let me make the sauce on the last batch which was fun, and when I started to go too slow, instead of yelling at me to hurry up, she asked me politely to go a little quicker which must have taken a lot of patience. My grandma also taught me how to bake, which took a tremendous amount of patience because I was constantly spilling flour, vanilla, baking soda, anything in the recipe that could be dropped I dropped it. I also never wanted to stay and clean it up and when I did, I still left half the stuff on the floor. My grandma is always patient with me no matter what I do, and I am very grateful for her kindness.

A time I was patient was when I was going on the Raptor at Cedar Point. There was a two hour line and me and my friend were getting bored. There was some music playing but that didn’t really amuse us for very long. But I had never been on the Raptor before and I was really thrilled to go on it, so I tried to focus on that excitement. One hour dragged by slowly as we inched forward in the queue. Then finally, after ten more minutes of waiting, I got to go on the Raptor and it was the best ride ever, making all the patience worthwhile.

When they had no idea when to get inside and how to protect their food. Our time is way easier than in the old days, they had to work hard at everything while everything is given to us. Our two time periods are a lot different. There aren’t too many days where I am patient but this day was one of them. I was playing a football game on a great sunny afternoon. I was starting quarterback and I scored two touchdowns and a passing touchdown just in the first half. At that point we were up by a lot and the coaches took out all the starters for the whole second half. I was expecting to still play but nope they told me to sit the bench for the rest of the game. This was very hard for me because I had to wait until the game was over to get up off the bench, just watching the clock tick down. I’m not a very patient person so this was extremely hard for me. I hope I’ll never have to do that again, but I learned a little about waiting that day.

I was patient before; I went hunting with my dad before, last November. I was in the blind with him for a long time, waiting for deer to come in. He said they come in at night, or towards late afternoon. We waited forever, sitting quietly and looking out into the trees. When they finally came in, me and my dad did not get one. Some other guys shot one and they all ran away. We waited maybe ten more minutes, hoping they would return, and then went in we were all there from early morning until late afternoon. I was patient the whole time, even though we didn't get a deer that day.

One day, me and my parents went fishing. Our fish finder was going off like crazy but no fish were biting. It got to the point, in a short time I might add, where our dog would bark like crazy whenever we started to reel in our lines, even if there was nothing on them. We waited, and waited, and waited, but still nothing came. Every once in a while we’d have to move again because of the current pushing our boat. After we’d been sitting there for hours on end, I felt something heavy on my line. I thought at first I was snagged on a rock, but when I started to reel in, the line came a little, so I reeled some more. I thought it felt like a fish pulling on my line, and then I called out, “Hey, dad, I think I have a fish!”. My dad told me to keep reeling steadily. Eventually, I felt like my arms were going to fall off, but the fish came into view! While dad got the net and pulled the fish out of the water, I asked, “What kind is it?” He said, “It’s a walleye.” I didn’t know what to say. My first walleye! And dad even said it was big enough to keep! After that, then we went home, filleted the fish, and had walleye for dinner.

It was a Tuesday morning at school, so boring as usual, and my best friend came in on crutches. I freaked out and ran over to her, and she told me she broke her leg and that she wasn’t allowed to hang out for a whole month. It was hard waiting a whole month to hangout with her, but her safety was more important than my amusement. It was two weeks after my friend broke her leg, and I was doing well at not bothering her, so I was proud of myself, but I got to help her around school by carrying her books. It was a few more weeks later; she was almost better, so I was excited and went and bought her a small gift. The next Tuesday my friend was out of the crutches and the cast and back on her own two feet; that’s the story of the time I was patient.

I am the type of person who you would call impatient, but I will try to explain it in the best way I can. The only time I am patient is when something exciting on TV comes on; I can wait quietly for my favorite show to start. My friends are always patient for everything, like waiting in long lines and for other things, but I am never patient in those same situations. I find it very difficult to wait for anything at all.

"Hailey, get down here I need you to open an envelope!" my mom said. We sprinted down stairs because an envelope can only mean a report card, letter, birthday card, or checking account balance. We got downstairs and we saw they had a camera out, and the envelope had a sticker on the back that said 99.1 radio. We open it and it says congratulations you won tickets to the first official concert with Justin Bieber! I was just looking at them in awe, my sister was freaking out! Then, my mom told me that my aunt is going with us! Surprise just kept coming and coming. Another huge surprise was the lines; about a thousand girls were lined up at the front doors of the River Oaks music theater. Then security started to move and spread all the girls out; we got pushed about a quarter mile away from where we were standing. Two and a half hours later we were waiting, then I see this boy's head pop out a window of the music theater and say, "Hello girls!". After he said that about five hundred girls went crazy screaming. Another hour and a half later from that, they started to let people in. The theater was cozy and warm for being out in the cold for four hours; it felt good. Iyaz was the special guest to get us warmed up for Justin Bieber. When he got out every girl was screaming their lungs out! He sang his songs, and the concert was a great experience for my first concert ever.

One day during the summer my phone rang. Not many people call my cell phone. I dashed to my room, but my phone was nowhere in sight! Oh where is it? I swear, I was about to completely tear down every thing in my search. I stopped, felt my back pocket, and there it was. I felt like such an idiot. I was freaking out over my phone because I couldn't find it, when it turned out to be in my back pocket the whole time. Anyway, it was still ringing. I looked at the contact. I was stunned to see who it was. It was my friend Sarah! I answered the phone and Sarah starts to speak. She wanted to know if we can have a sleepover in her back yard. I was so excited, but that same day my family and I were going to a fair. When I asked my dad he hesitated to say yes. I packed my bags, hopped in the car and was ready to go. I really didn't want to go to this peach fair thing; I just wanted to hang with Sarah. Here we are at the fair. I got out the car. My brother and I just wandered off. We went on a few rides, played a few games. All I was thinking about was how much fun I was going to have at Sarah's house. I was waiting and waiting and waiting. Finally! Yes we can go. Off to Sarah's. I couldn't wait any longer. I was so excited when I finally arrived at Sarah's house. It's about time. I had no choice but to wait, and in conclusion, that was one of the times I was patient.

Tap, tap, tap. The tips of my fingers bounced off the arm rest with every impatient movement. I had asked my mom to hurry up so I wouldn’t be late. I had told her, like I have a million times before, “Mom, you know how much being on time for practice means to me.” So I sat there slumped over on the couch, my backpack strapped tightly over my shoulders. This happens all the time, I thought my mom would have learned by now. As I waited, I turned on the television to keep me busy. Unfortunately, with every channel flip, I became more irritated. “Where is she? Why is she taking so long?” Questions like these swirled in my head. Then, my mom came stumbling into the family room. She snatched her keys from the counter and we hurried into the car. As I snapped my seat belt into place, I flipped the switch to open the garage. As I sat in my seat, wiggling anxiously, the garage door creaked open. My mom started the engine and we cascaded down the driveway and towards the road. Just to make my luck even better, we got caught in traffic. As the cars sauntered along, time was ticking away. The clock showed I was for sure not going to make it on time. I threw myself back into the seat. I closed my eyes and took deep breaths. Taking lots of deep breaths helped slow down my heart rate which allowed me to tone down my stress level. “Be patient.” I told myself. “Be patient. Relax, you’ll make it there.” All of a sudden my mom slammed onto the brakes. My eyes flew open to see that we had made it to the pool. The time read just enough. I was going to make it! I exploded out of the car with my bag on my back. At that moment, I told myself “see you can do it. You made it to swim practice, and all you had to do was slow down and be patient. Great job.”

I was patient when it was my birthday and I didn’t get anything. I thought I would get at least one thing but I got nothing. I didn’t do anything wrong but still I got nothing. The next day I got nothing; I didn’t ask for anything but I still got nothing. The next day I got nothing again. But that night while I was skating at Skate Port, I still had gotten nothing. Then, later that evening, I saw my cousin and she gave me some money for my birthday. I thought that everyone had forgotten but I was wrong. I was so happy, too. I had to be patient in order to get something and learned that you don’t always have to ask for something to receive it.

The power went out in our neighborhood one day. One day when my aunt was watching me, all of a sudden all the lights went out. So I thought we blew a fuse, so my aunt went to go fix it and it didn’t work. So she tried calling my mom but the connection got lost. Then we got our generator and watched the news and found out my mom got stuck on the highway. I was worried, but then we finally got our phones to work and some of our family came over. We were so mad because nothing worked for a week and we had to be very patient throughout the entire ordeal.

I've been waiting for like two hours. When am I going to get my food? I was hungry so I told my mom; she asked me if I wanted to go out to eat and I said sure and went and got my jacket on. Mom said she had to go get dad and told me to wait in the car, so I went and waited for them for a few minutes. When they finally got out, dad asked what was going on. He said ok and we went. When we got there, there were no other stores that were open. When we went inside there were like a billion people in there. I was so hungry I could eat a pig, metaphorically speaking. We went to the chicken area and we asked how long we would have to wait. And the guy at the counter said about two hours. After about an hour, I started to read a magazine and some people left but the people in front of us went in those seats. We were next to go sit down but it took about an hour before some people left. I didn't complain at all and I didn't ever talk at all, and I talk a lot. And that was the time I was very patient.

One time I was patient was when I went to the doctor's office. Yesterday I went to the doctor's office and the waiting room was so full that we had to stand. Because there were so many people waiting we had to wait along with them. We were number a high one, and it took us two hours just to get to sit down! It took a lot of patience because the waiting room time plus the time waiting for a doctor was about three hours. When I finally got in I felt so relieved! It felt like I had an elephant lifted off my shoulders. Even though it took a long time, it was worth it because now I am feeling better and back in school, which made all the waiting worthwhile.

Patience is sometimes hard to do if you are already excited, especially when you are eagerly anticipating a future event. But sometimes you are doing it, like if one of your family members is talking and you are waiting quietly for something else; that is a form of patience. It involves calming your inner feelings and accepting the delay without complaint, which can be a challenging but important skill to learn in daily life. Mastering this ability helps us navigate many of life's smaller frustrations with a sense of calm and understanding.

I asked my mom if I can get a phone but she said no, not yet. She explained that I can't have one until ninth grade unless I get a basic phone right now, but I would have to wait until ninth grade to get a real smartphone. I told her okay, understanding her reasoning, but then I asked when she was going to get it for me. She said you have to be patient and wait for the right time. I told her I would be patient, but I still wanted to know when that might be. She said as soon as possible, perhaps on my birthday, which felt like a specific goal. I said I’ll be patient till then and will not bug you about it anymore. That’s one time I had to be patient and learn to wait for something I really wanted.

One time me and my dad were at a store, and it was very crowded. There was a line about ten people long, and it was moving very slowly. My dad and I were starting to get impatient, shuffling our feet and sighing, so I told myself to calm down and wait my turn. But I was still not calming down, feeling restless and watching the clock. Then the very first person finally left after a long transaction, and the line moved forward one spot. Seeing this small progress, I was starting to calm down and decided to just wait for the next person to go, accepting that everything would take its own time.

My finger tips were icy as I sat and waited in the cold. The seconds tarried into minutes, which then turned into hours, stretching time unbearably. My body heat was escaping rapidly like sand in the winds, leaving me shivering. I trudged through the mud as the slick rain hammered on my skin, a punishment for my haste. I should have waited. I was patient as they explained it to me earlier, but I didn't listen to their warning. I should have waited. I should have waited, the words mixed together in my frozen mind. My bones were cold, and I was only about ten yards from home, yet it felt like a mile. My legs refused to walk as they shuddered violently. Wait, be patient, I reminded myself, trying to find a calm center. A cop car was in my parents' driveway, its lights off. I shoved my left leg through the mess of leaves and mud, knowing that patience wasn't a factor right now, only getting home was. Nine yards, eight, seven, six. I stopped, pulled my hood over my head but the wind and rain blew it off again, five, four, three, two, one. I was at my door step. I weakly raised my hand to knock. The door swung open before I could. Fast footsteps, then the door opens fully. I am showered with hugs. ''You should have waited!'' my dad cried, tears streaming down his face. I smiled weakly, finally safe and understanding the value of the patience I had abandoned.

There was a person named Alex. He wanted a specific video game for his Xbox console, thinking about it every day. But, his dad just got laid-off from his old job and his mom had a low-paying job that barely covered the bills. Since they had very little money for anything extra, he couldn’t buy the game he desired so much. A few months later, his dad finally found a new job at a local warehouse, which brought some relief to the family. But, Alex still didn’t have enough money saved for the game, so he continued to wait. A few more months passed, and with some birthday money added to his savings, Alex finally had enough for the game. His mom took him to the store to buy it, and he held the case tightly. He was very excited, his long wait finally over. He ended up loving the game very much, and the experience taught him that good things are worth waiting for patiently.

Have you ever heard your mom or dad say patience is a virtue? Well, I’ve heard it many times in my house, actually too many times. Patience is something that means you have to wait calmly, like when you wanna go see a new movie on opening night. You might have to wait in a big, long line because it’s a popular new movie, and everyone else wants to see it too. So you're gonna have to stand there and wait with patience, without complaining or getting upset about the slow-moving line. It’s all about staying calm while you wait for your turn.

A time that I was patient was during the summer break. My best friend was nice enough to invite me to Cedar Point with her family, and of course my parents said yes. It was a long two-hour car ride I think to Cedar Point, but it was fun because we brought lots of things to keep us busy. We watched a movie on my little portable DVD player, listened to music, and played some travel games. I had no trouble waiting till we got there because we were having fun. When we got to the hotel we picked our beds and then jumped in the car to go to Cedar Point; it looked so awesome. First we went on the Raptor; my eyes were watering it was so scary, then the music was so loud and fast I felt like we were going to fly off the tracks. Next we wanted to go on the Millennium Force, but the line was an hour long and we were stuck in the middle of it. So it would be useless to try to escape the line once you were in it. Then finally it was our turn to go, but the ride wasn’t working so we had to wait even longer. It wouldn’t cooperate so the ride operator told us that we could get free passes to go on any ride, and cut ahead of everyone else. We only got to do it once, but it was great. As you can see, us being patient really rewarded us in the end, and I think it was so worth the long wait!

I remember a time that I was patient when getting my first silly hamster. Patience is when you are understanding and tolerant, even when you really want something. I was very patient and happy to get my first hamster. I had to wait until the weekend to go to the pet store with my dad. And I got my first fluffy hamster. Actually, I got two of them because they were so cute together. And they are silly and they sometimes bite, but I was patient with them. And my brother was also patient when he had to wait to get his own pet fish. Patience is when you realize that you shouldn't get mad that you have to wait, and you understand that sometimes you have to be calm and wait to get the thing that you really want.

I was patient when I was waiting for a guy to ask me out, and I’m still dating him to this day. His name is Michael and yes he goes to my school. When he finally asked me out I didn't know what to say at first because he took so long to ask, and I still did not like any other guy but him. When someone is patient they don't rush through things; they wait for something or someone, just like I did. When I was patient, I didn't ask him out multiple times myself. I waited until he was ready to ask me out, because if someone doesn't like you back the same way, they might turn you down and hurt your feelings. Okay, well if you don't want to take my advice, you might just get hurt, so it's better to be patient and wait for the right moment.

I chose to write a story about a time when I was patient. It was my first time hunting; I was only hunting squirrels, but still, it was a big deal for me. What I had to do was walk quietly into the woods and find a good spot. Once you sit down you can't move or make a sound, or you will scare them away. So I was sitting very still for twenty whole minutes, listening to the woods, and finally I seen a squirrel come close. So I took my shotgun, aimed carefully, and shot her in the chest. I was patient so I got a squirrel in the end. So that’s my story on how having patience can help you succeed.

I was at the @NUM1 fair with my friends, drawn to a thrilling ride called the freak-out. The line was already long, so we decided to try some other attractions first to pass the time. Every time we looked back, the line for the freak-out had grown even longer, snaking through the crowded midway. We finally decided to just go get in line anyway, knowing the wait would be substantial. It felt like we were moving an inch every @NUM2 minutes, and I had to be very patient, shifting my weight from one foot to the other. On the inside I was ready to go nuts with anticipation, but I remained calm on the outside; it was the longest @NUM3 minutes ever!!!!, but finally we reached the front and could board the ride.

@PERSON1 and his dad were planning on going fishing on that @DATE1 @TIME1, a tradition they both enjoyed. They got everything they needed: fishing rods, a tackle box, fishing nets, bait, and a packed lunch. They drove down to the familiar lake, got into their small rowboat, and were off, the oars dipping quietly into the water. @PERSON1's dad was the first to catch something, a ten-inch smallmouth bass. It was too small so he threw it back and continued fishing. The lake was quiet today, perfectly still. There was a small breeze in the @DATE2 air, carrying the scent of pine. The sun was up but it was still a little cold, making the morning feel crisp. They sat there quietly, patiently, watching their bobbers. @PERSON1's dad got another pull on his line and quickly reeled it in. This time he caught a twenty-inch pike. Another one too small so he threw it back. ''The fish are really biting today hu?'' said his dad. But the truth was they had been out there for an hour and @PERSON1 hadn't gotten a single bite. They fished for another hour or so before taking a break to eat lunch. They just brought sandwiches, chips, and a few waters. When they were done eating they went back to fishing with renewed hope. @PERSON1 casted his line as far as he could get it to go, the lure landing with a soft plop. He sat and waited for about twenty minutes when he finally got a strong tug on his line. ''I got one. I got one,'' he told his dad, trying to reel his line in as fast as could. When he got it in the boat, they measured it carefully. @PERSON1 had caught a fourteen-inch largemouth bass. ''@CAPS1 like you caught dinner for tonight,'' said his dad with a proud smile. They stayed out about twenty more minutes then went in, heading home with a fish dinner; @PERSON1's patience had finally caught him a good fish.

When I was patient I was in a store buying something, and it was a long line so I had to wait to pay for my stuff I was buying, a simple magazine and a drink. I waited patiently, but the person in front of me had a big cart full of food and everything else, so I had to be patient when he was up. After he finally finished, I had to wait for all of the other people to get done paying for their food and anything else, each transaction taking its own time. I just stood there, looking around and practicing my patience until it was finally my turn at the register.

As I get older my tolerance for patience has grown bigger. I remember when I was six and completely foretaken when my mother had told me to wait to get my gifts on Christmas morning. After she said that I was angry at her and stomped to my room in a huff. I flopped hard on my bed and then eventually fell asleep from the frustration. My mother had come in my room later and told me I was allowed to open my presents, but before she did she said I need to have patience. Now as I’m older, I know most right from wrong attitudes, so when Christmas comes I don’t care about the gifts as much; I remember when she had told me to be patient to receive because you might not be able to get everything you want. When you're patient and listen to what your mother tells you, she can explain that you might not get a lot or what you want. So now my patience is great for most things, but since then I don't wanna rush and miss the details of what people have to say or I might get disappointed. Patience is a thing where if you don't have it, then things won't be understood sometimes and things could not turn out the way you wanted them to. Enthusiasm is different from patience. Patience means when you wait and don’t want to, while enthusiasm is when you are excited. People get those confused, so when a child is excited look for details and don’t say "be patient," say "calm down" because they could take it the wrong way if you don't tell them why. In conclusion these are ways I was taught to act, so please take my words into consideration, as they could help you understand the value of waiting.

Once before I went to @CAPS1 point with my friend @PERSON1 for a day of fun. I was patient on the long car ride there, watching the scenery pass by. I was patient in the long line to get inside the park, surrounded by crowds. I was patient in the even longer line to get on the dragster, the anticipation building with every step forward. I was patient to go on all the rides, understanding that the wait was part of the experience. Another time, I had to go to the hospital to get an echo on my heart. I was patient waiting for my results, sitting calmly in the quiet room. I am always patient, well most of the time. Once I went to @LOCATION1, and I was patient going through the slow security line. I was patient on the plane waiting to get there, enduring the cramped seat. I was patient to get off the plane when we landed, waiting for my row to be called. I was patient waiting for my luggage at the carousel. In my daily life, I have to go to school. I am patient waiting for lunch, listening to my stomach rumble. I am patient for school to be over, watching the clock tick slowly. I am patient to wait till class is over, focusing on the lesson. Like I said, I am mostly patient in these many situations.

The best ride at the amusement park was over two hours long wait, which felt like an eternity. Bad news for me become I am definintaly not a patience person. Like this one time I was waiting in line for an ice cream cone on a hot day. There was only two people in line but I didn’t want to wait so I didn’t want one anymore, I just walked away. That’s how impatience I was, but riding the best ride in the world I was willing to wait, believing it would be worth it. Two hours of waiting in line we seen a sign that said one hour from this point, which was incredibly disheartening. Very mad I kept saying to myself it’s the best ride you can wait an hour longer so I did, trying to stay positive. When we got on the ride it was fun and exciting, but the ride was only thirty seconds longer, which felt surprisingly short after such a long wait.

It's cold, it's raining, and I'm completely soaked; it's been one full hour and still no activity or movement in the woods. All I have to do is wait here quietly and hope for the best. I'm hunting deer, hoping for a clean hit with my new compound hunting bow. I'm a decent shot but not that good, so I need a close opportunity. I know patients is the key to deer hunting so I will just have to wait, no matter how uncomfortable I feel. I now see a deer, a nice buck, about fifty yard away and slowly raise my bow. I shoot carefully, and it hits true, so my patience pays off in the end with a successful hunt.

Well this story was sequenced out about ten minutes ago, right here in the classroom. When I had to keep a tremendous amount of patience and not get upset. Well as you can see there are multiple erase marks in the backround of my text, making the paper look quite messy. I accidentally wrote part two of this test on this page, using the wrong section entirely! I am so glad I had such a caring teacher that found that for me or I would’ve failed the assignment for sure! When I was sitting down at my desk quietly, working on my test, she (The teacher) walked up to me and held test up to my face, pointing at the mistake. I knew that meant something bad was wrong. When she said I did it on the wrong page, I felt a surge of panic. I almost flipped out but I held it back, taking a deep breath instead. I think patience is a great quality to have so you can get things done right and handle surprises calmly. I’m very glad I have a good amount of patience, as it really helped me in that stressful situation.

The time I waited for a party to happen was a lesson in disappointment. It was months until I’ve been invited to a party at zapzone by a friend. He told me the party was on a specific Saturday, and I was really looking forward to it. Two weeks he told me that, and still didn’t have the party; then he told that I had pay for myself accepted, which was a bit of a surprise. But it was a party so I didn’t mind too much, thinking it would be fun. Two weeks later I went school shopping for ten minutes, just a quick trip to the store. I came back he said he already had a party without me, which was confusing and hurtful. He wasn’t there because a party takes an hour or two so I just let it go, deciding it wasn't worth getting angry over.

Everybody loves Christmas, and they all have to be patient for it, counting down the days. Especially on the night before of Christmas Eve, the anticipation is almost unbearable. Everybody in my family always gets very excited and can’t wait until morning, especially me, as I love the surprises. I get so excited I can hardly sleep, tossing and turning all night. In fact, last year had to be the hardest year for waiting. It was four am on Christmas morning and I had woken up for no reason, far too early. I decided to go back to sleep and did for only about thirty minutes when I woke up again, my mind racing. I just couldn’t fall asleep no matter how hard I tried! I went downstairs with a couple blankets and tried to go to sleep on the couch when I saw the huge amount of stuff just sitting there under the tree. I sat up and looked around at them, wondering what was inside. I was so excited but I remembered that I would have to wait until everyone woke up, which felt like forever. So I tried to go back to sleep, pulling the blanket over my head. I would close my eyes and sleep for about four minutes at a time and eventually stopped trying, giving up on sleep entirely. It was five-thirty am, and the house was still quiet. I turned on the television, threw in a movie, and waited for some noise from upstairs. At six-thirty am most of my brothers were up and I couldn’t take it anymore, the wait was too long. I snapped and started to complain, asking repeatedly if we could start. I had become very impatient, my excitement turning to frustration. I finally was told yes and began to open my presents, tearing into the wrapping paper. I was finally happy and content, the long wait finally over.

A time when I was patient was when I was visiting a water park in Orlando, Florida, we were waiting in line for this water roller coaster and the line was really long and they had this line called easy pass where you wait an hour, then go to this machine to get a eazy pass ticket but we decided to wait in the really, long line. So half an hour later went by and I started to get really board so I asked my dad if he wanted to play this game called slapps, which is a hand-slapping game. So we played for a little while and time went past and we were about half way there and we started regreting stay in the huge line because it had already been an hour so and we only move to the half way market. About ten minutes later I stopped playing slapps with my dad because my hands were beat red and his hands were barrely even red if that, so we decided to take a break from the game. So we just waited and waited until we were there three quarters the way there, watching other people get on the ride ahead of us. After about ten to twenty minutes later we were finally boarding the raft, feeling a mix of exhaustion and excitement. We went through a cave then stopped like fourty feet then splashed in to a huge amount of water, getting completely soaked and laughing. It turns out that wait was worth it for that thrilling finale. So that is a time when I showed patients and learned that good things can come from enduring a long wait.

One time when I was patient was when we were flying to Hawaii. We were in the terminal waiting to board our connecting flight. God I thought how long can this take, just sitting in those uncomfortable plastic chairs. But evenaly the plane came and we were able to get on. Once on I thought ok this is the last plane we have to take today, so I can manage. But then the pilot said it was to be a seven hour flight across the ocean. Then I looked around to see what I had to do to pass the immense amount of time. I had my I-pod, a book, and the seatback screen in front of me with its limited entertainment options. Once we were in the air I thought I would take a nap to make the time go faster. But that only killed a hour so then I decided to watch a movie from the selection. I watched a popular action film. That took off another two hours, which was a good chunk of time. By then I was starting to get bored and a little restless in my seat. I decied I would read the novel I had brought with me. But after an hour and a half I finished the book and was left with nothing else to read. Then my I-pod come out and I scrolled through my playlists. I listened to music until lunch came a hour later, which was a welcome distraction. After eating lunch which took about thirty minutes I decided to watch another movie to continue killing time. I watched a long comedy which killed off enough two hours. Then with only two hours left I wanted to watch season four of the office, which I had saved for this part of the trip. Then when there was only thirty minutes left when they cut everything down for landing I watched us land in Hawaii out the window. It was long but I was patient and stuck through it, and I was finally rewarded with the tropical breeze.

When I have patient is when I go out to eat, because I have learned that being impatient can cause problems. So no one can speat in, my food if I just wait calmly. Like one time I went out to eat with my family to a nice restaurant. And we all was dress alike for my birthday, which was really fun. So I ask my daddy to tell them that my birthday is to day because I was excited. And I wanted a piece of cake now, right after my meal. So he want to tell what I said and they said they would be with us in a minute. So I waited and waited, tapping my fingers on the table. And finly I got so impatient I said bring me a piece of cake now or I will have this place brun down, which was a silly thing to say. Then my dad said bring her a piece cause she can have that happen, trying to calm me down. So they finly bring my cake with a little candle on it. We climbed in the rental car waving goodbye to realitives as we drive back to the airport after a wonderful family reunion. ìI canít believe that the airport had an opening earlier in the day and called us? As we rolled into the airport smelling that familiar strafoam smell, and checked in our bags at the counter. ìWe need three tickets to Chicago, please.î my mother explained to the clerk behind the desk. ìI'm sorry according to this your flight is fullî she told us through a chessy, insincere smile. ìBut you called saying there was empty seats and invited us to exchange our tickets for this earlier flight.î my mother replied, confused. ìI'm sorry ma'am it wouldnt be fair if we gave away seats that were rightful owned by other passengers.î she said again with another chessy smile, not helping at all. ìWell, you can have your orginal tickets back if you like,î she offered, for a flight leaving seven hours later. Seven hours! What am I going to do for seven hours in this airport! First my brother and I had races up and down the escelators until a security guard told us to stop. Then we took the shuttle bus everywhere around the airport terminals, just for something to do. By the third hour I knew the place inside out, every shop and every gate. Soon it time to leave for our new flight, but suddenly the speaker came on announcing our flight to Chicago has been deylayed by an hour and a half. Nine hours now really? This is torture! Luckly my mother took me to an extotic restraunt in the airport to pass more time. It was a beautiful restraunt with fancy decorations, a nice distraction. I felt happy that we finally left the airport, but also a little sad that our vacation was truly over. I learned a great lesson about patience during that long day! Itís not hard to be patient, and it is not impossible, it just takes practice.

A time when I was patience is when our family goes to Adventure point. My family and I go to Adventure point a lot. Usually, the lines are very long, sometimes over and hour! What is patience? Patience means that you are understanding and tolerant of delays or problems without becoming annoyed or anxious. A patient person experiences difficulties without complaining most people are impatient these days. Patience is like waiting calmly. For example, if you are in a traffic jam, in a long line at the store, or maybe you have to wait your turn for something. Patience is one of the best qualities someone could have. Every year more people become impatient. People want people to hurry or move faster. They need to gain patience by taking deep breaths or calming down and counting to ten. I think the world would be more peaceful if everybody had patience there would be no more conflict and if that happened some day, everybodies lives would be perfect and much more pleasant.

Being patient is a very hard thing to do, and most people are very bad at it, though some are good. I am one of the people that are bad at it. The hardest thing I have ever done in my entire life was wait in line for three and a half hours just to ride the dragster at cedar point. It was a very hot and sticky summer day and cedar point was packed. There were flies everywhere, tickling your legs, buzzing in your ear, and even biting you. You could hear the screams from a mile away, and overweight people were wearing shorts and tank-tops, eating popcorn. It was brutal! I had ridden every ride except for the dragster. The dragster is the ride that takes you up to the very top and shoots you down as fast as a bullet. The only problem was, if you wanted the first cart, which I did, it was a three and a half hour wait! “Mom, can I just go ride the skyscraper again?” I pleaded. “No! We came all the way to Ohio; we are not going to leave without riding the best, funnest ride! You are going to stand in this line and wait!” Mom quickly replied. “Fine! I never get what I want, do I!” “You get everything you want. You can go ride the skyscraper again if you want, but I am staying here! And I feel bad for whoever has to sit by you because they are going to have bruises and scratches all over their arms. Heck, you might pop their eardrum from screaming so much!” “Well, I don’t wanna put somebody else through that pain, but you I might!” By the time we were done fighting, there were only twenty minutes left, and we didn’t get the front cart, but the wait wasn’t even that bad in the end.

A time when I was patient was when I was helping a kid in my class on his project. We were doing a science project, and this kid didn’t understand anything about it. He would put things in the wrong place, write down things that didn’t go with science, and he didn’t listen to anything, so he was doing it correctly but then he lost it! I couldn’t believe he lost all of our hard work! So we started over, and I helped him more and was very patient with him, carefully explaining each step again. After three long days, we were almost done with it. When he was done putting the final touches on it, he presented it and got an A+ on it; he got an A+ on it, and it made me feel so good. I got rewarded for my hard work and for me being patient with him. To the end, being patient makes you feel good and the person you helped feels good, too. This was a time when I was patient and learned the value of it.

There once was a little girl named Kerry who was the important girl in the land of Narrative. Narrative was a little land filled with loving and patient people who waited for everything. And every child was patient but Kerry. Kerry was an only child living with her mother and father. Kerry hated being the only child, so Kerry's mother named Mom told her husband Dad that they should have another child so that Kerry would not be alone. Soon they told Kerry that she would be having a little brother or sister. Kerry was very happy. In fact, Kerry was so happy that she ran upstairs and began to make up baby names. Then she ran down stairs and shared them with her mother rocking in her chair. “I like Kevin,” said Dad walking toward the dinner table where Kerry and her mother were sitting. “Okay,” said Kerry cleaning the table. “Do you like Billy, Bobby, Ohio, Sammy, Tommy, or Ronnie?” said Kerry. “I like Lily,” said Dad pushing in his chair. “Me as well,” said Mother walking up stairs toward her bed room. “I can't wait till the baby gets here,” said Kerry on her way up the stairs. The next morning Kerry awoke early to see if her mother had the baby. “Mom, you have the baby yet?” said Kerry waking up her mother and Dad. “No,” said the Dad, “the baby has to grow inside of mommy, okay?” “Okay,” said Kerry. Nine months later, Kerry got up very early screaming, “Is it here, Mom, did it come?” “No,” said the mother lifting her head over her belly to see Kerry. “That baby will never come, I hate that thing, I will be lonely forever!” said Kerry walking toward her bed room. “Be patient, she will come!” screamed Dad from the other room. “She?” said Kerry, “It’s a girl?” Kerry got very much happy. Nine hours later, “Oh, oh, oh!” screamed Mother from her bedroom. “Are you okay, Mommy?” said Kerry walking into Mother's bedroom. “The baby is coming, call your Dad!” said Mother. “Kerry, yes, Mother is going to have to deliver this baby, okay?” Three hours later, Dad came home running up the stairs and went in his room and saw Kerry, his wife Mom, and the new baby Lily fast asleep. “Told you if you were patient she would come,” said Dad talking to himself.

Some stories of when I was patient are when I needed a teacher’s help, when my grandma had surgery, waiting for my turn in sports, and waiting for my mom at work. When my grandma had surgery, we waited for three hours in the hospital. During that time, I played chess with my aunt to pass the time. I also talked with my family to keep our minds occupied. We went to the gift shop there to look around. Also, we went to the mall nearby to get some food. Another time, the teacher gave us homework and I did not understand a part of it. The teacher was helping a different person, so I waited patiently at my desk. I skipped the difficult part and came back later; by then the teacher could help me. Then I finally understood the homework. Sometimes, my mom took me to her job after school or I would have been alone at home. While waiting for her to finish work, I mopped the floor to be helpful. I rested my head and put it on the table when I was tired. I talked with some of the employees and passed time by walking back and forth in the hallway. These are the stories about a time I was patient and managed through different situations.

A time when my dad was patient was when he had an important meeting with his boss, but the boss did not come yet. So my dad sat down and waited calmly. He waited and waited, and two hours later the boss came and said, “John, you wait for another hour because I need to talk to your wife because she is saying she really needs to talk to me.” My dad said, “Okay, but hurry!” An hour passed, and finally the boss came. He came and said to my dad, “Thank you for waiting.” Finally, he was done with his meeting. I said, “Dad, what took you so long?” He said, “Be patient.” That’s the time my dad became patient and showed great composure.

''If you would try to be patient and maybe you wouldn't be complaining''.  ''I'll try'' she says, then hangs up. Sure I think I am so mad that she thinks she can just apologize and it would be all better. She should've waited. I fonly she'd been patient, our friendship might feel more solid now.

“Can we watch @ORGANIZATION1.” I looked at the clock.
