I am never a patient person. Whether it's waiting for dinner to be ready or waiting for a friend to arrive, I am never patient. The only time I can be genuinely patient is when I'm waiting for school to start; I can wait hours, days, weeks, months, or even years if I'm waiting for that. Then again, the thing I can never be patient for is waiting for a friend to call, because I always want to be doing something every single second. I will run around the house for hours, pacing from room to room, until a friend finally calls. And when they do call, I rush right to the phone and answer it on the first ring. I will even sit there and stare at the phone, willing it to ring, waiting for someone to call. Another thing I can be patient for, however, is waiting for my mom to tell me to clean my room. I will always leave the house and try not to come back until bedtime just so I will never have to hear those words and clean my room.

My cousin was incredibly patient when we were waiting in line for the top thrill @CAPS1 at Cedar Point. The line almost took @NUM1 hours to get through. My cousin was just simply silent the entire time, calm and composed, and just waiting without a fuss. I, on the other hand, was very impatient. I was tapping my feet, running around in the little space we had, and so on. I was about to die of boredom. My legs hurt from standing, I was getting hungry, and I was feeling too hot in the sun. I just couldn't stand it anymore. She was just standing there, not talking or complaining at all. When the line started to move, I got a little happier but was still fundamentally impatient. After @NUM1 long hours, we finally got onto the ride. After the ride was over, I asked my cousin why she had been so silent the whole time. She said that her mom had warned that for every word one of us said, we would have to do an extra minute of homework when we came back to @LOCATION1. I was stuck doing homework for the entire next week. That's how I learned my lesson to be more patient in the future.

Being patient means that when you're in a bad situation, you don't complain and you endure it calmly. Some people aren't very patient and some are very patient. In my eyes, patience is very important, and I like to think of myself as sort of patient, or at least I think I am. One time I had to be very patient was when my family had to drive fourteen hours to get to @LOCATION1; it was not a fun experience. One bad thing about it was you always had to go to the bathroom at the most inconvenient times. Once you have the privilege to go when you want gets taken away, then you want it even more. But I kept saying to myself, be patient, we’ll stop at the next place. Another thing was you were always hungry or thirsty at the wrong moments. We only stopped three times the whole trip, and that was not fun. Also, whenever you did get food, it never seemed to be enough. But I didn’t complain out loud. Lastly, you just really want to get there; you couldn’t wait for the sandy beaches and the crashing waves. It seemed like we would never get there, and it was not the best experience. When we finally arrived, I realized that the entire trip was like a big test of patience and I passed, and actually, it wasn't nearly as bad as the long trip back home.

One day I went to the hospital, and the nurses gave me an IV, a cat scan, and had to pull tape off my arm. It hurt so bad, but I was patient through all of it. First, when I was getting the cat scan, I did not want to do it at all, but we had to, so I did it and was very patient and still. Also, when they gave me my IV, they missed my vein, so they ripped it out and put it in my other arm; I was very patient for the sharp pain to go down. Lastly, when I was done at @NUM1 o'clock pm, having started at @NUM1 o'clock am, there was a big piece of tape on my arm for @NUM3 hours. The nurse came and said, "We can go home now," and then said, "You can take the tape off now, sweetie." I said, "Okay," and I started to pull it off piece by piece. Then the nurse said, 'Here, let me do it!' She said, "@NUM4, @NUM5, @NUM6," and ripped it all off at once. It hurt so bad, but I was patient and didn't cry or make a sound. Now you know that I was patient even though I was hurt all day long.

I was patient when my dad said he would get me some new basketball shoes. They were the latest style and the exact color I wanted, but the shoes cost a hundred dollars. I asked a few times over the next week. He didn`t answer, so I knew what to do to show I was responsible. I decided to wash the dishes every night and keep my room perfectly clean. I wanted the shoes so bad; I cleaned stuff that was already clean, like wiping down shelves and organizing my closet. After a month of the constant cleaning, I still didn`t get the shoes. Thatís how something went wrong at school. I haven`t been acting right in school because I was so disappointed. I realized I had to get my stuff together and focus on my work. Then I got the reward.

Don't you just love waiting for something to come or happen and when it does you realize it was all worth waiting for? I know I do! Sometimes its too long of a wait and you just have to be patient. Patience is very important. I have had to use patience many times before. Recently, I have had to use patience. I used it to wait for my baby cousin Emma to be born. I had to wait a long time, thirty-eight weeks to be exact! I was just so excited I couldnt keep myself together. Now just yesterday she was born. The wait is over and I feel a great relief. Although, I still have to be patient to see her. But not much longer only untill I get out of school today. I have been waiting so long I can't even stand it! Every single day I used to mark it off on my calendar. I used to tell myself every morning that she will be here soon. But, the days never seam to go by fast enough. I kept asking my mom each evening, how many more days. It was pure agony! As the day approached I got more and more excited. She had gotten a lot of tiny clothes from people at her baby shower. I had to be even more patient to even see the clothes on her. I also had to be patient to finally hold her. Although I did already say a while back that I got to be the first cousin to hold her. Now that she is born and finally here, I get to be the first one to hold her, I can stop counting down, get to see her in her new clothes and can stop bothering my mom every day. So, all in all patience is important. If you use it, the thing you are waiting for is much better when you finally get it.

Patience is a kind thing, people being patient, but still complaining about it thats not patience at all. Patience is waiting calmly and being kind while your doing it. People that loose their patience easily really is not cool, its nice when someone waits for you without getting upset if say your on the phone talking to someone else, or even on the internet or something loading slowly. Its very poliete if you have patience, I donít know the exact definition of it but am just gonna guess, I think its a person waiting patiencently and quietly on the other person even if they need to get somewhere or are in a bit of a hurry themselves. It shows respect for the other person's time and situation.

A long time ago when I was seven I was going to be able to ride on the roller coaster; this ride is thrilling for everyone, said Alex. The adventure park was a fun place with many exciting attractions. As I was waiting in the long line to ride the coaster I was getting very impatient. This is when my brother said calm down we are half way through. "No I cant this is a long line," replied Alex. "Well here is what you do to speed up the time, try to tell her the reason in hand on behave or talk with us," he suggested. "Okay?" replied Alex. So I was to talk to the people in front of me and we ever to the ride already in line and found out a lot about them. I thanked my brother for the good information. I managed to find a way to pass the time. Thats a patient time about me, Alex, and the help of my brother.

Patience is a quality or characteristic of a person. It is not easy to be patient, but some people are very patient. Especially when you know you want to be mad at someone, but you donít. My older brother was always patient with me, especially the time I look back at and wish I could erase. It was that night I was going to stay at Aunt Mary and Uncle John's, my aunt and uncles. I had always had trouble staying places because I got home sick and cried. That is exactly what happened that night I regret. My cousins Lisa and Sarah, and I were playing board games in their room. I couldnít stop thinking of my mom. I told myself over and over ìstiff upper lip.î I had forgotten about her for a while then the feeling came agian, so I thought of how much fun I would have tomorrow if I just stayed the night. It didnít work tears rolled faster than rain falls. ìI want to go homeî I managed to sniffle. I ran downstairs to tell my older cousin Jessica, who was babysitting. She finally opened her door and brought me upstairs to get the phone. My mom answered and relized it was my voice and said ìwhat is itî all grouchy. I had sniffled and said ìI want to come home, I miss you.î and sniffled more. ìSomeone will pick you up soon. Be packed and ready.î She said and hung up. I sadly told Lisa and Sarah as I packed and waited on the wooden bench by the door. Soon enough a car came up the driveway and honked. It was my dad, I said bye once more and went out into the cold, wind and hopped in his car. ìWhy didnít you want to stay?î my dad asked calmly. ìI donít know.î And it wasnít brought up until I walked through our front door. I already knew my punishment, no more staying the night somewhere for a couple weeks, and I knew I deserved it.

I had to be patient many times. I had to be patient when my brother broke his ear-drum, I was waiting for x-rays, waiting to go on stage. These are sometimes when I had to be patient. When my brother broke his ear-drum I was about five years old. I had to wait with my brother in the hospital waiting room. It felt like forever. It was winter, I was in my pjs, and so bored but worried about my brother. In fifth grade I hit my wrist in a door and a wall. I was in the emergency room for four to five hours, but they were very good at their job. My mom and I were stuck watching the same show on the tv they had. It was very cold in the waiting room plus I had a cold pack on my wrist. Finally, I was waiting to go on stage for my fifth grade concert. I was so nervous and the nerves kept growing. I waited for twenty min but it felt like twenty years. I was sitting next to my friend which helped a little. When we got on stage I sang my heart out and was happy I waited. Those are sometimes which I had to be patient. I am not good at being patient, but I waited and got good results in the end.

Have you ever been patient? I have, especially this one main time in my life. That one main time in my life was when I was waiting for my dog to have her babies. My dogs name is Daisy Mae she is three years old and is full blooded pitbull. It all started when we took Daisy to the vet for her early check up. The vet said she was all good, then pulled my mom to the side. My heart was pumping faster than ever because usually when they pull the parents to the side it means something bad. My mom screamed and rejoiced. I ran to her and she screamed “Daisy is going to have babies” then I screamed with her. We went and got dog food and then we took her to the bark park and that night she got her very own steak at supper. The next few months were going by faster than ever. Well at least it seemed like it. Now Daisy was getting bigger. The vet said it should be six months at least until she has the puppies it`s already been five and half, mom said, that she has milk now. I told my sister, that evening. “I wouldn`t doubt it,” said my sister then we went and took Daisy inside for the night. The next day while I was getting ready for school my mom said hey sweetheart I called the vet and he said that he wouldn`t be surprised if Daisy had her puppies today then I said oh cool but let`s not rush Daisy she`s going through a lot right now. Then we said our goodbyes and I went to the bus stop. The bus ride usually takes like an hour to school but today it only felt like thirty minutes. The day was going by fast. Before I knew it I was home, I walked in the front door and my mom said “oh your just in time honey Daisy is having her babies” we both ran into the garage faster than ever Daisy was laying on a blanket, I rushed to her and she licked my hand. I told her everything is going to be alright. I went inside to get her a bowl of water and some soft food and when I come back out she already had two puppies. It took about an hour for the other two and then another hour for the other two after them. Turns out they were all girls. Now we have eight dogs at my house. The mom Daisy Mae, the dad Buddy, and all six little girl puppies, Cutie, Boots, Tinker, Bella, Harmony and Melony. I love my dogs and the patience was worth it.

On my birthday we went to go get a cake. I wanted an ice cream cake. It was over twenty people there. I did not have any patience. But my mom did. It was a playground near it. So I went to go play. While my mom got the cake she came and got me and we went to celebrate my party. It was a fun day that taught me a little about waiting.

Patience can lead to rewards, Barney the brown bear learned that one day when he was in line to get an autograph from his favorite singer. He might have been very frustrated but he just stayed calm and looked forward to meeting her. One day Barney seen a big news headline in a newspaper. He put a coin in the machine and opened the newspaper holder to grab one, it was jammed. He went into the gas station to tell the people but they were not there, he hit the top of the bell and nobody came. Barney was trying to be as patient as possible. He went to a different store and got a newspaper there. The big news was that his favorite star, Bella, was going to be in town. Barney hurried to the town and seen the line that was very long. He was so excited to see Bella. Barney got to the line at noon and has been there for one hour and she only got a few autographs done. This was going to be a long day for Barney. Barney got a hot dog and a soda from the sidewalk food business at two p.m. Barney was still the last person in line his patience went down quite a bit. At five p.m. there were only five people including him there. He finally got to Bella at six p.m. Bella and her crew notified Barney that he won the patience contest. They told him he gets to see her in concert, gets her phone number and wins a date with her. He was so happy he kept himself patient for five hours. Barney was about to blow his top but knew he would never forgot this moment. Also, Barney ended up being Bella’s boyfriend. That is when Barney learned that patience can pay off in the end.

When I was patient. There was a time when I was patient. There are more and more ways I get more patient when I’m not in no hurry to do something. I’m going to tell you a true story when I was patient. And I was not in a hurry to get it done. My first day at school and we was having fun with a bunch of people and on that first day we had work. When we started to do it some people was not patient. I looked around the bright room and I was thinking about how should I be patient, “just be patient I said” to myself I have to take the time and I could reach a good grade and so I was patient. The next day I was ready to see my grade on that work. I had a fun time and that’s the day when I was patient and taking my time, which really helped me.

A time when I was patient was when I went to the amusement park. I was patiently waiting for my turn to get on the rollercoaster, a wait that lasted for an hour and a half in the warm sun. I was also patiently waiting in a long, slow-moving line when I had to get something to eat from a crowded concession stand. Furthermore, I was patient when I wanted to get on any of the other popular rides, each requiring a significant amount of time standing in queue. That is a time when I was patient, enduring the lengthy waits for the enjoyable experiences that followed.

A time when I was patient was last summer. My friend, Sarah, took me to Cedar Point in Ohio. The place was so packed, it took five minutes just to get from the car to the entrance through the throngs of people. As we got in, the place looked amazing with its colorful rides and cheerful music! It was almost like a dream come true for any thrill-seeker. They even had a small train ride to take you from one part of the vast park to another. The first ride we went on was the Magnum XL-200. We waited, and waited for about ten minutes and then things got boring as the line barely moved. It had been almost fifteen minutes and we weren’t even close to the ride's platform! So we waited, and waited about ten more minutes, and things finally got a little faster as the line began to advance steadily. At this part, the line was moving a little faster, raising our spirits. Finally, it was our turn to ride. We were assigned a yellow car, and you could feel the adrenaline already starting to pump. After we were strapped in securely, the ride operator who locks people’s seats said “go!” and we took off like a bird soaring into the sky. In the end, the thrilling speed and the incredible view made it worth being patient.

Have you ever been a patient? Like at the doctor’s office? Well let me tell you a time I have. One time I was really sick with a high fever and I started crying because I was in a lot of pain. I was crying for an hour straight, feeling miserable. Then my mom decided to take me to the hospital where she works as a nurse. When I got out of the car, I somehow stopped crying, distracted by the large building. I told my mom that I stopped crying but she told me firmly that I still had to go see the doctor. When we went in we seen this man rushed to the emergency room on a stretcher. We went right to the waiting room and all the seats were taken up by other sick people. When Dr. Evans came out she asked a man to come in to see her with his young son. That fortunate event gave us two seats to sit in while we continued to wait. After about twenty minutes she called us in to a small, clean medical room. She examined me with her stethoscope and I was really scared because I thought I might have pneumonia or a very bad virus. When she came out of her small office I was holding my mom’s hand tightly for comfort. She came unto us holding a small piece of paper and my mom asked her anxiously what I had. Luckily she said I only had a bad cold and an ear infection, which was a relief. When we walked out of the patient room, my mom had to stop at the front desk to pay. She only had to pay about thirty dollars for the visit. We had to go get my medicine, so we walked to the elevator, went down to the ground floor, and went into the hospital pharmacy. The pharmacy was so full of people waiting, I felt like a pancake under another pancake in the crowd. When we finally got to the counter, my mom asked for my medicine and she got it along with a big lolly pop for me. When I got home I took some of the medicine immediately and went straight to bed. The following day I woke up feeling a bit better and about noon I got to have the lollypop as a treat. That was a time when I was patient through a long and frightening experience.

One day my sister was ordering a dress with a pair of shoes and a matching handbag from a magazine. But when she was ordering it they said the item was temporarily out of stock and would be delayed. The customer service representative explained that it had not yet arrived at their warehouse. You would have to wait, they told her. Rosy said, "no thank you for now, I know it will arrive eventually," said my sister with a sigh. The next two months passed and the dress had still not been delivered. Then the magazine company called and said, “we are very sorry for the late arrival of your dress, and to thank you for your patience we will offer it at no charge.” Pleasantly surprised, she ordered two more dresses from the same company and they arrived the very next day, which made her still happy with the final outcome.

I am not a patient person by nature. I hate waiting for anything and everything, from a late bus to a slow internet connection, and I often complain about difficulties with myself and others. I play volleyball on a team for my school, which really tests my limits. There are a few girls on my team that completely kill my patience during every practice and game. I am sure the other girls on my team feel the same way about them. These few girls are pretty nice people off the court, but volleyball is just not the right sport for them. In practice, one of these girls doesn't even try to improve her skills. She even said so herself that she is going to skip a few practices, and that casual attitude was driving me insane. Another girl tries pretty hard, but she is boring to play with, overly controlling on the court, and she thinks she knows absolutely everything there is to know about volleyball strategy. I think she made one successful overhand serve in all these years of playing volleyball, and now she thinks she can do it perfectly every single time. She can rarely even serve underhand correctly, for crying out loud! This third girl, oh my god I don't even know where to begin on how much of my patience goes into dealing with her. She was probably the worst player on the team before, and now that she has broken her pinky finger, she could be even worse considering how she hasn't played in about three weeks. But since she's still part of the team, she goes to all of our games and discusses plays with us and trys to act cool but fails miserably at it. It is actually kind of funny to watch sometimes. Now, I knew that these girls needed quite a bit of practice to improve, and I know it wont happen overnight as skills take time to develop. But I guess I'll just have to put up with them for the sake of the team and keep reminding myself to be patient.

Patience is hard for me. I am simply an impatient person. Patience in my life is a rare occurrence, so I will describe a time that I was patient. “You can get it this time,” I encouraged myself. I stared at the net, a tall and imposing barrier. The net was the obstacle. If the net was shorter I would be able to get my volleyball serve over. I took a deep breath, trying to calm my racing thoughts. I balanced the white ball in the palm of my hand. I lowered my left arm and raised it again quickly, sending the ball high above my head. I thrust my hand forward. Thwap! I struck the ball, but it went barrelling into the net. “Come on, focus,” I think. “You got this!” my entire team stared at me, their silent support giving me a little more strength. Clunk, clunk. I bounce the ball twice, spin it around once in my hand. I will myself not even to look in the crowd, blocking out all distractions. My hand strikes the ball. It flies over the net and smacks into the middle of the court. A wave of relief and joy washed over me. Since I was patient and didn’t give up, I achieved my goal. This taught me one thing. Patience brings victory.

Patience is something you have to work on. I do not have a lot of patience; I do not like waiting at all because it is not fun. I do not like waiting, because being patient is boring and five minutes feels like twenty minutes. Then when you wait you start something and then as soon as you start its time. Waiting for a package is the worst. You wait and you sit and wait, then you forgot about it and then it comes. One day I was waiting to go to my friend's house; it felt like forever since I’ve seen her but it had only been about ten months. I missed her like crazy. We have been planning this for weeks and it was finally the day I get to go over there. Now I was only waiting on my dad to drive me, and he takes forever. Finally we got in the truck, but the waiting wasn't over. We were waiting at a red light for what felt like five minutes. Then he gets a phone call and drove away slowly while talking. I swear we got stopped at every red light from my house to my friend's house and got stuck behind the slowest drivers so that made it worse. When we finally got there, I jumped out of the truck, ran through the door and down the stairs, almost tripping down each one in my haste. She practically jumped on me and we were hugging for like five minutes. That is why I’m not patient, because the waiting is always so agonizing.

My story is about a time I was patient. One day I was so excited because it was Halloween and my friends and I were going trick or treating. I was so impatient for the clock to turn five pm because my best friend was going to pick me up in her pink convertible and we would go trick or treating. I was very impatient because it was only noon, so I did my chores thinking time will fly by. So I did my chores, but my mind was elsewhere. Instead of putting dish soap in the dish washer, I put grapes in the dish washer. When the dishwasher was done I emptied it and all the dishes smelled like grapes. So I looked at the clock and it was only one o'clock. Then I remembered that my favorite movie was on so I ran to my room but instead I ran into the wall and got knocked out. After a few hours I was fine, so I told my mom that I will be patient because I don’t want to get knocked out again. On the bright side I told myself I only have a few hours and some minutes to go, so I went to my room and watched some T.V. until eleven twenty, so I had an hour to get ready to go trick or treating. But first, before I did my make up, I went into the kitchen and I put all the grape smelling dishes in the dishwasher and washed them the right way. Then I put my costume on; I was a bumblebee. Then I put my make up on; I looked so cool. Finally the clock turned to five and suddenly I heard a horn; my friend was here. So I got in the car and we went to pick up Cate. I almost forgot to tell you that my friend was a ladybug, Cate was a witch, so then we went trick or treating. So that's a time when I was patient and it all worked out in the end.

I remember, just a few days ago, my mother had to get her tooth checked out and guess what I did, I read a book! The waiting room was quiet and I tried to focus on the story. Even though it took forever, I was done with my twenty minutes of homework while I waited. When my mom finally came back we got up to leave and my feet were numb from sitting for so long. So far my patience was tested, but then we got ice cream as a treat. So you could get rewarded if you’re just patient and wait without complaining. It was a good lesson learned.

I must admit there are times when I’m not very patient. But I can still remember the day I learned what patience was. I was seven years old and I was going to my annual checkup at the doctor's office. It was around ten am on a Tuesday morning. I was with my mother in the waiting room, when an elderly man came in. He seemed extremely sick and I remember being really scared. The woman at the front desk came up to us and said it would be a wait; she explained that the man was very ill and could be dying. My mother told me to be patient but I didn’t know what that meant, so she explained it to me. She said, “You have to wait quietly and not complain no matter how long it takes.” I told her I could do it and sure enough I could, sitting still and looking at a magazine. Patience is a very important thing to me. I feel it is not only for yourself but for the consideration of others. When you complain about having to wait it is disrespectful to others who may need more attention. And I know other people are patient for me, so I should be for them also. It is a simple act of kindness that makes the world a better place.

Being patient isn’t that hard if you try. It was a Tuesday afternoon and I needed help with my math homework but the teacher was helping someone else. So I waited for my turn. Five minutes past and they still weren’t done so I decided to skip that problem. Ten minutes past and yet they still weren’t done so I just waited and waited. Then finally they were done, but it was only two minutes before class ended. Oh well, I guess I’ll give it another try and if I still don’t get it I’ll ask her tomorrow. So while I was trying to figure it out it just wasn’t making sense so I waited until the next day to ask her. So the next day in class I asked her about it and she said that we didn’t have to do that one and I laughed and told her I had tried to figure it out all yesterday. That is an example of being patient.

One day I spent a night over my best friend's house for two days and ended up going to school with her. Mind you all of my clothes and shoes were over her house still. I wasn’t really able to get my clothes because right after school I went out to eat. I was really angry because I left my brand new white shoes so I called her and told her to bring them to school. The next day I was really looking forward to getting them and I confronted her about it and she says she forgot so I gave her until the following Monday and she still didn’t give them back. Notice I was very patient with her and this was the month of September. I finally got them back in the month of November. Finally she gave them back and you will never believe that I am still friends with her because my shoes were worn out and dirty but I had to realize that she’s a good friend and I’m a patient person.

A time where I was patient was when I had to go to the eye doctor. I was in a rush because I was running late. It was Thursday and my appointment was at three o’clock. I was at least fifteen minutes away from the place. When we got there it was basically three fifteen, so I missed my appointment. I had to wait in the waiting room for a long time; my mother and I had to wait until all the people who made their appointment were finished. We waited at least an hour and a half. As I was being patient I talked on the phone and went on the internet. Lastly I listened to music the rest of the time until they called my name. In conclusion this is a time when I was patient.

"Hey, just sit down, my friend says. You don't need to be moving around like you're a fly on the wall." I sit down anxious to get up and move again. "There's too many people here we're never getting in," I say. The line was the longest to get my driving test, so I'm thinking to myself to get up and move around because I'm not a very patient person. I should be able to move around while I wait, but my friend thinks its annoying and awkward. "Hey, I wonder if they had a vending machine here." "I doubt it," I proclaim. My friend glances at me and I turn away. I got up and I walked away. I came back ten minutes later and my friend was gone. I sat down and talked on the phone for a little while. I sat and looked at everyone wondering who to talk to because I was bored. I wanted to get up so bad and move around but I would look like I was walking in a circle and plus my friend left. I sat and waited; thirty minutes past and we were getting close to 2:00 p.m. I was number fifteen and I'm number sixteen so I knew I was next. "Number sixteen, you're next," I think in my head like, "finally." I get up and walk to the teller. "Thank you for your patience, now how can I help you?" I looked at her and said, "Hello, I would like a driving test please." When I got my paper to go in I thought to myself that I wasn't patient because it seemed like I was there for like a cazillion hours. I thought again and think maybe I was patient; it was probably the boredom that made me impatient because I had no one to goof off with. So maybe I was patient after all. I never was patient in like forever but I did wait because I was ready to leave. "What was the wait? The driver's ed teacher says." Honestly I felt patient enough to be there for about two hours. This is the time I never knew but now I know I was patient enough to wait.

Patience is about waiting for something and not complaining about it. When you are patient you wait for something without complaining. If you are waiting for something and you start to complain that means you don't have much patience. It isn't really good to not have patience. Some people do not have patience at all, and if they don't that is not good. If you do have patience that is good, but some people don't and it is not good, because if something that you have to wait for is important, and you have no patience that could be bad. Some people have good patience but sometimes even if you have good patience you can still sometimes complain. And that is what patience is.

A time I had to be patient was at the doctor's office. The clock on the wall went around and around, its slow ticking marking the time. It was so boring I started to say the abc's forwards and backwards to pass the time. Every time a doctor came out, they did not call my name. I sat and sat with nothing to do, watching others leave. I tried to fall asleep, but the stiff chairs made that impossible. I tried to watch t.v., but the only thing that was on was the news and a boring documentary. Finally, after two long hours, they called me in, and I was so relieved the wait was finally over.

One time when me and my mom were patients was when we had to sit and wait for my mom to get her new license tags because it was her birthday that day. So it all started that morning; we had woken up, ate breakfast, and took our showers. We put on our clothes, did our hair, and brushed our teeth. By the time all that was about done, it was nearly ten o'clock. After we did all of that, we had left the house and then we had stayed in the car for a while, just buying time. We had got to the DMV and took our number, and we were both hungry so we stopped at a burger king on the way home. The long, slow wait at the crowded office made that the day I truly had to be patient.

Before, when I had to go to the doctor for a check-up, I had to wait forty minutes in the waiting room. So I just played my Nintendo Switch to pass the time. I was playing Mario Kart, racing against the computer. I got bored after a few races, so I just fell asleep in the chair. My mom woke me up because it was finally my turn. So we went in, did my appointment quickly, and went home. Then, at home, we had to wait another twenty minutes for my dad to get home from work before we could have dinner, testing my patience all over again.

Last month, I had to go get a root canal. I was very nervous about the procedure. I arrived at the dentist office, half scared to death by the thought of the pain. There were two people in front of me, so I had to wait my turn, which made me even more scared. The time had finally come for me to go back with the dentist. I was patient the whole time, staying calm and still in the chair. After it was done, I was fine; it didn’t even hurt. When I got home, I fell asleep from the relief, but I woke up in pain though, my tooth felt on fire. I never complained though, and when my mom was trying to hurry with my medicine, I never yelled at her to hurry or cried. This was the time that I was truly patient through a difficult experience.

This story is how I have been patient waiting for my birthday in three days. I have been patient by wanting to see what I get for my birthday even though it bugs me really bad! Also I’ve been patient because I’m having a sleepover with all my close friends. It seems like it is taking forever for the days to pass. At my sleepover there is going to be cake and ice cream! I can hardly wait! I’ve also been patient because I'm turning twelve, which is a big deal. Finally I’ve been patient by not asking all my friends if they are coming, even though some girls forget to ask their parents and it bothers me because there is only two days left. This story showed how I have been patient waiting for my birthday, but you have to be patient to do fun things, a lesson I have learned just recently.

When I was little we went to @ORGANIZATION1. I was finally big enough to go on the newest @CAPS1 @CAPS2! When we walked up to the line we noticed how many people were there. In conclusion, when you are patient, no matter how hard it is you will maybe get rewarded just like my family was.

Patience is a great thing. It means to be understanding and calm. Sometimes people can take difficulties and pain and still stay calm. Any time when your brother or sister annoys you, you're still patient and never lash back. "Wake up already!!" my brother shouted. "I’m awake!" I hollered. I took in a huge gulp of air and let it out with a sigh. "I’m so bored!" my brother shouted in my face, "can we go walking?" I was counting past ten in my mind and then finally spoke, "Fine." I got my coat off the rack followed by my little brother. We walked outside right when we saw my mom coming to give me a chore. "You’ll have to cut the grass today and rake the leaves," Mom said calmly, "after you walk your little brother." "Okay," I said, though I was completely furious on the inside. I tried to keep calm, but that didn’t last long. "Hey there!" my brother's friend said cheerfully, "can you come over and play?" he asked him. My brother looked up at me and I was closing my eyes, barely holding on. "I guess," I stammered, walking back home. I grabbed the lawn mower and right when I was about to turn it on—"Stop, get inside and start your homework. . . Then, you can go out!" "One two. . . Three..." I counted silently. I walked with a fake grin on my face. "On the other hand... go take out the trash!" "One hundred seventy-five...!" I kept counting. I ran downstairs, grabbed the trash, and walked to the trash can. As I dropped the garbage inside I tried to put myself in a happy place—Crash! I sped inside to gaze at what had happened; it turned out my sister broke my Xbox on the tiles because she wanted to play. If I get passed one hundred in counting in my brain I’m going to explode! I thought. I held my little sister and gave her to my mom. "She broke my Xbox!" I repeated. "Don't worry, your dad will fix it," Mom said calmly. "Now go get your brother." "Okay..." I speed-walked down to my brother's friend's house and told him I had to get my brother. "Let's go!" I shouted, "your brother is here to get you." "Coming!" he yelled. I urged myself to stay silent and patient and I managed to. We walked back home and I threw myself on my bed. "What a boring day!" I spoke to myself. "I don’t think I’m ever going to be this patient in my life again!!" And I smacked my head into the pillow and said, "Good night everyone!" and went to bed. Wow! What a day! Patience means to be understanding and calm. Patience is great. I tried and learned a powerful lesson, always try. My life is way better now because I try to stay patient and never hit my brother or sister even though they get me so mad sometimes. The world would be better if everyone would just stay patient; people have to try to succeed, it’s a very, very famous phrase.

It’s like when you're waiting in a long line; that’s patience. Or like when you keep on raising your hand and the teacher keeps on saying, "Do your work," and you do it again, so she will say, if you do that again you will go to the choiceroom. That’s when a teacher loses her patience because she has asked you repeatedly to stop. It shows that everyone has a limit, even those who are supposed to be calm. Staying patient in frustrating situations is a challenge for everyone, but it is an important quality to practice every day.

I am writing about a time when I was patient. The time I was patient is when it was the first week of football. We went down to Subway before the game and got a sub. I was the first one in line but then I was followed by other people; only one cut me at first but then others followed and I became the last one in line, it felt like an hour in line! Finally I was up next and I got my sub. It had turkey, lettuce, pickles, banana peppers, cucumbers, and great fresh spinach. I learned something in that line: being patient really pays off and by the time I sat back, it had been over thirty minutes. I sighed in relief. We were pumped for our first game; we played hard and we tied it, though, but that was still a great day! The experience taught me that good things come to those who wait calmly.

The time I was patient... One after school I was walking home with my friends from school. Being me, I wanted something to eat so I told my friends to come into Burger King's restaurant (it’s a fast food restaurant.) After we walk in to Burger King, the place is crowded so I waited in line. After about five minutes my friends said, "Come on man let’s go." So I say, "I’ll meet you guys outside." "Alright," they said. About ten minutes later it was my turn to order and I ordered a double stack and some fries and I got a free milkshake for my patience. She asked what kind did I want; I said strawberry and I didn’t have to pay for it, it was totally free. I went outside and I told my friends I got this for free and then they said, "Ooooooooh," that’s when we went home, proving that patience can have its own sweet rewards.

About three weeks ago I ordered a book series online, I had to be very patient so it wouldn’t feel like a year of waiting. This book series was not like any other book series; these books are my favorite, they’re called the Harry Potter series. I have read the series many times and I am still reading them. But, I had to wait to get them. I was trying to be patient, but it was hard. The mailing date said it would arrive in less than one hour, but I had to wait for five days before it came. When I finally forgot about them, they arrived! Being patient is a good quality people can have. So if you are patient you will probably get what you want, and the waiting makes the reward even better in the end.

A time that I was patient was when I took my first state test this year. The test was not too hard, but not easy either, requiring careful thought for each answer. I finished it with about one and a half hours left in the testing period. For an hour and a half I had nothing to do but just sit perfectly still and silent, staring at the clock on the wall. Sitting still and quiet for even five minutes is hard for a ten year old, imagine ninety minutes! At first I was fidgeting with my pencil, then my neck started to hurt from holding the same position, so I layed my head down on the cool desk. I closed my eyes and just layed there perfectly quiet and still, listening to the quiet sounds of the room. Soon enough the time flew by and the English Language Arts assessment was over for the day. I was very proud of myself for being patient and calm during those ninety minutes, proving I could handle the challenge.

Hi my name is Alex and I’m going to tell you a story about how one time I was patient. I remember when I was patient. It was Christmas day. There was tons and tons of presents under the tree, wrapped in colorful paper and shiny bows. There was tiny ones all the way to huge ones. But I couldn’t even peek at them because my mom and dad were still not up, and the rule was we had to wait for everyone. I wanted to go into my mom’s and dad’s room and wake them up right away. But no, not without some breakfast in bed, so when I wake them up they can hurry up and eat so I can open my presents. I carefully set the tray with toast and juice, trying not to spill anything. After my mom and dad were done eating I finally got to open my presents, and the wait made it even more special.

Patience is when you are tolerant and understanding, able to wait calmly for an outcome. Many people don't have patience, while others do. I am sort of in the middle, but here’s a time I had to be very patient. It was a bright and sunny Sunday afternoon. The sun was shining like there’s no tomorrow. Too bad I couldn’t play outside. I was too busy kicking back, eating popcorn, and watching a big football event with my brother. It could give me bragging rights I figured I needed some hope and patience. "Steelers," my brother yelled all happy and in my face. "Ha ha loser, lions are winning and steelers are loosing," he added. "Don't get too happy, there’s still plenty of time left," I replied, with a worried look on my face. I was afraid that I’d lose, but taking deep breaths in and out, I was very patient. The clock was winding down. It was the beginning of the fourth quarter. The score was 21 to 17, lions lead. I was still a bit worried, but I never lost hope. As the game was coming to an end, the quarterback for the steelers made an awesome pass and touchdown I screamed dancing and jumping around. I told my brother, "who is the loser now, huh?" Wow all it took was patience, and hope I told myself. Patience can mean a lot. Not only did I learn that me and my brother can get a little competitive but if you just wait and tolerate what’s happening around you, you’ll end up getting rewarded in the end!

I guess you could say that patience is one of my best talents. I go through many things that involve patience and I live through it without a word. But I know that there are a lot of kids that aren't as patient as me, some of them have all kinds of other feelings that make them impatient while others are just built that way. There was a fish named Finn. Finn lived around the Sharpfin archipelago, a dangerous place for fish that couldn't slow down quickly due to the strong, unpredictable currents. Suddenly, Finn sees a big chunk of meat on something shiny, a hook hidden just beneath. It was too far away to grab, though. Finn went home to his wife empty-handed. The next day, Finn went to the current and saw the floating meat again, drifting temptingly. Finn lunged for it and started chewing when something sharp stabbed him in the mouth. Finn started pulling fiercely when he heard a loud snap. When Finn tugged again he fell into the current, the line finally breaking. Finn was finally free! Finn also realized the current felt pretty nice, carrying him along. Finn ate a couple of small fish and slept. When Finn woke up, he saw a big ugly fish standing on two fins, a predator out of water. Finn couldn't breathe and he was in a net. Finn snapped at one of the fins of the other fish and died in the struggle.

The definition of patience is, when someone is in a car, & is going a long distance trip and you don’t ask to stop or keep asking and asking where you are going. Patience. What is patience? Patience is waiting for something calmly, without becoming annoyed or anxious. Its waiting for the right time to propose, or ask her on a date, understanding that rushing can spoil the moment. Life is going to be hard unless you're patient, as many worthwhile things require time and perseverance. You need to be patient when getting a job, carefully preparing for interviews and waiting for responses without giving up hope. Cultivating this virtue can lead to greater success and peace in all aspects of life.

This is a writing piece on how I had to be patient to get a phenomenal bowl of ice cream. My grandparents had just picked my brother and I up from our house to go get ice cream at Cold Stone. I had never gone to Cold Stone before, but my friends said it was really good. So I had asked my grandparents if we could go, and I was amped. When we arrived at our destination the line was huge, winding out the door. It was shaped like a snake, and the sign said “fifteen minutes wait.” I was disappointed and was about to leave when I saw it: the peanut butter cup perfection. It was staring me right in my face, so I talked to my grandparents and said we could stay. When we finally got to the front of the line I ordered the peanut butter ice cream. It was time to send my taste buds on vacation, and it was fantastic. It was so smooth and creamy. I was thinking to myself how I was glad that I was patient enough to enjoy that amazing dessert. That was the time I had to be patient to go get a phenomenal ice cream bowl.

Patient means that you are understanding and tolerant of delays or problems. A patient person experiences difficulties without complaining, maintaining a calm demeanor. There was a time when I was patient at a theme park. Being patient is difficult to do, but I did it before. “This line isn’t even moving,” my brother said, obviously not being patient himself. He then said, “Hello, man, can you walk any slower?” to the person in front of us. A nice man said in a kind, friendly voice, “I can if you want me to.” My brother replied, “Are you that dumb? I wasn’t for real. I might cut you just because of your stupidity.” He was only a year older than me and he thinks he’s all big and can do anything he wants. The man said, “Little man, you can’t cut me, I was waiting in line forever.” While my brother was making enemies, I was waiting patiently in line even though it wasn't really moving; inside I wanted to shout, but unlike some people I have patience and can wait. After my brother cut that man and didn’t get punished, he decided to cut hundreds of people. All those people were very mad at him, but not one did anything besides say, “Hey, don’t cut me.” That didn’t really help until he cut the wrong person, a young, pretty lady with beautiful blue eyes and pretty blond hair named Sarah. She said, “Call the police, this young boy just cut me and everyone else.” While I was waiting there patiently, my brother got kicked out of the whole park. When it was finally my turn, I got on the roller coaster. It was the best roller coaster I had ever been on. Being patient is hard, but it can be rewarding. I also learned that to be patient takes a lot of understanding and tolerance. Now, I know you get the best results when you're patient, and the worst when you're not.

Anyway, Michael is always very patient, hoping Mycaela will come around someday. It’s been almost two years with him quietly admiring her from a distance, and she still hasn’t come around. I just think that Michael is very patient and he is a great kid for handling his feelings with such persistent grace and respect.

As I was about to say the rude things on my mind, I quickly held myself back. I remembered that I wanted my dad to be proud of me, and that losing my temper would not help. So, as it was my turn to go on I finally did something good. I was so proud of myself on how I did not say anything, simply stepping onto the ride platform. When the ride was over I quickly went to my dad. I was so proud of myself on how I was tolerant. People going ahead of me wasn’t so bad in the end. Look like I can do something positive. If they thought they were gonna get to me, they were right. But, they were wrong if they thought I was gonna say something.

Every day I must be patient in difficult things. I must be most patient when I am playing or watching sports. Every weekend my brother plays in a football league and it can be wearing. I have to wait almost two hours for the games to be over and my parents make me watch the entire game. Freezing cold and all I could do was wait, and wait, and wait. What I was waiting for was the charity walk to start. I had friends with me but they mostly talked with themselves, leaving me and my friend Sarah. Her dirty blond hair whips her face, and she hunches her back against the wind. My yellow lab, Max, tugs on his leash and Sarah, being the one holding the leash, stumbles sideways. “Are you sure you don’t want me to take him?” I ask for the tenth time. “No, I got it!” she says happily. I was cold, bored, and hungry, but at least I didn’t have my arm being pulled off. “Are you sure?” I felt so bad, Max was my dog, I should be holding him. Which was no easy task. “Really!” Sarah says lightly, “I got it!” Max pulls her again and Sarah falls into me. I catch her, and she mumbles a sorry. I had my doubts, but I still think I should take him. All day I’ve been complaining. I was joking about our luck with the weather partly, but mostly, I just wanted to start a conversation. “I think my hands are numb,” I say shoving them into my pockets. “True, at least it’s not raining, like the weather man said,” Sarah smiles, and I smile back. A voice booms out of the speaker, “All walkers. Let’s get moving!” I glare at Sarah and ask one more time, “Do you want me to take him!” She pats my back and says slowly, “I got it.”

A time I was patient was when I had to babysit my little cousin. He was just a little baby, so I knew that if he started crying, or got upset that I couldn't get frustrated with him because he's a baby. There were times when he would start crying for no apparent reason and I just wanted to scream, but I knew I couldn't and that I just had to be patient with him. I would gently rock him or try to offer him a bottle. I also knew that I couldn't get upset, or angry because it might make it even worse for him, so I had to be patient and wait for him to stop crying and for me to calm down before I could go anywhere near him. I was understanding and tolerant and I didn't lose my patience. Practicing that skill is very important for anyone caring for a child. I am proud of myself for being able to keep my composure in crazy or chaotic situations like that, and not losing my cool, or patience, with him or anyone else.

Patience is a key role in life. If you are not patient, you will live an unhappy and frustrated life. Almost everything in life calls for some patience. In this narrative essay I will write about a few different times when I was out and I had to be patient. Such as when I was waiting to get out of school on a holiday. And when I had to wait until my mom woke up to go to the mall so I could get my new video game. I’m currently writing my comic book, though I haven’t begun drawing it yet. Here is a major scene in the first book. “Hey, are we there yet?” the little girl asked with curiosity in her voice. “No, not yet,” the guide replied with a sound of fear in her voice. They were lost, really lost in the big forest. “Are we there yet?” little Anna asked again, tugging on a cloak. “Please, Anna, you’ll just have to be patient,” the warrior said, becoming annoyed very quickly. So they walked for hours, but still no sign of the castle. Little Anna was eager to meet the queen, for she had imagined the queen as a kind, patient, and beautiful woman. The warrior could see that Anna was tired; lifting her onto her shoulders she said to Anna, “Look, see if you can spot the castle from here.” After a few long, patient minutes, Anna finally saw the castle towers. “I see it, I see it!” she said with a big smile. Jumping off of the warrior’s shoulder, she bolted down the narrow path way. Because she had waited so long, she was as excited as ever. Not only because she had found the castle but because she had learned how to be patient on the journey.

A time I was patient was when I got my braces. I was so nervous, so it was hard to be patient. I waited in the waiting room for about fifteen minutes, trying to calm my nerves, and then the assistant finally called me in. First, she told me what she was going to do, explaining each step of the procedure. Second, she took an x-ray of my teeth to see their alignment. Third, she put metal bonds with a really strong glue on the back of my teeth to secure them. Fourth, the orthodontist put the brackets on with really strong glue, which felt a bit strange. Then the assistant put the wire between the brackets and metal bands, tightening everything into place. Finally, she asked me what color I wanted for the bands, then she put them on and I was free to go. The whole process took two hours, and I had to sit still in a dental chair for that entire long time. I had to use a lot of patience; it was hard but I did it. That is the time I had to be truly patient.

“So what do you want for your birthday?” “A PlayStation.” “What else do you want?” “Just a PlayStation.” I have been wanting a PlayStation 5 for so long. It was my thirteenth birthday and I never wanted something more. All my friends had it. Whenever I went over to their house we played night and day. I wanted one… I wanted one really bad. The only exception was that it cost five hundred dollars and I already had a one hundred dollar birthday party; all together it would be a six hundred dollar birthday. So my mom and I decided on an agreement: I pay half then she will pay the other half. From that day on I asked everyone for money as a gift for my birthday. I didn’t want any other presents; I had my eye on the prize. So normally you have a family party where all the relatives come over, give you your present, and celebrate. I knew that's where I would get my three hundred dollars. Everything seemed perfect; I had it all planned out. Have the family party a couple days after my birthday then go buy my PlayStation! I didn’t mind waiting two or three days. I figured I would live. “Hey mom, when are we having the family party?” “Next month.” At that moment there was steam coming out of my ears; I could feel my face burning up like I was putting my head in a fire. You may not realize it, but next month is a whole month away from my birthday. If waiting thirty days isn’t patient then I don’t know what is. From this day on I still haven’t gotten my PlayStation, but two days from now I’ll be holding a stack of cash in my hands and heading to Gamertop. If I had to wait any longer I probably wouldn’t have made it. I’m not very patient, but this experience certainly tested me.

A time I was patient was at my friend’s cousin’s birthday party. I was patient because the whole entire time that we were at the party I was waiting for an answer from my parents and my friend’s parents to see if me and my friend could have a sleepover. So during that time that my friends and I waited we colored a couple dinosaur pictures, watched a movie, ate dinner, played in the basement, went in the garage and ate cake and ice cream, decorated and painted our dance tool boxes, colored some more pictures, and watched my friend’s cousin open his presents and much, much more. Then it started getting dark outside so we tried to take a little nap, but it was hard with a whole bunch of kids screaming. Soon enough it was time for my friend to go, and then my parents said that we could have a sleepover. But then my friend’s mom said not tonight because my friend has a volleyball game in the morning. It felt like I waited for nothing at all. Then I realized that when you're patient, you get what you want more often, even if it doesn't happen right away.

Being patient is important, as I’ve learnt before from experience. Once, I chose to babysit my cousins Leo and Max. Leo is eight years old, and Max is six years old. I had to watch them for three hours all by myself. I was able to call my aunt anytime I was in need of help, but if I did call, I wouldn’t get paid. I was to be paid twenty dollars if I could handle Leo and Max. This is how I was able to do so. I arrived at my aunt’s house at about one thirty on the dot. Leo and Max had just gotten back from a friend’s birthday party, where they surely devoured a ton of sugary foods, like candy, cake, and ice cream. I could tell they were hyper as soon as I walked in the door when they greeted me with bubbly attitudes. My aunt left and I was stuck with them. Leo wanted to play on his PlayStation. But Max wanted to play Xbox. I began to get irritated when they started to argue over what to do. I was about to call my aunt when I decided that being a little more patient was well worth getting paid. So to settle their contradiction, I found a board game that we could all play and enjoy. After playing the game for two hours, we went into their back yard. Leo and Max played tag while I watched. However, Max, being the unfair one, denied that Leo had tagged him, and began to pout. I was frustrated at them immediately, and picked up the phone. But then I decided that, with only one hour left, I could handle them. So I told them that we could play hide-and-seek instead, and even though I would normally loathe being the seeker, I told them that only I would count so they wouldn’t fight. Finally, my aunt came home and I got paid the money I had earned. That day, I learned that being patient always has its rewards, both in money and in personal satisfaction.

Patience is being polite by waiting for someone or something. For example, if you are waiting in line for a ride at an amusement park or something, then if you are patient you're being nice to other people by not trying to hurry them or something like that. If you are impatient and you are standing in line, you would be mean to other people by saying things like “hurry up, I want to be on that ride” or “hurry up and start the ride already.” That is the example. Being patient means that you are understanding and tolerant, calmly enduring difficulties without complaining. One time when I was patient is when my parents did not know it was a half day at school. One day in elementary school we had a half day which parents didn’t know about. After school I waited in the parking lot for close to thirty minutes waiting for my parents to pick me up, watching as other students gradually left until I was nearly alone. I was starting to think my parents weren’t coming until a teacher noticed me and asked what I was doing. After I explained my situation the teacher kindly let me call my parents. My dad apologized and went to get me after I explained, and then I could finally go home. This experience taught me the value of staying calm.

I’ve been patient plenty of times, but when I ordered a new game console is when I had to be particularly patient. My dad and I were getting a game console that would be at our porch in two weeks. For me it felt like a life time, but I had to keep patient and focus on other activities. Not for those fourteen days did I complain, neither did my dad, as we both understood the delivery process. when it finally came, it was definitely worth the wait, and we enjoyed setting it up together. That is a time when it was necessary to have patience and to not complain, and it made the reward even better.

A time when I was patient is when I was at the festival. I wanted to get something to eat and the line was big, stretching far from the counter. Another time is when I wanted to get on a ride the line was giantle large. It was for the massive, towering pirate ship, the swing, which looked exciting from a distance. There was also a line to play this basketball game and it was big, with many people ahead of me. Despite the long waits, I remained calm and eventually got to enjoy the activities, which made the day fun.

Have you ever had enough patience to deal with seven screaming kids? I can proudly say that I can. It all started when my uncle Steve and Aunt Mary decided to move to Florida. They needed a lot of help so my Aunt decided to take all five of her kids and my sister and I down to Florida to help them. The only problem was there were seven kids and only one of her. So we packed up all of our bags and headed out. My Aunt has an expedition car so all seven of us could fit. But, it didn't take long for everybody to get uncomfortable. Everybody starts to feel smocshed in and get really hot. So all of the seven kids start fighting. My Aunt got real stressed real fast. I thank god that there was at least a DVD player in that car. But I was sitting in the front so I didn't get to watch it. After about two hours I’d had enough. My legs were getting all cramped up, and the constant motion was making me dizzy. By now we had been driving about five hours, only having one rest stop. It was dark out now. We were the only ones on the road at the moment. I sank lower in my seat. Then BANG! Everybody screamed, even my Aunt. At first I thought we got into a car accident, but when I opened my eyes I was alive. We had hit a deer. It slid across the hood of the car! Finally after about ten hours we reached Florida. It was three in the morning! I ended up surprising myself with how much patience I had. After that I don't think that I want to go on a road trip again, but I learned I can handle more than I thought.

Patience is when you have problems and don’t complain, accepting situations with calmness. You need patience at an amusement park to wait in all the long lines for the popular rides. Patience is also not complaining about being bored on a long car ride, finding ways to occupy your mind. You need to be patient to fish or to be rewarding, as it can save others headaches and make the experience more peaceful. You won't always be stressed if you are patient, approaching challenges with a relaxed attitude. So you should always be patient; it can make your life so much easier, long lines won't seem so long, and fishing is very rewarding for those with patience.

Patient day. I remember the time when I was patient for a toy car. Four years old, I had to wait for four whole days. Each day it felt like I was in jail. So I was getting mad each day, slapping people in the face; it was so funny, but my dad and grandma were mad at me. Then my mom put me on punishment. Then a couple days later I was doing good in school. So my mom was so proud of me. Then she bought me a lot of stuff. Later that Christmas day we had turkey and ranch dressing. Then I opened my presents. I got the toy car, two monster truck cars, shoes, and Nike’s blue, red, and all colors you can think of. So that is why I was patient for that toy; I was so happy and my grandpa stopped by and gave me three dollars. Then he took me ice skating, and I had to wear these skinny tights. But it all worked out for me at the end. I got everything I wanted and I even got a loud touch with the three cars. It felt like I was rich for Christmas day.

One day this girl really wanted to go school shopping. She had to wait because her mother said she didn't get her money now; she would get it later. Her mom said wait until later. The girl did not know that her new stuff was up in her room, so when her mom got back, the girl had said, "When are we going to go?" Her mom said, "Go get your jacket upstairs in your room." The girl went upstairs to get her jacket, and when she went up in her room, she saw new clothes and five pairs of new shoes. The girl had to scream, and she came downstairs and told her mom thank you. Her mom said, "You're welcome." Her mom said, "I told you I was going to get your stuff." And the girl said, "You just have to wait with patience."

Patience is a feeling that you get when you experience a difficult task and do your best to overcome it without complaining about the task, like when you're getting paint out and then you squeeze the tube and it won’t come out, but you still keep trying until you figure out that it is all gone. Then you go get a new bottle to start using. I wish that more people were patient, then we wouldn’t have to listen to constant complaining from others. The world would be a much more peaceful place if everyone practiced a little more patience in their daily lives.

A time when I had to be patient was when I had to watch my little brothers and my two cousins. This was going to take a lot of patience. One day I got a phone call from my aunt. She said she needed a babysitter for my two-year-old and seven-year-old cousins. She said she would pay me if I would watch them. So I said sure. I had no idea what I was getting myself into. A couple days later, my mom came home and it turned out pretty good for me after all. The children were finally calm, and I felt a great sense of accomplishment for having managed everything so well.

Patience is probably one of the hardest things to do in the world. One time I remember when I was patient was when my family and I went to Cedar Point. When we went to Cedar Point we all were ready to ride the Magnum, which we never got to ride the last time we were there. So we were planning on riding that first. We got in line, and after a little while we had to wait for the rain to stop; the wait was an hour and fifteen minutes. So I decided that I would be a little more patient and not complain. Although, not being able to sit down after a while gets kind of painful, but I still never complained. A little while later I actually started forgetting I was in line because the people started letting more of us on. I guess not complaining works because my whole family was in a good mood after we got off the ride. So I decided to learn how to be a little more patient with people because of how good everything worked out until we got to the bumper cars, where our patience was tested once again, but we managed to have fun regardless.

Waiting into the grand double doors of the fravential I am greeted by a man in a suit. "Welcome to the fravsthat," the man says as soon as we enter. We can walk on further to the main hall, a vast space opening up in front of us. "When does the show start?" I ask excitedly. "Not until about eight thirty," my mom replies. Eight thirty was about an hour away and we couldn’t sit down due to the crowd ahead of us. Ten minutes passes by and only one person was admitted into the show. Not even the elegant music could mask the crowd's uproar. Another fifteen minutes passes and our seats finally await us. Walking down the walk way I ease into seat forty-two as the show begins, the lights dimming to a hush.

Being patient is sometimes a difficult character trait. Patience is a good one to have too, as it can help you in a lot of situations. If you have patience, you won't get nervous or anxious about something. I was patient when I had to wait a week for a birthday present my friend Sarah was getting me. I didn’t think about the gift that much so the wait didn’t really get to me. I knew the present was going to be really cool, which made being patient a little bit harder. I was still able to keep the curiosity off my mind. I had to make sure I didn’t think about it, so I wouldn’t beg my friend to know what it was, because that would be impatient. If you're impatient people might get annoyed because you will always ask questions, and get on their nerves. It is good to be patient with friendships, so you don’t become mean to them or anyone else. It is certainly not good to be impatient with your family. If you are patient you can work things out better, and stay more on task and focused, leading to more harmonious relationships.

When you're at a store or the doctor or anywhere where you have to wait for something, you always have to have patience or you will never be able to do anything. I remember when I was at the store with my mom we had to wait in this long line just to buy a few groceries. But if we didn’t have patience we would have put our stuff back and went back home. Since we did have patience we got to buy our stuff and complete our errand for the day. That is why, if you don't have patience you won’t be able to do anything you want to do, as many worthwhile things in life require waiting.

Here’s a story about a time when I was patient. So the story begins at Art Prize, and I loved to see the beautiful art there, but I was dying to see the winning picture. My parents told me to wait until we all see the rest of the Art Prize's amazing art. So I sighed and replied, "Okay, we can see the rest of the Art Prize things first." While we were looking at the art the whole time I was thinking about the winning piece. That is all I thought about for a while. A little bit later, I was thinking of what a blessing it is to be here at Art Prize. So I cheered up and decided patience is good. And if you wait for something for a while, it all of a sudden seems more valuable. A couple hours later I started to head to the car, and my mom interrupted and said, "Don’t you want to see the winning piece of art?" "Oh yes, I forgot," I replied. There was not a line now, so when we went to see it there was no crowd. It was the most amazing thing I have ever seen. It was a picture of soldiers drawn out of just a pencil. That day I learned that patience is important, because that way it was worth the wait to see something that you like, making the experience even more special.

A time when someone else I knew was patient was when I was trying to have a sleepover with my friend Lily. My parents ordered pizza for me and my two brothers because they went out for their anniversary dinner. It was around six pm when they left, and we just started digging into the deep dish pepperoni pizza. Halfway through dinner I got a text from my next door neighbor, who is my best friend, asking if I wanted to have a sleepover. I replied saying that my parents are out, they’ll be back in a few hours, and that I’ll ask later. Finally, around nine pm my parents came home and I asked about the sleepover. My mom said, "I don’t know," and walked away. About an hour later I got my answer. It was a yes! I texted Lily and said that I could. She replied, "Finally!" Now I had to go pack. Quickly, I went to my room and got everything I would need for a sleepover. I was just about to walk out the door when my mom shouted from upstairs, "I need you to take the dogs out before you leave!" So I dropped everything, put the leashes on the dogs and stood outside in the pouring rain waiting for them to finish up. When they were done I grabbed my stuff and ran out the door before she made me do something else. When I got to Lily's house she opened the door and let me in. I said, "Sorry it took so long. Thanks for being so patient!"

I don’t have a time when I’m patient, so today I'm going to write about how impatient I am. I think one day I was in a long line at the store. It was a hot day and I was ready to go to my cool and big house to relax and chill out. You all know how old people are; they walk slow and talk too much, if you haven't already noticed. One of those people was in front of me. He was taking all day taking out his wallet and talking too much to the cashier. So I said, "You know what, I’ll just go to another store and get me a Slurpee right now, I can’t deal with this slowness on such a humid day," and I left the line immediately.

Being patient can sometimes be very hard, especially when whatever you are being patient about is really distracting and painful. This is the story of how I had to be patient when I fell outside and hurt myself. One day, my brother and I were playing outside. We were having fun throwing water balloons at each other. I was already soaked from head to toe, but we still kept playing. Suddenly, I heard a buzzing sound by my ear. I turned around and saw a huge bee next to me. I was only eight years old and very afraid of bees. I turned and ran down the driveway and kept going around the house, thinking that the bee was still following me. I was starting to get tired, so I tripped and fell, scraping off a good amount of skin in the process. I immediately began to cry when I saw blood passing from the cut. I ran inside to tell my mom. "Mom! I fell!" I managed to scream between sobs. "Oh my gosh! Let me go find some band-aids," my mother replied. The pain was intolerable for my little body. I kept silently crying, but I knew I had to be patient while my mom went to look for bandages. Just last week I had wasted a bunch of band-aids by plastering them across my doll's face. I had to be patient and wait for a long time, till my mother finally found the bandages. "I found them!" my mom said, while running down the stairs into the living room where I was sitting. "Thank you for being so patient." She stuck the band-aids across the cut on my leg and then gave me a lollipop. I knew I had been a good girl by being patient and waiting calmly.

Yo! I’m the narrator, you know, the dude that tells the story. Well, I’m gonna tell you a story about patience. Ok, so, there was this armadillo. His name is Arnie. Now Arnie is no ordinary armadillo. Arnie was an armadillo without a shell. All the other armadillos made fun of him and told him to get a shell. So Arnie, being the smart armadillo he is, thought about this idea and decided to make a shell of his own. Arnie went to the junk yard to look for things to help him make his shell. He found a lot of light weight metal, so he took it home, melted it down, and started the long process of metal smithing his shell. It took him many days of careful work, hammering and shaping the metal. When his shell was complete he tried it on and it fit nice and snug. The next day he went to school and everyone was so impressed and it was super shiny. Arnie was no longer made fun of. Arnie had to be patient to make his shell, and his patience finally paid off.

Being patient is a very difficult thing to do. Many people can’t be patient. For example, my brother. I jumped up in excitement and put them on and it was a perfect fit. My mom came in the room and said they were supposed to arrive on Friday but since you were patient, they came early.

I have never been a “patient” person, unlike this girl I know named Sarah. She is always patient, like the time I was scared to go sledding down the hill and I would not go down. I hope some of it rubs off on me because I need some, and as soon as possible, and a lot of it too, because I bet I’m the only person in the world without patience, wow!
