I stood in the elevator tapping my foot, smooth jazz music humms out of speakers above me. Eventually the all too familiar click was head and the smooth metal doors slid open to reveal a well furnished hallway with many other people waiting for their turn of departure on the flight. I slipped out, trying now to become trampled by the massive crowd, then, silence. My footsteps echoed off the polished floor as I searched for room 104. Finnaly finding my destination I open the door and step inside where many other squirring children are waiting. I remove my coat and hang it on a nearby hook, trying not to draw too much attention to myself. I continue by searching through the magazine section, torn up old magazines and delicately handled sports illustrated are flipped through until I find an interesting looking article on swimming. Magazines under my arm I choose a seat in the far corner to wait in. Minutes pass, I can tell that the child next to me is becoming impatient fast, he taps his mothers jacket repeatedly and asks the same thing he did five minutes ago, “Mom how much longer?” The mother checks her watch and in a closely annoyed tone replies, “not much longer now dear.” Sighing, the little boy slumps back in his seat and jams his thumb into his mouth to keep him occupied. I roll my eyes, but can’t help but crack a smile at his actions. Somewhere across the room, a girl about my age frowns as she texts on her cellphone, after a quick glance at the clock she scowls and continues. Just then, the glass door slides open and a woman with a homemade perm and tired eyes steps out. Across the waiting room, patients look up at her, their eyes full of anticipation and hope. “Jane, the doctor is ready to see you now.” Relieved, I avoid the angry glares from other patients and follow her out the door. “You know it’s funny,” she says well snapping her gum. “For someone so young you were the most patient person out there!” I merely nod my head and grin because I understand that patient people, experience difficulties without complaining and I am very grateful that I’m a patient person.

One day my brother, my mom and me were going to the doctor’s because my brother was sick. When we got to the doctor’s office’s and sat in the waiting area. They called my mom and brother. So I had to stay. My mom told it will only take two minutes. Guess what she was wrong. It took her two hours to come back. So while I was patient I texted my aunt and friends. Finally they came out. Guess what my mom said “how are you sweety”, then my mum told me my brother was sick. I was so patient that we got to eat at McDonald's after the appointment. I was patient at the clinic so then we spent thirty minutes there. I was so tired I started to fall asleep in the car. I was proud of myself because I was patient; its not that hard to believe, its actually easy. That’s a lesson I learned that day.

Patience is when you get in a long line at the grocery store when you are waiting for a new video game. That happened to me when I was on the great jorney to california. I had to stand in six very long line for up to three hours it took forever to get on the plain when we finaly got there we were hungry so we had to wait inline for forty minutes when we were finally up to get our food we were starving we ate and went to a friends house we stayed for an hour it started to get bouring but I had patience and waited turns out it was not so bad after all. Being patient is an important thing in life wether you are or arnt patient is up to you that week was all about patients and lines lots of both it was a long day. Sadly we had to leave after that day which equals. Yap you guessed it for patience first was had to go huston, texas then Dallas then we had to drive six hours to get home when we got home we were so tired and passed the story to my friends and family, who all agreed that my patience had been truly tested.

To be considered patient, you must be tolerant and understanding,and you cannot complain. I love babysitting my little cousin, especially when they are still infants. This Saturday, I went to my cousin’s house to watch her daughter Lisa’s baby, for about three hours. I was getting paid fifty dollars, and I couldn’t wait.When I got to their house, the baby was sleeping , and I woke her up as soon as her mom left. As soon as I did that, I figured it was a bad idea she started screaming at the top of her lungs. I picked her up, rocked her, played games, put her in the swing , and even tried to feed her but nothing worked. I was so upset, I fell like screaming. The baby cried for an hour and a half, and wouldn’t hush. Tthen I said, “Sweetie, what’s the matter ?” As soon as I spoke, there was a moment of silence, she had stopped crying. At that moment, I realized I was being patient because I stayed somewhat calm and I didn’t complain to Lisa’s mom, and that felt like a real accomplishment.

Every year since I learned about Christmas and presents, now that I think about it, they never said you’d have to wait months until the holiday came around. I love Christmas, but once a year or so I am not patient enough to wait until December rolls downward. The first chilly day of December told me Christmas was coming along with all the decorating, carolling, and wistful feelings of holiday joy. I usually try to pass the time by having snowball wars with my cousins in the backyard. I still feel the temptation, trying to rush time, which makes me anxious, and it feels grueling to wait so long, but I still try to be patient and let the temptation go away. When Christmas Eve came, I feel grateful I made it this long with patience because I am just like my parents and can't wait for anything that takes a month. Then it comes around as slow as possible and then leaves quicker than I could think, leaving me to wonder how fast it left. Just like the saying, time flies when you're having fun, but the wait itself feels like an eternity.

Once when I was a little boy, about seven years old, I was extremely patient about an Avatar toy I wanted. Ever since Avatar: The Last Airbender was on television and in stories, I was crazy about them, and I still am today. Aang, the Avatar, is the only person in the Avatar world who can master all four elements: water, earth, fire, and air. Now I can write you a whole entire book about the show. So I saw an Avatar toy set on T.V. and I asked my mom if she could buy it. And she said when she got the money, but until then, no. So of course I was upset. So I was waiting, counting the days as they went by. Then finally that very payday came, and you know what that means. "Payday, payday," the day has arrived, the day I get my toy, but I didn't know that she only got two hundred dollars, so I had to wait another week. I was so upset that I ran upstairs and locked my door and cried myself to sleep. My birthday was coming up. I was so upset that I forgot all about the payday, and when my birthday was here, can you guess what? I finally got the best gift of all, the Avatar toy, and my mom said that all that patience I practiced got me what I wanted in the end.

Patience is like waiting for something and you don't complain it's taking too long; you're just sitting there waiting quietly. Here is an example. One time I was waiting to go get a check-up at the doctor's office, and you're sitting there quietly, reading a magazine, and just waiting without making a fuss. That is a clear example of being patient, where you accept the wait without frustration. It is a valuable skill that helps in many situations throughout life.

One day a kid was going to school and was going to turn in a paper for math that he did. During English class, he was doing a chapter sketch. His teacher called him over. The teacher asked if he had a page of a story that was due a month ago. The kid said no. The teacher asked why, and the kid said because he had been going to a basketball tournament. The teacher said he had until tomorrow. Then the next day the kid is at English class and said he was sorry but he didn't have his paper. The teacher asked why, and the kid said because his grandpa died. The teacher said okay, he could have one more day. Then the kid finally got his paper done and turned it in, learning the importance of meeting deadlines.

I have been patient lots of times in my life, but this time was really hard to be patient because I was so excited about building. Left in my reach, we had been planning it for a while now, and we started on a Tuesday after school was over. We got like half of it done that day, but then we couldn’t work on it again for a week because my brother, sister, dad, and mom all had work or other commitments, so I had to wait a whole week just to work on it again. It was really hard to be patient this time though because I had been waiting to do this for a while. After a week finally passed, it seemed like a month, but now I could finish my work and I was so excited. A few days later we finally finished the walls, painted a blue and gold for U of M, and my loft was all we had left to do; we just had to put my bed in my loft, then it was ready to sleep in. I was so happy that we had finally finished my room and I could sleep in it, making the long wait completely worthwhile.

One time that I was patient was when I was saving up to buy a game. The name of the game was Halo Reach. I had to wait several weeks until I could get it. Each week, I would put a little bit of my allowance into my savings jar, watching the total slowly grow. But I was patient by waiting the whole time and not asking my parents over and over again for the money or for them to buy it early. I focused on other games I already owned to pass the time. Finally, the day came when I had enough, and I went to the store to buy it myself. The feeling of finally playing it after such a long wait was incredibly rewarding and taught me the value of patience.

The little filly a few days after the older horses began to run, Sparkle, a small, anxious, chestnut foal saw her mother plowing a large oval and covering it with what looked like dust. "What's mother doing, Mama?" asked a very curious Sparkle. "She's plowing." replied Daisy, the young horses' caretaker. "She's going to be in a race called the Kentucky Derby next year and that's how she will practice." I want to race! "hollered Sparkle excitedly "Patience my darling, you're not even a full-grown filly! " Daisy stated, conclusively. And so Sparkle waited patiently for weeks, watching from the fence. When she could, she ran the track at night under the moonlight. She counted her times and she got faster and stronger with each practice. Two years later Sparkle was the champion, a title she reached for three years in a row. "Daisy was right! " she claimed "Patience is the key to success!"

“Did you buy it yet?” I yelled across the room. “I have not yet, let's get it ordered,” my dad said back to me. I was buying a scooter on the internet and it was being shipped from China. The website said the scooter will get here in five to eight business days. “Yes!” I yelled as I bought it, “Now all that’s left to do is wait.” The next morning I woke up at six am to catch the bus to school; during all my classes all I could think about was the scooter. Patience, I need patience, I thought. After school I would go to close country until five when my parents would pick me up. Five business days finally came. “I can't wait any more!” I yelled. After close country my mom drove me home and I sprinted to the mail box. “Darn it!” I said. “Oh yeah, the website tried to charge our credit card extra money so we had to cancel the order.” “I am sorry,” my mom said, “let's buy you a new one from a different store.” The new scooter finally arrives three business days later. “It’s about time,” I said with joy as I unwrapped the box.

One time when I was at Cedar Point amusement park I had to wait about two hours to go on the Top Thrill Dragster. I was so patient because it was my first time ever going on the dragster. Me and my dad were waiting and waiting, watching the coaster shoot up and down the track. When we got to the front of the line I was so scared that I was going to pee my pants. When we got on the rollercoaster I said that I don’t want to go. So my dad asked if his son could get off the rollercoaster and they said when you get on there is no getting off. So I had to ride it and when I did I wanted to go on it over and again. The initial fear was replaced by an incredible thrill. Even though it was a seventeen-second ride it was the best thing that I had ever waited for in my life so far. That is the time when I had to be patient to get something that I really wanted, and it was completely worth the long wait.

I had to be patient waiting to go to Disney World. It went through many months of planning and appointments. I was so excited and had to wait patiently through many school achievements and other activities respectively. On the days leading up to the trip, I would help with everything, making sure especially to finish my chores. My parents would tell me, "You must be patient. We will get there." I had to be patient. I did all my homework, and in the process, I worked hard to get a good grade. I watched the days pass on the calendar and did everything else I needed to in the meantime. Sitting on the plane finally felt so rewarding because such a vast wait was then over, and the vacation was everything I had hoped it would be.

Do you know someone who is patient? I do; my mom is very patient with us kids. When I just blow my top, my mom is still cool and calm. All the time, my little brother makes me so mad that I can’t stand it, but she is barely ever like that. Even when my grandma died, she stayed cool and composed. Two of my aunts just broke down that week, but they are good now. Every day, things don’t make her very uptight. When my sister makes her mad, my sister always regrets it. I want to punch her when she makes mom mad because it wears off on me and she gets cranky. So as you can see, my mom keeps her patience so well, and that is a quality I truly admire.

My friend was waiting for two hours to talk to my dad, who was busy fixing his motorcycle. He was waiting, waiting, and waiting patiently till my dad fixed it. I was wondering what the question was the entire time. He was sitting inside, watching TV and waiting for him to be finished. Then my dad was finally done, so my friend asked if we could ride the motorcycle. My dad said yes, and we were all happy. My friend was being very patient throughout the whole long wait, and it really paid off in the end.

Being patient is a good thing because if you are, then you can handle some rough times in life. Patient people can manage by bringing something to do. They could wait there for three hours and not be heard complaining. There are some people that can’t wait there for three hours. There are some people that can’t wait there for ten minutes. These people get mad at that and they will just give up. But after all, of those people that can and can’t wait, people can’t just quit. Some people wait there for one hour and will blow up. And then there are people that can’t do it but they do it anyway. So all you have to do is find anything to do if you can’t handle the wait, and that is how you learn to be patient.

“Dad, are we there yet?” I keep asking over and over again. “Not yet, but almost,” he replied. Today we are going to Adventure Park, and I am so excited! After I asked my dad when we would be there, about twenty minutes later we finally arrived at Adventure Park! The line to get our tickets was long but not too long. Once we got them, we went to look for a locker to put all of our stuff in! The line for that wasn’t long, so we did that fast! We were now all hungry, so we went to go eat! By the time we got into the restaurant, the lines to order were very long! Ok, so now that we are all done eating, it was time to ride some awesome rides! “Oh, man!” is what I kept saying when the lines to the rides were super long! But so far I have been a very patient girl! But, ok, say I had to go change my clothes to go into the water park and change back or go to the restroom—man, these lines were super long too! Now that the day is almost done, and the park will be closing, my family and I went into the gift shop; we were in there for about thirty minutes walking around. When we were done and we were ready to check out, the checkout line wasn’t long at all! Finally, there was a line that wasn’t long! All that day I was a very patient girl, even with everything that went on throughout that long and exciting day.

A time that I was patient was when my friend and I were at the theme park on vacation. I was having a blast. My family didn’t come because they don’t like roller coasters. We decided to ride the Thunderbolt, and it looked like a really long wait. After an hour and a half of waiting, it started to rain. It was just sprinkling at first, but it was enough so they had to close some rides, including the Thunderbolt. We really wanted to ride it, so we waited patiently until the rain stopped. After another hour, most people had left, so we were at the front of the line. My friend and I got front row seats and had a lot of fun. It was worth waiting two and a half hours for it, and we even went on it twice, which made the patience worthwhile.

A time when I was patient was when I was in second grade and I had to wait to play football till this year. I was patient because I waited for a long time without doing anything, simply watching the games from the sidelines and hoping for my turn to come. I never complained or gave up on my wish to join the team, even when the seasons seemed to pass so slowly. Finally, this year arrived, and I was able to sign up and play, which made all that waiting feel worthwhile. That experience taught me the value of patience.

Do you know what patience is? Have you ever been patient? Well being patient is something you need in life. I’m going to tell you a little bit about being patient. First, patience is a big thing. Patience is something we need for when we go shopping, or when your in the car. You must be patient when you are in the car because if you don’t then you could get into an accident by rushing or making a hasty decision. Patience has many qualities. If you aren’t patient when you are some place then you are going to become annoying. When their are long lines or something and your not patient people are going to get very frustrated and annoyed with you. Second, being patient is important. If you have kids and you're impatient, then your going to teach your kids to be impatient. That’s not a good thing for them to learn. As you can see I have told you as much as I can about patience and why it matters in our daily lives.

A time when my parents were patient was when I wouldn’t eat my dinner. One night my dad made chop suey for dinner. I didn’t like chop suey at all! The smell of it really made me gag! But, my dad loves chop suey so he makes it all the time! We all sat down to eat. I ate a potato and my dad gave me whole scoop of chop suey. “I’m not gonna eat it,” I said. “I hate chop suey.” My dad sat patiently at the table waiting for me to eat what was on my plate. “Fine,” I said, “I’ll eat the meat out of it.” I took the fork and stirred the chop suey around looking for the meat. After I ate all the meat, I said, “Now I am done.” My dad laughed at my stubbornness. “Eat the vegetables out of it,” my dad said. “But no! I hate celery!” I whined. After a half hour of the war of wills my dad won. I really wanted to leave the table but he was very patient with me. I ended up eating the chop suey and leaving the table. That was when my dad was very patient and showed me how to handle a difficult situation calmly.

One time when I was being very patient was when I was with my grandparents. We were suppose to be going to Disney adventures and my grandma said she wanted me and my cousins to be ready by a certain time so we wouldn’t get there that late. So the next day we get to her house right there at eight like she said and we had found out that she had over slept and we all looked at one another because we new that it was going to take a long time. So I said that’s ok we can wait and we all went into her house and waited until every one was ready without complaining. So as we were walking out I noticed that my grandparent were caring suitcases and I said why do you guys carring suitcases my grandma and that we were going to spend the night in a hotel I so we would be even closer to Disney adventures. So she drove all of us back to our houses to get our things and one extra pair of clothes after that we were as our way to the hotel and ready to go to Disney adventure that next morning. Even though we were suppose to go earlier, our patience made the whole trip start off smoothly and happily.

One time I had to be patient was when I went to Texas with my mom, dad, my sister and my grandma. My cousins live in Texas so we were going to visit them. We had to drive twelve hours in a small cobalt with five people. We had to be patient on the car ride there because we were all really exited and the space was cramped. When I first found out that we were going I was really happy and I knew I would have to be very patient during the long journey. We had to drive the hole day then get a motel to stay in. Then we had to drive till about noon and we were finally at my great aunts lake house, my my grandmas sister. It was so fun geting to see them again! But then came more patients on the trip home. We were all sad to leave but we had a great time. The trip home felt shorter than the trip there but still long. When we got home everyone of us was tired and tired of being in the car but we were glad we didn’t have to drive anothe hour home like my grandma. That was a time when I had to be patient, and it showed me that good things often require enduring a long wait.

This is a story about a time I was patient. It was late at night and all of a sudden a wire from my braces popped out of place. It was sticking out of my mouth, poking the inside of my cheek, and there was nothing I could do about it. I had to wait for my mom to get home to help me. I was scared but I remained patient, carefully avoiding moving my tongue near the sharp end. I kept waiting calmly until my mom finally got there and we got the wires safely out. In the end, my patience paid off and the uncomfortable situation was resolved.

A day when I had to be patient was on my birthday. I was waiting for my dad to give me some money so I could go to the store. I waited all day until six o'clock, and when he finally agreed, I got twenty dollars. It was worth being patient because if I had kept rushing him, he probably would have lowered the price and it would have been my fault. Another time I had to be patient was when I was waiting for my mother to pick me up from football practice. We had to wait for a while and I was the last one there. I stood under a tree when it started raining and lightning, so I couldn't put on my helmet as it would have conducted electricity. Being patient in these situations was important, as rushing would not have changed the outcome. In the future, if you are in a similar situation, just don't rush.

What exactly is patience? Patience means to wait calmly for something without getting upset or annoyed. One of the times that I had to be patient was when I wanted my ears pierced. I tried everything for four years, including begging, pleading, and even cleaning my room without being asked, but it still didn’t work. My mom said I had to be sixteen before I could get my ears pierced. So instead of annoying her further, I sat back and stayed patient. By doing that, I got my mom to change the age to twelve. So all I have to do now is wait until soccer is finished and find a place, and she’ll take me. Patience really helps in many different ways and I encourage you to try being patient when you want something, because it will all fall into place in the end.

Sometimes being patient is hard, but I’ve had to do it a lot of times. One time in particular was very life changing for me. It was my favorite day of the year, my birthday. I’ve always waited for this day long and hard every year until it comes. I got up really early to see all my presents, but there were none. My mom was just watching T.V. like nothing was important and I said to her, “Good morning.” All she said back was, “Good morning, why are you up this early?” I just went back to sleep. When I woke up again, nothing had happened. So I just waited patiently in my room until something happened, but nothing did. Eventually I went downstairs and played video games until noon, just waiting for someone to say “happy birthday,” but yet, nothing. So I just acted like it was a normal day until six pm when I went in the basement. There was a surprise birthday party for me with presents and friends and everything. I was glad I was patient because I got a good party and now I’m patient every day.

Last summer I went with some friends to the annual Christian rock festival. The festival is about Christian rock music. The part that sticks out the most is seeing my favorite Christian rock band, MercyMe. They played new songs and had a lot of amazing guitar solos. I bought one of their cd's and it was amazing. The part that made me patient was the long line that my friend Jake and I had to wait in to get autographs. It almost stretched out the gate into the parking lot. The bad part was we were pretty much at the end of it. Even though the wait was long, the girl behind us was super nice so we ended up making a new friend. When we finally got to the front, the wait was all worth it. All of the band members were super nice and I gave their lead singer, Bart, my lucky bracelet. That was the time I was patient and it led to a memorable experience.

One time there were two twin chipmunks, their names were @PERSON1 and A.J. @PERSON1 always had patience, but A.J. not so much. One day it was sunny with a cool breeze. A.J. decided he wanted to go on a trip with @PERSON1. So they packed up their camping gear and headed farther into the woods. It was around dusk when they reached where they wanted to be, a small clearing near a stream. So they tried to build a fire. A.J. started gathering firewood and tried to start the fire how their mom and dad had taught them. As I said in the first part, A.J. has no patience so he kept on trying but after a while he stopped; he would hit the rocks together once and it wouldn’t start, so he would give up and try again a different way. So @PERSON1 tried, and in just @NUM1 minute he got it started with a steady flame. A.J. didn’t care, he got the acorns and started cooking. But every time he’d only leave them on for @NUM2 seconds, so they were always cold and hard. He tried and tried, getting more frustrated with each attempt, and finally he just stopped. Well, it took @PERSON1 a full @NUM2 minutes to roast them perfectly. A.J. was really mad now, his face flushed with anger, so they went to bed without another word. When @PERSON1 woke up in the morning, the sun was just rising, and he found A.J. cooking breakfast over a new, carefully built fire. A.J. had finally learned to be patient, understanding that good things come to those who wait.

My head was in the sky. It was mine. The ticket I'd been dying for was actually mine, a small piece of paper that felt like a golden key. One day I was being really patient. I was babysitting and it was going great until the kids started fighting! It was my two little brothers, of course. They were hitting, kicking, and the youngest one was even biting; so I told them to stop in a firm but calm voice. They did for a while, playing quietly with their blocks, and then started again over a toy truck. So I went back to their room, the floor littered with toys, and told them to stop again, explaining they needed to share. So they stopped for good, until my little brother @PERSON1 started to copy everything everybody said, repeating every word in a silly voice. So I said stop or you’ll go to your room, pointing to the door for emphasis. So he stopped, his lower lip trembling slightly, and everybody was good for the rest of the night, eventually settling down to watch a movie. They were all quiet and well-behaved until mom and dad got home, and now that's a whole different story. So that's the time I was patient with my little brothers and sisters, and it felt like a real accomplishment.

A time when I was very patient was last year. My auntie said she was taking me to a basketball game, a promise that filled me with excitement. So the next day when I woke up, I woke up far too early, the sun barely up. My aunt never told me what time she was coming, which was frustrating. So I got ready at @NUM1 am, putting on my favorite jersey. So at @NUM2 am I called her, my fingers tapping nervously on the phone, but she didn’t answer. So then I just was watching TV and playing my game, trying to distract myself. Then around @NUM3 pm my aunt called back saying she had to go to the store first. So now my frustration started to build up, a tightness in my chest. I wanted to call her back and ask her questions like where are you going and how long you're gonna be gone, but I was trying to be patient and not pester her. Now at @NUM4 my mom said lets go! Now I was really getting mad because I was not expecting to leave with my mom, my plans feeling up in the air. So me and my mom got home at around @NUM5 pm from running her errands. Now I was real angry because she had not even called since we was gone, and I thought I had missed my chance. So I called her, my voice a little shaky, and she said she was comin' down the street right at that moment. I was so happy, my frustration melting away instantly. So later on that day I had fun with my cousins and aunt at the game, and the wait was worth it.

“@CAPS1, when @CAPS5 we open presents?” I asked, barely able to stand still. “@CAPS2 we get back from church,” she replied in her calm mother-voice. It was our typical @DATE1 schedule: make @CAPS3 Eve dinner all day, go to the @CAPS3 Eve service, have grandparents for dinner, than all the kids get to open one present than go to bed for about one hour, get up, and open more presents. “Amen,” our pastor concluded the service. “@CAPS5 we go now, @CAPS1?” I blubbered, tugging on her sleeve. “@CAPS6,” she said firmly, taking my hand. @CAPS8 we ate dinner, a delicious meal I could hardly taste. I felt like I had ants in my pants, I was so excited, my knees bouncing under the table. Time seemed to go by so slow; I felt like I was @NUM1 years old before my grandparents finally finished their coffee and left. Finally we were all gathered around the @CAPS3 tree, its lights twinkling. @CAPS8 I was about to open my present, my hands trembling with anticipation. All it was was a sleeping bag, soft and blue. Then my dad said, “you @CAPS5 all sleep on the floor in @LOCATION1 room, but be sure you go to bed.” @CAPS8 I was laying on the floor in my new sleeping bag, while my sister was sound asleep beside me. I was thinking, I wonder what I’ll get for @CAPS3, imagining all the possibilities. I eventually fell asleep, my dreams full of wrapped boxes. The next morning at @NUM2, I jumped out of bed, woke my sister up with a shake, and ran into my parents room to wake them up, unable to contain myself any longer. I was thinking finally we get to open all the presents. That was a time where I had to be very patient, but it was all paid off in the end with a wonderful Christmas morning.

Patience is about waiting and having to wait for the stuff you want, like if I want anything, patience is that you have to wait before you get it. So patience, it means that you have to wait in a good manner, which involves staying calm and not complaining while you wait for your turn or for something you desire. It is about enduring a delay without becoming upset or frustrated, understanding that good things often take time to arrive. This virtue helps us to handle situations gracefully when we cannot immediately get what we wish for, teaching us the value of self-control and peaceful expectation. Ultimately, practicing patience leads to a more peaceful and satisfying experience when we finally receive what we have been waiting for.

Once I was taking a test and it was really long. I was done early, and my friend and I waited a long time for the others to finish. They gave us two and a half hours for the test, but I finished with an hour and a half to spare. My friend finished within five minutes of me, so we both had a lot of time left. I read a book but finished it quickly, and then I had to wait another hour to actually do something else. It is important to remember to bring something to do while you are being patient, as it makes the waiting much easier. If you have nothing to do, you should just wait quietly without disturbing others. Patience is a good quality that can be cultivated through such experiences, and it can be used by waiting calmly for something or for someone, which is a valuable skill in life.

One day I asked my parents if I could buy this game that I wanted, and they asked me how much it was. I said that I did not know how much it cost, so my dad said that we would go to the store and see the price. When we got to there, we found out that it was quite expensive, and I asked if I could buy it. He said maybe, but after a while I started begging for it. He still said no firmly. When I went home, I went to sleep, and the next morning I was at home watching television. I saw a commercial about the game, and it said that the game was still available. Later, when we went to the mall, I saw that the price had been reduced, and so I finally got to buy it after waiting and being patient for a while, which felt very rewarding in the end.

Everyone is patient one time in their life. I remember I was very patient one day when I was ten years old, and it was all because of a piece of popcorn. A small little popcorn kernel got caught in my throat, and that was an agonizing day, but I was very patient throughout the ordeal. One day, about two years ago when I was ten years old, I swallowed a popcorn kernel after going to a movie. I remember eating one last piece of popcorn from the popcorn box and then throwing the box away. Well, right as soon as I had walked out the door and eaten my popcorn piece, it started to bother me. My mom and I walked into the Target nearby to get some supplies and do some errands. I started to get really thirsty because of the popcorn kernel stuck in my throat. I asked my mom if she would buy me a drink because of how thirsty I was, but she said she only had a credit card with her at that moment. That meant she could buy her things but she could not buy a pop from the food court, as it required cash. I understood the situation, so I just tried not to think about my discomfort, which was very hard to do. Soon we pulled up to our next errand, the bank, because my mom needed to get some money to pay off my tennis instructor. I asked her if she could please hurry because the popcorn kernel and my lack of something to drink was hurting me. She said she was going as fast as she could and that we were only a few minutes away from home. I knew that we were more like fifteen minutes away, not just a few, but I did not argue with her. The kernel and my thirst were starting to get to me badly. It felt like it had been three hours, but it had only been fifteen minutes by the time we finally got home. I threw the door open and ran inside to get some water immediately. I ran, opened the fridge, opened a bottle of water, and chugged the whole thing down quickly. Then I went outside to help my mom bring in the supplies and things, and then I drank more water with a smile, feeling much better. In conclusion, we all learn to be patient sometimes, and I was patient to get home and drink some water, which ultimately relieved my discomfort and taught me the value of enduring a wait calmly.

There have only been a few times in my life where I really had to be patient, but the one I can remember the most was when I was at the airport with my family. My parents and I were waiting at our terminal for our flight to our vacation destination. We had been waiting about thirty minutes when we heard an announcement over the loudspeaker. They said something had gone wrong with the plane but it should be fixed in about an hour. We eventually found out that the back door had been slammed too hard, which broke one of the important parts. They needed a new part so the emergency slide would function properly. An hour of waiting sounded okay at first, but then there was another announcement that changed things. They said they were sorry, but they could not get the part right away, so the wait would be a minimum of three more hours. That sounded worse, but I kept calm and tried to wait patiently. My mom, however, was freaking out a little bit. Three hours had passed, then four hours, and then even more time went by slowly. My laptop and my iPod ran out of power, so I was just fiddling with my fingers with nothing else to do. Then we heard another update that the part could not be obtained until the next morning. A big groan swept across the entire terminal from all the waiting passengers. But luckily, the airline provided us with a free night at a hotel until the flight was ready. The wait was exhausting and tested everyone's limits, but we all had patience, so we got through the difficult situation together without too much trouble.

A couple of days ago when I was at cheer practice, a lot of drama was going around our team. It was fifteen days before the competition and everybody was yelling at someone. There was so much yelling and talking back to our coaches that no one could understand what we were supposed to be doing. The side I was on for the pom routine in our second formation wasn't in the diagonal line we were supposed to be in, and we weren't getting to the kickline in time because the people on the other side were pushing us farther down the mat, so we had to walk a lot farther than they did. @LOCATION1 was yelling at the side I’m on for not getting to the kickline in time, even though she's the one pushing us farther down so we can't get there. Then she started yelling at @PERSON1, saying it was all her fault, so then @PERSON2 said to @LOCATION1, “@LOCATION1 stop blaming everyone else for everything, you aren't perfect at everything either, and you're the ones pushing us over so we can't get to the kickline in time.” @LOCATION1 didn't know what to say, but she said, “@CAPS1 up @PERSON2! that isn't true,” even though you could tell that she knew it was true because the next time we did the kickline she didn’t move closer to the center; she moved farther away, and @PERSON3 got to her spot not really on time but just a couple of seconds after she was supposed to. I thought that @PERSON2 was being loyal to @PERSON1 even though @PERSON1 might not be one of her best friends; they still are friends, just not best friends, and that moment showed true team spirit.

A time when I was patient was when I wanted to go outside and my sister wanted to go but she wasn’t ready. She had to get her hair done and some clothes on. I waited patiently and didn’t say nothing, even though I didn’t want to wait, I did because I wanted us to go outside together. I walked out the door quietly, then my sister yelled, “I want to go, wait!” So I went back in the house and waited for her to first find some clothes; she went upstairs and found some. She put her clothes on, then she had to look for her shoes. She searched the whole house and then found them in the corner. So we were about to walk out and I said, “Girl, what’s wrong with your hair?” She felt her head and said, “Oh, I forgot.” So we went back in the house and I tried to put her hair in a ponytail and it wouldn’t fit. So I let her try to do something herself, and she couldn’t. So I parted her hair and put it in two ponytails. Then we finally went outside. That’s a time when I waited patiently on my sister, and it felt good to help her out.

When I was getting ready to leave my uncle's ranch, I was waiting patiently for my dad to get back so he could help my brother put the @NUM1 on to the trailer. It had been @NUM2 hours and my dad had not come back yet. I was having a difficult time taking my @NUM3 off the trailer because it was too heavy, and my dad was still riding his @NUM3. The sun was getting lower, and I was starting to feel a little frustrated but tried to remain calm. When my dad finally got back, my brother immediately went to go ride his @NUM3, leaving me with the heavy work. I was having a very difficult time trying to get everything packed and leave, but finally my mom and sister decided they wanted to leave too, so they finally helped me, and we managed to get everything loaded up together.

It was @DATE1 in @LOCATION1, @LOCATION2. My cousin, @LOCATION3, and I were going up the street to the carnival they were having. When we got there it was raining and only one of the rides was open. So we sat around under an awning till all of them were open. We went on all of them, but I wouldn’t go on one. It was called the Freak Out. There were lights flickering and loud music blaring from it. We were in the line for it but I got out. @CAPS4 said, “Why did you get out of line?” “I am scared,” I replied. “I want to go on it though,” he said. “@CAPS1 you wait till later?” I asked. We waited for an hour. I sat on the bench and @CAPS4 said, “@CAPS1 we go on the ride now?” “@CAPS2 we @CAPS1,” I said, my heart was pounding so hard I could hear it. That’s when @CAPS4 said, “I @CAPS1 wait.” “@CAPS3 lets get it over with,” I finally agreed. @CAPS4 was nice to wait till I was ready to go on. In conclusion, my cousin is the nicest for waiting so patiently for me. On the up side, I love that ride now and I'm glad he helped me face my fear.

Have you ever been patient before? Well I have. I was sitting there in a nice warm and cozy seat, exhausted and dozing off, waiting for them to call my name, @PERSON1. It kept going through my mind: @PERSON1, @PERSON1, @PERSON1, but nothing ever happened, so I just sat there waiting patiently. My mom was sitting next to me reading an Avon magazine that she had picked up from the small, round wooden table centered right in the middle of the silent orthodontist office. I kept asking myself things like, I wonder what they're gonna do today, I wonder if I'll get my expander off, or what about my top braces. Then I started to stare at the office ladies typing away on their computers. The sound of metal tools was ringing in my ear, coming from the back room. Finally, a girl walked out and the assistant called, "@CAPS1" I was excited and nervous at the same time, but I was proud because I had sat there the whole time patiently without complaining, and it made the eventual call feel like a real achievement.

Patience was on our way to the big city, to go to a very special baseball game. Can you guess what the game was? It was the Detroit Tigers, at the Comerica Park stadium. We were so excited, it was the first time we had ever been in Detroit. "How much longer till we get there?" I asked. "About an hour, why?" my mom replied. "Because it's so boring sitting here for four hours straight." "I know, but you have to be patient." "Okay," I thought in my head. "I wonder how I could be patient for that long?" I just thought for a moment. Then a minute, then boom! I was out cold; for two hours I slept. Then I woke up just as we hit traffic. I asked, "Are we there yet?" "I hope so," my dad said. So I sat there waiting patiently. About ten minutes later I asked if we could turn on the radio. "Sure," my mom said. We sat there for about another twenty minutes. Then we finally started moving, and I tried hardest not to be annoying, thinking about what I was going to do when I got to the game. I was thinking maybe I’ll get a bit expensive, but by the time I thought anything else I heard, "We're here!" "Yay!" I screamed. So we got out of the car and walked about a quarter of a mile to the ticket booth. As we were walking up I thought, "I guess all it does take is patience."

Two weeks ago me and my family went to Six Flags for Fright Fest. The lines were going to be long and I would never be patient, I hate being patient. We went on Gotham City first; the line was only ten minutes. Then we went on the Superman, that one was a little longer. Me and my sister got permission to leave and go on the Riddler. Then we rode the wooden rollercoaster, the one that goes off the track a lot; we waited fifteen minutes between each stop. We finally got to where we saw the coaster, but people with these Flash Passes kept coming. The Flash Pass takes you to the front of the line. When we finally got to the front of the line my patience was gone. The roller coaster went off the track. It was a two-mile coaster but a fun one. That is the time I was patient.

One day, last year I had to be really patient. My mom had told the family that we would be going to Six Flags soon. I was filled with excitement and I couldn’t wait, so I asked her when and she said she didn’t know yet. This made me upset because last time she said that about going somewhere, we ended up not going. The only thing that I knew for sure was that it had to be on a Saturday because she works during the week. I was just happy that school was finally out so I didn’t have to worry about homework. So I waited until Wednesday and then asked my mom if we could go that Saturday. She said no because we would have to plan it more and that we couldn’t randomly go one Saturday. That week I bugged her every day until she finally started planning it. The first thing she did was look at her work schedule to make sure she didn’t have any meetings or projects for the coming Saturday. My stomach dropped when she told me that she had stuff to do, so she kept looking at her schedule. The next free Saturday she had was two weeks away. I was okay with it though because that’s better than nothing. Throughout the next two weeks I saved money up for Six Flags. When the two weeks were finally over I had about fifty dollars saved up and I was practically bouncing off the walls because I was so excited. I think that was the most patient I have ever been.

Patience is waiting without complaining to do something you want to do. When I was at an outdoor mall with my mom, two older sisters, younger brother, niece, and dog, I waited patiently to go to the Apple store to try out the iPad. When I did, I realized that the iPad is awesome! Afterward, we went to get ice cream. My little brother got a root beer flavored slushie, while my niece, dog, and I got vanilla ice cream. After I finished my ice cream I put the container on the ground and let my dog lick the rest from the bottom. We had spent three hours there! What a surprise! Then we went home, feeling happy and content after a fun, patient day.

One time when my brother was patient was when my dad and I taught him how to pitch. My brother easily developed a nice windup and delivery but the arm angle was off. But this didn’t stop him. My dad asked him if he wanted to stop but my brother said, "No!" As time went on, my brother started to get better and better. He now enjoys throwing a seventy-mile-per-hour fastball at a catcher. On days that he’s inaccurate he doesn’t give up; he keeps trying and doesn’t whine. My brother is now the number two starter in the rotation, thanks to his own patience and determination.

"Be patient! It will be here soon, don’t worry," Mom said. A patient person experiences difficulties without complaining. Well, over these few days (which feels like centuries) I have not been this so-called "patient" person. Halloween was coming in a few days and my costume still didn’t come in the mail. I’ve been waiting and waiting but the wait is taking too long! For the fifth time I watch the little red hand on the clock go around. They said it would come on Tuesday but it didn’t. "I’ve been sitting here since ten o’clock; where is the mail truck!" I scream. Then I glance at the clock; it's only ten fifteen. What! It feels like an hour! How can someone bear to wait this long! "It's coming," I say to myself. A few hours later I see a little white postal service truck wander along the street. (Finally, that’s it!) I rush to the window to gaze. Nope, it keeps going past. I sigh then drag myself down the steps. "No!" I sob in agony, "why does this feeling consume me like this?" I stroll to the kitchen and a brown box is on the counter. I get giddy as I take giant sneaky steps to it. "It's here! It's here!" I yelp as I hop up and down. Finally, my patience was rewarded.

One of the many times I was patient was when my mother, my sister, and I went to a restaurant. We ordered our food and found a table. We were sitting there waiting for the food, and the minutes seemed to stretch. I asked my mother, "How much longer is it going to take?" My mother said, "You have to be patient and wait." I fidgeted in my seat, watching other tables get their meals. And then a little while after, our food was done and the waiter brought it to our table. The hot, delicious smell filled the air, and I took my first bite. It was totally worth the wait.

About three or four times I was patient; it was when I was five and it was my birthday and my grandmother went shopping for me. I had to be patient and wait for her to come back with my presents, watching the door for any sign of her return. The other time was when I was seven and it was Christmas day and I was up super early and ready. I had to be patient, once again, and wait for my dad to wake up so I could open my presents, listening for any sound from his room. Then the other time was when my friend had to do something, so I had to be patient again. I waited till he got back, passing the time by looking at my phone. This will conclude my paper on being patient.

The time I was patient was when we went to the beach. "Mom!" I exclaimed. "Let's go, I want to leave; I'm packed and ready to go." My mom and I were in the house packing everyone's things. It was a beautiful morning in July and it was also my step dad's birthday. "Honey, you need to be patient, okay, we have a long drive. Do you have everything you need?" Mom got me thinking. I had to get coloring materials, the portable DVD player, etc. I had my swimsuit and a towel; what else did I need until my stomach growled? It sounded like a bear protecting its cubs, fierce and starving. Then I remembered, ding, I thought in my head, food—that's what I need to get. So I rushed into the kitchen like a race car trying to win a race. I packed turkey sandwiches, pb&j sandwiches, chips: salt and vinegar, sour cream and onion (my favorite), and jalapeno cheddar (yum). Now I have everything, I thought, "let's go." I told my mom and again I rushed out the door. "Got the address?" asked my father. "Yes, Dad, I got it." Later, when we started to go, my sister fell asleep. She was sleeping like a rock the whole way there, although I don't think rocks snore. After two hours of being awake in the car, I thought maybe I should try to sleep, but the excitement was rushing so fast I could feel it; then I fell asleep. I thought I would be able to stay awake the whole way, but I was marked impossible. Finally, my step father yelled, "Wake up!!" I was so tired when I woke up. "Are we there yet?" was the first thing that came out of my mouth. "Yeah," he said, and, of course, the first thing I did was jump up and out of the car! "Stop!" my mother shouted. I paused as if I was a character in a video game and the player pressed pause. "Come take in some of the bags." "Okay," I said with a scowl on my face. "Remember, you have to be patient," Mom said. As I took in the bag, there it was: the condo of my dreams, and the first thing I did was sleep.

Being patient isn’t always that easy. In fact, last year was one year where I had to sit in a car with two rude, screaming, and crying kids for five hours. Last year I was so excited to see my great grandmother in the city with my grandpa. My grandpa is fun to talk to, but later I found out my two younger cousins were coming. This was going to be a long car ride. We packed our things in the car. I brought my iPod and a book, but my cousins brought loud, noisy, and flashy toys they bought just for the ride. As we started heading for the city, I turned my iPod on and found out it only had ten percent battery left. Halfway there I was almost dead of boredom, and the kids were just settling down. When I was sure they were asleep, I decided to join them. Whack! I awoke to a slobbery slap to the face. "We’re here!" my cousin announced. Finally, I said to myself as I was still waking up with a sore and stiff neck. After we were done visiting my grandmother, it was about three hours later and my cousins were all asleep again, and I knew it was going to be a nice, quiet ride home.

There was a day when I was patient and I was so nice, and this girl was so in a hurry she was getting on my nerves because she kept pushing me and hitting me. So I just let her in front of me and we were in the lunch line and a lot of people were ready for lunch. The lunch lady said to stop pushing her. Then we were in class and so I raised my hand and she said to be patient. I said I am patient so shut up, so shut up please, but she didn’t shut up. So I had another time and the teacher called on me, so she got mad at me. It was a long and frustrating day, but in the end, I managed to keep my composure through it all.

I am going to write about the time that I was patient. One day, after my family and I came back from church, I asked my mom if she could make breakfast, but she would not answer me because she was on the phone with my grandma and my grandma talks a lot. It was so agonizing. For example, I kept pacing back and forth in the kitchen, but then I just sat down on a chair and tried to wait quietly. After an hour of patience, my mom and grandma finally said goodbye and hung up the phone and I finally got my breakfast. The wait felt endless, but my patience was rewarded with a warm meal.

One summer day, it was about ten o'clock. My mom woke me, my brother, and dad to get ready; I don’t know what we was getting ready for, but we got on the road as soon as we could. I fell back to sleep in the car when we were on the highway. I woke up from a big screech of the brakes and when I looked up, we were in a long line of cars. "Where are we?" I asked. "Six Flags," said my brother. I could hear impatient people all around me. They were honking, screaming and yelling while people tried to pay their way into the park. It seemed like we were moving faster than some of the other people, and we was one of the first people to get in first. That was the most impatient group of people I’d ever seen, and I was glad we finally made it inside.

Please stop her crying! I just wanted to get out of the car and walk home. There were seven of us in a suburban that were all smushed together! So we couldn't even move our arms; I felt like I was locked in jail with chains on me. It was five o'clock in the morning and I saw a big sign that read welcome to Florida. So at that point we only had a hour or so left and I was so excited. We finally made it to our destination Key West. It was the longest trip of my life! But I tried my hardest to stay patient and wait. But in the long run I realized I didn't care because I had a whole weekend of waves and a temperature of eighty-five degrees. When I thought about how long it was to get here I didn't even want to think about how long it is going to take to get home! But now I know I have the patience to go home, and the memory of the beach will make the return trip easier.

A time when I was patient was just yesterday. I had just finished part one of the test and I was very anxious and I wanted to get up and move around, but we were taking the state exam so I could not. Instead I entertained myself in any way I could such as pretending to sing, writing songs in my head repeatedly, and even twiddling my thumbs! So finally the teacher let us get up and talk. I was sitting next to some of my friends so I just talked to them. Somehow we got into talking about dungeons and dragons; they kept asking me what class they would be and what they were. Anyway I kept trying to talk but I keep getting interrupted so I just relaxed and waited for my turn. Finally it was my turn to talk, but we had to go to lunch so I never did get to say what mine was. This is a time when I was patient, and I learned that sometimes waiting calmly is the only thing you can do.

Have you ever got annoyed because someone kept saying be patient? I have and I'm gonna tell you about the time I was patient. One time I was on my way to visit my grandparents, the plane ride wasn’t as bad as what I'm gonna tell you. When we got to the border crossing we had to pass through the immigration border; it was hot!!! I think the temperature hit one hundred degrees? We had to wait in this small, cramped room with about fifty people, and they had no A.C. All of us were waiting for the bus to come, and after two long hours a bus finally arrived. We were getting on when about ten people came barging in front, so we missed that bus. Then we waited again for a bus, and after another three hours a bus arrives again. We were trying to get on, but then again we got pushed out of the way. So we missed that bus; I was so frustrated and so did my family. Another thing I got frustrated at was there were thousands of flies all over the place, buzzing around incessantly. So we waited, and after two more hours a bus arrives, but my little brother was in the bathroom, so we missed that bus. My mom was telling me to calm down and be patient, so I stayed patient until the fourth bus came. We got on, but the bus didn’t go where we were supposed to, so we had to go back to the same place we were in, but again my mom says stay patient. One of the officers over at the place saw how long we were waiting, and once the next bus arrived after another four hours and thirty minutes, he held everybody else up, let me and my family get on, and told the driver “take them by there self,” so we had the bus to our selves, and you know what, it was all worth it in the end.

There was a time when I had to wait on handling my personal business. My sisters and I came into the house and one of them went to handle their personal business while I was being patient, trying not to yell and knock hard on the door, telling her to hurry up in whatever they were doing. By the way, my older sister is fourteen years old and my younger sister is ten years old. I had waited and waited, being very patient not to be laying on the door, banging on it, even though I really had to handle my personal business. It felt good to be very patient around them, who are non-patient people, because think about it: when you really have to handle something in the bathroom or restroom, people will think you are a rushing person instead of a patient one. Anyway, they will talk about it to anyone that he or she knows as a bad thing when they are just talking about anything. In the end, this was not a time where we wait to be patient for others; it was a time for me to practice my own patience.

Patience may seem easy but, however, it can be hard. Waiting in line, waiting for a package to arrive, etc. all requires patience. Everyone, no matter how young or old, has patience just like I did when I was in fifth grade. Each day I wondered if it was a dream or a nightmare. Everyday when I was in fifth grade I always wanted something that would change my life eternally—a little sister. After three long years, that wish would finally come true. I was very patient waiting for our letter to be granted or denied. Before I knew it, my mom, dad, and I were on a plane headed straight for China. There we would see the Great Wall, the Forbidden City, and Tiananmen Square, not to mention our main purpose to adopt a little sister. I had no idea what I was in for. I was patient for two more weeks, and then we went to the lobby and she was with her caregiver along with all the other families waiting for their child too. I couldn’t believe we were the first ones to receive our gift from China. Big moment! The moment my mom tried to take her she started wailing, pinching, kicking, and who knows what else. After an hour or so she calmed down and she calmly played with her toys and such. That night we went out for dinner at a local restaurant. My dad ordered a milkshake and he let her try some of it; that was also a big moment. He did not get it back until the glass was empty. We soon learned that she would be a rollercoaster with her ups and downs. She loved cake and ice cream and wanted dad only. It was dad’s dream come true. In conclusion, you will use patience everyday no matter how big or small. Patience will work its way into your life no matter how hard it is. Everyone has patience; the question is, “will you use it?”

A person I know that's patient is my dad; he is very patient. Like one time we were in the drive-through at McDonald's, and soon as we pulled up, the lady was like "just one second" and she left. We were sitting there for five whole minutes, and I saw people getting out of their cars and going in the restaurant to order their food. But my dad, he just sat there, adjusting the air conditioning, until the lady came back. I was so mad that the lady made us sit there for another five minutes, but then I was happy cause I got my food. Then when we were pulling off, my dad said, "See, that's why patience got us our hot food," my double cheeseburger and my large iced tea with chocolate chip cookies. My dad taught me a valuable lesson that day about staying calm and not letting frustration lead to nothing but drama and not happiness.

The time I had to be patient was when I had to wait in line to ride the roller coaster at an amusement park. First, the park was fun, but waiting in line took patience; we had to wait in line for about a half hour. Some people kept leaving because it was too long of a wait. I had to stay patient if I wanted to ride the ride. Second, I was excited to ride the roller coaster, so I stayed in line. Staying patient was a little hard when people were pushing and cutting in front, but it was worth it when I got to ride. The feeling of the wind and the speed made the wait completely worthwhile. As you can see, sometimes it's good to stay patient, but when you get to do something fun, it's worth it. When people push you, you just had to stay calm and be patient, and you will eventually get your turn.

I’m always patient. I’m really patient until my birthday, and then when I get presents I don’t need to be patient anymore because I wait a whole year for presents and then I wait for @CAPS1 because it’s only like a month away from my birthday. And this year I’m being patient until @CAPS1 because I’ve already know what I’m getting. But that’s what I’m patient for, just about nothing else I’m patient for, like waiting for dinner or for a show to start. My patience is saved for those two big days, and the rest of the time I just want things to happen right away. It’s a special kind of waiting, reserved only for the best rewards.

Patience means being understanding and tolerant. I find patience difficult to come by, along with many other people. Some people are graced with the gift of patience. Those people find it easy to wait even when it’s the night the final book of your favorite book series comes out. “@CAPS1 @CAPS2,” the clock taunted me by moving slower than ever. Why @CAPS10 wasn’t back yet I didn’t know. All I knew was going to happen that night that was a very bad thing. It must have been the unbearable heat getting to me because when the door slammed shut @CAPS10 argued that @CAPS4’d only been gone for five fast minutes. I didn’t believe her, but we climbed into the car and drove down the twisty, turning road. We had timed our car ride perfectly to see red lights at every stoplight. It was like the lights were mad at us. We also got stuck behind every slow person with no way to get around them. Just as I had a scream budding inside me we saw a green light and cruised into @LOCATION1. Coming up on my right came the book store and my jitters became more uncontrollable. I bounced up and down like I was on a trampoline and stopped the split second I saw the line in front of us. “No way!” I shouted, “I don’t have any patience left to wait in this monstrosity of a line.” It was like the whole town was in on making me as annoyed as possible. I lugged the lawn chairs from our van to wait in line. Flop. I fell into the black chair and waited. This was going to be a long night. “@NUM1 minutes till midnight,” my mom explained to me. “That’s impossible,” I told her. “You can make it.” She was right, @NUM1 minutes wasn’t that long of a wait. I breathed in the smell of coffee coming from inside and listened to the hum of chatter among the people. The @NUM1 minutes would be over soon, and for the first time that night I was patient. Click the seatbelt went into place and I cracked open the final book of the @CAPS6 @CAPS7 trilogy. What will happen? How is it going to end? My mind was full of questions. “So, was that wait really that bad?” my mom asked. “I guess not,” I answered sheepishly. “Being patient paid off,” my mom lectured. I didn’t reply I was already reading a mile a minute. I learned being patient really does pay off and not complaining makes life a lot easier. Patience is understanding and now that I’m a little better at being patient, things will be a lot better.

One time I was patient because the teacher had to tell me something. So I waited by the door but then she had to go to the office so I had to wait some more, just standing there quietly. When the teacher came back she told me thanks for being patient and gave me a sticker. Patience really means you can wait without getting upset. Some kids don’t be patient; they get so mad for example, there was @NUM1 kids in one group we were playing a game and they would get so mad because they didn’t get called on a lot. But the game was random; you pick a stick and whoever’s stick it was went. So being patient means you have to be able to wait for your turn without getting angry, understanding that everyone will get a chance eventually.

Patience is something or someone who likes waiting for someone or something. Patience is part of life. I sometimes don’t have patience but I should have patience, because without patience you will get nothing, because something in life you have to wait for. Good things often take time to arrive, and if you rush, you might miss them. That is why you should have patience, to receive the good things that come to those who can wait calmly and without complaint. It is a valuable quality that makes life smoother and more peaceful for everyone.

“Let’s go!”, I yelled while running to the entrance of the huge theme park. “Wait a minute, you got to wait for your friend”, my mom said. As I stopped to wait for my mom, my best friend @PERSON1 and his brother @PERSON2, I started to kick the rocks to keep me occupied. Once they finally caught up to me, we walked into the huge theme park. “Let’s go to the top roller coaster first!”, I said excitedly. “Okay, we can go on it, but me and @PERSON1 are staying in the back”, my mom said. “Great, because me and @PERSON3 are going in the front row!”, @PERSON2 yelled. As we started to walk to the line it said that it would be a @NUM1 minute wait for us to go. After we got in line I thought to myself, wow this is a long line, looking at all the people ahead of us. It wasn’t that much longer that we finally got to the rollercoaster ride. “Click!”, the belt buckle sounded when we all got in the rollercoaster. “Woo!”, everybody said when we took off. After that fun ride, I told myself I can be patient when I need to be, because the reward was definitely worth the wait.

@PERSON2 and I went to the store. @CAPS1 was picking up some marshmallows and chocolate to make s'mores. @CAPS1 was walking down aisle six when @CAPS1 came upon a huge bunch of people looking to buy stuff for s'mores. So @PERSON2 and I went in the line. @CAPS1 sat there for at least fifty minutes waiting for marshmallows and chocolate; but @CAPS1 came out with two marshmallows and two chocolate packs. I asked her, "@PERSON2, why do you have two!" @CAPS1 said that when she waited they were getting rid of them so they gave her two for the price of one. I smiled and we thanked her! When we went back to the car we told @CAPS2, our other sister "@PERSON1", that we got two. @NUM1 said something, and @CAPS2 sister snickered. We went back into @PERSON2’s car and put the bag in the trunk where one other grocery bag was, and then took off. We got home and @PERSON1 ate three, I ate two, and @PERSON2 ate five. @CAPS1 had watched us. Thank you.

You have heard before: patience is a virtue. If you don’t know already, being patient means you are understanding and tolerant, able to handle delays without getting upset. The opposite of this is probably having a temper, or having a very short time before you get truly angry. I believe having patience in life is incredibly important, and I try to have patience every day. I believe that life is a marathon, not a sprint, and by this I mean if something takes time, you have lots of it to figure things out. I related life to sports, because I am a fairly good athlete. I play football, which also requires lots of patience. When I make a good pass and my receiver drops it, I remember to have patience with him, just as my coach did with me when I was learning. Football is a team game, and we all have to have patience with each other to succeed. Although sports are a great example, patience goes much further than that, you must have patience with yourself before you can have patience with others. And what do I mean by that? Whether you’re a kid or an adult, you must forgive yourself when you do wrong. If you come in late for work, you must brush it off and say to yourself, “It's okay, don’t do it again.” Make sure that you forget about everything but what you just said. And once again I go back to sports. If you lose a game, you look at the film, realize what you did wrong, and don’t make those mistakes again. Then, you forget about the loss and concentrate on winning the next game. I believe patience is one of the most important virtues a person can have, helping us through daily challenges and long-term goals.

Patience is where you can wait or stay put for someone or something without getting overly upset. Some people can be very, very patient, calmly enduring long waits. Patience is one of the worlds most important lifeskills, a true virtue in our fast-paced world. Having my best friend live across the street is great. He has one older sister, named Sarah. Sarah was blessed with downs syndrom. This basically means she doesn’t understand things as fast as you and I, needing more time to process information. Knowing Sarah as well as I do also comes with a downside, a challenge. You need to be extremely patient. Sarah is a wonderful person and, I guess a great teacher, but when you are having a bad day, be grateful because not everyone is as blessed as you, and we can all learn from her example of joy.

Everyone has to have patience. Everyone has patience; it just depends if it is a long patience or a short patience. People always say, “Patience is a virtue.” Teachers need a lot of patience for what they do, especially if they are first-grade teacher, dealing with young children who are still learning how to behave. When you get into high school, all the way up, teachers expect older kids and young adults to be more well-behaved. Now if you have a job that you focus on adults, your patience might not need to be as high or long. Like my dad, he is a lawyer and he deals with adults; his patience is not close to what my mom's is. My mom also deals with adults, but she grew up with four brothers and she was the oldest, which might have taught her more tolerance. My dad expects people to be on time within a couple of minutes. Whenever I say, "Come pick me up at seven o’clock," he will be there by seven o’clock exactly. Now my mom, when she comes to pick me up and I say seven o’clock, she will be maybe ten minutes either way, early or late. That is my story about the people I know and their different levels of “Patience.”

Patience, my mom, my sister, and I were sitting on the couch and we were going to go to the store to get groceries and then go to the school clothes shopping. My sister didn’t really want to go, but my mom made her, so she was already mad about that. We went and got food that she apparently “didn’t like,” but she was just being her normal self, acting with a sense of entitlement and greed. “We are here,” said my mom, “we are at the mall to go shopping,” she said to my sister. She doesn’t like the popular stores or the styles that I do, maybe because she doesn’t think she can fit into them, but anyways we went in and she didn’t see anything “she liked.” So she started throwing a temper tantrum right there in the store. My mom was so patient with her, speaking calmly and trying to find a compromise. I couldn’t believe how calm she remained. So we lost track of time and she took me to get my spare items while my sister finally calmed down. It was a long afternoon, but my mom's patience made it manageable.

It was a Tuesday morning and John was in class messing around at his desk like usual. John isn’t usually the patient kind of person. Then his teacher asked a question to the class and John had thought in his head that it was one of the best answers. John’s hand shot straight up in the air, one of the first hands raised. “Okay class! Lots of answers,” Mrs. Berry said. Mrs. Berry is kind of more of a round person, with some big glasses to see, but all of the students love her as an English teacher. “James, what's your answer?” she asked. James was just scratching his head. “Okay, never mind. Sarah, your turn?” “Is it a type of language?” Sarah answered. “That's a good answer though,” the teacher replied. There were about five more hands in the air. In John’s head he just wanted to blurt out his answer, but he knew that this time he was going to at least try to be patient. “Let's hear these last two people and then we will go to recess,” Mrs. Berry exclaimed. John was raging with impatience inside his head, but outside he looked as calm as could be. “It’s a comparison,” another student said. “Is it a metaphor?” the teacher asked. “Yes, you’re right, it was a metaphor,” she confirmed. “Oh darn it, that was my answer!” John mumbled under his breath. But even though another classmate took his answer, John was happy because he knew he had managed to wait patiently for his turn.

A time when I was patient was last year, every day I had to be patient because of my aunt. Last year, my aunt would pick me up in the back of the school. Once when me and my dad were supposed to go to the races, I had to be patient. But I had to wait for my dad, and he said he was getting off work at five o’clock, and that’s the time the races start. I show loyalty to a lot of people that I know, and they show me loyalty in return. This mutual trust is built over time through shared experiences and consistent actions. For instance, I stand by my friends during difficult times, offering my support without hesitation, and they do the same for me when I face my own challenges. This reciprocal relationship forms a strong bond that is not easily broken. We keep each other's secrets and defend one another when needed, creating a foundation of reliability. This consistent exchange of faithfulness proves that loyalty is a two-way street, essential for any lasting and meaningful connection between people.

Finally, after four long months of persistent work, I did it. I got up on the bar and performed the cast to handstand perfectly. All my waiting was over. That day, my coach told me, “I told you that you could do it; it just takes time and patience, but today was your day and you did it.” This is a time I had to use patience to achieve my new skill. I learned that being patient is hard, and all you can do is wait and see what your perseverance will eventually bring you.
