For this passage I am going to tell a story about the most patient person in the world. In the Old Testament long ago there was a man named Job who was very rich, very happy, and was loyal to God. One day the devil pointed this out and said that Job would easily turn away from God. God denied this, so the devil said, "Let me destroy his crops and livestock, let me take his camels." God said, "Fine, but do not hurt Job himself," and the devil agreed. When Job was having a bad day the next day, one of his servants came in and said, "A great fire has fallen and your livestock was attacked by wolves; we are the only ones left." Then another servant ran in and said, "Your camels have been stolen!" Then a third servant came in and said, "The roof has fallen in the hall; your family has been killed!" Even though Job was beginning to become sad and sat in the dust, he would not curse God. Soon the devil came again, but this time made Job horribly sick. Even though this went on for years, he still would not curse God. When God saw this, he sent the devil away and healed Job. He blessed him with a new family and fortune, and then Job was happy again.

A long wait began when I was only four at the time. I had moved to Florida. Yes, moved to Orlando, Florida from Michigan, Novi. Quite a long way down south for me, but I was a young little girl who didn’t care too, too much. So I lived in Florida, went to kindergarten, made friends, moved into a new house, and so on until I was seven. That is when I found out that we were moving again, back to Michigan. Well, now I wasn’t four anymore. I had a lot of amazing friends here in Florida, in particular two of them, and now I would have to start all over again. I didn’t hate the idea, but I didn’t love it either. Of course, it didn’t exactly matter; we were moving anyway. I knew from the beginning that I would easily have fun and make new friends. The only thing I didn’t want to leave behind were the old friends, memories, and all the other stuff I loved about this place. So I took along my memories, promised to keep in touch with friends, and then moved. Novi was different but good. There were plenty of changes to adjust to, but it was pretty easy overall. I made plenty of new friends with whom I now hang out every day. I’ve slipped into life here like you slip into bed every night. What I do is fun and feels like normal. I have now been living here for four years. I have been exchanging letters, emails, events, and memories with friends down in Florida and friends here all this time. But even so, I long to go back down for a visit. I have been patiently waiting for it to happen. Now, I think that patience is paying off, because I finally get to visit this year. My only difficulty has been that I don’t get to see everyone, but not for long. I see all my friends here all the time, and now I’ll get to see my older friends too. Yipee for me! I can’t wait! The years of waiting have finally provided me with this wonderful opportunity.

When I got bit by a dog I was in Houghton when it happened. The dog jumped up and bit me in my face. So my dad and his friend put me in the truck and we went to Portage, a hospital in Houghton. They had me sitting in a hospital bed for three hours. Then I got shipped to Hurley. And then I sat in the hospital watching TV, still waiting for surgery. Two hours later I got it. So all together I sat for five hours. And all that time it could have got infected. And I got processed as a patient so they could keep their records. But I had to have patience; after all, I was a patient, and that is what the situation required of me until the very end.

I am patient every Thanksgiving and Christmas. I have to be patient every Thanksgiving. I get so hungry I start to whine and I have to wait for the meal. Today was Christmas Eve and Tommy, the boy, was so excited, he was bounding off the walls! "I wonder what Santa will bring us," said Tommy, looking through a catalog. "I want this and this, and this, oh, definitely this." "Tommy, you need to be patient. Christmas is tomorrow and you need to do your share and help clean the tree," Tommy’s mother says. "But I want presents now!" Tommy whines. "You know," his father says with a grin, "if you aren’t a good boy, Santa will only bring you peanut shells." Finally, Tommy gives in and says, "Alright, I’ll help." It seemed like many many hours later to Tommy, and it was time to go to bed. He was happy that he had been patient, because he knew, in the morning, he would have presents waiting for him under the tree.

Patience. It was a warm summer afternoon around two o'clock and I was at my sister’s house playing Wii with my niece, when my brother-in-law Matt comes into the living room and says, “I’m bored, lets do something today!” So we all decided that we would go to Michigan’s Adventures for the day. My sister Sarah told us to pack the cooler with snacks and drinks and to put pillows and blankets in the back seat of the car. But little did we know that we were actually having six hours to drive to go to Six Flags and that Sarah, Matt and my mom have been planning this for weeks. After being in the car for two hours I moaned “are we there yet?” “No,” said Sarah, “we’re lost.” “Oh,” I replied. But I really didn’t think about how we were lost because we’ve been to Michigan’s Adventures a thousand times before. For the rest of the ride there I was pretty quiet. In other words, I was very asleep. When I woke up it was because my niece was shaking me with excitement. I stretched and squinted from the sun’s rays, and when my eyes adjusted to the light I looked around and realised that we were at Six Flags! When we got in, the first ride we rode was the Superman; on that ride you sit and things lock around your legs and stomach and it tilts you over so it’s like you're flying. We wanted to ride it so bad but the line was two and a half hours long. While we were standing in line we found things to do like swing and play on the metal railing, play I Spy and all sorts of things, and when we finally were on and off the ride I realized that it was really fun, and worth it, and that I was patient and didn’t complain.

My mom is very patient. The reason why my mom is patient is because when she goes to the beauty shop she calls three hours of waiting not a long time, calmly reading a magazine the entire time. Another reason she is patient is because if I don't do my chores she doesn't get very upset; she just asks me to do it again in a calm voice. My mom is also very patient when it comes to work because she does not get frustrated when she has a lot of work to do like writing a five-thousand-word paper, methodically working through it section by section. Her consistent calmness in these everyday situations truly shows her character.

Patience is the art of waiting calmly. Patience is dealing with teachers at school and trying to understand their point of view. Without patience you and your younger sibling or your teacher would constantly be fighting. That’s why patience is so important. Patience should be constantly exercised. In sports it helps you accept the referee's call, whether its a good or bad call. Patience is also needed when learning a new skill because you’re not going to be good at it the first time you try. Patience makes perfect. School is a great place to use patience, whether learning something new or dealing with a difficult teacher. You need to use it while dealing with small children because they are always trying to get reactions out of you whether they’re being good or bad. In the end, it’s a tool that helps you navigate daily life. It's very important to have that ability, whether for small things like learning or big things like testing. It is better to have patience than not, as it leads to more peaceful and successful outcomes.

In my life there has been many times where I have been patient and times when I have not been patient. For example, the other day I asked my mom if she would drive me to Target so I could get some gum. My mom said yes, but I had to wait a little bit. I was patient by waiting calmly for my mom to take me. When I got to Target my mom told me to hurry up. I ran into a long line at the checkout, so I had to wait. Instead of getting all mad I was patient. Also instead of my mom getting mad she was also patient. One example of me being impatient is about a week ago when I asked my dad to play catch with me. He said yes but that I had to wait a little while. I got very mad for some reason and lost my patience. I started yelling about why I had to wait. I then realized I was being rude and that I had lost my patience. I said I was sorry and then we played catch, which was much more enjoyable because we were both calm.

Patience is one of the things that people need to have. I remember when I was in the store and my cousin wanted to go home and her mom was being patient and said to wait. My cousin was impatient that day because she wanted to go home immediately. I think that patience will help you go through life. For an example, if you were going out with your friend and she was driving and you got tired and wanted to go home and said "let's go," then you were the one that was impatient because she was the one driving. Patience will always be one of the things we have to practice. If you are patient you could do things much better. You have to sometimes wait for managers to call you to get the next job you applied for. But you can't be impatient or you won't get hired for that job. You always have to be patient because you don't know what would happen if you weren't patient; it truly is a key to navigating life's many challenges successfully.

A time when I am patient is when I want something really bad, like a new phone or to get on the computer or something similar. But that is not the only way to be patient; you also have to be patient in other places like in church, where you must sit quietly, and in the doctor's office, where you wait for your name to be called. So there are many different ways and situations in life where you have to be patient and wait calmly for your turn.

I was patient when I had to wait in a very long line at a leader amusement park! In Florida, I had to wait for three hours for the ride, The Mamba. It went from zero to eighty in just a few seconds! When going eighty, the coaster went straight up and then stopped at the very top, which was two hundred yards high; we just sat there for like ten seconds! Then it moved again and we went straight down at a thrilling speed; it was really cool and felt like flying. It was definitely worth the long wait in the hot sun. That was the time I was patient and it paid off with an amazing experience.

It takes a lot of patience especially when you are travelling for many hours straight. When I was ten, we went to Australia for a half a year. Me, my mom, and my dad left at five in the morning for the airport. We waited there for a long time before our flight. When we finally got on the plane, we took the hour-long flight to Los Angeles. Then we had a fourteen-hour flight to Los Angeles, which felt endless. We waited in those airports for a long time between flights. Then came the fifteen-hour flight to Sydney; that was the longest flight I’ve ever been on. The plane was a huge double-decker jet with many people. Then we took the final two-hour flight to Hawk Bay. It was a really long and tiring trip that took a ton of patience. Well, we went there because my dad was making a golf course, which also takes a lot of patience, but it is a lot more fun to build. That was the most patient I’ve ever had to be in my entire life.

Last year I went to New York City with my mom, my step-dad, two of my brothers, my aunt, my uncle, and, my aunt with her two kids Jack and Zack. The first place we went was the Statue of Liberty. We got in line for the ferry that takes you to the island where the statue is. The line was huge and gigantic; I thought, "Oh great," because it was nearly ninety degrees outside and we were going to be waiting here for at least an hour. After about a half hour I noticed that the line goes into a building. What was in there? I wondered. All of the kids except me were complaining, and my parents were starting to get irritated. We finally got in the building and guess what, another gigantic line! Yay, what fun! At least the building was air conditioned, which was a relief. We had to go through metal detectors and stuff before we got on the ferry. The ferry ride wasn't bad but it was quite full of other tourists. On the bright side we got to sit down for a while. We all got off the ferry and looked up at Lady Liberty; it was actually really big. Unfortunately they closed down the part where you get to go inside it because it was so hot that day. Oh well, it was cool enough just seeing it from the outside. We walked around the entire island and were trying to find the ferry to go back. We found the ferry and waited in the line again for a long time until we finally got on the boat. I was proud of myself for not complaining the whole day. Apparently my mom was too because when we got back to the hotel she pulled me aside and thanked me for being so patient and well-behaved during the long outing.

Patience is like waiting your turn to talk in a conversation or waiting for a slow webpage to load on your computer; patience can be helpful in many ways such as waiting calmly till you get to your destination on a long trip or waiting for the person you called to answer the phone so you can talk to them. Patience can help you experience difficulties and delays without complaining or getting upset, making the situation easier for everyone involved. It is a valuable skill that makes daily life much smoother and more pleasant.

Two summers ago I went to Canada and Maine. We had to drive for eight hours straight. I mostly just sat in the back seat and listened to my CD player. It was a very boring car ride. One time my sister and my mom were pacint was when l went to dicks sporting goods and l wanted a new bag and adidas sandles and crazy scocks. I do not have much patience because this year I’m getting a laptop. Every day I look up one I have in mind, but I can't download anything on my iPod. Last year for Christmas I got an iPod favor, but I had to wait till Christmas Eve because my family pitched in and we bought it on Black Friday. So I looked at youtube videos on iPod touches because I could not wait any longer. It is hard to have patience when you want something so much, feeling as if you already have it in your hands.

A time to be patient is all the time. If you were not patient you would run all the time, rushing from one thing to the next without pause. You will never have time for your family and your self, just like my mother tells me when I’m eating: “slow down, you’re not going anywhere.” If your food was about to go somewhere, you would not be able to catch it because you are too tired from all the rushing to do it. Always take your time to learn how to be patient; it is easy if you just take your time and breathe, focusing on the moment you are in right now.

One day me and my mom, dad, and sister were going to Universal Studios to go to the Wizarding World, as it is a famous attraction place. Me and my dad are walking and he asks me if I want to go on this roller coaster called the Dueling Dragons. I wasn’t too sure about this because it was my first time on a roller coaster, so I say no, but I never knew if I liked roller coasters, so I said fine, let's go. There is still like twenty people in front of us, so my sister is like, “When are we going?” and it feels like the time is going slower, and slower and slower. So my sister is like, “Finally, our turn is next, five more times!” Finally our group goes and my dad says, “It's ours!” I take my sunglasses and my dad takes his sunglasses and we sit in the front. Here it goes climbing the track and my sister is like, “Ok this is fun,” then we go like seventy miles per hour. I can't even scream, we are going so fast, then we go upside down and twist and stuff, then it ends. My sister is like, “No, no, no, I like roller coasters!” and that is the time I was patient.

On a morning during summer break when every one of my family members wake up at seven or eight o’clock am, me, my brother, and my sisters told my mom, “Can we play the PlayStation and the laptop?” My mom said, “Sure, but you guys have to wait for each other’s turn,” and we said, “Ok.” Then we played it. Each person had one and a half hour to play on both things. I let my brother and sisters play first because I’m the older one and I have to wait patiently until it was my turn. Well, until it was my turn, we would have to take turns playing the game on the things. We would do that until the day was done, or until tomorrow was done. That would be it until next weekend or until we can play it again. And that’s what I say I do as being patient at home and to respect my brother and sisters.

There were many times when I was patient. There was a time when I was patient for a whole month. I was getting a new basketball video game, but it didn’t come out until another month. So I had to be patient. I could not wait until the game came out; it seemed like it took forever. It was the day before the game came out and I lost the money that I was going to use to get the game. So then I had to save up sixty more dollars to buy the game that I wanted. I had to get two weekend jobs so that I could help make the money that I lost. So two weeks passed by, then I went to the game store so I could buy the game. When I walked in the store, the manager told me there are no more copies of any basketball games. So I had to be patient for a whole other two weeks, and I got very mad. So I waited two weeks for the game and I finally got the game. I was so mad I had to be patient that long, but I got what it was worth in the end. So that is my story about being patient.

A time when I was patient was at my grandma’s house in Florida. My cousins and I had to wait for my grandma to get home so we could go to the beach. After about an hour of waiting, my cousin and I started to play video games to entertain ourselves so the time went faster. My grandma had probably worked for eight hours. Then at three pm, I decided to watch a movie. I had been patient for the whole movie, and in the middle of the movie, my grandma finally got home. We all waited patiently till she was ready to go to the beach. This was a time when I had been patient, and it felt good to finally get our reward.

I remember a time when someone I know was patient with me. It was near the beginning of the seventh grade. I had enrolled in band that year, playing the trumpet. We played songs and had tests to ensure everyone was playing right. But on my tests, my band teacher, Mr. Davis, noticed something funny. I was playing the wrong notes. He told me I needed a long private lesson if I wanted to play my notes right. So one afternoon after school, I took the lesson. I started by playing my notes for him. He said they were wrong. Then Mr. Davis broke down the notes for me one by one. He told me the correct way to play the notes. He had me play the notes again and again, sometimes together. When I messed up, he showed me how to play them, being very patient with me. Then, finally, I was playing every note correctly. The lesson was about forty-five minutes and he was patient the entire process. Now I play my notes right thanks to the lesson and Mr. Davis’s patience. Now I know that if I need more lessons in the future, I can count on Mr. Davis’s patience to help me through any required classes.

This year I tried out for the eighth grade volleyball team for my school. There were so many girls trying out that I was nervous for what team I was going to get on or if I even would make a team. So I worked on my hardest and figured, I had had experience from the other teams I was on before and I was now confident I would make the team. After three days of tryouts they had grouped us into either The A, B, or intermural team, according to your skill level. We got a letter that afternoon, and I made it into the A team! We then got right into practice and games, winning most of the games, and improving on working as a team. Then a couple days ago, we played against Northern Middle School. As northern middle school, we obviously were rivals and were determined to beat them, for “bragging rights,” we joked, but most important because we really wanted to do our best. The first game was very close, but we won, and I played about half the time, serving, hitting and moving all around the court. I felt very confident in the second game also, even though I didn’t play as much as I wished; I still had fun! In the game of volleyball, you play three games in a match. The best two out of three wins the match. At that time we had won both of the games, which meant we won, however we still had to play the third game. Even though we won the match our coach wanted us to win all three! “Pretend like it’s the winning point, and play your hardest,” she would say. So as the third game started, I was on the bench with some of the other players. I waited till about half of the game and wondered when I would be in. Time had gone by and I was getting discouraged because I hadn’t played yet. I asked the coach a couple of times if I was going in or not, but she was too busy watching and coaching. So I sat, and about one point before the game ended, she looked at me and said, “can you do it?” I shot right up and subbed in. I went to the back of the line, tossed the ball in the air, and hit it! I had made the winning point! In the end I learned to trust my coach and to have patience, because it usually is for the best! But boy did I have a great time serving the winning point. It really taught me a valuable lesson about waiting for the right moment.

The word patience means a lot of things. It can mean waiting for something and much more. It also talks a lot about self-control. It takes time and effort to develop. I’m the type who complains a lot and I don’t have much patience. Other people, they don’t complain; they just have it. A lot of teenagers have no patience. As you get older you can develop patience, though some adults still don’t have it; it depends on if you work at it. It also depends on what the person has gone through in life and the lessons they have learned along the way.

My mother is the most patient person I know. When she drops me off at practice she waits two and a half hours for me to cheer, fly, and dance the whole routine. When I go to science programs she waits at least two hours until it’s over. Every morning she waits on me to finish getting ready, never honking the horn from the driveway. After school she waits on me to buy something at the snack table in the lobby, never hurrying me along. All that she asks is for us to return the favor one day. She doesn’t rush us unless we’re late. And she always hugs us before we leave, her patience a quiet and steady gift.

I think patience is when someone is able to wait and not complain. I was never patient, so here is a story I have made up. One day there was a girl named Ally. She really wanted to go to the park. I have to be patient when I’m taking the state mandated standardized tests at school. I’m patient because I have to wait for my classmates to finish their own state mandated standardized tests. Patience is a truly good thing to have in life. Good things often come from practicing patience, and bad things tend not to happen as a result. But what exactly is patience? Patience is being able to handle problems and delays without whining and complaining about them constantly. Patience is being able to wait calmly while others around you simply can’t. Some people are naturally very impatient, such as my dad at some times. For a month or so, he had been diligently saving up his extra money for a new television. Once he had finally saved enough, he immediately went out and got a new forty-two inch flat screen television. However, if he had waited only about another single week, he could’ve gotten a model about a foot bigger for the exact same price during a major sale. Let’s say your little sister is incessantly bagging you and you ask her nicely to stop, but she just won’t listen. So instead of totally flipping out on her, which will undoubtedly get you into tons of trouble, you can just patiently wait for a parent to get home so she gets in trouble and you don't, which is the wiser outcome.

Once upon a time there was a girl named Ella. She had always dreamed of one day being a real princess. Every birthday or holiday present she ever got was either a fancy dress or a piece of shiny jewelry. She absolutely loved to try on different dresses in front of her mirror. She had two sisters, both a year older than Ella; their names were Grace and Anna. Their house is an old, charming house located deep in the woods. One day Ella went out to the end of the driveway to get the mail, and a man dressed in a fine tuxedo gave her a letter that looked very fancy and important. Ella carefully opened the letter and read it aloud, it said “Dear Ella, you are invited to a royal ball at the king's castle on the night of the harvest moon at eight pm.” Ella screamed in pure excitement. Ella decided to go to the mall immediately to look for a perfect ball gown. She found a beautiful, sparkling gown but it was far too much money. She asked the kind lady at the front desk if there was any way they could lower the price if she helped around the store for a couple of days. The lady agreed, and Ella accepted the offer. She worked and worked for hours, sweeping and organizing for two full days. And finally, her patience paid off. She was allowed to take the gorgeous dress home. She drove home and quickly put the dress on. She only had an hour before the ball, so she had to hurry. She put her makeup and best jewelry on and looked at her self in the mirror and said with a smile, "I did it." She got in the car and drove to the castle, which was so beautiful with the way the moonlight hit the gold paint on the gates. Ella got out of the car and walked inside the grand castle. She walked down the wide staircase and every one stared in awe. It was Ella's best day of her life to have everyone think she was so beautiful. She went to the dance floor and danced with several handsome guys. Then the prince himself came up to introduce him self and when she turned around, he immediately fell in love. Ella couldn’t believe the prince had talked to her, of all people. He asked her to dance with him. They danced together all night long. When the prince later went on the stage, he called her name and she nervously went on stage beside him. He asked her, "will you marry me?" and without hesitation, she said yes. She had finally become a real princess, proving that sometimes dreams really do come true if you are patient and work for them.

One time when I had to be patient was when I had to babysit. My family friend has a one-year-old baby, and I have a six-year-old brother. I had to babysit both of them because my mom and her boyfriend were going to have a double date with our family friends. Things were great until they left. My brother was in preschool at the time, and they gave him these paper books and worksheets to do, and I had to help him. I thought, "Okay, this will be easy." I had him read the book, and my mom told me that he knows the words, so I wouldn’t have to sound out every single one. I had to, but he wouldn’t do the work, and the baby wouldn’t quit crying, and the dog wouldn’t stop barking (he hates when babies cry), and the house was crazy! I started to panic. What was I supposed to do? I didn’t want to ruin my mom's plans, and I definitely wanted to prove her wrong. I calmed down and remembered what one of our friends said; he told me to be patient. I let the dog outside and picked up the baby and headed back to the table where my brother was playing. First, I read the book aloud; it got both of their attention. Then I told him, and I made a game out of doing the work, and it was all good. Then dinner time came. I made some food that we all liked and set the baby in his high chair with his food and gave my brother his plate. I turned around, and he threw his plate at me, and food was everywhere! I got mad and told myself, "Be patient." I cleaned up the mess and fed the kids and put in a movie, and they all fell asleep! I quietly cleaned up the house, and my mom and friends walked in and were surprised I did it. Patience is a big part of life; if you lose your temper, it just makes things worse. Learning to stay calm in chaos is a valuable lesson for anyone.

One day my mom came home from work. She came in and said, "Honey, do you want to go shopping for your clothes now or later?" I chose now. So my mom changed her clothes, and we were off to the store. It was around five o'clock, so it was rush hour. It seemed like it was taking forever, and I was getting mad. Then my mom said to be patient and that it would be over soon. This is a time when I was patient. After ten minutes, things started to clear up. It still took a while, but it was getting better. In less than twenty minutes, we were pulling up in the mall parking lot. There were a few cars in the lot, but it didn’t seem like much. When we got into the store, that’s when I really was mad. The lines for you to purchase your items led all the way to the back of the store. Then my mom said, "Now look. The lines are long, as you can see. Are you sure you can handle this and have patience?" "I’ll try," I said. After we got in the store, we were looking for my clothes, and we were also looking at the long lines to see if they went down some. We got my clothes, then got in line. We spent about an hour's worth of time in the line, and it made me mad. Not only did it make me mad, but it made me hungry because I had skipped lunch. When we got out of the store, we were happy and hungry. We left the store and went to McDonald's. When we were down the street from McDonald's, there was this traffic line; we got closer and closer to McDonald's and then realized that line was the McDonald's line. We got in the lot, and I knew for sure that I was going to have more patience. So we waited, and the line went really fast. We got up to the speaker, and my mom ordered a fish sandwich for her and a chicken sandwich for me. We got to the next window, and they gave us our food. When we got our food, the lady said, "Thank you for your patience." Then she asked us if we would like a free fry of any size for our wait. We told her yes and that we would take a large fry. My mom turned to me and said, "Do you see what happens if you are patient?" I said yeah, and patience is a good thing to have. That was a time when I was patient, and it showed me how staying calm can lead to positive outcomes.

The time I was patient, I had trouble with football. I needed help doing everything, but my dad helped me. He taught me how to throw, kick, run, and carry the ball. Being patient allowed me to learn from my mistakes and gradually become better at the sport. It was a valuable lesson in perseverance and trusting the process of learning something new.

Patience is probably one of the most important things in your life. If you are patient, most people will probably like you more. For example, if you are in line for something at school and you were patient, you will probably get a "thank you" from one of your teachers for being so patient. You will want to be patient because if you are not, you wouldn’t want to lose it in front of all of those people and cut in front of them, and possibly get thrown out of the amusement park in front of all those people; then, you would be embarrassed. This is why I think patience is important. It helps you maintain your composure in frustrating situations and prevents you from acting impulsively. By waiting calmly, you show respect for others and avoid creating unnecessary conflicts or problems for yourself. Ultimately, practicing patience leads to better outcomes and a more positive reputation among your peers and authority figures.

Fishing is a great sport, but it takes a lot of patience. My first fishing trip was at a lake about ten miles from my home. I have loved fishing ever since then, but the trip wasn't easy. We finally fixed the car and drove the rest of the way. Once we got there, we had two problems to fix: we had no bait and needed to find a good spot. We found a nice spot on the other side of the lake. We had to scavenge for some bait, which took about two hours to get enough. We were finally ready to fish. We got the rods, set up the chairs, cast our lines, and waited. There was no way to make fishing faster, so we sat, hoping for some bites. In the end, my uncle, my friend, and I caught five fish! That's why I love fishing because it requires patience and rewards you with a sense of peace and accomplishment.

Being patient requires a lot of tolerance and inner strength. For most people, it's hard to be patient but sometimes it is very important. It takes immense patience when you are out hunting. After about three deer seasons, my patience finally paid off. I was using a bow and a six-point buck walked out. This is a story about the virtue of patience. Patience is profoundly needed in life. Sometimes when you get very frustrated, you need patience to see you through. One reason is if someone or something gets you mad, you need patience or you can get into serious trouble. For example, if you get mad because of someone and you start a fight, you’ll get in huge trouble at school or with the law. Or if you try doing a difficult task and you can’t, you need patience or you might break something in anger and get in trouble for the damage. Another reason for patience is if you are working with a partner or teaching someone, you need patience so you don’t hurt their feelings if they can’t do something right the first time. They might get discouraged and not want to be with you anymore. A third reason for patience is if you know someone who keeps getting you mad or keeps humiliating you, you need to have patience with him or her. Just ignore the person or walk away so you both don’t get into a conflict. If you wouldn’t have patience, things could end drastically for everyone involved. So that is why you should always have patience. Without it, you can get in trouble, lose a friend, and a lot of other things could go wrong in your life. That’s precisely why you need to cultivate patience in your daily actions.

I have a lot of patience, and for example, I really wanted to know if I made the volleyball team, and I had patience, I did not complain or pester the coach. I believe having patience is very respectful toward yourself and others around you. Once I had a difficult test and really wanted to know when we were going to receive our grades back, but I had patience and waited quietly. Others in my class did not have patience; they kept asking the teacher what we are going to get and when, and they were constantly complaining about the delay. Another example is when we were going to go to the state fair on the last day of summer, and we still hadn't planned the specific day. I did not have a ruler for that project at that time, and it made it worse; leaving the patience behind, the more I thought about it, the more it made the waiting difficult. I've learned that sometimes you need more patience, and sometimes not so much, but it is always a valuable skill to have. Practicing patience leads to better outcomes and less stress for everyone.

I woke up at around 3 am not feeling very good. I was staying at my friend Sarah's house for a sleepover. I tried to wait it out until she woke up on her own, but I just couldn't wait any longer so I gently woke her up. I told her I wanted to go home and that I felt sick, so I called my mom, and in about twenty minutes my mom had come to pick me up. I told her in the car that I thought I was going to be sick. I had to wait and wait, feeling worse with every minute, until finally we got home; it took about two hours from the time I first felt ill until I finally threw up. It was a horrible and uncomfortable experience that required all the patience I could muster just to get through the night. The ordeal taught me that sometimes, even when you feel terrible, you have no choice but to endure and wait for relief to come.

My mom has a great deal of patience with me and my brother, especially with all the fighting going on in our neighborhood. She worries constantly and insists that we come home early, never wanting us to be out late when such dangers are present. There was a time that I didn’t want to be patient but had to be. We as a family were going to go to my grandmother's house for a holiday. Thirty minutes later a truck came around the traffic jam and started fixing the road, though I don’t know why since there was nothing obvious to be fixed. Finally, around an hour later we were let past, and we continued our ride to our destination, the delay a test of our patience that we had no choice but to endure.

Lots of people are good at being patient, but I’m not so good at it. However, when you're traveling a long distance, you have to learn how to be patient. Several times a year, my mom, my sister, sometimes my dad, and I drive up to my grandmother’s house. She lives about four hours away, near the coast. My grandmother loves when family visits, so we don’t mind taking one weekend every few months to go and see her. I’ve had to have been there at least twenty times in my lifetime. My mom works the night shift at a well-known hardware store. Usually, she works ten PM to six AM. So when she gets off work, we would pack up and leave. I always bring my headphones with me to keep me entertained, but most of the time I just sleep. One time, I had drunk lots of pop and was very hyper. I was annoying my mom a lot, so I put in my headphones and started acting like an idiot, singing along to the songs loudly. Until, my headphones died. I felt my heart break a little, and I couldn’t fall asleep then. I was still hyper, so I started listening to the radio, but all we could find was country music. Since we were going north, we were traveling away from the control tower of the cool radio stations. Finally, we reached “The Up North Store” where we always stop to get gas and food when we go to grandmother’s. I got some chips and even more pop. I gave a tiny evil laugh to myself as I handed the items to my mom. Back in the car, I finished my food and was bored once again; there was simply nothing to do. I was angry at that point, so I just looked out the window and sighed. Soon enough, I had fallen asleep. I woke up to the sound of us pulling into the driveway, and my grandmother running out to come greet us. Finally, we were there, and I had survived yet another long ride to my grandmother’s house. Then I remembered, we had to drive home too. Even though I make this trip several times a year, I’m almost positive I will never stop getting bored during the ride. Being patient is simply not one of my favorite things to do.

My brother Matt has never been the patient type of guy. He always gets very frustrated and visibly agitated whenever something or someone takes too long. While we were there and waiting in line to be seated, I made a playful bet with Matt’s girlfriend. The bet was that however many impatient comments he said during the meal, she would owe me two dollars for each one. If he did not say any impatient comments at all, I would owe her two dollars. After the waitress took our orders and left, we all started talking. The adults talked about work and other daily things, while me and my nephew talked about school and other topics as well. That conversation took up at least a couple of minutes. For the last couple of minutes, we watched the football game that was going on the television above the bar. One time when I was patient, I went hunting with my mom. You have to have a lot of patience to do that, as it involves long periods of quiet waiting. My mom didn’t want to shoot the mother or the fawn, because then the young fawn would be all alone in the world and likely not survive. So we waited patiently for more deer to come in, hoping for a buck, but none did. But I still had my patience in me, determined to see it through. When it started to get cold and dark out, we thought no more deer were going to come in, so we just decided to pack up and go home, and plus my mom was starting to lose patience a little bit herself by that point. But that’s the time I was patient for a little while, and I felt proud of myself for it.

When I think about patience, I usually think of my mom, and how incredibly tolerant and understanding she is with everyone. Even when she has explained a difficult math problem to me about five times and I still don’t understand, she helps me without complaining or showing any frustration. A good example of this is when she and my dad taught me how to ride a bike. It was the first time and I was about five years old. My dad was at work and my mom and I were bored, so she went into the garage and pulled out my new bike with its training wheels recently taken off. My dad had told me that you needed to turn the handlebars before you crashed, but I kept forgetting and falling down. Devastated that it wasn’t easy, I gave up a little bit after only a few attempts. Now, though, my mom gently persuaded me to try again, encouraging me with a soft voice. Holding on firmly to the back of the bike, she told me to pedal forward. She let go, and yelled, “turn! Turn!” but it was no use. I turned the wrong way and toppled over onto the soft grass. “It’s okay. You almost had it!” mom said rushing over to me and brushing off my knees. Putting on a brave face, I tried again, determined not to let her down. Over and over, I tried to ride my bike, wobbling and weaving across the lawn. Not once getting mad at me, mom helped me up each and every time I fell. On my one last try before it was time to go back in the house for dinner, my mom let go and I rode all by myself, shakily going around the corner and back! When I got back, we both did little happy dances, my mom congratulated me with a huge hug, and we called my dad immediately to brag about my new accomplishment. To me, my mom showed incredible patience that day. She didn’t let me give up and she never complained about the time it took. Overall, my mom is a perfect example of patience, and because of that steadfast support, she taught me how to ride a bike!

So after thirty minutes, only a few people had gone through the line. My mom almost fell asleep standing up, and I was just standing there waiting patiently. But my arms hurt and my back ached. I was so ready to get out of that store. My dad was reading a magazine while he was waiting, an ESPN news issue to be exact. When there were only a few people in front of us, I was happy that we could finally buy the clothes. We got up to buy our clothes and then a cash register broke. The lady said it would take an hour or two to fix, so my mom started to complain loudly. We had sat in line for an hour and a half for this to happen. My dad was fine with it because he was so into that magazine. I could not believe that this happened; I was so disappointed and ready to go, and so was my mom, so we got my dad and left. My dad said, "I am at the good part." I didn't get the clothes that day, but we went the next week to get them, a lesson in patience learned.

I was patient when we were on the bus after we had just arrived at school. The kids were loud and noisy in the morning, a chaotic start to the day. There were a lot of kids trying to get off the bus when someone jumped in front of me; then I fell back into my seat. There were about twenty to twenty-five kids getting off the bus, all pushing to get out. So I waited calmly for all the kids to pass me, then I got up and walked down the aisle to the door. The bus driver noticed my calm demeanor and said, "Thanks for waiting." Then I left, feeling good about having kept my patience during the morning rush.

It was last fall, and my friends were talking about how cool Xbox was. They were saying how if you get Xbox Live then you can play with people around the world. They were also talking about the new game that was about to come out, that was called Call of Duty Modern Warfare 5. I had searched it up online and it was voted to be a ranking of five stars. Now that's a good game. I had asked my mom and my dad if I could get it. They both would always say, "We'll see." After another month I had asked my mom again and she said why don't you wait till Christmas. And once I went to my dad's house he said Christmas is just around the corner. But I said that everyone has it, can't I just get it now? My dad said no, so then after that I had waited two months thinking maybe he had changed his answer. And again he said no. So I went to my mom's house and asked her; she said that I should be able to wait and she also said if I ask again I won't get it. And so Christmas came and for my last present from my mom and my dad I had gotten an Xbox with my favorite game. I was so happy. And now I know if you have patience and you wait long enough, you’ll get what you want.

I am always patient. But do you know when and where I am really patient? It is when I am getting my hair cut. Every time I go to get my hair cut there are a lot of people in the barber shop. Some days people say they have to go somewhere for a party or for church and need their hair cut pronto. So I let them go ahead of me, and I have to wait and be patient. It makes me kind of happy to be patient because I am helping others, and I believe that if I ever need someone to be very patient with me, then I will want them to be patient in return. It feels good to contribute to a kinder, more considerate world in this small way.

This is about a time I was patient. First, I was babysitting my cousins. Their names are @PERSON1 and @CAPS1, and they had to be kept out of the way because the adults were rearranging things upstairs, so we sat downstairs. Next, @PERSON1 and I watched a movie. I was called "itches" too, as they did not sit still; it took a lot of effort not to yell at them to sit down and watch the movie. It was at the beginning, and I wanted to play with @CAPS1, who was sitting quietly in her crib. Finally, they were almost done upstairs. The couch was moved and the chair, so it was more roomy upstairs. That was the time I was patient and managed the situation calmly.

I used patience when I went to Cedar Point @CAPS1. I used it when I was playing a video game. As I was packing, I grabbed my PSP and put it in my bag. I was bored halfway down there, so I grabbed my PSP and started playing, which made me lose track of time. As we traveled, my family did too, and we were pulling into the hotel; we were so close to the park, but as soon as I got there, I needed to maintain my patience. We got in line and were sitting there forever, so I played my PSP. The PSP helped me use patience. I used my PSP to help pass the time. It would have been hard to wait, but my PSP kept my mind occupied and helped me stay calm.

Patience is usually good or bad for me. Here are a few reasons why patience can be hard or stressful. If you are waiting to get a shot or life-threatening results, it can be very difficult. A way to avoid normal patience issues, like being bored, is to get some notes or school work to do or listen to an iPod. Patience is needed everywhere. For example, during car rides, birthday parties, vacation commercials, waiting for school to be over, restaurants, holidays, or whenever you say “I cannot wait,” and etcetera. To sum up a few ways about patience in my description, it is a common part of daily life that can be managed with simple distractions.

A time when I was patient was when I was waiting at the dentist for my brother. My brother's name is @CAPS1 and he is sixteen. One day we went to the dentist because my brother had to get his wisdom teeth pulled. My grandma and @CAPS2 were waiting for hours. After a while, she went to the backroom with my brother, so I was sitting in the waiting room alone. Thankfully, I had my @CAPS3, so I watched a few cartoons and listened to music. A few minutes later, I went to the bathroom. When I got out, a nurse told me to come with her; she led me to the backroom with my brother and my grandma. I learned that the doctor hadn’t even started yet! At least I could talk to my brother. So for what seemed like days, the doctor finally showed up. After an hour or so, the operation was over. Then we had to sit and wait for the anesthesia to wear off. My brother was acting loopy and crazy, which was actually funny. Finally, we left, and I was glad I didn’t lose my patience throughout the long day.

When I was really patient was when I wanted my car and mother to cook me some lasagna. I did not have any of it since my person passed away on @DATE1. My mom had my @CAPS1 cook @CAPS2 for my first birthday. When she cooked some for my first birthday party, it was all gone. My @CAPS3 mother cooked @NUM1 pans of it. It was so good it was gone soon as she had put it out; when I say soon, I mean soon. I turned @NUM2 years old, and my mother did it big for my birthday party. My mom died from open heart surgery; she was @NUM3 years old. She had a lot of friends at her funeral, which was very nice. But getting back to what I was writing about, in @DATE2 I asked my @CAPS1 to cook me some. She said to me, "Girl, it costs too much to make it." I said, "@CAPS1, do you want me to give you some money to cook the food for me?" She said, "No, save your little money that you have." I said, "But @CAPS1, it’s okay to take my money to buy my lasagna and cook it for me." She said, "Girl, what did I say?" So I hurried up and put my money in my pocket, then I was keeping it moving. When we got in the truck, she said, "Now @CAPS5, I am going to cook it for you when I get some more money and when I pay my bills." In @DATE3, she finally cooked me some. The day she cooked it was @CAPS6 @NUM4, @DATE3. My aunties came over and got some, my brother and sister got some, and my @CAPS1 and @CAPS8 got some. When they all wanted some, I stood there and watched them get it and waited for them to stop getting some. Later, when my @CAPS1 and @CAPS8 got some, I did not tell them when it was enough because I live in their house; my brother and sister live with them. The lasagna only lasted for @NUM5 days, and that was it. When she cooked it, I was happy. I brought it to school and ate it for my lunch, which made the long wait worthwhile.

One time when I was patient was when I was at the end of the year in fourth grade and I’d just signed up for football. I had to wait from the beginning of summer. When I got my football pads, I was so excited for football I put them on about four times before football even started. The summer passed by and it was time for the county fair. In the summer I show cows at the fair, so that made the time zip by really fast. Finally, it was almost time. I only had to wait eleven more days until the day of my first practice. When the day came, it went by super fast and six p.m. came quickly. Then it was time to go. I liked football that year and I have played football ever since. It took patience to wait for football. Two months may not seem long, but for a ten year old it is hard to wait that long.

The time I had to be patient was when my brother was going to get me a present when it wasn't even my birthday yet. This is how the whole story began. It was a hot summer day and I had been doing my chores which include raking, mowing, and a lot more yard work. Mom and dad and my brother Travis had been talking a lot. When I was just sitting downstairs they would tell me to go do my chores, and then I could see them talking quietly. It bothered me a lot that I couldn’t hear what they were saying. I finally just carried on doing my chores and I just got done mowing, which took two hours, and I went inside and I started to watch tv. Suddenly I heard “click click tap bam,” then I heard a sudden yell of my brother Travis saying “hey get back here.” I went to our fourteen curly stairs and suddenly I was greeted by the licking and slobbering of a six month old puppy. I grabbed his collar laughing and saw his name was Max. He is now a three year old happy mutt and that was my brother’s present to me for getting all A's and doing a lot of work around the house. I love my dog, but that was the time I had to be patient.

One time I waited for a game but I couldn’t get it yet. So I asked my mom if she could buy me a new game. I asked her how much does it cost? Sixty dollars, I said. Then she said you have to wait for some days. A few days went by, and then I finally asked my mom again if she could buy it for me. She said yes. I said thank you. Then the next morning we went to the game store. I saw the game I wanted on the shelf. I told my mom that was the one, so we went to the counter and bought my game. I was happy that my patience had finally paid off.

The doctor appointment. On October fifth, me and my mom were getting ready to go to the doctors. Once we got there it was so crowded. I felt like we had been there for weeks, days even. There were a lot of kids crying and playing. I was so exhausted just from waiting for my turn to see the doctor. Twenty minutes later it was still not my turn. I was trying my hardest to be patient but it didn’t help at all with all the noise of the kids running around. I walked up to the register and that’s where I found out my appointment wasn't till three o’clock and it was only one. We had to wait a long time, but we managed to stay patient until my name was finally called.

One day my dad and I had a doctor’s appointment at two pm, so we went there on time. Then my dad and I sat there for a while. We thought it would only take a few more minutes. So we waited for fifteen minutes. Then my dad went and asked the receptionist how long it was going to take. They said about fifteen more minutes, so we waited for fifteen more minutes. The doctor still didn’t come out. We waited for another twenty minutes. My dad went to ask the doctor again. They said a few more minutes, so we waited for fifteen more minutes, and then the doctor finally called us. The doctor was over an hour late. When we went in the room the doctor said sorry because he was late. That’s how me and my dad were patient that day.

Being patient is a hard task to write about. One day I was with my mom in the city, looking for a pawn shop to sell an old necklace. We got stopped at nearly every red light on the way there, a journey that felt endlessly slow. Yet, no one complained in our car, even when we reached a certain red light that seemed to last forever. Right before the light turned green, a very old lady with a metal walker stepped in front of our car, moving at a painstakingly slow pace. We waited for several minutes for the old lady to pass safely to the other side. Surprisingly, still no one complained, and we simply watched her progress with a quiet understanding. It was a small moment, but it truly demonstrated the value of patience in our daily lives.

When you hear the word patience, what do you think of? I think about a person standing in a long line at a grocery store when there's a dozen people standing in front of you. In the fifth grade, my sister and I played the patient game one summer. It was about who could go the longest without any food, and all you could drink is water; the winner would get a whole box of Dunkin' Donuts to themselves. On the third day, I had about five bottles of water to fill my empty stomach, but my sister was still hanging in there, determined to win. By the fifth day, I had consumed about eight bottles of water and all day my stomach groaned loudly, along with my sister's. On the seventh day, with all the groaning and the growling, my sister was hanging on and so was I, though just barely, as I drank yet more water. Finally, on the eighth day, I snapped and had so much food that my whole pantry was gone. My sister Emily was cheering and she said, “Don’t worry, I’ll let you have one of my three chocolate doughnuts,” and she kept her word. In my opinion, that was a true display of patience and endurance.

One of the worst feelings in the world is discovering that your flight has been canceled. This has happened to many people, but only one family in my family has experienced it directly. My cousins were going to come to Florida for Christmas, and we were all so excited. Cara and I were texting and e-mailing each other daily about what we were going to do while they were in town. They had been planning this trip since last summer, but now their flight was canceled! We were so mad! My cousin's family had to be so patient because they did not know if they would be coming to see us or not. My grandma kept calling my uncle for updates every hour. My grandma finally had a good idea for them: to get on the next available flight. The only problem was that the next flight was at midnight and it would take them two hours to get here after landing. When they finally got here, I was at the airport waiting anxiously. When I saw my cousin, she said, “Everyone else was so patient but me!” I expected the exact opposite, but no! I thought that my cousin, Cara, would be the patient one, but I was wrong. In the end, it was a relief that they made it, and at least someone in their family was patient throughout the whole ordeal.

A time when I was patient was when my dad and I went to Leslie to go hunting for the day. We wake up very early in the morning, at four o'clock, and get there just before five. We stayed there in the cold, quiet woods until almost noon, and then we left. When we were there, my dad shot a doe in the early morning, around six o'clock. He shot another doe later, about ten in the morning, so we left with two big does in the back of my dad's truck. That was a long, cold morning of sitting and waiting silently, and it was a time that I was very patient.

One time I was patient when I went to the dentist for a check-up. When I went to the dentist I had to be patient because when we got there we got checked in and there was a lot of people there, so we had to wait a long time in the crowded waiting room. When I was waiting, I was sitting on the ground being really bored, flipping through old magazines. I kept asking my mom if it was almost my turn and she kept saying she didn’t know, to just sit tight. Finally, the dental hygienist called my name. So I went in, then the nurse got me ready for the real doctor, taking X-rays and cleaning my teeth. Then when she was done, I had to wait even more for my dentist to come in because he was still working with a different patient. But then he finally came, checked my teeth, and then I was all done! That is a time when I had to be really patient, and I was proud of myself for handling the long wait so calmly.

Patience someone was patient with me when I did not understand something. Someone was a teacher. The teacher did not complain about helping me, and along with the students in the room, they were all very considerate. When the teacher was helping me they sat and quietly did their work. The teacher understood that I did not understand how to do the work. It was during math class, and we were learning about positive and negative integers. My question was, "How do you order them from least to greatest?" She replied, "I can show you, would you like me to?" I said, "Yes, please." So for about ten minutes she helped me. In that time my whole class sat and did their work without a single complaint. That is one time when people were patient with me, and I truly appreciated their understanding.

Where do I begin? There wasn't ever a time when I was patient. I was always rushing people to do something and getting mad because they wouldn't do it fast enough or go fast enough for me. I would just get an attitude and show my frustration openly. That is why I can't be patient, and now you know the reason why. The end of the story is simply that I have never learned the teaching on the way people are coming from, and that is my own failing to acknowledge.

Having a meltdown! I have experienced this specific scene when I was in the fifth grade at Cross Creeds Christian School. It was the day of the school play, and we lived just around the corner. After fifteen minutes my patience was a little thin, almost gone at the fact that my mother wasn't there yet. Then twenty minutes later I had a temper tantrum and cried, and my patience was like a balloon that popped and lowered slowly as I grew angrier and angrier at the fact my mom wasn't there yet. This mistake will likely happen again to me, as I made the wrong choice to get mad over something ridiculously dumb. Learn from my words; I should not give up but keep trying to be better.

I’m going to tell you about a time when I showed patience. When my family and my mom’s boyfriend went on vacation to an amusement park. When we got there it was packed full of people. So we jumped in line for the first ride. We were so excited that the ride operator said fifteen minute wait. At first the line was moving very fast. Then all of a sudden it started moving like a sloth. It was so hot and humid that it was awful. We checked the time; it was forty minutes already. It felt like three hours. I was running out of patience. Then we got in the shade and it was cool and nice. Finally, we were the next to ride; we got on and it was a nice one. My sister and brother were so happy. My mom’s boyfriend timed the ride; it was only forty-five seconds long. We waited one hour for a forty-five second ride. That was one time that I showed patience under difficult circumstances.

Patience is something you need to get through your everyday life. To have patience means that you are understanding and tolerant. Most people do not have much of it, but others do. Like my brother, he has some but not a whole lot. There are five kids in my family; three girls, two boys. I am not going to lie, but I am very annoying sometimes. My little sisters and brother are also obnoxious. But my older brother is the most obnoxious of them all! He is the one that freaks over any little thing we say or do. But this one time, I don’t know what got into him. This was going to be interesting. We were sitting at home one time, and my big brother was being very patient, when we would annoy him. He would usually get his fists ready. So my sisters, brother and I kept fighting and messing around with my brother. We would tell him to shut up or even smack him in the arm. Yet, he would just sit there like nothing was wrong. He would usually beat my siblings and I if we would fight, but this time he didn’t care at all! I was seriously starting to get worried because that wasn’t like him. So I got up and smacked him right across the face with my fingers sliding off his cheek leaving his face red with four finger marks. He had been very patient ever since we started being annoying, but I think at this point, I cut the thread of calling him nice. He got up, with his left hand wide open for a smack. Before I knew it, I was on the floor crying. I ran to tell my dad. Oh, did I mention I’m daddy’s little girl? I think you could’ve figured out that my brother was the one that got in trouble. He had shown so much patience by being tolerant during all those things, but in the end, he got cracked by my dad, and so did my fingers. At least I never got in trouble. That’s when being daddy’s little girl comes in handy, and the story serves as a lesson on the limits of patience.

When I am patient is mostly in the woods. This is when I am hunting. You have to be patient to wait for deer, as they move quietly and cautiously through the forest. They don't always come; sometimes it could just be a fawn wandering by. Other times it can be does feeding in a clearing. But when you see a buck, that is everything. You first have to wait for it to come in close enough for a clean and ethical shot. When it does, you have to wait for the right moment to slowly bring up your gun without making a sound. Then you have to wait for the perfect shot, ensuring a clear line of sight. If you get it, you must be patient and wait for it to die, respecting the animal and the hunt. If you cannot find it right away, do not give up; you must patiently track it. That is when I was patient, and that patience is a fundamental part of the hunting experience.

One time my volleyball team went to a fast-food restaurant. I was one of the last people off our bus, which means I was one of the last to order. I stayed there very patiently as everyone ordered ahead of me, listening to the chatter and the sounds of the kitchen. I talked to my friends as they waited too, helping to pass the time. Next I figured out what I was going to eat: a cheeseburger, a large fry, and a large drink. I watched the clock as my eyes got droopy from the long day. "Number 57," the lady finally said. "How may I take your order?" she asked. I told her what I wanted, and she put it on her register, and I began to wait for my food. A couple minutes later, I got my order. Finally, after being patient, I got my food and rejoined my team. That was the time I was patient at the restaurant after the game.

People with patience are great teachers, and my mom is one of those great leaders. She has a great level of patience, which she demonstrates daily while managing a family and many responsibilities. When we ask for things over and over again, she doesn't get angry and outburst; she just says no or yes with a calm smile. Even when she comes home from a long and tiring day at work, she never complains. She just keeps a smile on her face and finishes the rest of the day's adventures. When she wakes up early in the morning to take us to school, she has a bright smile on her face and she never complains about being tired. My mom is a very patient woman and a great teacher and leader in our home. I appreciate everything she does for me, my brother, and my dad, showing us the true value of patience through her actions.

When I had to be patient was when I wanted a PSP. So there was a time when I wanted a PSP so badly that I asked my parents for it immediately. They said I had to wait until my birthday, which felt like a very long time away. But I really wanted it, thinking about all the games I could play. I decided to wait patiently, marking off the days on my calendar. I occupied myself with other activities while thinking about the future fun. After waiting for a long time, my birthday finally arrived, and I was thrilled to finally get a PSP as a gift, which made all the waiting worthwhile.

I remember I had to use my sister's old phone, the Blackberry Pearl. It was really slow, it dropped calls constantly, and the keyboard was horrible. My birthday was coming up, and I really needed a new one, so I asked my mom if I was going to get one for my birthday. She said, "Maybe. Be patient." And I really wanted to know, so I kept asking her, and she said probably not. But I didn't give up hope. I was really patient until my birthday finally arrived. When I woke up, I saw presents on the kitchen table! My family watched me open them one by one. When I had one left, I opened it. It was a huge box! And I opened it to find another box inside, and then another, and another, and another. Finally, I got to the smallest one. I opened it and the side of the box said 'iPhone' on it!! I got an iPhone! I was so happy! "That's what you get for being patient," my mom said with a warm smile, showing me that my patience had truly paid off in the best way.

One time I was patient; I was really patient. I was invited to a sleepover, and when I went to the sleepover, we went to the store to get pop. It was taking a long time because the store was crowded, and the line was very slow. I just waited quietly without complaining, even though I was eager to get back to my friend's house. I understood that sometimes things do not happen quickly, and I remained calm the entire time. That experience showed me what it truly means to be patient, and I felt good about handling the situation so well.

What is patience? Being patient means to wait for something that may take a long time, but you understand and wait without being rude. An example is you're waiting for a toy that just came out. Everyone has it and it's the coolest toy in town. The problem is your mom and dad can't afford it right now. When you understand that money is tight and you don't stand by your mom's side begging for the toy every day, you're being patient. If you are doing that, then you're not being patient and your mom is going to say "stop, you're being impatient." Before you are rude and keep begging for what you want, think of other people, understand why it might take longer than you want, and be patient. It is a valuable quality that helps everyone get along better.

I’m writing a story about patience. Patience can be like saying I’m waiting for you to get done with whatever you're doing. Something like the teacher has been waiting for the kids to be quiet. And they can’t, so even though she’s getting mad, she is still being patient with us instead of saying "get out of my class," giving us chance after chance. Because she wants us to be good and stay in class, she controls her frustration and speaks to us calmly. This shows how patience can help manage difficult situations and teach others the right way to behave.

I know a person that’s way more patient than me! That person is my sister. My sister is the most patient person you’ll ever meet. I am not patient at all. First of all, when we're going somewhere, my sister would just sit there calmly, reading a book or listening to music. I would say, "Can we leave now?" and start pacing around the room. My sister never gets upset when we have to wait; she just finds a way to occupy her time peacefully. My sister is always patient, and I really admire that about her. That’s why I think she’s such a patient person.

One rainy afternoon on a Saturday, my little brother’s friend's mum called and needed me to babysit. She and my mom were going out soon and wouldn’t be back till nine p.m., so she needed me to come over. My mom drove me over there and dropped me off at seven p.m. She went through a brief entry on what to do if there is an emergency. When they left, me and the kids wrestled and watched television. We ran around, talked to each other (mainly they tackled me), and I lifted them upside down. Then at lights out, I put them in bed and covered them up, checking on them twice. After they brushed their teeth and went to bed, I walked down the stairs twice to read my book. I let out a real sigh and then I turned on the television, needing a lot of patience because my mom was late to get me back, but I managed to stay calm until she finally arrived.

There is a time in everyone's life when they have to be patient. The time I was patient was when I was helping my younger brother learn how to tie his shoes. I know this sounds like an easy task, but it really isn’t. Time after time again my brother attempted to tie his shoes but could never do it. So I told him to go get one of his shoes and I would teach him. When we got started I thought this would be over in about five minutes, but no! He could not make the bunny ears correctly. So we tried and tried again. He would get so close to tying the knot and then he would get so excited he would pull the laces as hard as he could and they would fall to the floor. I really wanted to give up and just let him use his shoes with straps, but no, he was determined to tie his shoes himself. After about an hour of practicing, he finally got it! He didn't tie them perfectly, but it was good enough to keep them tied, and I said good job and started to walk to the kitchen. Then he asked about the double knot. So of course I walked over and told him just cross the two bunny ears and loop one around, but he didn't get it. I had to have shown him a billion times how to do it! But he still didn’t get it. We hit the half hour mark for the double knot lesson, and I went in the kitchen for a juice box. When I came back, my brother had a smile on from cheek to cheek and held up his shoe proudly, having finally mastered the double knot on his own.

A time I was very patient was when I had to do a school project on birds, which included building a life-size scale model. On the model I had to glue new parts on every single day. But the glue took two full hours to dry completely. So I had to redo the gluing three separate times, which made it a ten-day project instead of just seven. I worked harder than anyone else in my class, but I kept accidentally breaking my wonderful creation. The delicate wings would snap off, and I patiently had to glue them back on, holding them in place until the adhesive set. I finally completed it, though it took way longer than I originally wanted or expected. I used patience, carefulness, and a steady hand to finally succeed in creating the model I had envisioned.

A time when I was patient was during an afternoon I was with my mom and she decided, “let's make some cookies.” So we got all the ingredients ready and mixed the dough. They looked so good even though they weren't cooked yet. My mom said they had to go into the oven for twelve minutes! I did not want to wait that long for my cookies. As they started to take their shape of big, dark brown, round, and soft treats, my mouth watered and I wanted them now. The timer buzzed finally, my mom went over there, grabbed a hot pad and almost took them out of the oven! Right as I was about to get one, my mom snapped, “they need to cool down first.” She set the timer for another five minutes! I did not think I could wait that long. My mouth watered at the amazing smell. I was dying, I wanted them so bad! I thought the wonderful smell could kill me! Every minute seemed like an hour. Then the timer buzzed again and I sprinted over there, grabbed a plate and tossed two of the biggest cookies onto it, and while doing so I burned my hand a little. But I did not care; I took a big bite out of a cookie and my mouth was in heaven. My patience paid off in the end; it was so worth the wait for the delicious, warm cookies I got.

School is a place where you have to keep patient. By the end of the day you can run out of patience. You have to try hard to tolerate everything and maintain your patience. Most of the day it will be fun. Maybe if you just go along with it you will be cool and stay patient. But patience is something I use when it comes to waiting for lunch, and for the bathroom. See, every day I have to tolerate people who sign up for the bathroom right when I need to go; I have to wait until my name is called. I start to get very hungry before lunch, but I need to wait for that, too. Once I finally eat, I then have to be patient for my favorite class, which is gym. I have to be patient like this every single day of the week. I need to tolerate all of it weekly, and that is how I get through my school days.

One time I was patient was at a water park. Guess what day it was—it was the Fourth of July! When we pulled up to the ticket booth the man in the little booth said, “ticket please.” Then we pulled up to get a parking spot. When we got out we ran for the gates. But just then my sister forgot her towel. So I ran back to the truck and got it for her. Then we got into our bathing suits and went toward the water. The first ride I wanted to do was called the “Tornado!” Now I must tell you, this ride was very scary looking. But I said, “does any one want to go with me?” My dad and my mom's friend from work said yes! So we got in the line. The line was huge, with about fifty to sixty people in it. The wait was around two hours! But I did not complain one bit. Then we heard a blood-curdling scream from the ride. Then a man, a woman, and two young kids got spit out into the pool at the bottom. Finally, we got our tube and went up the stairs. We got up to the huge opening where you could see the twenty-foot drop-off into the bright pink and yellow funnel. About ten minutes later we were at the port where you get on your tube. Then we went down. My mom's friend went down backwards. I said, “yes, you get to go down backwards. Hooray!” Then we started going down and then we just dropped; it felt like we freefell, going like forty miles per hour. It was scary. Then we got spit out into the pool. I found my mom and my two sisters. They laughed at my mom's friend because she was crying. Then she said she didn’t feel good. So she went to the truck and took a nap. Then I rode rides the rest of the afternoon. That is a time I was very patient while waiting for an exciting ride.

A time when I was patient was when I went to the mall with my mama, and she had come to the mall to get some new clothes. That mall was incredibly crowded. I was so patient waiting in that one spot, even though I was just ready to leave everybody behind when finally our time came to move forward. That was a time when I was truly patient. I was so proud of myself for how I held it all in. The feeling of accomplishment was immense.

A momma bird was laying eggs. She layed three beautiful, blue, perfect eggs. Days went by, and the eggs did not hatch. The momma bird got upset. She talked to papa bird, and he said, "Just be patient". Weeks more went by, and the momma bird got aggravated. Again, the papa bird said to be patient. In her spare time, the momma bird would keep herself busy by twiddling her wings, shopping for worms, cooking meals, and cleaning the nest, but nothing could get her mind off of the eggs. Months went by. Years went by. Decades, centuries, and millenniums went by! But the momma bird was still patient. Finally one day, the eggs cracked, and she was so very happy. Almost immediately, the two oldest birds took off in flight. The third asked, "Why can't I fly yet?" and momma said, "Just be patient."

I was very excited to get my first iPad. But, there was a very long line at the store. Repeatedly, my mom kept on telling me to be patient. So, I just stood there quietly. When I was patient, we were on our way to Six Flags with Sarah, her mom and dad and her brother and I. We were driving to go there. It took us three hours to get there. “Click.” “Ok, cool grandma thanks.” I say. “You’re welcome,” Grandma says. “When will they be here?” I say. “I don’t know.” If you don’t know what I’m talking about, which you probably don’t, I’m talking about my shoes I just ordered online.
