I believe that patience is a good characteristic in a person. Being patient is good because you have to wait without getting angry or frustrated. For example, if you were in a popular amusement park, you would have a lot of people wait in line to get on a ride; if you're patient you would wait calmly, but if you're not, you might leave the line and get out, missing the fun. People might respect you more when you are patient and calm. Impatient people get angry quickly and cannot wait, which often leads to frustration. Though waiting for things can be difficult, losing your temper is not nice for anyone involved. In conclusion, I believe that being patient is a very important and valuable trait to have in life, helping you through many challenging situations.

I said hello just to see if she was still there, even if I had a feeling she wasn't, which she was. She told me, "you kept me waiting for the longest time ever." I told her, "wow, you're so patient; I would never wait that long." She said, "come on, youíre @CAPS4 best friend. I would wait forever for you." So we continued talking, and I was amazed by her incredible patience.

Have you ever been patient? I know it is hard for me to be patient! I usually am not patient because I really like things done right then and there, I don’t really like to wait. I can be patient, however! I can be patient when I am waiting short periods of time. Usually I like to rush, not on my work, but socially, I rush! Being patient means to wait, usually without complaining or moaning. An example of patience is when you are going to a party at seven and it is only four, you have to wait for a long time! Usually the time seems to go slow, which tests your ability to stay calm. Patience is a quality that is important for getting along with others and managing frustration. That is why I am working hard to try to be patient. You should too, as it makes life much smoother!

Last year, in early November it was my birthday, so I told my parents what I wanted for my birthday and out of everything I said “Mom I want a PlayStation” (PlayStation 5 station console). So the next day we go out at three in the morning to get my console and we were at Best Buy. So we walked up to the store and we opened the door and there had to be over a hundred people in the store. So we walk over to the game aisle and there were two left and their was five people in the section so we grabbed one of the two. But when we got in line half of the people in the store were already in line. Then we waited in that stupid line forever it literally to us like hours to get through to the front of the line. We got home at almost eight in the morning. This story is not about what I wanted its about patience. So I was patient for two and a half hours waiting to buy my PlayStation, and I learned that wherever you go use patience you will get thought about and treated nicer than you expect.

One day my dad and I decided we would go fishing. We were supposed to leave early, but he kept delaying. He kept saying five more minutes, so I just sat there in the car, trying not to get annoyed. I waited and waited, looking out the window. Finally I got out to find him a sleep with a note on his chest saying ten more min. I realized then that patience sometimes means accepting things you cannot change, even when you are excited to go.

A time when I was patient is when I was at home watching my baby brother for for my mama so she can go grocery shopping and my brother was crying cuz he was sleepy and hungry so I put him to bed and I had to be patient cuz he was a baby and my mama was gone for a long time and she had to do other stuff like shop for clothes, groceries, shoes, when my brother woke up he was crying and I couldn’t stop him from crying no matter what I tried and when my mama pulled up he stop crying and he started laugh That’s a time when I was patient and learned how important it is to stay calm!

When I went to see a popular concert. I was in the audience and The audience Was very loud and excited. The situation showed my patience were not the best people around me pushing so I waited in front of everyone and I got from the twelfth row seat out on the floor. It was a test of my ability to stay calm in a crowd, but it was worth it in the end.

I am writing about a time when someone I knew was extremely patient. He was having to be patient with one thing: teaching me how to swim. When I was very young, once at a hotel pool, I had almost drowned. Since then I was afraid to swim. So, my patient friend taught me how to swim at a pool in his trailer park. What he had to be patient about though was getting me into the deep water of the pool. He wanted me to go to the deep end of the pool but I was too afraid I would drown. So then he decided he needed to get me into the deep end somehow. We got out of the pool and walked to the deep end. He just told me to jump in, but he should’ve realized I wouldn’t just jump in. He did eventually get me into the water of the deep end, but all I would do was hang onto the edge and not let go to swim or anything. So after that, I just got out and he began to get a little frustrated. He was patient though, and kept working with me. After what seemed like hours, he pretended he was going to give up on me. I told him if he stayed, I’d go in the deep end. So he did, and I jumped in and realized it wasn’t so bad after all. So now I love swimming, especially in the deep ends. That’s how my friend's hard work and patience paid off for both me, and him.

It was the month of March and I, a hopeful student, had applied for a university. I had applied in January and was patiently waiting for a letter addressed to me from the admissions office. From the beginning of the month I had checked the mail box every day. Every day as I ran down the driveway I hoped that day would be the day the letter would come. I was afraid because the middle of the month had passed and still no letter. It was like waiting for that one moment at the climax of the movie when you think the main character will make his move. Friday was the first day of spring break and I was eating lunch. I thought to myself "Today is the day it has to be." I heard the sound of the mail truck pulling up to our mail box and bolted for the door. As I met the mail lady she smiled, everyday she sees me. Every day she sees my smile fade as I check the mail for that one letter address to me. She looks at me and says "Today is that day." Patience is a hard thing to get, but in that month of March I had had my fair share of patience.

A time I was patient was when I really wanted a game called X-Men Origins: Wolverine and my mom said I had to wait until Christmas came strolling down the road. I can understand why she said that because we were a little short on cash at that time so we had to make the rest of what we had last a little longer. After a few weeks had passed I forgot all about the game then on Christmas day my sister and I got down stairs so fast then when we were opening gifts I noticed a gift with my name on it. I go grab it and I opened it and it was it X-Men Origins: Wolverine and two other games that I wanted. After that I go up to my room grab my console and headphones pop in X-Men Origins and played it all day long. The long wait made finally getting the game feel even more special and rewarding.

One day, I had to be patient. Why? Cause I had ask my mother can I go skate but she told me to be patient so we wait and till she said yea. After waiting we was mad cause my mother had to go get the money for my sister. So next always be patient but if you do not be patient you will not get your way. Like one day my sister Haven and I want to go to the movie with our friends so we had to be patient for a whole hour why cause we had to wait and till mom got off of work for she can give Haven some money and me some money. So that is how you be patient. It is not always easy, but it is often necessary to get what you want in the end.

When my friend and I went to the amusement park, it was very busy. We didn't have to wait a long time for the first ride, but for my favorite ride we had to wait a long time to get on. My friend was very patient and I was not. I kept complaining on how long it took. Eventually we got on the ride and had a blast. It was horrible waiting, but it was worth it because the ride was the best one there. It's the best ride in the whole wide world. That day taught me that a little patience can lead to a great reward.

To write about a time I was patient is hard for me to do so since I am not a patient person, but I am going to try. Three days before the trip to Cedar Point felt like an eternity; I could not wait for it to be here. I did try to make the time rush by, thinking about the roller coasters and the fun, but it didn’t work. I had been off of school now for a few weeks and I had done everything I wanted to do, from playing games to riding my bike around the neighborhood. When me, my mom, my sister, and my friends go we always have a lot of fun together, of course. Every night since I have known we are going to Cedar Point I would sit on my bed and think. One day when many kids would ask and complain to their mom saying, “I can’t wait, can’t it come any sooner?” but me, never, not once. I know that no one could make time go by faster, no matter how much you wish for it. So I waited, I did my chores, I packed my bag, and I watched tv. Trust me, it was very long, very boring, and the urge to complain was itching at me, but I didn’t. I took a deep breath every time this restless feeling would happen to me. And I would say to myself, it is only a little wait compared to other things in life. I would also think about how lucky I am to be going to Cedar Point when some kids never get to go. I know I am a very impatient person and I am trying to fix it. This is what I try to do and what I did while waiting for Cedar Point to come along. This is what patient is to me, and in my life. This is also a time in my life when I was patient, and I felt proud of myself for managing it.

Being patient is something I am working on. Well, I have a baby cousin coming from another state and she was adopted from California, so I have never seen her before. I have only seen her in pictures and photos that my aunt sends. So I have heard her little voice on my phone before; she sounds so cute and I’m missing my aunt and uncle too, I haven’t seen them in several years. Our whole family is still being patient, waiting for them to come tomorrow or today. It’s a surprise visit they planned, and I am being patient, trying to keep myself busy so the time will pass. I am excited to finally meet my new cousin and give everyone a big hug after waiting for so long, which is a good lesson in patience for me.

It was a cool, crisp morning in late November. The sun was just coming up as I got into my box blind, my breath making little clouds in the air. It had snowed the previous night but it was only a light dusting. Then again, I was in the upper peninsula of Michigan, so that was normal. I was hunting for a monster ten point buck with my brand new rifle, a gun that could kill a deer from hundreds of yards away. I have been sitting for an hour but it felt like a whole day. I’ve only seen a squirrel and he was fun to watch and all, but not the rush you get when you see a deer. Then I heard it, “Grunt, grunt!” I was looking in the direction the sound was coming from. “Grunt, grunt!” Gun up, my adrenaline kicking in. “Grunt, grunt!” I see movement, put my scope on it and I see it. It’s a—it’s a grouse? I lowered the gun, calmed down, and watched it eat some corn I had scattered earlier. It was now time for lunch and all I had was a turkey sandwich, an apple, and a bottle of water. I started with my apple, eating slowly while looking around, when I saw a brown figure move through the trees. I grabbed my gun with my apple still in my mouth. So picture a guy with all his camouflage on, an apple in his mouth, and looking through a scope. As I looked, I realized it was him, the big buck. Massive horns, a big body, and he was probably five, maybe six years old. I put my crosshairs just behind the shoulder and I clicked the safety off. I slowly pulled the trigger, my mind a blur, and “Boom!” A perfect shot. Later that afternoon, I found him and he was big, a true trophy. I got him mounted and that’s where he is now, on my wall, a reminder of the patience that finally paid off.

I was patient when I had to wait in line for two hours just to ride the biggest roller coaster. Then I finally got on and it took off, accelerating to seventy miles per hour. I was stuck to my seat for five minutes then it went down a huge hill at seventy miles per hour. I got off and rode it again, the g-force pushing me back into my seat and I was faced forward the whole time. The drop is incredibly steep and takes your breath away. The ride was about three minutes long and it seated twenty-four people. I went on the Power Tower ride after that and it was intense. My favorite part was the replay of the ride photo; it was fun to see everyone's faces. I came home as it was getting dark in the evening. I woke up the next day and ate breakfast, thinking about the whole time and how I waited with patience, a quality I saw in everyone else in those long lines that day.

The time when I was patient I was about seven years old because I was in second grade; I'm older now but back to what I was saying. One day when I had to be patient was when I was waiting for the game @CAPS1 @NUM1 to be released. I was waiting outside the GameStop, full of anticipation. Here is a way that I had to be patient, and we all know that everyone has to be patient with others. It was my birthday, a day I had been looking forward to. I wasn’t thinking of my birthday party, or my cake, or the ice cream; no, I was thinking only of getting money from my presents. I opened the first present, but there was no money inside. I moved on to the second present, and yes, this time there was some money. I continued opening presents one by one, hoping for more, until I got to the very last present. It was a card, and it just had to have money in it. I couldn't wait until I could finally buy something with all the cash I had collected. How does being patient fit into this? Well, after my birthday, I had to wait, and wait, and wait some more to actually get the thing I wanted. It took nearly five whole months! Could you believe it, wanting something so much and having to wait that long? Well, anyways, my patience ultimately payed off. When I finally got the item, I couldn’t believe it. It was the best thing in the whole world. That is why being patient is very hard to do, especially if it's for a long time, but it’s also a good thing to do because it pays off in the end.

Tick, tock, tick, tock. Every muscle in my body urged me to run and look for my dad. Tick, tock, tick, tock. But I stayed put, my eyes anxiously scanning the crowds. Tick, tock, tick, tock. And then I saw him. Tick, tock, tick, tock. I ran forward and gave him a giant hug. The clock in my head finally stopped ticking. Hi @CAPS1 @CAPS2 and @CAPS1, I am gonna tell you about a time I was patient. I think that I was really patient when I got back from a trip I took with my friend to @LOCATION1. This is a story about a time when I was patient. It was the @NUM1 of @DATE1 and we were on a plane about to go on a cruise. When we finally got to the ship I was so excited, thinking about how much fun I was gonna have, what my room would look like, and going to all these cool new places. So we got on the dock and there was a long line, but I was patient and waited to get on the ship. Then, there was another line to check our passports, so I was patient and waited once more. Then my dad said, “Ready?” I said, “Ready for what, another line?” He said, “No, to look at your room and relax.” I was so excited. One time I was going to see my friend who lived at the end of the street. I walked there, taking in the scene of the sun going down and the young children playing and laughing carelessly. A @CAPS1 skateboarder waved at me but I didn't trust him enough to wave back since he seemed like a weird person, not to be mean or anything. I finally got to her house and knocked on the door. She answered about @NUM1 seconds afterward, saying, “Oh, hi @CAPS2!” she exclaimed and smiled kindly. Then she told me, “I have to finish my homework and eat dinner first.” I nodded in understanding. So I went to wait for her at the nearby park. I sat on a swing and gently swung myself back and forth, watching the sky change colors. A full hour went by. I patiently sat there the entire time, wondering if she was still coming out. I decided that maybe I should just go home since it was getting dark. Just as I got up from the swing, I saw she was finally outside. I went over and told her I had to go home because it was late, but that I could come back tomorrow. That was a time I was patient.

One afternoon, I was very patient when our flight got delayed. We were going to Florida that afternoon when all of a sudden the delayed sign came up on the monitor. I was kind of sad but I said I had to be patient! Our flight was postponed for several hours. So when we were waiting we did a lot of things! First we went to eat in the food court! We decided to go to Chili's. we also had to wait for our food! Got some good hatch green chile burgers & they were very good! Then we went to the airport gift shop! At the airport gift shop I got three key chains for my friends! Then I got myself two magazines & a reading book! I also get some Cinnabon cinnamon rolls! They were very good! Next we just took a little walk around the terminal. Then we went and sat down & relaxed for couple hours. Then I fell asleep! when woke up we were just about ready to board! I was very excited to finally get to Florida & enjoy all of the sunny weather! I learned that being patient really does matter! That was the time I was really patient.

Being patient! Patience is a good learning skill. The three steps to being patient are being quiet, not complaining, and waiting a while if you have to. My mom and I went hunting with John, my step dad. We had to be quiet so a deer could come. We sat there being quiet. I think it was the quietest I've been ever! All of us were getting sick of being quiet but we had to be in order for a buck could come. It was very cold and l was dressed warm but I was still cold. There was a little heater in the shed thing we were in. we couldn't complain being cold or tired. Or just waiting, so we all sat there not complaining that was good. When l was about to ask if we could go in a ten pointer came out of the woods to find something to eat. We were waiting patiently for the deer to come closer. John loaded the gun and pulled the trigger. The buck jumped and ran off. Perfect shot! We got out of the shed and searched for a blood trail. We had to wait a while to find the deer but it was worth it. The right way to be patient is shutting your mouth, not whining and waiting. A good skill to learn is being patient. Being patient is a valuable lesson.

Being patient is a very hard thing for me but one day I learned my lesson. It was a Saturday and my mom woke me up at six she said we had a lot to do. When we got in the car I didn't know that I was going to have to be patient the whole day. First on our way to the farmers market we got stuck in a traffic jam for about forty-five mins to an hour. When we finally made it to the farmers market we had to stand in line for about twenty mins. I told my mum I'm ready to leave but she said I have to be patient and that being impatient is a bad thing. After we left there we had to take my grandma to the doctors it took them almost two hours just to call her name. then it take another hour to get checked out. After that we went shopping for some clothes and shoes and the mall was very crowded and busy. We were at the mall for like four hours and most of the time we were standing in lines. Finally, we went home because it was time for my mom to start cooking. I learned that I need to work on being patient because it is a part of life and helps you get through long days.

At one point in life you would have to be patient. Being patient means that you are understanding and tolerate. Somebody that’s patient experiences difficulties without complaining. There was one point in life when I was patient. Yay! Yag! My mom is taking my friends and I to Six Flags. I called many friends, and told them if they wanted to go.  Meanwhile, we packed up some water bottles and hopped into the car. We were all looking out the window. OMG! Look at those big roller coasters. One of my friends shouted out. There we were at Six Flags; the first ride I saw was the Goliath. The highest and fastest roller coaster there well, it only lasted ninety seconds. So we were all talking about it, then we decided to go on it. Wow! The line is huge. We all said. I shouted out its ok, I heard its an awesome ride lets just all be patient. Meanwhile, we waited and waited, until we were finally the next people to ride. We went on the ride, and then all of a sudden the ride start, we didn't know and it only lasted ninety seconds. We waited about two hours but it was worth it. In conclusion, I really do think that being patient is a good thing in life, even if it takes hours. I learned so much from just going on the ride, we should all be patient because no matter where you are, you will always need to be patient.

I remember one time I was patient, it was when my grandma called and said she was go send me fifty dollars. So I asked her when she was to send it and she said Friday. Today was Monday so that mean I had to wait four days. So the next day had came up and the mail truck came by and I thought I had money but it wasn't Friday yet, so I said, “Darn it.” Wednesday came, I was still waiting so I tried going to the day can past by “Forget it! So then it was Thursday they had my favorite game on sale “The Bully” the case had a yellow sticker that said fifty and no tax at all, so I was mad and sadly went home. My dad woke me up and said “its Friday” I jumped up, I rose up ate breakfast then I check the mail, it was bills, bills,bills and “my money” my grandma sent me an envelope. At last I said I have money, so I bought some ice cream and I bought my favorite game “Bully”. That’s the time when I was patient and it paid off in the end.

Patience in basketball involves understanding and being tolerant, which are essential qualities for any team sport. In order to play on any sport team, you have to have patience. I say that because you might not always get the pass or score the point but you are still important to the team; your time will come. A time when I was patient was when I was on the basketball court during a game. Our team, the Carmen Ainsworth girls basketball team, was competing against Flushing. A young lady from Flushing was awarded free throws after a foul call, though truthfully I didn't even see the foul and I'm not even sure if it happened, but you can't argue with the officials. She was shooting her free throws and she was taking forever, meticulously preparing for each shot. I'm surprised her shot wasn't blocked by time itself. What was she waiting for, a new basketball? I didn't say anything out loud. I just stood there, nice and patient, waiting for the play to continue. Eventually, the girl shot the ball, and she didn't make either of her attempts. Anyhow, I was so proud of myself for maintaining my composure; I felt really happy for myself. I’m just now realizing that the whole time I was standing there I didn't make a face, or say anything, or even think something negative in my head! I was just standing tall for the first shot, minding my own business and watching to see if it would go in. Then on the second shot, I prepared myself by assuming the box out position: I sat down, put my butt down, hands out, and faced the basket. I was really happy for myself and I even told the girl good shot after the attempt. Hence, it pays off to be patient. One, I got the rebound, my teammate scored a point, and I also got an assist. Two, I was displaying the right way to act to the opposition. Nobody's perfect, and you'll have to wait and see who will score the next point, which is all part of the game.

It was my first game of the season and I was pumped, ready to go in at a moment's notice. The coach yelled "big guy" and I was immediately by his side, eager for my chance. Then he said next play you're going in, filling me with anticipation. Then the assistant coach said no, I wasn't allowed to go in after all. The whole time I didn't complain or show my frustration. I never said one word of protest to anyone. Instead, I helped other people by fetching water and offering encouragement. It was still fun being part of the team atmosphere. The whole time, at least I didn't complain and make it worse for everyone else by having a negative attitude. The whole time I was on the sidelines, cheering for my teammates. I never went in, not once, for the entire game. I was very patient throughout the experience. Not to say I wasn't mad internally; I was very frustrated. At least I got some exercise just from standing and moving around on the sideline. The whole time I supported my teammates, I encouraged them, and I helped in any way, shape, or form that I could. I listened to them complain about their own playing time, but I did not join in; I only gave support. There I was, so mad I could have killed, I was ready to play but my coach said no. It was my time to shine, I felt, but that one stupid word, "no," stood in my way. But at least I learned something about being a good teammate even when things don't go your way.

Hunting, specifically when you are turkey hunting, requires you to be extremely still and quiet, which means you have to have a lot of patience. If you move even a single muscle or make a slight sound, all the turkeys will spook and run away. Sometimes you will be sitting for hours and hours in one spot, just waiting on that one perfect shot opportunity. I remember when I was hunting with my dad in the woods, sitting silently under a large tree for probably three hours, and finally a small group of turkeys came into view. Unfortunately, just about when I had a shot lined up in my sights, my dad shifted his weight and scared them all away with a sudden noise. But I still had the patience to stay out there in the blind for another two hours, hoping for another chance. That experience is my prime example of having patience while hunting.

One day, two years ago, I was going to visit the city on the Amtrak train. The line for boarding was incredibly long, and we were told it was a two-hour wait just to get to the front. Once we finally got to the front of the line, we had to go all the way back to the end because my mom realized she had forgotten the physical tickets at home. So now we had to wait another two hours to get back to the beginning of the line, which was frustrating. Once we got to the counter again, the guy told us that we could have just told him our name and he could have found our tickets online, which would have saved us all that time. My mom got really mad at that point, but eventually we got it sorted out and we got to go on the Amtrak train, which was a really fun ride once it started. That's the time I had to be patient for over four hours while standing in extreme heat, a true test of endurance.

In my opinion, being patient is when you're waiting your turn for something without getting upset or frustrated. And being impatient means not waiting your turn and trying to rush ahead of others. Throughout your whole life you will need patience because sometimes you might just have to wait for things to happen. I have patience, and I know a lot of people who have patience too. I was raised to have patience; when you're doing something, don't rush through it because you can mess up the outcome. Conversely, don't go way too slow either because then people will think you don't know how to do it properly. You can just go at your own pace so you can get the task done right and the way you want it to be done. People who don't have patience aren't always happy all the time, as they often feel frustrated by delays and obstacles.

Have you ever had to be patient before? I have, and this story will tell you all about it. Last year on my birthday, my uncle @CAPS1 promised me a phone, but I had to wait for him to get the money. I had to be patient. So I waited, and then @DATE2 finally came. More months passed, and I still hadn’t heard from my uncle. I began to become frustrated with him because he had promised me that phone. I told my mom about my disappointment, and she said he has always been like that and to keep my patience; so what if he got it a little late. I was thinking in my head, a little? It’s been almost a year! Then on @DATE1, my uncle came over for my family reunion. He told me he knew that I thought he forgot about the phone. I knew he was right, but just then a little light bulb went off in my head—he couldn’t have forgotten about it. Soon it was time to eat, and that is when he presented the @CAPS2 touch to me. I was so excited I just had to jump up and give him a hug. He told me that whenever he promised me something, he would test my patience to see if the wait was worth waiting, and in this case, it was. So whenever your patience is being tested, keep your cool; it will all come to you soon. To conclude this story, I want to say patience is important to have because without it you will never be able to wait for anything in life. The @CAPS3.

You will say that you are bored very fast. Most people are, because when you get out in the woods there's nothing you can do except watch and wait; if you make one noise you will see nothing your whole hunt. Patience is a hard thing to have, but there are rewards to having it. I had a band teacher who was notoriously forgetful, and no one could remember him giving us our report cards. So after a few weeks of waiting, I made a lighthearted bet with him that if he didn’t bring us our report cards the next day, he owed me a bag of raffles. Weeks went by, then months went by, until finally it was the end of the school year. And he still didn’t have them. Once schools started up again and we were halfway through the next school year, my band teacher walked in and gave me two packs of Skittles. I then remembered the deal we had made and said, "Yes, but you are only supposed to give me one." He told me with a smile, "The second one is for being too patient." It was a small gesture, but it perfectly illustrated the unexpected benefits of waiting calmly.

Patience is a valuable thing. Everyday I go to basketball practice to watch all my friends play. I do conditioning practice because a few weeks ago, I broke my ankle playing soccer. It takes a great deal of patience to sit in a gym and watch your friends have fun for an hour and a half, unable to join them. Every Tuesday and Thursday I sit on the bench and watch the team play a basketball game. I have the choice to simply not go to the games, but I have patience, so I go. It is very boring to just sit there, but I do it so I can watch and learn, hoping to play again next year. You know now that patience is a virtue. It takes lots of patience to do really anything worthwhile. Do you have patience? Patience isn’t when you're sitting somewhere for a while and get upset with someone; it is when you are calm and waiting without frustration, knowing that your time will come.

The one time when I was patient was on the state test of last year. Some of the ways I was patient was by keeping to myself or, as you know it, being quiet. The state test is not that hard, but when you have to have patience, that's when it gets hard for you, and for me. Patience is key because you will have to use it for a long time in life! But let's get back on track, shall we? On the state test, when you are done, you have to wait for your classmates to be done. So in that spare time, you can read a book or quietly check over your work. Patience is also important because when you are taking the state test you can't rush through it; you have to take your time and know that you are timed. That's where patience comes in! Sometimes when you are done with the state test you can just sit there and think about what you did today; the reason I say this is because of other people! If everyone in the classroom doesn't have patience, you are most likely to fail the state test. You have to have a silent and quiet room! Now if everybody in the room is being silent, then you can and will do good. When I take the state test I show patience when I am done because I care about other people's work habits during the test. I understand that you don't have the state test anymore, but it is about being patient! When I get my test results back this year in seventh grade, I hope I did good because my classmates and I all had patience! And remember, patience is the key thing to success on tests and in life.

One day at school, a student was waiting in line to get his lunch when out of the blue, a few kids popped right in front of him. The student said to the kids, "You know you have to go to the back of the line, right?" "No we don't," said the kid. Then a few minutes later, a girl named Sarah (that the student likes) was going to the way back of the line, but the student said she could cut in front of him. So she did. Once the student and his friend got up to where they got their food, they were waiting to pay for it when the kid a few spots away from Sarah couldn't remember his student ID number. It turned out he was a new student, so they had to make him a student ID number right there before he paid for his food. Finally they got through the line. Sarah sat down with her friends, but the student had nowhere to sit because his friends were outside. So Sarah saw him and asked if he wanted to sit with her, so he did. Finally, he was done eating, and Sarah asked if the student wanted to hang out at recess and he said sure, but one of Sarah's friends was not done eating so they had to wait for her. When she was done, they went outside. This was what the student was waiting for, but just then the bell rang to go inside. He was a little mad, but he got to hang out with Sarah the whole time waiting, which made it all worthwhile.

Last summer, while I was up at my family's cabin, my stepdad taught my brothers, friends, and I how to water-ski. It being a daring activity, I am not really the adventurous type, but I tried first. Using all the steps my stepdad told me to, and being patient with myself, I got prepared in the water. Out of the blue—literally, we were on a lake—I got up on my skis just like a pro! Now I could make all the turns! When the water skiing session came to an end and I brought the boat up to the cabin, I insisted that my younger sister try water skiing at least once. But when we got out to the lake, and I had skied a few times in a row, she was up to here, trying to decide if she was going to try skiing for sure. We sat there for what seemed like half an hour waiting for her decision. But, in the end, she decided not to try. I was very proud that day because I didn’t try to persuade her or pressure her into trying it. I was very patient with her. And although her decision was the wrong one in my opinion, I am still proud of myself to this day for the patience I showed on that boat.

When I was about seven years old, my mom used to be impatient all the time and got so annoyed at little things! But then one day, she was going to take a shower, but then people kept on going into the bathroom, and she had to wait. She got patient for a while, and I went up there. I saw her and hid. As I peeked from end to end of the hallway, she was still standing there, almost falling asleep, and she was still displaying patience. Another person stepped into the bathroom, and I quickly went there and said, "Excuse me, but my mom is coming, she’s been waiting." So I woke up my mom, "Mom, mom, wake up, go take a shower!" and she woke up and took the shower. After she came out, she said, "Ahh, it kind of feels good. That was better." I learned a lot about waiting from watching her that day.

When I was about seven and my mom was pregnant with my younger sister, it was the night before she had her. We were all asleep when my mom started to scream; we all went into her room. My dad asked her what was going on, and she said, "She's coming!" My dad raced to the car, put it into gear, and left without us and my mom, who was about to have a baby. Then, when my dad realized he forgot us, he came back home to pick us up. It was already morning by then. They took us to a room at the hospital and prepared my mom. Me and my little sister were waiting in the seats next to her. Then, when they took her to get an ultrasound, we had to wait some more. It was finally time to deliver her. Me and my sister and grandma had to wait outside the delivery room; we were so patient as it took over an hour to get her out. When they were stitching my mom up, they brought my little sister to get all cleaned up. We could see her through the window. I had to see her get her first bath and shots, and when they put those patches on her, I had thought she was an alien. But when they brought her to our room, my mom looked exhausted, and my beautiful baby sister was so beautiful. My mom said she was so proud of us for being so patient waiting for our little sister. She said she would name her Lily, and we all liked that name. I was so happy that day, a memory I will always cherish.

Patience is something not very many people truly have. I am in between; I can be patient at times, but at other times I’m not. To be patient is to be understanding and tolerant of delays. It also means you can go through tough times without complaining. Every year I'm not that patient, and every year we go to Mackinac Island for Labor Day, to walk the bridge. The rule is, if you don’t complain, you get fudge. I thought I wasn’t gonna get fudge because I had pulled muscles in both my legs, and the night before, embers from a fire had burnt my legs. I knew that to get fudge, I had to be patient. So I got dressed, walked to the bridge, and gathered up all my confidence and patience and started the mighty walk. Every year we try and beat our bridge walking time, and I thought my legs would slow us down. So I told myself "be patient" over and over, and then I sped up, going past the first three miles in forty minutes because my legs were worn out. I knew to beat our record we would have to walk two miles in less than twenty minutes. We were walking faster than I thought we could, and my legs felt like they were ready to burst! I couldn’t do it anymore. I knew I had to stop and complain, but my legs kept telling me "Keep going!" My mind wouldn’t let me stop; it was tolerating the pain and being patient. I also had to be patient if I wanted that fudge. So I cranked up the speed and sped to the finish line, not only to get fudge but also to beat our record. Thanks to patience, I got delicious fudge and we beat our record. That’s a time I’ll never forget, because I had patience and I kept going until I crossed the finish line. That’s how I was patient, and I’m glad I was patient with my legs. I’m not very patient, so thank goodness for patience when it counts!

A time I was patient! Being patient is all about being tolerant and understanding. Sometimes when I'm in a bad mood, I have to be patient when someone asks me a dumb question or gets on my nerves. One day last year, I was feeling sick and upset; it was during summer vacation, and my little sister Chloe wanted some ice cream, but not from the ice cream truck that rode by every twenty minutes—she wanted it from the ice-cream shop, which was about seven to ten blocks away. I was buried in my blanket when she jumped onto my bed. "Hey, hey, I want to go get ice-cream. Please, please, please!!!" she chanted. "No," I said in a mean voice. "Chloe, you little hobgoblin, get off my bed or I will get you!" I was younger and in a terrible mood that crying sounded so silly and stupid. Tears came to her eyes, and I didn’t realize at that moment that she was little, only four years old, and didn’t quite understand that I didn’t feel good. I apologized and explained that I was sick. Immediately after, she ran out of the room and ten minutes later came back with a hot cup of tea, and Chloe said, "I made mama make you some tea." That was heartwarming to me. After I drank it, Chloe asked if I felt better. I said a little, then Chloe got on my bed and started bouncing. I was patient with her and knew that she didn’t fully understand yet. So I got up and took her to the ice-cream shop to get some ice-cream. Chloe was happy, and that made me happy. I felt extremely proud that I was patient with Chloe even when she got on my nerves. I know I wasn’t patient with Chloe at the beginning, but at the end I was, and that's what mattered most.

It was a sunny Saturday morning and we were up at the lake house. We all wanted to go on the boat and go tubing. We went cared out to the boat and got all ready to go; we tried to start the boat, but there was nothing. My uncle and cousin took the back of the seats off and peered into the back; there was boat-loads of water—the bilge pump had stopped working. My step-dad took a look at them and said that it was going to be re-wired. He had soon re-wired the boat, and it still hadn’t worked. All the kids were now getting antsy and starting to complain. Every adult said we needed to have patience. Everybody had now calmed down and walked away to find other things to do. Pretty soon we heard a boat start up that sounded like my uncle’s; we ran down there with excitement and, sure enough, it was started. We hopped in and there we went, tubing down the river, the wind in our hair. Later that day, my mom had said to me, "Patience is a virtue," and I finally understood what she meant. It was a good lesson learned on a beautiful day.

I’m constantly patient mostly because of my younger sister. Sometimes it's easier than others to be patient with her, but most of the time I’m able to manage. I think this is a great example. One chilly autumn evening I was in my mothers room and I saw her doing her make-up. I asked “Mom, how did you get so good at putting make-up?” She responded “with patience and years of practice.” The next day when I had gotten an allowance, I asked my mom “Hey mom, can we go to the store, later?” Mom replies “Why, sweetie?” I answered “So I can get some make-up to practice with”. “Okay.” Mom says. When we get there, there’re so many choices to chose from! I asked my mom to help me select the best ones, and she showed me a few basic items. After we check out; its time to go home and practice! Sadly my first lesson in make-up didn’t go to great, but I did ask my mom for some help and she said “Don't worry, I know you’ll catch on soon!” and I wondered out loud “Why does it matter?”, Mom almost said as a whisper “because anyone can pay someone else to do their make-up and hair, but almost no one can or will take the time and patience to learn it their self.” I realized then that patience truly is a valuable skill to learn.

When my mom and I got into the checkout line at the grocery store, we heard impatient groans and sighs around us. Almost every line was extremely long and the whole store was packed with people rushing to get their items. I groaned along with everybody else, annoyed at the long wait and shifting my weight from one foot to the other. My mom continued her cheerful whistling, and didn’t seem to notice the commotion. “Mom this is going to take forever!” I whined. “Don't be so negative. It’s not that long.” she replied. She saw my responding glare and chuckled. “How about we play a game?” We continued a game of eye spy for fifteen minutes or so as the line slowly progressed, spotting a red box and a blue sign. After we finished our game, mom continued to make small talk about our dinner plans, and then checked her list to make sure we had everything while I played a game on her phone. Soon we were up next and I smiled in relief, and thought to myself it was a good thing mom kept us occupied! As we walked out of the store my mom said, “See, when you’re patient, you get food!” We both laughed and drove home, the earlier frustration completely forgotten.

Every year me and my entire family take a trip to the coast to the sunny beach. Everyone in my family that goes is me, my mom and my dad, my little sister, my three cousins, my aunt and uncle and my grandparents. We all stay in one big hotel suite together, which usually has four bedrooms, so it's a bit cozy but fun. Out of the whole year we only stay for two weeks, which always feels much too short. So I have to be very patient the other three hundred and fifty one days, counting down on my calendar. While we are there we fish for sharks and sting rays from the pier, hang out on the beach building sandcastles, and swim in the ocean or the pool. So it is absolutely worth the wait for all that fun. I always have a great time and now I wait patiently for next year, dreaming of the warm sand and ocean waves.

I remember it all clear as glass ice. It was two summers ago when my mom, two brothers, and I went to the amusement park. The car ride was about an hour and a half, maybe two hours, through winding country roads. I was really excited about going on the new ride at the park- the Maverick. With nothing to do but listen to music and stare out the window at passing fields, this car ride was turning into forever. Of course, once we got there we still had to go on lots of other rides first. We usually start at the front and work back, doing things in order, which is our family's tradition. This I didn’t mind since we went on mostly big roller coasters with a few exceptions for rides like the antique cars, the spinning tea cups, and the log flume. My mind was kept plenty distracted from the Maverick with how much fun I was having at the time, screaming and laughing. Unfortunately, it became harder to keep my patience once we got to the Maverick since the line was nearly an hour and a half long, snaking back and forth. I guess that the line was to be expected considering that it was a new ride and very popular. After waiting for so long we finally got to ride it, buckling into the sleek cars. The Maverick was amazingly epic, with fast drops and sharp turns. Finally, all of my patience had paid off, and I had a great day that I will always remember.

I’m going to write about a time when my sister was being patient to go to the dentist. One day my mama said she was going to take my little sister to the dentist for a check-up. My sister was so happy, clapping her little hands together. Also my mama had to go to other places too, which made for a long afternoon. First, we went to the mall to get me a homecoming dress, looking through several different stores. After that, we had to go to the shoe store to get me some shoes to match the dress. Third, I went to go get my hair done at the salon, which took almost an hour. Last, we were on our way home but I told my mama my little sister had to go to the dentist, reminding her of the appointment. When we got to the dentist, we had to wait twenty minutes in the waiting room, looking at magazines. I told my little sister “I.M.G this whole day you have been so patient. I couldn’t do that.” She just smiled, happy to finally be at the place she was looking forward to all day.

Why wasn't my uncle there yet? Come on! I was saying I had trapped myself, my back was pinned, and the only thing I had to call for help with was my cell phone. Where was Uncle @PERSON1 from @CAPS1? All I could do was quickly look back to see what was wrong: I was at my uncle's house waiting for him to hurry up so we could go hunting. I couldn't wait. Opening the truck door very quietly and slipping out with my @NUM1 gauge, I then ran out into the woods and into my tree stand. We had had this stand for as long as I could remember. That, I now see, was a bad thing. The ladder was old and rotten, and it felt like it would break. The top platform bowed and had broken quite a few times in different spots. We kept telling ourselves that we would rebuild it, but we never got to it. So after carefully climbing up the shaky ladder, I let the gun rest at my side and waited. Hunting required a lot of patience, but I didn't need any that day. There, standing on the horizon of the tree line, was the biggest buck I had ever seen; I almost said aloud it was so beautiful. Loading a shell into the barrel, I took aim and... Boom! I shot and missed my luck! The stand tilted violently to the side. I reached for the gun so I could put it on the platform, but it slipped and slid down, hitting the edge. The gun landed bent against the tree. I turned just in time to see the stand coming down. I turned so I was facing the falling structure and tried to get up, but I had sprained my leg. Then with a great crash!!! The stand fell on me. I was trapped beneath it, my back pinned. I tried to move, but my back hurt too bad and my arms were starting to bleed. I was lucky I didn't break my neck, and so my problem was I wasn't patient at first. But I learned my lesson the hard way and was patient enough to wait until my uncle was within yelling distance. I got in trouble, and learned the hard way to be patient.

So one day in fifth grade I was running around playing tag on the playground when, "push," I got pushed off the slide. I fell and landed on my arm so it went numb, and then it was in pain so badly. My mom took me to the doctor's and we waited for two hours. I just sat patiently by not moving my arm at all, watching other people walk in and out. Finally, they called my name. They told me my arm was broken but they could not put a cast on there. So we went to the other doctor's office across the road, waited @NUM1 minutes, and I got a blue cast. About a month later I got it taken off and went back to the x-ray room, but then the doctor said I had to cast it up again. This time I got a red cast, and eventually I got it taken off for good. And that's the time I was patient.

The time I was patient was when I went to the @CAPS1 graduation at @CAPS2. My dad went there and he did a bunch of training; he was there for like @NUM1 months. At the end, if they made it through, they got an award. So there was kind of a lot of people in the audience. We had to dress really nice for the formal ceremony. We had to sit through all the people getting awards that we didn't even know. The worst part was they gave long speeches. Then after what seemed like hours, my dad finally got up to receive his award! I was so happy he got his award! Then we got to leave. That was the time I had to be patient.

Go! @CAPS5 coach yelled. The @CAPS5 soccer team and I were running sprints to get warmed up for our game today. My whole day was planned, first soccer then my friend's birthday party. I could hardly wait. That's when I felt a rain drop pound down on my head. Before I knew it I felt another, and another, and another! Suddenly it had started pouring. My team and I rushed under a nearby awning. Boom! The thunder nearly shook the ground. Finally the refs came over and announced, "the game has been delayed." I sighed and slouched down on a picnic table. I knew now I would have to be patient if I wanted to get through today. There we sat under the awning as rain slammed down on the roof and thunder cracked. "How would I make it to my party now?" I thought. Boom! Boom! Boom! More thunder came. It had to go @NUM1 minutes without thunder for the game to resume. Before I knew it we were already on minute @NUM2. Even the slightest bit of thunder and we would need to start back at @NUM3. We were now at minute @NUM4. We listened closely until we heard a boom! From far north. Frustrated, I said, "Oh my gosh, come on!" My team began to count the minutes again. Finally, after the longest @NUM1 minutes of my life, there was no sign of thunder or rain. The game was back on! My team and I sprinted on to the field. We played our hardest that game but, sadly, we lost @NUM6. We walked off the field with our white socks and jerseys splattered with mud. Every one of us were sopping wet. My mom gave me the "hurry up" look and I quickly ran to the car. "I will still make it to my party but, I will be just a few minutes late and I have to change in the car," I said to myself. As I sprinted through the wet grass I heard my coach yell from behind me, "Have fun at your party @PERSON1, and thanks for being so patient!" I smiled and replied, "Thanks coach!" That day I realized being patient is a good quality to have. Many people appreciate it when you are understanding and don't complain during difficult times.

On the way back home from a doctor's appointment, I was getting annoyed about being stuck in traffic. I did not want my mom to get annoyed more, so I tried a great deal to be patient. Once in a while I would play with the seat belt or look out the window. @NUM1 minutes have passed and I was getting more impatient, but I still kept my composure and stayed quiet. Once I finally got home, I went to my bed and relaxed, glad I had managed to stay calm.

Patience it take a lot to have patience. One time my sister was trying to hate me but I didn’t let her get to me, and I have patience until I get mad. I am writing about when someone was patient. My mom was patient when she didn't get her money that day. She wanted it to come but it did not, so she was mad for a minute, but the next day it came. And I said I told you mommy it was coming today. She did get her money, yes, and she had been waiting for it. That one day she did not know where it was, so she did not know what to do when it did not arrive.
