I remember when I went to my step-grandmother's house to visit my step-grandmother for the summer and went fishing. I didn’t really want to do it because I am a very impatient person. The creek we were going to fish in was right behind her house. I grabbed a fishing rod and went into the ‘backyard’. I flung my fishing line into the water and waited. After maybe ten minutes of nothing, except my sister who caught most things, the line finally started to unravel. Excited, I leapt out of my seat, knocking it over, and grabbed the reel. Twisting and twisting the handle for what seemed like forever, I brought it up. The fish was small compared to what my sister caught seconds later. My step grandmother threw the fish back. After another ten minutes I became frustrated and went to swim. After an hour of swimming, I went back to my rod and decided to be more patient. I waited until my line started moving and I got up, and twisted the reel faster than before. I’d caught the biggest fish of the day. I sat down and waited an entire hour for my line to move again. I then caught another fish. Happy, I dropped my rod and told my step grandmother. My patience led to me catching the biggest fish of the day and learning something new about the value of waiting calmly.

Patience is when you can wait a while without complaining or giving up about waiting and that is patient. An example of being patient is, let's say you're standing in line for two hours to get tickets to see your favorite band play. Now waiting two hours in line is being patient to get the tickets, without complaining or anything. Being patient is very respectful to yourself and others around you. But I also think that everyone could use a little patience. I think that people should think about patience more often. If everyone in the world didn't have patience the world would be a crazy mess. Example: everyone would be waiting for things too. Everyone would be trying to be first all the time. It could just be crazy and nothing would get done properly. So I’m happy that there is patience in this world and that many people have it, as it helps keep our daily lives peaceful and orderly.

I was patient when I had a doctor's appointment. Me and my mom had been waiting almost an hour for them to call me. Twenty minutes later the nurse finally calls me. She says sorry for your wait and thank you for being patient. Then after that my mom took me to get something to eat, so we went to a drive-through. We were waiting another fifteen minutes later when they give us our food from the drive-through window. The worker also said sorry and thanks for being patient. It felt good to be acknowledged for waiting calmly, and it made the rest of the day much more pleasant.

This is a story about what patience means to me. Patience is when you have a problem and you don't complain about it, choosing to wait calmly instead. For example, I had to give my mom some money, but I did not have the money right then and there. My mom did not complain; she waited quietly because she had patience. Patience does not mean you keep begging. It means that you are understanding and tolerant of the situation. If your dad said he is going to give you some pizza, have patience and wait on that pizza without pestering him. When you have patience, people will often have patience with you in return. For example, if you were watching tv and you did not want to get up yet, people might have patience and wait for you to get up. Patience does not mean you keep asking repeatedly. For example, I was at the grocery store once, begging my mom for candy, not realizing that if I had just shown a little patience and waited for her answer, I would have gotten the candy, but I didn't. This is my story and what patience means to me.

A person I know that is patient was my old teacher named Mr. Johnson. He was a very patient man although we often got on his nerves. Even if we didn't understand a question that he had explained a million times, he was still patient and would try again. Even when we got attitudes with him, Mr. Johnson was still a patient man and never raised his voice. I think Mr. Johnson was determined to be patient with us, as he must have prayed for strength because he was always patient with us through thick and thin, during good days and bad. Mr. Johnson was the most patient teacher and person I have ever known, and I will always remember his calm demeanor.

Patience, what's the first word that comes to your mind when you hear that word? Waiting? I know that is the main word in my mind. Here is a story about a time when I was very patient. Every kid dreads standardized testing; it was a Tuesday morning and we had to be completely silent for the entire duration. It is hard enough to be quiet, but it is even harder when you are sitting next to your friends, and you are a girl who loves to talk. We had to do the writing portion, and writing is the worst for me because it takes so long. But when I was finally done, I felt really good, and I remained quiet for everyone else who was still working. That is the story of when I had to be patient and wait silently until the very end.

Patience can be a very hard thing for me to have at times. For example, when I go to restaurants and we wait for our food, I get bored very easily. One time, I had a sore ankle from an injury in soccer. A couple months later, it still hurt in the same spot, so my mom set up an appointment with my doctor. When I did go to the doctor, she felt for a lump or a fracture in my ankle and said, “I don't think there is anything wrong, but we won't be sure without more tests.” Therefore, she sent my mom and me to the urgent care center out on Main Street with a note that said I needed an x-ray. After about a twenty-five minute car ride, we were there. When the kind lady checked us in, we waited in the x-ray waiting room. My mom texted my sister saying we would be a while. I had to have patience because we were waiting there for a whole hour, which felt like forever! Clearly, this was a time I had to have patience because I was already nervous about a possible broken ankle and the long wait only made it more challenging.

Being patient is a wonderful thing to be. Here is an example of me being patient for my birthday. My birthday was coming and I was extremely happy, but I knew I had to wait. I would always count down the days, so I had a personal calendar just for counting down to it. After that, I made lots of birthday lists of things I hoped to get. I went to different stores to see what they had for gifts. For an example, I saw this beautiful shirt that had a matching belt, and I really wanted it. In the final days before my birthday, I was so excited I could hardly eat. I also went to the local bakery and checked out all the wonderful cakes they had. Finally, the day came and we went shopping for all the stuff I wanted. I conclude that it was all worth the wait because I was patient and did not complain.

A time I was patient was when I had to be patient for having a difficult task without any help. Not one complaint came from me. It was so hard. I had one hour to finish it, but I knew I needed three hours to complete it properly. The test was so challenging that not even a college student could finish it in the allotted time. I focused intently, working through each complex problem step by step, refusing to give up even when the concepts were confusing. The pressure was immense as the clock ticked down, but I remained determined to do my absolute best with the time I had. The @ORGANIZATION1 was the hardest match test I had ever done, and completing it required all the patience I could muster.

“Mom, how much longer?” I complained at the airport, “We have been waiting for about two hours now.” “It will only be a couple more minutes, sweety,” replied my mom in a stern voice. “It better take only a few minutes because I really want to go to Disney World,” I complained again. As you might know now, we are in an airport full of people. We had to wait for six hours before our flight took off for Florida. It took a lot of patience that I thought I never had. In the first hour of waiting, I was really, really bored. I had nothing to play with besides my Gameboy Advance. The Gameboy Advance is a boxy-looking object that folds open. There is a screen on the top and controls on the bottom half. That was my only fun that I could use to keep me busy and not fall asleep. I was very bored. But thankfully I found a T.V. that they had at the airport. We went over to the seating area to watch, but the only channel we could watch was the news. I did not like watching the news at all, so I played my Gameboy. I played that for about an hour. I hadn’t said anything to my mom the past two hours or three hours. I didn’t want to bug her, so I left her alone. When the next hour passed, we boarded our plane finally. We waited a total of six hours and fifteen minutes. It was a painful but memorable experience. When we boarded the plane and found our seats, my mom said to my brother and me that she was very proud of our patience. To this day I realize why my mom and dad don’t like to fly to places anymore.

It was July 12th. It was almost time for Billy's birthday. Billy was going to be six years old. He was helping his mom make his birthday cake. After they were done making the cake mix, Billy's mom put it into a cake pan. She put the pan into the oven for two hours. "I can't wait for my super yummy chocolate birthday cake to be done!" said Billy. A few minutes later Billy asked if his cake was ready. "But Billy," said Billy's mom, "We've still got about one hour and fifty-five minutes until your cake is done." "But that will take forever," whined Billy. "You've got to use your patience, Billy," she said. "Mom, what's patience?" Billy asked. "Patience is waiting for something without complaining," explained Billy's mom. "Besides, you can do something while the time passes by faster. Like play a game, ride your bike, play with your friends, or play in the sand box." "Okay," said Billy, "I'll go do something else." So Billy went downstairs to play his video games. When he was done playing his video games, he checked the oven to see how much time had gone by. There was two hours and thirty minutes left. So Billy decided to go out and ride his bike. He put on his helmet and got on his two-wheeler bicycle. He went for a ride on the neighborhood trails. He saw his friend and joined them on their bike ride. After their bike ride, Billy asked them if they wanted to go play in the sand box. They all said yes. So they went to the backyard and played in the sand box. Billy and his friends all made this huge sand kingdom. It had big castles and it had a trench all around it. It took up the entire sand box. Billy went inside to ask how much time was left on the oven. "Mom, how much time is on the oven?" asked Billy. "Only five more minutes," said his mom, "you should take that time to brush off all that sand. I see you and your friends are covered in it. And when you're done you can invite them in for a piece of cake." When Billy and his friends were done getting the sand off of them, they all went inside and had a piece of cake. After everyone finished their cake they all said, "It's the best cake ever!"

“Come on, Mom!” I yelled. We had just gotten our tickets for my favorite amusement park in the world; Cedar Point. “Calm down, Alex,” my mom told me. “I’m coming,” she said. I’m not usually super hyper, but I just love roller coasters. It’s also nice to just take a day off and drive up to Cedar Point. I live in Michigan, so the drive isn’t that short. My mom had just finished giving the man our tickets. “Enjoy your day at Cedar Point,” he told us. “So, Alex, what do you want to ride first?” my mom asked me. “How about the Magnum?” I asked my mom. “Why not?” she replied. By the way, if you didn’t know, my name is Alex. But that’s not important right now. What’s important is getting on the Magnum. My mom and I waited in the line for about an hour. It seemed to take a while, but before I knew it, we were buckling up. Now I know the Magnum isn’t the biggest ride, but it’s still pretty big. To be honest, I was a little nervous. Everyone gets nervous before their first ride, and as we were going uphill, everything started to get smaller, and I started to get more nervous. The Magnum ended up being a blast! After the Magnum we rode the Mantis, the Raptor, the Wicked Twister, the GateKeeper, the Valravn, The Mean Streak, the Top Thrill Dragster and the Maverick. “All right Alex, pick the last ride,” my mom said. Now that was easy. We still hadn’t gone on my favorite ride yet. “Let’s go on the Millennium Force,” I said. We got in line. The sign said the wait was two and a half hours. Now, I’ve been on the ride, and it’s definitely worth it. The wait ended up being a bit longer. The wait was four hours, and I wanted to leave after three. I waited, though, and even though I thought it wouldn’t be worth it, I waited. It was totally worth it. The waiting was terrible, but it was worth it. I really enjoyed my day at Cedar Point, and I’m glad I waited for the best ride.

It was about the middle of July when my family and I were going to visit my grandparents. They live in mid-Ohio. I was so excited I spent the days before counting down with all of my siblings. We gathered our toys and accessories. I was pumped. Finally, my mom and my brother finished packing the morning of the trip while my dad and I were all set. We packed everything in our old, blue van and we headed off. An hour in I asked my dad, “When are we going to be there?” “Not until much later,” my dad said, so I slept. My brother was being silly and kept poking me in his seat while I was sleeping. We stopped for him at a gas station because my mom had to use the restroom, and I started to get excited again. It was about two o'clock. I had to wait to get to a hotel. I was still happy because we were in mid-Ohio and we would get to see my grandparents and have an awesome time together. That was my story about the time I had to be patient.

I am going to write a story about patience. Patience is when you wait calmly for somebody to do something. One example of this might be if someone else is fixing something for you and you really waited them to be finished so you can move on with your life, but it is the type of thing that takes time, maybe a lot of time, but if you want it done right, you will have to wait. Sometimes it will not be a person you wait for, but an inanimate object, like a television show, which can not be rushed, even though sometimes you want to rush it. With a human however, if you rush them to do something, which can happen, it might end up being not as good and even breaking in about ten seconds after them doing it, though it might end up happening faster. You might also wait for nature too, such as a sunny day when it might have been raining for over a week. You also might be waiting for the power to come back on during a storm. It, for me, have really wanted the power to come back on during a storm because there is nothing to do!!! Patience is also about waiting for your turn or for a feeling to pass, like when you are bored and must simply endure the slow passage of time.

One time when I was patient was when I broke my thumb. I was patient cause I wasn't complaining about it and I wasn't crying about it. I really wasn't doing anything about it because I didn’t think it was even broken, and it wasn't really bothered me. Then I waited to see the doctor and got it checked; the doctor didn't think it was broken either, especially since I almost beat him in a thumb wrestle, but he x-rayed it just in case. When he came back with the x-rays he said it was broken, and he was very surprised; I was surprised too, and every one was surprised by the news.

This past summer, my family and I went to Flagstaff. When we were in Flagstaff we were going to the Grand Canyon. It was basically a big ski slope. When we went to the top on a ski lift, I was scared that I was going to fall. When we got to the top I could see Flagstaff and sort of the surrounding area. I got dizzy and I didn’t like heights, and I started to throw up. I was happy to get in line to go down. When I got down I felt better and then I felt like I was going to throw up again. I love my mom and she helped me feel better. That day was the worst day of my life. I was happy the next day when we went to the local museum and had a much calmer time.

Sometimes its hard to be patient, especially when you have to be tolerant to little kids. Well I have to do that sometimes, when I go to visit my little cousin, Sarah. Sarah is eight years old and gets on my nerves. She asks dumb questions and does stupid things and I don't like her at all. My mom says, "When you grow up, you two will be best friends," yeah, right, I don't think so. Whenever I visit her I just have to tolerate her and be patient. For now I have to deal with her, but when we grow up we might become friends, but maybe not, and only time will tell.

Once when I was patient was when we went to Green Bay and it took forever to get into our hotel, and when it was finally the time we got in the hotel and it was three there time which was which is two our time and I was a little upset. The next day we went to Toy R Us and my sister was mad and my mother wanted to get a van and we tried a white van and me my bro and dad like the white one but my mom and stupid sister didn't like the white Dodge van and we tried the silver van and my mom and dumb stupid sister loved it but me my bro and dad hated it oh and we got the dumb silver van and it took hours to get the dumb van and it was stupid going home. The whole trip required a great deal of patience from everyone involved.

Patience is the way to being a truly virtuous person. Fundamentally, patience is waiting a while for something, as it requires self-control. If you wait a long time without getting mad or reading out in frustration, you are what people call patient. If you keep up this habit, you will have a good life that is more peaceful and rewarding. Cultivating this quality helps you navigate challenges with a calm and steady mind, leading to greater success and happiness in all your endeavors.

The first time I learned patience was when I was very young. My mom said she would buy me a PlayStation, and I wanted it so badly. But I had to wait to get it, so I did, and I waited and waited and waited. Then I figured it had been a whole month and still nothing had happened. I was just so mad, but I didn't do anything. So we went to Walmart, and she finally bought me the PlayStation. I was incredibly happy. Later, I asked for an Xbox, a Series Seven. My mom said to wait, so I waited for three months, but still nothing. Four months passed, nothing, and five months, still nothing. I was just so angry, but a whole year passed and I got a new house. It was awesome; I got my own room and a television. I also got an Xbox Series Seven, too. Being older is truly awesome because you learn that good things come to those who wait.

Oh, I have a great story about patience! One day, I was at my grandmother's and grandfather's house. There were my two brothers, my little sister, my grandmother, and my grandfather, and myself present. My grandfather was ready to serve up ice cream. All of a sudden, my brothers and sisters started yelling, "I'm going first, I'm going first!" My grandfather asked, "Lathan, what about you?" I responded by saying, "I'm not being a part of this!" I thought to myself, how long is this going to go on? Since this was all suddenly getting me a little freaked out, I said, "Everyone! Get in line!" They were like, "Okay." So, patiently, everyone got in the line and took their turn choosing what kind of ice cream they wanted. And what a choice we had: vanilla, strawberry, mint, or cookie dough ice cream. Everyone settled down and enjoyed their ice cream cone, showing how a little patience can turn chaos into a pleasant and orderly experience for all.

I was patient when I was going to the doctor's office to get a check-up. I did not complain about it, even though I had to wait for two hours in the waiting room. Then, when I finally went in, they took a couple of X-rays, which took about another hour. After that, they took some blood tests and other routine examinations. Then, at the very end of the long process, I finally went home. That was the time I was patient, understanding that sometimes you must endure a long wait for necessary things without frustration.

One time I was going hunting. We got to the woods at five or earlier in the morning. When we got there, we found a spot to sit on the ground. We were going to stay in the woods till dark or until we killed our limit of deer. When it was only half an hour till dark, we saw a doe, but when we moved the gun to shoot it, it ran away. We stayed still, not moving or talking, just waiting patiently. Then more deer came, but they were really small, so we let them go. When there were like fifteen minutes left till dark, a good-sized doe came out. It was too far away, though, so we waited for it to get closer. Then, boom, the rifle goes off. It dropped but was still alive, just laying down. We waited like ten or more minutes, and then it finally died. That was one of the times I was patient, and it ultimately led to a successful hunt.

There are many ways to be patient, like while you are waiting in the lunch line to get your food or when you line up to leave the room. Here is a time when I was patient. It was time for this trip to go skating, and I was talking to some friends. I wanted to go right away, but I did not say it because I knew I had to be patient. Then we got there and I wanted to get in and skate immediately, but they had to tell us all the safety rules first, so I said nothing and listened. Then we walked in to skate, but there was a long line for skates. I did not push or shove my way through; I just waited patiently for my turn. Then I finally got my skates, had a great time skating, ate a snack, and then left. This is how we can be patient.

Patience, can you be patient? Some people are and some are and some are not. Sometimes I cannot be patient. Well, here is a story about patience. One time at school in the lunch line, it was very long. It would barely move. I wanted lunch so badly that I was not being patient at all. But for some reason, my friend was being very patient. I said to her, why are you so patient? She said because everyone is going to be able to get something to eat eventually. I said yeah, that is true. So I tried to be patient like her, and before I knew it, the line had moved and I was sitting by my friends, talking and happily eating my food.

I was so bored, but I knew it would pay off in the end. I was on a flight to visit my grandparents, and it took many hours. In that time, I found ways to pass the time. I went to the bathroom, I ate the lunch they provided, I played with my mobile phone for a while, and then I slept for a bit. After I woke up, I played a game on my phone again. Finally, the pilot announced we were landing, and we were there at last. It felt good to have been patient during the long journey.

I was patient in gym class today for my skill test, and I did great, I got a perfect score. We have many students in my class, so it was quite the long wait. Also, when it was my turn, it took about half a minute to do it. We wasted all of the hour on the skill drill, and I was waiting to play dodgeball all hour. It was a bit sad because we didn’t get to play dodgeball at all. So I pretty much wasted my entire hour on the skill test, and it certainly tested my patience. That is the end of my story about waiting.

I had to be patient when I really wanted a new bike, and I had to make money for it. So I went to the neighbors' houses, picking up leaves for them until I showed them I could also shovel their driveways. Over time, I slowly saved all the money I earned. Finally, I had enough money saved for my new bike. It was hard to be patient and wait while I worked for it, but in the end, it really paid off when I rode my new bike home.

A day of dreadful patience. “Can we leave now, Dad? I’m so bored,” I complained. I waited for an answer, but I guess he just resorted to ignoring me. We were here in the cold warehouse, waiting for these lazy people to load up his truck. Impatient guys. “That’s it, I’m gonna go talk to these guys and see what the whole holdup is. Wait here and don’t touch anything,” Dad said. So I sat here, cold, bored, and hangry, waiting for what seemed like hours. Finally, my dad got back and told me it might be another hour. The things impatient men resort to. We were sitting here and getting pretty impatient. We decided to just go and walk for a while to the nearby food court. After we got some food, we went back to the truck. City slickers are just plain dumb. A forklift driver had somehow managed to get his forklift stuck in the trailer. That’s when my dad had it. He got out and then all we heard was hollers and screams. FINALLY! After my dad yelled a bit, we finally got back on the road. That day I learned that some thing I definitely don’t have is patience.

The time I had to be patient was when I was at my first football game. I wanted to get in but I had to wait in a very long line. I waited an entire hour just to get in. The team was tied in the third quarter, seven to seven, and it was the final play of the game and we were still winning. The coach had an injured player so he put me in. I ran so fast I tackled the guy with the ball, he fumbled, and I ran for the touchdown. If I wouldn't have been patient, I wouldn't have won the game cause the coach wouldn't have put me in. That was the time I was patient, and it truly paid off in the end.

One time I was patient is when I went to get my hair cut and she told me to come at two o'clock. But when I got there at two, she had like three people in front of me, but I didn't care because I didn't have to do nothing after. So I was just going to sit there and be patient, and I had my best friend with me so I wasn't bored and we was just sitting there talking and texting our boyfriends. So then the lady that was about to cut my hair came to me and said I am so sorry, but I told you the wrong time, and I said oh it's ok, I can wait. And when she got done with their hair, the ladies came to me and said they was sorry. So then she had one person left, and by the time she got done, it was getting on like four-thirty. And that was the time I was being patient, and it all worked out just fine.

To me, patience is one of the most important traits in a person. To be patient with someone is very important. It can make you friends, it can get you a girl or boy friend, and it can get you some of the best things in life. One time, patience got me a new hockey stick. About a month ago, I broke my old hockey stick in an away game. After the game, I knew I needed a new one, so I went to the pro shop at the ice arena I was playing at. “Do you have the Bauer Connor McDavid vapor XXX?” I asked, wondering if it would be easy to get it. “Sorry, buddy, we just ran out,” said the salesman, giving me a little shrug. I knew that if I wanted the stick, I would have to look harder. When I got home, I looked on the internet to see if there were any stores nearby with it in stock. No luck. I guess I’ll have to order it online, I thought to myself. The delivery didn't arrive quickly. It took about three weeks for it to finally arrive. It was worth all the time and effort, proving that good things come to those who wait.

I have patience until summer vacation comes along. I try to do my best in school until summer arrives. For example, last year I was on the honor roll three times. Over the summer, if I have to do book reports or a summer project, then I will do it and I won’t leave it until the last minute. Then, I’ll wait until school starts again, which will be a fresh new year. I’ll also wait until summer again. But in between we have some breaks and days off, though I think we still have enough assignments throughout the year, since we go to school five days a week. School can be really fun sometimes, for example, I wait for field trips and school activities. But we have to be careful so the principal doesn’t take our privileges away; for example, if our behavior is bad or we get too many detentions, she’ll take it away from us. That means all of my patience will be for nothing. That really wouldn’t be fair because most of the time my classmates are the ones causing the trouble, not me.

A time when I was patient well it didn’t just happen once it happens all the time. The time I am patient is when my mother is either talking or at the hair salon getting her hair done. Today I am going to talk about the time she goes shopping. When my mother goes shopping she brings all the females in my family my cousins, aunt, and grandmother. I either go in the mall with them, stay in the car or stay at home. I will talk about when I go in the mall with them. They shop for at least eight hours max ten hours. They just don’t go to one mall and stop they go to at least two malls three max. They also visit a lot of strip malls too, for example stores like Simply Fashion and Rainbow. They are going to a hundred places for at least eight hours my feet start to hurt and I'm getting hungry and tired but, I don’t complain because I am being patient. Now we are in a mall I go to carry bags and go into a lot of females clothing stores like Victoria's Secret, @PERSON1, and @PERSON2. Then they shop for jewelry, make up, perfume, and every woman item known to the world. Plus I get lost because they leave me behind in the stores. In conclusion, I am very patient for my mother no matter what she does or how long it takes.

I’m writing about a time when I was patient. Because I was about to go to a party and I had to be patient but I didn’t manage to stay calm. I had got angry and I just couldn’t be patient. And I also know someone who is patient, but that wasn't me that day. They just couldn’t wait they really couldn’t wait but I waited, waited, waited and I got mad I couldn’t even wait no longer. I was actually was waiting on my aunt to come pick me up and she didn’t show up. I called my mom and she said she was going to take me to the party and I was patient and she didn’t come either. So I didn’t go to the party and I was mad. Because my mama didn't come pick me up, I ended up calling my grandma and she came and picked me up. That was the only time I was patient, but it was a hard lesson in learning to wait.

You have to be patient when you go on a trip. I was patient on my trip to Pennsylvania last summer. I had to be patient for two hours before me and my family finally arrived at our destination. The next day I had to be more patient because we went to an amusement park. There I had to wait in very long lines for all the popular rides, and it is really hard to be patient when you are excited. Is it hard for you to be patient when you really want to do something? That’s the story of when I had to practice having patience during my vacation.

It’s about three o’clock the clock tells me, but I can’t go to sleep because my grandfather and I are going fishing. So it’s eight o’clock now my grandfather was suppose to be here at seven, but my grandma kept saying he’ll be here, so I believed her but I was a little worried. Now it’s ten o’clock in the evening by now. I’m just furious I am about to cry, but my grandma said he’ll be here, and I said, “Forget it he won’t come,” and went in my room. Then I realized he will be here he will be here. Then I heard the door open I ran and it was him I ran and said you finally came and we ate then I look outside and seen the boat. That’s a time I should have had more patience and trusted that he would arrive.

I remember a time when I was patient. I was at home it was Christmas time. I was the first one up and I just wanted to open all of my presents and gifts but I had to wait till every one got down stairs and for my mom to get the camera ready. Then we opened presents. My brother and sister went first because they are the oldest, a rule my brother made up. Then finally it was my turn I just randomly took the present and ripped the paper off not even looking at the present because it was my turn after waiting so long. I had been patient all this time and that was the time when I was a very patient person on Christmas morning.

Patience to me means trying your hardest to wait on someone or something. I remember one time when I was patient. Me and my family went to the water park and we wanted to get on this water slide. The line was incredibly long, with a lot of kids and adults ahead of us, so we waited for what felt like an hour. We finally were second in line, so close to the front. The kids in front of us were very kind and offered to let us get in front of them, but we politely turned them down, deciding it was only fair to wait our turn. So we were waiting patiently while the life guard was giving instructions to a young boy, telling him to hold on tight because it was his first time going down a water slide. But then something scary happened. The little boy fell off his tube, hit his head on the side, and almost drowned because he didn't know how to swim. The lifeguard acted quickly and pulled him to safety. It was a scary moment for everyone watching, but after everything was okay, we still went down the slide and had a great time for the rest of the day.

Clunk! I jolted in my seat as the rental car crashed into another pothole. "Look who's awake," my mom barked in a voice as annoying as possible. "You slept for so long I thought you might sleep until school starts back up." "Where are we?" I asked in a dreary voice. "Ohio," replied my mom's friend Sarah. We were going to Florida with my mom, Sarah, and me, my sister Emily, over spring break. We would be staying in the Florida Keys. While we were there we would be visiting my dad as he was working in the area. I knew it was going to be a memorable trip, but I also knew the long car ride there would be the ultimate test of my patience. It would take us two or three long days to reach our destination. The second day would be the hardest of them all. This was the day we would be driving through the winding mountain roads. I can usually pass the time when I am riding in the car by reading a book or listening to music on my headphones. However, when we reached the peak of the second mountain, everything went completely hectic. First off, my sister (who was sitting next to me) started screaming because there were not any guard rails and we were in the lane frighteningly close to the edges. Second, my sister started grasping my arm like her life depended on it, her nails digging into my skin. Last, and worst of all, my bladder started acting up! All of these things combined to turn our pleasant ride through the mountains into a rollercoaster ride that I will never in a moment ever forget. The whole time I was thinking to myself, "I'm going to go insane! Just make it stop." As if on cue, the screaming came to a halt, the pressure of my sister's grasp on my arm was relieved, and we were pulling into a welcome rest stop with bathrooms. If I had not been patient during that ride through the mountains I would have truly gone insane. I would be sitting in an asylum. I will always remember that harrowing ride through the mountains as a lesson in enduring discomfort.

Today was the first day I was truly patient. I couldn’t believe it. I was so proud of myself. This is how I was patient. I was in a long line waiting for ice cream and this teenage girl went up to the counter and said, "Excuse me, I have to be somewhere in ten minutes. If you don’t get this line moving then I’m going to have to talk to the manager." All the guy behind the counter said was, "I’m so sorry but you will just have to wait until everybody that was in line in front of you gets their order before you." "Seriously, are you kidding me?" she yelled as she stomped away, and that’s when I knew how ridiculous I must have looked when I’m impatient. So I waited calmly in line until I got up to the counter and I said, "Do you have to deal with a lot of people like that, because you handled the situation very calmly." And he said, "Yeah, there are a lot of people that are like that around here. It's truly sad. So, what would you like to order?" I told him my order, a double scoop of chocolate, and walked home. As I walked home licking my ice cream, I felt so proud of my calm behavior and decided that I’m never gonna be impatient again in such situations.

A time when I was patient was when I was waiting for my gymnastics meet to start. I had to wait two long hours along with the rest of my team. We began by warming up and stretching thoroughly, and then we were talking about who we thought would win the team trophy. After a while, we asked our coach if it was almost time to start. He said it was going to be another hour due to a delay. So, we talked some more about our routines and practiced some basic skills for floor exercise on the sidelines. We started a head-stand contest and did as much as we could to make the time go by faster, trying to keep our spirits high. We asked our coach another half hour later and he told us it was going to be a half hour longer because they had to get another judge. Finally, an hour later, the judge arrived and the coaches had their brief meeting and we started the meet. That is a time I was patient, waiting for the competition to begin.

I’m going to write about when I was patient. One day I asked my mom if I could get a phone. She said if I could be patient and wait until my birthday, I would be able to get a phone. So I was patient. I didn’t ask about it every day; I just waited. Time flew by and on my birthday, my family surprised me and she said yes. You see, when I was patient enough to get a cell phone, I got one. Have you ever been patient with your family? Tell me, did it work out or did it go bad? With your family, if you are patient, it probably will work out for you, just like it did for me. And that is what happens when you are patient and wait for good things.

"Did it come yet!?" I yelled, sprinting home from the bus stop, my backpack bouncing wildly. She was still standing by the mailbox, holding a thick wad of envelopes, flipping through them slowly. One of these, I hoped with all my heart, was the letter. "Not yet, honey," she said with a sympathetic smile, "but there’s plenty of bills to go around." I wanted to scream in exasperation, but I took a deep breath and remembered what my grandma had said, "just wait long enough and you’ll get what you want." I trudged inside and plopped down heavily on the couch. This letter meant so much to me. It would say which advanced classes I would be in. It doesn’t sound that important, but only the elite could get in and this meant the world to me. I would be challenged, my parents would be so proud of me, and I would get fifty bucks from grandma. See, you take a test at the end of the school year and wait the entire summer for results. Pretty good system, huh? No! Pretty soon, other things distracted me—swim meets, tennis, books—and I learned that it helps to be patient, and time goes by a lot faster. Grandma was right, I guess. One late August afternoon, right in the middle of the summer, I was on the porch reading a novel. Out of the corner of my eye, I saw the mail truck. The mailman shuffled around in his bag, pulled out a stack of mail, placed it in our mailbox, and drove away. I leaped out of my chair and ran to the mailbox, my heart pounding. I surveyed the mail quickly, my fingers flipping past catalogs and flyers, until one official-looking envelope caught my eye. I ripped it open and sure enough, it read I have been selected for the following advanced classes: Social studies, Mathematics, and English! My patience finally paid off!

The time I was patient was the time I was eight years old. It was a snowy night, and my mom and dad were buying a new car. It took so long; I was so hungry. My mom and dad were talking with the car dealer at his desk, discussing numbers and papers. My brother and sister were playing a game on their phone to pass the time. When my mom and dad were finally done talking with the car dealer, they got up to look at the car they wanted. Just then, one of the worker's brought me and my brother and sister a small box of cookies and little cartons of milk while my mom and dad were looking at the interior. We ate them quickly, and soon we got hungry again, but I showed patience and didn't complain. My mom and dad found the car they wanted; they chose a van with a television inside. They paid for it, signed the last of the papers, and we left. When we did, my father took us to a diner to get some food, and I was glad I had waited so calmly.

I consider myself to be an always patient person, that is, until I have to sit for hours doing nothing; then I can become quite restless. My mom is patient too, she has a great deal of patience, especially at the library where she works. A lot of people can be very rude to her, complaining about late fees or books that are not on the shelf. She just listens calmly and helps them as best she can, never raising her voice. It amazes me how she maintains her composure, and I try to learn from her example in my own daily life.

One day, just a few months ago, me, my brother, and my mom were waiting in a long, winding line to put our school supplies on the list. We were number one hundred and fifteen, and they had just called number forty-two. It was around ninety percent humidity outside and we had to stand there in the heat. It was so long that the new battery I had just put in my Nintendo DS went completely dead. It took around two and a half hours just to get inside the building. Then, once we were in, there were even more lines to navigate! We barely got our things that day, the store was nearly picked clean, but because we were patient and waited our turn, we did manage to get what we needed.

I didn’t know where we were at; I had never been to this part of town before. Then my dad told me we were at this place called Buddies. I’d never been there until that day. The waitress put us at a circular table near the window. Then, she asked us if we would like anything to drink. I told our waitress I would like a Diet Pepsi. My sister got a fruit punch, as always. My mom and dad both got a Mountain Dew. My brother got a cherry Pepsi. I don’t know why we all got different drinks. It took fifteen long minutes to get our drinks though. My dad wasn’t so patient; he kept sighing and looking toward the kitchen. He knew that the food would take forever. Finally our waitress came out with our drinks on a large tray. She apologized for the wait. Then she took our order. The wait for our food after ordering was another twenty minutes. My dad was very impatient, tapping his fingers on the table. I was the only patient one at our table, trying to keep everyone calm. The restaurant wasn’t even that busy, which made the wait feel longer. I told my dad to just be patient, that the food will be right out any minute. So we waited and waited, making small talk. Finally, the food came out, steaming hot. We ate all the food, got the bill, then left. That was the time I was patient when everyone else was not.

I am going to be writing about a time when I was patient. Me and my family were setting up decorations one day for my tenth birthday party. I was so excited and jumpy. I was turning ten so it was a big deal for me. We all ready had the cake which was decorated in beautiful yellow and white frosting. It also had a picture of horses running on it and “Happy Birthday Hannah.” The party started at eleven am. I was in my pretty pink flowered dress and putting streamers up. I kept asking what the time was, and my mom would just say to be patient. I had to wait. I was a very impatient girl. I was just so excited I couldn’t wait. I then remembered that I was supposed to be patient so I was. I played games and read books while I was waiting for the guests. Then before I knew it the door bell rang and all my family came running in with presents and cards. I guess all that waiting really payed off. I also got some really cool presents, and I learned that being patient makes the final surprise even sweeter.

Everyday at school I have to be patient to get my food like pizza, salad, sandwich with milk which is bad all the time but I check my milk. I had to be patient to get my gum to chew after lunch. The line in the cafeteria is always very long and moves slowly. I stand there waiting my turn, watching the clock tick away. Sometimes my friends are ahead of me and they get their food first. I just have to wait quietly without pushing or complaining. Finally, when I get to the front, I can choose my food and my milk. Then I can go sit down and enjoy my meal with everyone else. Learning to wait my turn is an important part of having patience every single day.

Elkhorn Jr. High school, October 15th, Colton Thornbourne was having a pretty bland day, he absolutely hated school, he just wanted to go home, but his teacher told him to sit down, shut up, and do his work. So he tries to kill time by flicking eraser tops at the chalkboard. After about sixty eraser tops, he looks at the clock and it reads, 1:30. He complains to his teacher and she says, "Colton, if you don't be patient I'm going to send you home!" Colton exclaims, "But I want to go home!" The teacher says, "That's it Colton, to detention after school." So Colton sits down in fear of detention and does his work, all day, without complaining. "Finally," the teacher says when the bell rings, signaling the end of the school day and his long period of forced patience.

I was waiting, looking forward and staring at the silent audience. Yet I couldn't really see that well since the stage lights coming down on me were quite blinding. I stood next to my best friend Sarah. On the other side of the stage was our competitors Mark and Johnson. As I kept staring forward I thought about how I got here and why I was here. I was gazing out the window of the small classroom while Mrs. Perkins kept talking. She said there was a contest for the whole seventh grade. We needed to get in pairs and write a story about anything we wanted. Sarah and I looked at each other and shook our heads yes. Later that day I rode my bike over to Sarah’s house and thought about what to write. Mrs. Perkins also said whoever wins gets to go to more writing competitions. I was so excited, almost jumping up and down, because I love writing and competition. I jumped off my bike and ran to Sarah, already shouting out ideas. Finally we decided on something to write about. It would be an adventure story about how a plane crashed in the middle of a jungle. By the end of the week we had ten pages written down. I went on my Acer and typed the ten page paper. After all the spell checks and grammar checks we printed our story and turned it in. The results came at the end of the day; it was a tie between Johnson and Mark and Sarah and me. So our writing was given to the state for another competition. Ironically, Mark’s pair and my pair won again! I really hoped we wouldn't tie for the country competition. So here I was on the stage, still staring at the audience, all done thinking about how I got here. I was so tired of waiting. Sarah told me to have some patience so I did. After twenty minutes of judging the president came up and said Hannah and Sarah have won first place. We jumped up and down and got our trophy. Sarah and I found out that hard work and patience can really lead to something great, a lesson I will always remember.

One Monday I was patient waiting for a game to arrive. I waited two years for it to come and the game finale came. I started out the Monday like it was any other. But the Monday just kept dragging on so by the time I got home I just sat on the front porch the rest of the Monday waiting for it. It never came so I just went to bed. The next Tuesday I came home and checked the mail but it was empty so I slumped onto the couch and watched TV. I looked out the front window and there was a package that was just delivered. You wait until you get to the very top, then you splash down a steep hill into the water below. Well, that was one of everyone's favorite rides, so there was a long, winding line that hardly seemed to move. Patience is the ability to be tolerant, understanding, and face difficulties without complaining. Patience isn’t something they teach you in my school. There isn’t a book you're assigned to read called "Patience 101," there is no movie called "Patience is the Key." None of that exists, even if you live in a world where a necklace can be turned into a camera, or a cell phone is a gun. I have just been assigned my first undercover mission and it’s not at all what I had expected. So far, all I have done is sat on a cold, metal bench next to the strength meter at a dusty county fair. What people really don’t understand is the immense patience that is put into being a spy. Sure, there's an occasional car being blown up, but not today, not for me. I hear the clock in my hand go ‘tick, tock, tick, tock.’ ACCESS DENIED, LOADING, there’s some action. The subject, the person I’m assigned to watch, is on the move and, oh, never mind, all the subject has done is buy a three-dollar bag of popcorn. I start to doodle a spiraling design in the dirt with the toe of my shoe. I’m just about to abort the mission, seeing that nothing is happening, when all of a sudden I find a clue. There in the dirt that lay just before me, I see a tiny, glinting computer chip. I carefully pick it up and spray it with a fingerprint-revealing mist. A purple, fluffy cloud of vapor surrounds the chip. Sure enough, when the purple cloud vanishes, I see that the subject's fingerprints are clearly on the chip. I pull out my laptop and insert the computer chip. LOADING, LOADING are the words that stay on the computer screen as if refusing to leave. I sit there waiting, bored. I remember patience. I think to myself that if I’m able to defeat twelve armed robbers with nothing but a tablecloth, I’m sure I can sit here and just be patient. At least twenty minutes have gone by now, but it feels like twenty hours. The computer still has written on the screen, LOADING, LOADING, LOADING, and then it was successful. “SUCCESS!” I say aloud and people start to stare, but I don’t mind. I click the square on the screen that says “open.” A small message opens up that says “MEET me at the ice cream parlor.” I close my laptop and start to slowly walk over to the ice cream van, observing everyone and everything around me. A man wearing a wrinkled yellow shirt and a lady with a purple scarf draped over her head are the only two people standing by the ice cream stand. I walk a little bit closer and I realize that the man has a gun tucked into his waistband. I pull out mine and with a few loud roars they were both in handcuffs; of course, they were both working with the main suspect. I would have never been able to successfully complete my mission without being patient.

My mom couldn’t wait any longer; she was about to take me home, her foot tapping impatiently on the tiled floor. I told her to be patient and it would feel like time is going faster. He was still looking for the needle, then he came back in the room a final time and said he found it. It was in the other doctor's room above the sink on the dresser. After I got my shot, the doctor thanked me and my mom for being patient and not leaving. After he thanked me, he gave me a sucker and shook my hand. Me and my mom left out and went to the store and got something to eat, and I felt proud of our patience.

“Mom, can I get a puppy?” “Not now, honey.” “But Mom,” she pleaded, “just a puppy for my birthday in the spring, just be patient.” “It’s a big decision.” The little girl made her way down the stairs to sulk in the living room, where she thought of a brilliant plan to make the sixty days until her birthday go faster. “I know,” she said, “I will make a sixty-link long paper chain.” Each and every day, or sometimes counting down the days, she ripped one paper link off. She ripped them off after school, then before bed, and even counted down the weeks and months. Before she knew it, it was finally the morning of her birthday. She sprang out of bed, ran to the chain, ripped the last link off and said, “Mom, can I have a puppy yet? I was so patient.” “Well, you see,” said her mom gently. “Your dad and I have been thinking, and it is a very big responsibility, so let’s talk about it again next spring.” “Okay,” she sighed, “I’ll be patient.”

I think that patience is about waiting instead of rushing things. If you are patient, things will actually come faster than you think. For example, if you want something and you have to wait in a line, instead of running off and finding something else to do, it will always help to just wait. Be patient with whatever you are doing, just be patient even if it is waiting for the school day to be over. If you are waiting for a game at the gym to come, just have patience and wait because it might keep you out of trouble. Be patient with whatever you are doing, even if you are waiting for a turn, just wait as it is not a big deal. Stop rushing things and just be very patient, and you will find everything works out better in the end.

“John on Mark, where are you,” Tom said in a frustrated undertone. Mark was supposed to come over to his house. Tom had just gotten a new trampoline and they were planning on bouncing all day after school. Tom was starting to get worried but he waited patiently by the window. Finally his mom came and told him that Mark wasn’t coming. That's when the phone rang. Tom answered it and heard Mark on the other end. “Sorry, Tom,” Mark croaked. He didn’t sound well. “Mark,” Tom shouted into the phone, “Mark, Mark where are you?” “I’m at my house, get over here.” Tom’s mom pulled up at Mark’s house and let him out. Tom didn’t care about manners at this point, so he opened the door and marched to Mark’s room. Mark was laying in bed looking up at the ceiling with his face looking very swollen. He turned to look at Tom, held his gaze, then looked back at the ceiling. Mark wasn’t at school that day either. He explained, “I went skiing up at my family cottage. I wasn’t patient when I was in the air and I tried a jump I wasn't ready for. I got crushed and none of it would have happened if I had waited for the right moment.”

One time I was patient was at my dad's house. Our power had just gone out so we figured we would wait for up to two minutes just like it always happened before. After a couple of days, we still didn't have power and I was getting impatient. On day three, we called the power people and they figured out a tree had fallen on our power lines. They came and fixed it, and we finally got our power back. It was a good lesson in waiting for things to be resolved properly.

There are two reasons why I think patience is important. The first is because if you are not patient, then you can end up distracting other people around you. For example, if you finished your math test early and you kept telling everyone else to hurry up, it’s distracting. Now that you’ve interrupted everyone, they have lost their train of thought and now they might have to start their work over. A few weeks ago, my sister and I were out walking my dog and he pulled so hard my little sister fell over and my dog ran away. We had to be patient and wait for him to return. My sister kept wanting to call my mom to tell her the dog ran away again but I told her it would be rude to call because it would distract her from her work. Another reason why patience is important is because if you are not patient you can get hurt. Let’s say you were going down the stairs and your sibling was in front of you and you needed to get downstairs quickly but they were walking down the stairs very slow, so you pushed them; they could get very hurt from a fall. In conclusion, patience is needed always and cannot be forgotten if we want to live together safely and respectfully.

“Tick, tick, tick,” the clock was counting down. “Tick, tick, tick,” so close, come on, I whispered as the clock kept going. My heart was beating like a race car engine. I could hear my heart go boom, boom, boom as my mind raced with what I was going to do for fun—jump in the pool, watch a video, play a game. So many options, what should I do? “Tick, tick, tick,” I could almost hear the pool calling to me, “swim, swim, swim.” What should I do? I looked at Mrs. Sprowl, then back at the clock, then at Mrs. Sprowl, then back at the clock and Mrs. Sprowl again. My heart was almost jumping out of my body with so much anticipation. “Tick, tick, tick,” “almost there,” I said as I stared at the second hand. “Tick, tick, tick,” so close I said, so close, just one second left then I can swim in my pool. “Three,” I almost jumped out of my seat and yelled, “Two, one!” “Class, class, class,” we have some announcements, said Mrs. White. I was happy when it was over and I ran outside to wait for my dad so I could finally have my freedom and start the summer.

I was patience the whole entire time, maintaining a calm and steady demeanor throughout the experience. I was happy on the outside, putting on a brave and content face for everyone to see, but on the inside, I was quietly wrestling with my own thoughts, and I truly wish I got a better score to reflect the effort I felt I had put in.

As a child my mom always taught me about patience, a lesson I couldn't quite grasp back then, which is why I’m writing this about her now. My mom is very nice, cool, wealthy, and most of all patient. There were so many things I did as a child, and still some things now, that would test her, yet my mom would just calmly collect herself as if we didn't even do anything wrong. It's kinda funny how much patient she has, a seemingly endless supply. Along time ago, I have a clear memory of wasting grape pop on her new carpet!! Wow how scared did I get….I think I wet my pants!! Instead of hiding it like any other kid would, when she got home I immediately cried to her that I wasted pop on your carpet, pleading don't get mad. She replied in her soothing mother loving voice, telling me exactly how to clean it up. I passed her a dry towel and smiled, explaining just remember this time a kid I can't reach the sink's) Without yelling she walked, she walked up stairs and wet the towel her self. I stayed down stairs looking at the ugly purple mess I made, still trying to help my mom, but she just told me to sit down. She said this holding my hand gently. By this time momma got done with the stain I was fast a sleep on the couch. My mom gave me a kiss on the cheek and didn't wake me up!! The gig was up soon as she picked me up. I said in my morning voice, is that you?? My mom being so patient simply smiled. I then asked what's for breakfast?? in a high pitched voice. I will get on it she said while taking out my breakfast. I love my mom.

Last year we went to the amusement park, it was about two weeks before school started. That day schools by the park had just opened so there was no lines to wait in. We couldn’t have picked a better day. Then we got to the mantice ride and I didn’t want to go on it, but my mom said nothing will go wrong, okay? I said fine I’ll go on to the ride. We are about to take off going up the hill and right when we got to the top the ride stops.’ I was freaking out at first but then I got over it. So we have been up there for about ten min or so and we had to be patient.’ My mom and dad are on the inside of them.’ We were sitting on bicycle seats and they were not comfy. So then another five min pasted by and now we have been stuck at the top for fifteen mins.’ This is were we had to be completely quiet and patient, just waiting for something to happen. Then the ride started and we got down to the bottom and finished the ride. They gave us a pass for us to cut in line on the tornado force ride. That is all they gave us. So we had fun the rest of the day, but that day I learned in life you have to have patience!

Once upon a time their was a princess named Isabella. She was invited to a royal ball where she awaited her handome prince. As her carriage arrived she paused at the people before getting out, taking a deep and steadying breath. Finally she stepped out of the vehicle. Isabella walked gracefully down the red carpet. As she arrived, the more noisy it got as the princess finally aproched the opened doors. The beautiful girl walked to her throne and warched the village people dance among her. She sat for two hours, waiting with a quiet and hopeful heart. She wandered will he show up? and will he like me? She doubted her luck as the minutes continued to pass. The princess grabed the microphone, calling out into the hall! Does anyone know where my prince is? A complete silence went over the croud, and for a moment, it seemed all was lost. Finally at the last minute, an anonomyse voice called out from the back. I am the prince! A sigh of relif came over her. He explained, I’m so late, I fought a dragon and a thousand knights to get here to meet my love! awwwww! The crowd said softly. And they lived happily ever after, their patience finally rewarded.

The one time I was patient is when my mom took me to go get my birth certificate so I could play football. When we got there the parking lot was full I mean cars was so close you could hardly get in and out without scratching someones car. My mom parked across the streets. When we got in there it was at least fifty to sixty people it packed. People were standing so close to each other you would know their body temperature. The bench was full of people and they were parked like sardines. It was hot and smelled like must, a truly unpleasant atmosphere. We picked a ticket with sixty-five on it and they were on twenty-two. When they finally got to our number I was fast sleep, completely worn out from the long and tedious wait. Wile we was in there I lost ten pounds from all the heat and standing.

I’m not a very patient person. I always whine and complain. My two best friends Sam and Sarah were already together with this new girl, who was pretty good. “You want to be partners with me and make a group?” Sarah asked. “Sure,” I responded. Once upon a time there was a boy named Alex. When I went to the game with @LOCATION1, @PERSON1, and his mom and dad, I learned a lot about patience. @PERSON1 has Down syndrome, and he likes to watch games. Are you patient? Well, I am always patient. I am going to tell you about a time when I was patient at school. One day I had to register for school and it was very busy. A time when I was patient was during last @DATE1. My friends and I were waiting in line to get an autograph from the Detroit Tigers @NUM1 baseman @CAPS1 @CAPS2. I was patient when I went to the doctors. When I went to the doctors, me and my mom waited patiently for a long time in the crowded waiting room. It felt like years but it was only for @NUM1 hour. I read some old magazines and watched the other families waiting their turn. I asked my mom, “Why did it take forever?” My mom said, “Because there are other people before us who also need to see the doctor.” “Oh,” I said, and I understood that waiting is just a part of life sometimes, so I sat back down and continued to wait quietly until it was finally our turn.

One day I was a patient person at a water park and I was waiting to get on a water slide, but there were like twenty people in front of me. At the same time, it was so hot and I didn’t know what to do, I realized the ground was burning hot if you had no flip flops on your feet. Then I said to myself this better be worth it or I'm going to be furious. But it was a long line, so I decided I was gonna be patient about it. I hoped I would have fun on this ride, and eventually, my turn came.

I was patient last year when I was taking a very important test and it was not done on time. I really hate being patient and when I do have to wait, it is incredibly boring. Patients seem like they take forever to finally be over. And then people just start getting headaches from the stress and frustration of waiting, and then you get in trouble by your mom or dad or teachers for talking too much because you are so restless. And that is exactly why I don’t like being patient at all.

Patience is when you can wait for a long period of time and not complain about the delay, but I don’t think I have very much patience myself. I think patience is like waiting in a long line for hours and not caring because you are a very patient person, but everything in life takes some patience. Playing games, driving in traffic, eating while waiting for your food, and even being at school all day, they all take a lot of patience to get through. It is a challenging skill to master for sure.

Every single school year I wait patiently for the summer vacation to finally arrive. It feels like a terrifyingly long time waiting for that final day, but it is always worth it in the end. The anticipation builds up with each passing week, making the final reward of freedom all the sweeter when it finally comes.

Hi, I’m Emma Johnson and I have green eyes, blonde hair, and I have a good personality. Okay, so I am going to tell you about a time when I was focused on being patient. We all have our times when we are very patient, and the times when we lose all patience we have. I’m not the most patient person, but I have my times, and so should everyone else. Life is so much better in the long run if you are patient and handle things calmly!

I’ll have to wait until school ends, the meet ends, and the @ORGANIZATION1 ends to go home, but I can live. All that is on my mind is to live the whole school year, patiently, without messing up or failing badly, and that is my plan.

Even though you @MONTH1 not know @CAPS1, there is patience all around us; you @MONTH1 not even know you're using the patience like waiting in a line for lunch or waiting for something, but you are. Here is a story about when I used patience. One day, on a hot @DATE1 day at wider point, we decided that we were going to go to the water park. As soon as we got there we jumped into the first pool and I waited for my dad. After a while of playing we decided to go on one of the water slides; @CAPS1 was the water slide at the park. @CAPS1 was so big you had to take @NUM1 flights of stairs to get to @CAPS1, but after I went back I knew @CAPS1 was worth the wait because the ride down was so exciting and fun.

My story is about a time when I was patient was in (@DATE1). I was waiting for “@CAPS1” to come. I was being patient because we were going to @LOCATION2. I couldn’t wait to go but I remembered to be “patient”. The less I thought about it the faster time passed by. Then it came, it was time to head to “@LOCATION2”. When we were in the car on our way there I couldn’t wait any longer! More and more roads passed by. We passed city to city; state to state. It was the next day already and I still couldn’t wait. During the long ride I fell asleep and when I had woke up, we were already there. I had to have patience because riding in a car from @LOCATION1 to @LOCATION2 is a long drive. While being patient I got to see many things and travelled through different states, which made the journey part of the fun adventure.

Patience is something that most people don’t have, and it was the central virtue I discovered I needed during a particular incident a couple of years ago. I was picked up from school by my mom, who intended to take me home but decided to stop for groceries first. When we arrived at the store, she asked if I wanted to come inside, but after thinking about all the reasons why I didn't want to, I of course said no. I remained in the car, where the temperature felt like it was at least ninety degrees outside. I was sweating profusely within just ten minutes of waiting in the stationary vehicle. My mom still wasn’t out of the store, and the time stretched on. There were so many moments when I felt the urge to become angry and frustrated, but I consciously didn’t let myself get that way. I even watched as other people entered the store and then came out with their bags long before my mom finally emerged. It was at least two full hours before she had finally come out, carrying her groceries and offering explanations and apologies for why she was so late. I wasn’t mad at her; I just understood her reasons. Most of the time I am not a patient person. Actually, I am never patient for situations like that, which is why I was so profoundly glad I was able to be patient for this story.

Sometimes on days when I have very little patience at all, I have to consciously control myself so I don’t just go off on someone or say something totally mean to them! A perfect example was last summer when we went camping up in the mountains. We always go for about a one to two hour hike during these trips. Our destination is usually Lake Serene, but just before that, to get there, we take what my dad calls an “adventure hike!” This path takes you through dense woods and over, or sometimes even through, a shallow river. Crucially, there are two ways you could take: a direct five-minute hike straight to Lake Serene, or a much longer, hour to two-hour hike through the winding woods and over slippery logs. On days when I have very little patience at all, and just want to get straight to the lake to relax, we always have to go the long way around! And everybody hates it by the time we finally get to the lake, because I will just complain and complain some more! (Honestly, sometimes I get annoyed at myself for complaining!) Then, on the way back it's usually more fun, but only after we go swimming in the freezing cold water! (My dad always says it clears my head! But it really doesn’t!) And by the time we get back to our campsite, we are all ready to have dinner, but dinner isn’t ready yet. So then I get to be in a bad mood… again! And have to wait some more, testing my patience all over again.

Two years ago, my two-year-old cousin Lily was adopted from China. My aunt, uncle, and their son had to wait an arduous three years before they could even see a picture of her and begin the extensive paperwork. The people at the orphanage were not being very fair or cooperative with them. They let almost twenty other people, who had begun their adoption efforts a full year after my aunt and uncle, go ahead of them in the process. My family had to travel all the way to China from their home, which was in Ohio, and then wait in a hotel for three days until they were finally permitted to just see her. After that first emotional meeting, the orphanage made them wait another entire week to finalize the adoption. Finally, the day came when they officially adopted her and named her Lily. They went through more tedious paper work, signed documents promising they would always take care of her, and then began the journey home. After they arrived, Lily didn’t sleep at all during the first week or so. Since China is twelve hours ahead of Ohio, her internal clock was completely reversed; she would sleep during the day and be wide awake at night. They eventually, with great consistency, taught her to sleep during the night. That little girl required a lot of patience from everyone, but she was finally, happily adopted into our family.

The time I was remarkably patient was last summer when we went to Cedar Point. The day was hot and the park was crowded. When we finally got in line for my favorite roller coaster, the line was incredibly long and moved very slowly. After what felt like an eternity, we eventually got to the front of the line, but just as it was our turn to board, the machine broke down. So then we had to go to another ride, and I couldn't wait very long in this new line because I desperately had to go to the bathroom. I walked out of the line and went to the nearest restroom. When I came back, I saw that there were many more people in the line than before. Instead of getting upset or complaining, I just took a deep breath, found my family, and waited calmly until it was finally our turn to ride.

My dad, Robert, is a man who demonstrates patience every single day. He goes to work at his office and, like anyone, he can't wait to come home, but he never gets stir-crazy or antsy like I do when I want to leave a place. No, he simply focuses and does his work diligently, waiting until five o'clock when he is officially allowed to leave and go home to our family. He always patiently waits until that clock strikes five, never trying to rush out early or shirk his responsibilities. My dad has always been an incredibly patient person, and I truly look up to him because of that consistent and admirable patience he shows in all aspects of his life.

I was at the Great Wolf Lodge and we could not go in the main indoor pool because some kid had pooped in it. A big part of the pool water had turned a murky brown, which was very unpleasant. We were disappointed to learn we could not go in for three whole hours while they cleaned it, and the waiting period felt very boring. To pass the time, we decided to go outside, and that is when we discovered there was another pool out there the whole time that we had not noticed before. We ended up having a fun time swimming outside instead, which saved the day after the unfortunate incident inside.

A time when I was patient, I have been patient plenty of times but one I mostly remember is when I was waiting for a friend to get home from school, since I had missed school that day. While waiting I did plenty of things to keep myself occupied. I played my Xbox for a while and I got on the computer. But while on Xbox I saw one of my friends come online. He lives in a different state. After he got online we played for most of the day, then I got off and watched television because I was bored. Nothing good was on so I got back on the computer, but I was still bored. So I tried to take a nap, but that didn’t work. After that I tried to play my Xbox again but after another hour, it got boring. I still played for about another half an hour till I just redid my account while listening to music and played some more till my other friend finally got online. We played all day till night, and my patience was finally rewarded with a fun gaming session.

My friend was patient last week in the lunch line, where he waited about fifteen minutes. I had gotten to the cafeteria before many of the other students were in line. He was behind the second and third graders. He was patient by not cutting in front of them and didn't complain at all. The line was longer because there had been a school presentation and then it was lunchtime; the second and third graders didn't have lunch yet so that was why he had to wait. I thought he did a good job waiting. When many students were filling up the tables I saved him a seat next to me. He finally got his lunch and I saw him go over to the fruit and milk cooler and grab an orange. I waved to him across the room and he saw me. When he came and sat down next to me I told him he did a good job being patient and waiting to get his lunch. I was almost done with my macaroni and cheese when he said, "Thanks for saving a seat for me." When we both finished we took care of our trays and walked down the hall to the gym. We were glad we didn't have to be in that loud, crowded cafeteria. In the gym other kids were playing a small basketball game. He grabbed a basketball. I waited until the second graders were done, I was patient, then the teacher told the younger students to go back to class. When I got the ball I asked him if he wanted to play around the world. It was one of his and my favorite games we played together, and we enjoyed a few rounds before our break was over.

Boom! Boom! I knew my cousins were at the door because they were all heavy handed. So I ran down the stairs and opened the door; it was them. Then, we all got into the van. "You all ready to have some fun?" my mom asked, and we replied, "Yes!!!" It was so boring in the van but I had to be patient. After we got to Ohio we stopped and got some food. After twenty minutes we got back into the van. When we got to the amusement park we were all excited; it was going to be a good day I thought, but I also knew that it was going to take some time and patience. Next, when we got into the park we all went straight to the roller coaster. It was a half an hour wait. This was going to take a lot of patience so we waited and waited; when we finally got on and off we realized it was worth it. Then we got on a lot of rides, but the best one was the disaster-themed one. When we got back to the van we all said it was fun. Then I realized I had been very patient throughout the entire day, and it made the experience much more enjoyable.

One day me and my friend were going on a trip to Alabama. It was the most boring car ride ever! Imagine just driving in a car for twelve hours, just driving and stopping to use the bathroom. And to make matters worse, I had the smallest bladder there, which as I can imagine was quite a challenge! But we did get to count Waffle Houses because the farther south you go the more people like waffles. I’m not kidding, there was at least one Waffle House every few miles. And a kind of funny thing was we weren’t just going to Alabama, we were going to the very bottom of Alabama. So when we finally crossed the state line, we still had to wait two more hours. But when we finally got there we had a blast! And I have to admit one good thing came from the experience: long car rides don’t bother us as much anymore, having built up our patience on that long journey.

I am going to tell you about a time when I was patient. My younger cousin was at my house and needed help on his math homework. Because no one else was home, I had to be the one to help him. We sat together on the living room couch and I began to help him. The reason I had to be patient was because he didn’t know how to do any of it, not even the simplest problems. It was a long and repetitive process, taking almost two hours before we were finally done with it all. And that was a time when I truly had to be patient.

My father has recently lost his job. It has been a hard time for our family. It has been exactly three months since my father has had a job. Without the patience of my father, our family could not live with such stability. Well, job or no job, I will always love my father. This would be true because of my father's great level of patience. Patience is a very difficult thing for some people to master. One time I was at a huge family party with many guests.
