The next day, as a reward, my mom sent me over to my cousin's house for a sleepover. This was because I was being patient at the party and did not complain further. I learned that being patient isn't always a bad thing. You receive good things when you choose to be patient.

Melay was a little girl, waiting for her parents in the dense bush. She didn’t know why she had to wait there. Her parents seemed distressed all the time now. "It must be something I did," she thought. Her sister was not as patient as Melay was waiting. Her sister had to be doing something all the time and could not sit still. So when her parents didn’t come and somebody else did, she wasn't happy. Some boys came walking along the road where they were hiding, carrying rifles. Melay was thinking, “these are boys waiting along the street. Are they crazy!” If their parents told them to hide, it was always for a good reason. She sat there thinking about this when she heard a loud crack! "What was that?" she thought. She looked to where her sister was supposed to be and she wasn't there. "Where was she?" As she looked out to where the boy soldiers were standing around laughing. "What were they laughing at?" Melay looked closer and saw that it was her sister. "No!" she cried out. "Where are my parents, they should be here by now," she thought. The boy soldiers were walking towards her. That's when she saw another two mangled and depleted bodies. She found out that it was her parents. She started running, running away from the tragedy. She made it about a mile before she had to hide. She hid in a thick bush. The boy soldiers were walking around looking for her. Suddenly one cried out, "There she is!" They dragged her out of the bush, and walked for what seemed to be forever. Finally they reached a building. Melay was screaming at herself, "If only I had waited. If only I had waited." They took her into a room and the boss raped her, then they quickly shot her to death and dragged her into a dumpster. If only she had waited.

I remember this hot summer day I was on my way to the dentist. I left school because it was the second to last day, and I left school about forty-five minutes early. My appointment was at four-thirty. So I arrived at the dentist's office at about four-fifteen. There was about four people ahead of me in the waiting room. So I waited patiently. And four-thirty passed, so I went across the street and ordered a small drink. After finishing my drink, I bought some gum from a store, and it was now five o'clock on the dot. I'm still waiting, so I go and ask the front desk manager how long it will be until I go in. She said she would go check for me. She came back and she told me I can go right on in. I felt so happy for myself for being so patient and not complaining, and I even got a toothbrush for being patient!

A time when I had to be patient was when I needed help with my schoolwork. My dad is very smart so whenever I needed help, I usually ask him for help. Well I get out of school at three o'clock, but my dad gets home from work at six. So, if I wanted his help, I would have to wait patiently by myself, even though I didn’t understand the assignment. I would put the homework that needed help back in my backpack until my dad got home, and I wished I only had homework that didn’t need help on. After I finished the homework that I could do on my own, like all my math problems, then it was time to eat dinner. As I ate my dinner, I would watch the clock. By that time I was done waiting, and my dad was finally home, ready to help me. We would sit together after dinner, and he would help me understand the difficult subjects so much more, making the long wait worthwhile.

Once there was a lonely puppy who felt very sad with no one to play with. One day he decided to send a letter to a random address and then he waited and waited and waited for a reply. A few weeks later, to his great joy, he got a reply to his letter, and it was from another puppy who was also looking for a friend! They soon became best friends, writing to each other often and sharing stories. The puppy learned that patience pays off, usually when you least expect it. The two friends were never lonely again, and the first puppy was very glad he had been so patient.

On a cool October evening my friend Sarah and I climbed on the bus headed for the Halloween event at the big amusement park. Sarah and I were with our church group, and we were all together till one in the morning. We had been riding all different rides all day and we finally got in line for the biggest roller coaster. The sign out front said the wait from this point was two hours, but we were determined to wait it out. I was around eight o'clock then so that would put us on the ride around ten. We soon found out that the park also started a fireworks show at nine, and lucky us we were standing right next to a haunted house. Around nine-thirty all of us were pretty bored so we played different hand games like slide and lemonade to pass the time. About every five minutes we would hear loud, obnoxious screams from the haunted house, and we always heard feet running like they were in a race. Then at about ten o'clock we finally got on the ride, and we all loved the thrilling drop. When we got off someone suggested we go on the spinning ride, and all the adults loved the idea. As we walked over I could smell sweet treats from a nearby stand and could almost taste an elephant ear on my tongue. Little did we know that we would have to walk through the clown carnival to get there. It was filled with evil clowns and other spooky creatures, which was not a good idea given the fact that half of us were afraid of clowns. When we got to the ride entrance there was a giant line, but it was only going to take forty-five minutes. The ride was over and boy did my head hurt from hitting it on the head rest so many times during the spins. On the way to the exit we saw a ton more of spooky attractions we had missed. We found out later that we had waited in line for a total of five hours for all the rides that night. We finally got on the bus, tired but happy, and headed home. That day I truly learned that I have a lot more patience than I thought I did.

A time when I was patient was when we were leaving on vacation. It seemed like I had been waiting forever to go to the beach, really it had only been about a month since we booked the trip. I was so excited, but I had to be really patient and let the days pass. Sometimes its hard for me to be patient because I like things to be done right away, so waiting a whole month to go to the beach was very hard for me. The night before we left was probably the hardest of all. I was so excited I couldn’t sleep at all, just thinking about the ocean. The day we left I was so excited and I was running all around the house yelling that it was finally time. Finally we loaded up the car and left for our destination. We drove our car there so it took almost two long days. But it was worth it, the beach was really fun and pretty, with soft sand and big waves. We also went to the boardwalk amusement park and had an awesome time on the rides. I had to be patient at the amusement park since there were long lines for the popular rides, so we had to wait a while for each one. I had a really fun time on my vacation, and the patience I practiced made the trip even sweeter.

Everybody uses patience sometimes in their life, and I have to use it everyday, especially for basketball practice. There could be a lot of different reasons that someone would need to be patient. Well, I have three reasons in particular that test my patience. My first one is when people don’t pay attention during drills. It frustrates me a lot. When the team members goof off, our coach gets mad. She will either tell us to knock it off or she will make us run a couple of laps around the entire gym. My first reason leads directly to my second. The second thing that irks me is that when people don’t pay attention, they get lost in the play and have no clue what is going on during the game. There is a lot of people who take a long time to catch on to new strategies. My second reason leads to my third. My third is when somebody new joins the team and we have to start from the beginning. We just had two new people join the other day and the season is half over already. The newest member of the team can not make a shot to save her life. She doesn’t put all of her effort into it, which is hard to watch. There is only like two out of ten or twelve people on the team that is actually good at shooting. Looking over my thoughts, all of this is stuff I have to be patient about. If I wasn’t patient, I would be in trouble with the coach and it would mean I would have bad sportsmanship, which is important. I deal with it and put up with all of this though, because I love the game. Over the years I have learned a lot about patience from basketball. I learned how to be patient with others and with myself. I’m glad I know how to be patient now or else where would I be? Probably not on any teams or in any clubs, and I would have missed out on a lot of fun.

I remember a time when I was patient, it was kind of hard to just sit there waiting on the doctor to call my name. The chairs were stiff and the air felt still. But I suffered through it. Instead of me getting mad about how the lady hadn't called my name yet, after waiting like twenty minutes, I just turned my music player on and listened to my music while reading a magazine. The soft melodies and the colorful pages helped the time pass more quickly. Before I knew it the nurse called my name, “James,” she said with a smile on her face. So I got up and went to the room she directed me in. When I left the doctors office and I was going on I thought to myself “maybe being patient isn’t that bad after all!”

Almost every time you need to be patient when you are at the doctors or in the hospital. The waiting can seem to stretch on forever. What I do to pass time when I’m at the doctors is play I spy. I play it with my mom every single time we find ourselves in that situation. There is usually a lot of people at the doctors when I go, which gives us plenty of things to spot. There is magazines but I think they are boring, so they just sit on the table untouched. Therefore I play I spy to stay patient and keep my mind occupied. Otherwise I would be very, very bored, just staring at the clock on the wall.

Last year I had to go to the doctor on my birthday. So after I came home from school I left right back out, feeling a little disappointed. When we got there we had to wait in the lobby. There were crying babies every where, we still had to go to the movies, and shopping, and I could feel my special day slipping away. After what felt like an hour, there were still too many people in front of me. I started to get mad, tapping my foot impatiently. Finally, they called my name. I was so happy I didn’t know what to do, finally free to start celebrating.

A time when someone was patient was when a guy named Mr. Jenkins was driving and a little girl named Sarah was walking on the side walk and it was a red light. She yelled out loud “go old man!” The old man went and she followed him to the store and she asked what was that and Mr. Jenkins says that was nothing. “No you tried to hit me!” “No you were rushing me so I went,” he explained calmly. Sarah says to Mr. Jenkins I was losing my patience. Mr. Jenkins tells her “well learn how to control it then,” showing great restraint himself.

“Mom!” Lily whined, her voice escalating into a wail. “You can’t do this to me. I’m ten!” “Lily, calm down. I know you are ten, and at that, a very responsive ten year old. But I have told you before, I can’t leave you at the house all summer. Your father and I have work honey!” “Mom can’t you just hire a babysitter? What about Emily? She babysitted last year!” Lily’s mother sighed. “I know you liked Emily, but she just wasn’t fit to the requirements I was looking for. Besides, you said you wanted to be a babysitter! Why not try and help at the daycare?” Lily used her well practiced glare at her mother that said “but if!”. This conversation had been held two weeks ago in the kitchen of the Fullers. Susan, Lily’s mother, was taking her to the county’s only day care, Sunny and Bright Daycare. The name made Lily want to gag. “Susan remember sweetie, be nice and try to help out a bit. I love you!” she called as she started to pull out of the driveway. Lily turned to face the small building. The sign above the building stated “Sunny and Bright Daycare. A friendly and loving environment”. She had that gagging feeling again. She turned back to see if she could spot her mother’s red, battered, sedan speeding down the poorly paved road. But all she saw was a trail of dust. Great, she thought as she entered through the double doors that had a picture of a big, grinning, clown. “Lily, why don’t you play with little Tommy?” Mrs. Adams said, comforting “little” Tommy in her arms, actually, Tommy was seven, which Lily thought was a big enough age to not cry when someone yells at them when they’ve asked to play “one” for the billionth time. “Lily we need to talk.” The middle aged woman, shunning Tommy to the side, said, “honey, you’ve got to understand that kids need patience and love. Heck, I remember you as a kid! Boy were you an attention hog!” Lily looked like she regretted yelling. She smiled and went to find Tommy. Maybe he’d still be game for Uno.

I was patient about getting my phone. I had to act extra special so my mom could decide when I would finally get it. Finally, on @DATE4, my mom was up when I got up for school and she said, “@CAPS2, you can have your phone now.” I hugged her tight and ran out the door very eagerly to try it out, my patience finally rewarded.

A time when I was patient was on @CAPS1. I got to open our presents at nine thirty in the morning, but I had to wait and wait for my parents to wake up. So for two long hours I watched television, the time passing slowly. I thought @CAPS2 would be hard, but @CAPS4 I made it through without complaining. That @CAPS1 I thought was the funnest, @CAPS4 I lied, I think this year will be even better. That day I made breakfast in bed for everyone, carrying the tray carefully. I got my mom a couple things of perfume, which she always likes. @CAPS4 of course she doesn’t use them often; I do, because I love the smell. I got her some candles as well, vanilla scented. We got my dad a bright orange sweat shirt, his favorite color. We also got him some @PERSON1, which he really enjoyed. It was a morning where my patience made the final celebration even sweeter.

One time me and my family were at @CAPS1 point over the @DATE1. My sister really wanted to go on all of the small kiddie rides with me but I didn’t feel like it; I was too old for those. I wanted to go on one of the fastest and tallest rides there, a real thrill. The @CAPS2 @CAPS3 @CAPS4. It looked really cool with its loops and drops, so my dad and I ran over to the entrance, weaving through the crowd. But when we got there the wait time on the board said one hour and forty-five minutes, a very long time. I really wanted to go on this ride but it really wasn’t worth standing in that line for so long. So when the line started moving and we were half way there the signs still said @NUM1 minutes, not much progress. I told my dad maybe we should do this another day when it's less crowded. But my dad said that we’ll be through soon and he told me to just watch the people on it go by and not talk, to make the time pass. We moved up only a little more and the time was still at @NUM1 minutes, so my dad finally agreed and said maybe we should do this another day and then we left the line to find my mom and sister by the merry-go-round.

I was patient once when my dad had said he was going to give me a letter every @DATE1 because he was too far away for me to visit; he lives all the way in @LOCATION1. A time I was patient was when I was at a dentist office I had to get six teeth pulled. When we were waiting I kept asking my mom "when are we going, when are we going," over and over. When they finally said my name, I walked into the room feeling nervous. I asked if it was going to hurt and they reassured me, saying "you won't feel a thing." The doctor put a tube near my mouth and told me to close my eyes and breathe. Without even knowing, I fell asleep from the gas. I was asleep for two hours, and when I woke up and wanted to get out of the chair they said "no, no, no," so I sat and sat until fifteen minutes later when they finally let me out. I was all loopy and had to be put in a wheelchair. When I got to the front desk they let me take two toys and my mom gave me a wrestler action figure. When we were about to leave my mom talked to the doctor and they took forever. When we got in the car my mom took the wheelchair back and we were off. During the ride my mom told me I couldn't go to school that day because of my teeth. She said not to look in the mirror but I did anyway and my face looked gross and puffy. I had to wait three hours for food and drinks so I was very thirsty. When she finally said I could eat I was so happy. I am still being patient because the doctor said that grown-up teeth would come in a few months but it has been two years and nothing, so I am disappointed. But now I have to be patient and wait for my mom to take me to get braces, which is gonna hurt really bad.

On a fine Tuesday morning, I was heading toward the dentist's office. I wasn't pleased at all. I didn't want the time to pass so we would get there, but it did. Right when we got into his office, a nurse came in and checked my temperature, heart beat, and other basic things. When she was done and left, we waited and waited again. We sat there for another ten minutes before the dentist himself came in. When he was finally done, we checked out and left, and thankfully I don't have to go there again for a long while.

One early morning in Boston, Massachusetts for a figure skating competition I had completed, I was waiting to hear if I made it to the final part of the event. After an endless wait, they were finally about to call out the numbers of the people who made it. I kept saying my assigned number over and over again in my head. They called Sarah’s number, and I felt a pang of hope. I kept waiting for my number to be called, but they never called it. I had not made it, and I was very disappointed, but I knew I couldn't do anything about it except try again next time.

Patience is a huge part of life to be successful. While you have problems and obstacles, having patience is what makes you a good person. To be honest, I’m not a very patient person, but there was one time I was, though I don’t really know how I managed it. I was waiting in a long line to pay for some earphones that I absolutely loved; they were a brilliant blue, my favorite color. So I was waiting, and five minutes passed, then ten, then I completely lost track of time but I knew it was a very long time. Then the cashiers started having trouble with the registers, which made everything slower. So I waited longer and longer until some people from the back came out and were trying to fix the machine. Then I had to wait even longer, feeling my frustration grow. I guess I stayed in that line for more than an hour in total. I really loved those earphones, but as much as I wanted them, I just couldn’t wait any longer. I finally gave up and put the earphones aside on a nearby shelf and left the store in a huff. I was really mad that day, thinking I had missed my chance. Two weeks later, we came back to the same store, and luckily the blue earphones were still just where I had put them. Yesss!! I was so relieved and happy that my initial patience, though it had broken, had ultimately paid off in a roundabout way.

One day, my mom was really patient with me during a frustrating car ride. We were outside just talking to each other when my grandma and grandpa called to see if we wanted to go to their house. Of course my mom said “yes” right away. So I went inside and packed some things to take with me because they don’t have anything fun at their place. When we hopped in the car, turned on the radio, everything was all fine. It was fine for about five minutes until we saw that traffic was backed up in my subdivision. I was fine at first until I got a text saying my cousins were already over there. I was so mad, but my mom just kept her eyes calmly on the road. I kept on screaming and saying, “Mom, go faster!” but she simply ignored me. It was like my words went through one ear and out the other. Then I got another text saying they were gonna be playing football in like fifteen minutes. He asked me, “When are you gonna be here?” I said, “I don’t know,” and of course my brother was already over there because he had spent the night. It was a bad night for me knowing I was missing out. I was still trying to tell mom to hurry up, but she didn’t listen. So then I decided I was going to ignore her back. That didn’t work because she wasn’t talking anyway. So I fell asleep around four o’clock. I thought I had gone to bed forever, but I woke up at five in the same exact spot in the traffic. I was devastated. I yelled out the window and said, “Why is this happening?” Then I went to bed again out of sheer boredom. When I was sleeping, I felt the car go faster as the traffic finally cleared, until we turned the corner and got stuck in another traffic jam. I asked my mom how much longer, but she didn’t reply. So I screamed it again and she finally yelled back, “We’re here!” I looked out the window and we were finally at my grandparents' house. And I got to play football after all. Then I heard my mom laughing in the house with her parents. I never found out why she was so quiet during the drive. Maybe she just wanted to see her mom and dad without any drama. That was the time I truly saw how patient my mom could be.

Awhile back my friends and I made a backyard game called "Sneak n go Seek". I had just taken a great sniping position behind a large oak tree. I had a great angle in all but one direction, which made it a perfect spot. The great thing about this spot was that everyone walked past it to get around in the woods, so usually it didn't require any patience. That's the part I was wrong about, as I soon discovered. I ended up waiting over twenty minutes, completely still, until I finally saw one of the people that were playing. I aimed my nerf weapon and fired, and according to the rules he was now on my team and under my command. We waited for a while longer before another player was seen walking close to us. Then my new partner got up to fire his weapon at the other player and unfortunately got shot himself. He didn’t notice me when I quietly crawled away from him, so I was safe for the moment. The only problem now was that I needed a new place to hide and wait. I found one quick behind a thick bush. Again I was waiting for over twenty minutes, feeling the time drag on. Finally I saw another player and got ready to shoot. But when I finally got my weapon from the ground, the person was already gone. This made me pretty mad seeing how I waited so long and didn't have a single person left on my team. I got up and went looking for someone to recruit, losing my patience and getting increasingly frustrated. "Is anyone even out here?" I whispered to myself. "Got you now!" someone shouted from above. Then my friend jumped down from a tree. He told me that the whole time he had been up there, watching me. He was waiting for me to get close enough to his tree to shoot. This whole time he was waiting with just enough patience to shoot every single person one by one, teaching me a valuable lesson about the game.
